headline: The Artist Dustin Yellin Is on the Lookout for the Dark Side
abstract: Mr. Yellin doesn’t bother drawing the line between art and artifact as he accumulates items that lean toward the morbid.
lead_paragraph: When you think about the millions of strange things we have wrought over the centuries, it is a mystery why we have such inadequate forms of classification to break them all down. That thing over there that does nothing? That’s “art.” This thing here that does something? “Design.” That thing over there that has done nothing for 100 years is an “antique,” and this thing here that once did something but now does nothing? A “found object.”

headline: The Price of Amazon
keywords: ['Book Trade and Publishing', 'E-Commerce', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: Bookselling was once a local business. Now Amazon has a larger market share of new and used printed books than any company has ever. That gives it extraordinary power.
lead_paragraph: The Amazon.com story is remarkable. Within living memory, bookselling was a local activity. A major city would have two or three large independent stores selling new books and other large, scruffier stores selling secondhand books. Paperbacks would receive wide if uneven circulation on bus station and drugstore racks. It was not a perfect system, but it had the advantage of being diffuse and thus hard to control. The hippie, black and women’s movements of the 1960s would not have been so successful in challenging authority without the bookstores, which made their ideas widely available and sympathetic in a way that television, for instance, did not.

headline: Text of Navalny’s Closing Remarks in Russian Court
abstract: Following are translated closing remarks by Aleksei A. Navalny, the opposition leader, at his trial in the Russian city of Kirov on July 5, 2013.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Aleksei A. Navalny, Russia’s most prominent political opposition leader, delivered an emotional speech on Friday in response to a prosecutor’s closing arguments demanding that Mr. Navalny be convicted on embezzlement charges and sentenced to six years in prison. A co-defendant, Pyotr Ofitserov, faced a five-year sentence. With the court proceedings in Kirov, a regional capital, streamed live on the Internet, Mr. Navalny delivered a rhetorical broadside against the Kremlin, in which he said his opposition work would not stop, and sought to rally public support. “I cannot run away from myself,” he said. “I have nothing else but this.” The judge said a verdict would be issued on July 18.

headline: A Bee’s Prickly Dream
abstract: Prickly pear cactuses around the city are filled with pollen, and bees find the blossoms irresistible.
lead_paragraph: The flowers of the prickly pear cactus (Opuntia humifusa) are evolution’s answer to a bee’s dreams. They are filled with pollen, abundant in season, and easy to locate. For humans, they are also stunningly beautiful, if ephemeral. Each satiny yellow bloom lasts about a day, opening broadly in the first hours of the morning when temperatures are still relatively cool, and closing again as the sun sets. A good-sized plant displays up to a dozen two-inch flowers every day from mid-June through early July in and around New York City.

lead_paragraph: Angela Curtis, 47, a former prison officer, was angry when she heard that Anthony D. Weiner would be speaking at her daughter’s high school graduation in Queens. As a congressman, he had lied to the public and embarrassed his family, she thought. What more did he have to say?

headline: Lincoln’s Surveillance State
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Civil War (US) (1861-65)', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: The N.S.A.’s data-mining has a historical precedent in the federal government’s monitoring of the telegraphs in 1862.
lead_paragraph: COLCHESTER, Vt. — BY leaking details of the National Security Agency’s data-mining program, Edward J. Snowden revealed that the government’s surveillance efforts were far more extensive than previously understood. Many commentators have deemed the government’s activities alarming and unprecedented. The N.S.A.’s program is indeed alarming — but not, from a historical perspective, unprecedented. And history suggests that we should worry less about the surveillance itself and more about when the war in whose name the surveillance is being conducted will end.

headline: The Plaza Hotel Goes Into Hiding for a Face-Lift
abstract: A 62,000-square-foot mesh banner designed by Paul Britten covers the facade of the hotel and is an architecturally correct rendering of its face.
lead_paragraph: Angeline Blom biked to the southern half of Grand Army Plaza, between West 58th Street and Central Park South in Manhattan, and pulled out her camera. She snapped the Apple store across Fifth Avenue but not the Plaza Hotel, even though it was right in front of her.

headline: Missile Defense Interceptor Misses Target in Test
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Missiles and Missile Defense Systems', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Some skeptics of the missile-defense program saw the failure as further evidence that the technology was unreliable and might not be worth the expense.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A test launching of an advanced missile-defense interceptor failed to hit its target high over the Pacific Ocean, the Pentagon said on Friday, four months after the Obama administration announced that it would spend $1 billion to increase the number of interceptors along the West Coast in response to verbal threats from North Korea.

headline: The Undying Influence of Ancient Egypt
abstract: An exhibition at the Yale Peabody Museum of Natural History explores the culture and impact of the land of the pyramids.
lead_paragraph: YOU WILL NOT FIND RECENT EXAMPLES of Egyptomania — the Bangles’ “Walk Like an Egyptian,” say, or the street-dance known as Tutting — in the “Echoes of Egypt” exhibition at the Yale Peabody Museum of Natural History. But the long reach of Egyptian civilization comes through nonetheless, in nearly 100 fascinating and diverse objects documenting both the culture of ancient Egypt and the way it has reverberated in the West and in Islam through the ages.

keywords: ['Keystone Pipeline System', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Global Warming', 'Oil Sands']
abstract: The president said he would approve the remaining part of the pipeline from Alberta to Gulf Coast refineries only if it would not “significantly exacerbate” the problem of carbon pollution.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The political ground may be shifting under the Keystone XL pipeline.

headline: A Kinder, Gentler Way to Thin the Deer Herd
abstract: Hastings-on-Hudson hopes to become the first suburb in the United States to control the deer population through contraception.
lead_paragraph: HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, N.Y. — When Mayor Peter Swiderski took office, he vowed to fulfill a campaign promise to do something about the deer, which are seemingly everywhere in this Hudson River village.

headline: Let’s Make a Deal
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: There’s no time like a long holiday weekend to talk about immigration reform. Doesn’t it make you long for the days of big messy deals?
lead_paragraph: At this point in the long holiday weekend, I’m ready to kick back and discuss immigration reform. It’s a very important issue. Plus, I have found it difficult to keep a dinner party conversation going with the farm bill.

headline: Women’s Final Is Appropriate Conclusion to Illogical Tournament
abstract: Sabine Lisicki faced a difficult path at Wimbledon like the one her opponent, Marion Bartoli, took in 2007, but Bartoli has not lost a set in this year’s tournament.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — A pair of unlikely hands will hoist perhaps the most coveted prize in women’s tennis Saturday, when one of the most unpredictable Wimbledon tournaments in memory culminates with a final between No. 15 Marion Bartoli of France and No. 23 Sabine Lisicki of Germany.

lead_paragraph: July 5, 2013

headline: The C.I.A. and the N.Y.P.D.
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'September 11 (2001)', 'Editorials']
abstract: A report by the agency’s inspector general about officers embedded in the Police Department deepens concerns about domestic spying.
lead_paragraph: A newly disclosed report by the C.I.A. inspector general about the agency’s relationship with the New York Police Department after Sept. 11, 2001, deepens concerns about the dangers to civil liberties posed by domestic spying. The inspector general concludes that the agency did not break a federal law barring it from domestic spying. The report also shows, however, that agency officers who were embedded in the Police Department after Sept. 11 were poorly supervised, suggesting that no one at the agency knew fully what they were doing.

headline: A Green, Rustic Setting for Shakespeare
abstract: The romantic comedy “As You Like It” is staged outdoors in Morris Township, mosquitoes and all.
lead_paragraph: ALL THE RAINY WEATHER of late has made for lush greenery surrounding the Greek Theater at the College of St. Elizabeth in Morris Township, where the Shakespeare Theater of New Jersey is offering an agreeable outdoor production of “As You Like It.” (And the mosquitoes on a recent night were out in force.)

headline: Designing Dashboards With Fewer Distractions
keywords: ['Wireless Communications', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Automobiles', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The car has become a mobile computer, with Internet access and an array of apps, but safety experts worry about drivers’ attention.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — The engineers working on Honda’s new Acura MDX luxury sport utility vehicle were obsessed with giving customers more — more space in the rear seat, more fuel economy from a high-tech engine, and above, all, more apps, maps and connectivity.

headline: Sabotage at the Election Commission
abstract: Proposals by the Republican majority on the Federal Election Commission would provide further aid to politicians and operatives who run roughshod over campaign laws.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Election Commission is already in a state of wretched dysfunction, but it will only get worse if Republican members succeed in crippling the agency further when the commission meets on Thursday. The three Republicans on the commission appear ready to take advantage of a temporary vacancy on the three-member Democratic side to push through 3-to-2 votes for a wholesale retreat from existing regulations.

headline: After Ruling, States Rush to Enact Voting Laws
keywords: ['Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'State Legislatures', 'Discrimination']
abstract: Experts predict an increase in lawsuits in states that are no longer covered under the Voting Rights Act after the Supreme Court ruling last month.
lead_paragraph: State officials across the South are aggressively moving ahead with new laws requiring voters to show photo identification at the polls after the Supreme Court decision striking down a portion of the Voting Rights Act.

headline: Don’t Punish Student Borrowers
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Student Loans', 'Interest Rates', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Editorials']
abstract: The doubling of the interest rates on student loans cannot be allowed to stand.
lead_paragraph: With the student debt crisis already hurting the economy and hobbling the young, the last thing the country needs is a federal policy that makes college even more costly. But that’s what the country got earlier this week when Congress allowed the interest rate on the subsidized federal loans to double from 3.4 percent to 6.8 percent.

headline: A Naughty Squirrel, and Other Puppet Mischief
abstract: The Puppets Take Long Island Festival is geared for people ages 3 to way up and will be held at various locations.
lead_paragraph: ASKED TO NAME a few highlights of the Puppets Take Long Island festival, starting tomorrow and running through Aug. 31, Liz Joyce, founder of Goat on a Boat Puppet Theater in Sag Harbor, put a performance by the Boston puppeteer Bonnie Duncan near the top of her list.

headline: Titanium Fills Vital Role for Boeing and Russia
abstract: A Russian foundry produces large quantities of the strong, light metal, which is a major element in Boeing’s new jets.
lead_paragraph: VERKHNAYA SALDA, Russia — Boeing needs to make its airliners lighter, and for that it needs titanium. And for that lightweight and strong metal, the American aircraft maker comes to this small city in the Ural Mountains.

headline: Davis Shows Off Swing in Rousing Mets Win
abstract: The Mets’ Ike Davis has returned from almost a month stint in Class AAA, where he worked on improving his hitting and mental game.
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — The Mets’ clubhouse felt like a changed place — less colorful, perhaps a tad quieter — after Ike Davis was sent to Class AAA a month ago to disentangle his swing and unclutter his head.

headline: Homes Keep Rising in West Despite Growing Wildfire Threat
keywords: ['Wildfires', 'Land Use Policies', 'Fires and Firefighters', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Just as many Easterners resist stepping back from their increasingly flooded coast, Westerners build where they want to build and balk at controls.
lead_paragraph: The death of 19 firefighters in Arizona this week highlights what has become a fact of life in the West: Every summer, smoke fills the big skies yet people continue to build in the places that burn most. More people live in these areas, and many balk at controls on how and where to build.

headline: Reining In the Regulators
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Editorials', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: A new Senate bill would serve the interests of reckless banks and careless corporations.
lead_paragraph: For all its rabid partisanship, Congress has shown time and again that it is willing to come together to deregulate corporate America. The latest example is a new bill in the Senate that would effectively end the independence of independent regulatory agencies, including the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, the Consumer Product Safety Commission and the National Labor Relations Board.

headline: Chile: Rape Ignites Abortion Debate
abstract: The case of a pregnant 11-year old girl who was raped has set off a national debate about abortion in one of the most socially conservative countries in Latin America.
lead_paragraph: The case of a pregnant 11-year-old girl who was raped has set off a national debate about abortion in one of the most socially conservative countries in Latin America. State television reported that the girl, known only as “Belen,” is 14 weeks pregnant. Police arrested her mother’s partner, who confessed to abusing the fifth grader. Doctors say her life and that of the fetus are at high risk. But ending the pregnancy is not an option. Chile allowed abortions for medical reasons until they were outlawed in 1973 by the Pinochet dictatorship. The current government of President Sebastián Piñera has opposed any loosening of the prohibition. Many Chileans were venting outrage about the case on social media on Friday. (AP)

headline: Howard Joining Rockets After Rejecting the Lakers
abstract: Dwight Howard committed to the Rockets after mulling offers from five teams and became the first star in modern N.B.A. history to walk away from the Lakers while still in his prime.
lead_paragraph: Dwight Howard soared into Los Angeles last summer as a flawed but celebrated savior, a smiling, muscle-bound, mischievous superstar who could dominate the court and carry the Lakers into another glorious era.

headline: Mapping Protests in Cairo
abstract: Thousands have taken to the streets of Cairo to protest or support deposed President Mohamed Morsi.
lead_paragraph: Thousands have taken to the streets of Cairo to protest or support deposed President Mohamed Morsi.

headline: Davis, Drafted by Yankees, Breaks Out With Orioles
abstract: Chris Davis, a star this season who arrived for a series in the Bronx with 32 homers, has no regrets about turning down the Yankees after the 2004 amateur draft, he said.
lead_paragraph: There were 1,498 players picked in the 2004 amateur draft. The 1,496th was a high school slugger from Longview, Tex., named Chris Davis. The Yankees used their 50th-round choice that summer on Davis, just in case he changed his mind about attending the University of Texas.

headline: Where Mandela Kept Hope, Guide Tells Their Shared Saga
abstract: Ahmed Kathrada, a longtime anti-apartheid activist and fellow inmate of Nelson Mandela, has shown Robben Island to world leaders and celebrities.
lead_paragraph: CAPE TOWN, South Africa — As Ahmed Kathrada led President Obama and his family recently through the prison on Robben Island where Mr. Kathrada had spent much of his life, he explained how the rules of apartheid had granted him, because of his Indian ancestry, long pants and socks. One of his fellow inmates, Nelson Mandela, as a black man, received short pants and no socks.

headline: For Mets Draft Class, Dreams Didn’t Last Long in Minors
abstract: Of the 52 players drafted by the Mets in 2008, all but 12 had washed out of organized baseball by the start of this season. The figures for most of the other clubs weren’t much better.
lead_paragraph: A year ago, with the sun high in the sky and the air thick with heat, Michael Moras led a group of young players across a weed-dotted Little League diamond adjacent to a noisy day care center in Easton, Conn. His shoulder blades protruded through the back of his old Mets T-shirt as he gripped a baseball in his meaty right hand and watched his players dart across the outfield grass.

headline: In Oregon, a Demand for Safety, but Not on Their Dime
abstract: Amid budget woes and facing an increase in taxes, Oregon citizens have taken up patrols, adding to the debate over what government is for and how community is to be defined.
lead_paragraph: GRANTS PASS, Ore. — It might be well established by now that money cannot buy happiness. But can it buy public safety?

lead_paragraph: Early one March morning in 2007, John Beattie woke to discover that his right arm and leg were numb. When his wife asked what was wrong, he told her, “I think I’m having a stroke.”

headline: Knicks Lose Copeland to Pacers
abstract: Chris Copeland, who averaged 8.7 points a game for the Knicks last season, signed a two-year, $6 million deal with Indiana.
lead_paragraph: Chris Copeland, who became a valuable reserve for the Knicks last season, agreed to a two-year, $6 million deal with the Indiana Pacers on Friday.

headline: Egypt Crisis Finds Washington Largely Ambivalent and Aloof
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: A muted White House reaction to the turmoil reflects both mixed feelings about President Mohamed Morsi’s ouster and Egypt’s shrinking role in American policy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In polo shirt, shorts and sandals, President Obama headed to the golf course Friday morning with a couple of old friends, then flew to Camp David for a long weekend. Secretary of State John Kerry was relaxing at his vacation home in Nantucket.

headline: Former Mets Pitchers Facing Off in Toronto
abstract: Toronto’s R. A. Dickey and Minnesota’s Mike Pelfrey, who parts of three seasons together with the Mets, are scheduled to oppose each other for the first time.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — When R. A. Dickey blew a tire on his bicycle at 7:30 one morning in spring training, the person he called to rescue him was Mike Pelfrey. When Pelfrey was out to prove that he could kick a 50-yard field goal in Port St. Lucie, Fla., the same year, the person he took along to verify the result and share in the fun was Dickey.

headline: In One Quick Game, Murray Changes Pace of a Match
abstract: At 1-4 of the third set against Jerzy Janowicz, Andy Murray played a nearly flawless service game, giving him an extra kick at a critical point in the match.
lead_paragraph: Jerzy Janowicz was feeling it. After breaking Andy Murray early in the third set of their Wimbledon semifinal Friday, he held serve with authority, thumping an ace to go up, 4-1. With the light beginning to dwindle, he was two games from taking a two-sets-to-one lead, and he knew the roof over Centre Court would have to be closed for the match to continue. To that point, Janowicz was weaving a potent spell of powerful serving, aggressive baseline play and deft drop shots to keep Murray from finding a rhythm.

headline: Michigan: Detroit Sues Insurer Over Casino Money
abstract: Detroit has sued a bond insurer, Syncora Guarantee Inc., blaming it for the withholding as much as $11 million a month in casino revenue, the city’s emergency manager said.
lead_paragraph: Detroit has sued a bond insurer, Syncora Guarantee Inc., blaming it for the withholding as much as $11 million a month in casino revenue, Kevyn Orr, the city’s emergency manager, said Friday. Mr. Orr was appointed in March to lead the city out of a fiscal crisis that has put it on the brink of bankruptcy. Detroit seeks a court order barring Syncora and other defendants from limiting its access to money from its three casinos. Syncora insures some of the $1.4 billion in “certificates of participation” issued by the city to shore up two public employee pension funds as well as swap agreements through which the city hedges interest rates payable on some of the certificates. Casino-derived revenues were pledged to secure the swaps, Mr. Orr said.

headline: Finding the Perfect Spot to Shoot
abstract: Kevin Breslin scours the city to identify alleyways and vistas that directors would find ideal.
lead_paragraph: A member of the Teamsters union and the Directors Guild of America, Kevin Breslin is a filmmaker and a location scout for commercials. Over 20 years, he has maneuvered crews through the city and arranged thousands of shoots, including the New York Lottery’s “If I Had a Million Dollars” and Verizon’s “Can You Hear Me Now?” spots. Mr. Breslin, 56, lives in Belle Harbor, Queens, with his wife and youngest son.

headline: Good Friends, Big Helpings
abstract: Celebrating a signed contract on an apartment with a dinner of barbecue in Queens.
lead_paragraph: Alchemy, Texas, a barbecue joint that opened in the back of a sports bar in Jackson Heights, Queens, on April 1, has a solid pedigree — it’s a spinoff of the highly rated John Brown Smokehouse in Long Island City — and enviable early love from the foodie nation, including the Village Voice, which called the prime rib “nothing short of spectacular.” And yet it still hasn’t quite caught on with the city’s barbecue-obsessed. “It’s weird out there,” said Josh Bowen, the chef and one of the owners, adding that the restaurant was not permanently committed to the site. “One night we’ll sell out, and the next there’ll be no one there.” On a rainy night last week (was there any other kind?), three of the six tables were empty, in contrast to the robust trade at the Legends sports bar in the front. Meats were served by the pound, on paper plates, and plastic checked tablecloths and paper towels caught the overflow of good stuff, which Mr. Bowen said combined Texas tradition with the neighborhood’s South Asian spices, plus touches that belonged to neither school. The next night, Mr. Bowen said, he would feature frog legs on the chalkboard menu. “This is a place to experiment,” he said. Hence the name.

headline: Looking for Fun in All the Queens Places
abstract: A new app introduced by the borough’s Chamber of Commerce serves as an all-purpose tour guide, but it isn’t comprehensive.
lead_paragraph: There are almost too many events to keep track of in Queens this summer. The usual draws, including the MoMA PS1  Warm Up  dance parties and the U.S. Open tennis tournament, remain as enticing as ever. And then there’s the Major League Baseball All-Star Game, which takes place at Citi Field on July 16. Add in the  Thunderbird Intertribal Powwow  and the annual Hot Jazz/Cool Garden concert series, and it seems as if a trip to the city’s largest, most diverse borough is inevitable.

headline: Assessing the Women’s Final
abstract: Thee Wimbledon veterans take a look at the unlikely final between Sabine Lisicki and Marion Bartoli.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — Wimbledon 2013 was supposed to be the Serena Williams show. Two weeks ago, all the talk was about the supposedly near-impossible task of stopping the indomitable American from claiming her sixth title at the All England Club.

headline: China: Anti-Japan Violence Punished
abstract: A court in China convicted and sentenced a man to 10 years in prison for battering the owner of a Japanese car during anti-Japanese protests that swept the country in September.
lead_paragraph: A court in China convicted and sentenced a man to 10 years in prison for battering the owner of a Japanesecar with a motorcycle lock during anti-Japanese protests that swept the country in September, official news media said Friday. It was an assault that prompted debate about violent undercurrents of popular nationalism in China. The attacker, Cai Yang, was among 12 men sentenced by courts in Xi’an, a city that experienced violent protests after a territorial dispute with Japan flared, Xinhua, the state-run news agency reported. The dispute has brought an upwelling of public anger that also draws on bitterness over the Japanese invasion and occupation of China in the 20th century.

headline: Piano Man of a Silent Screen
abstract: Steve Sterner is one of the last remaining silent-film accompanists, playing at the Brooklyn Academy of Music and at the Film Forum in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday evening, Steve Sterner, 62, walked into the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s Harvey Theater and sat at an upright piano with a sliver-view of the screen.

headline: Before the Songs, a Precisely Made Chai
abstract: For Chandrika Krishnamurthy Tandon, the Grammy nominee who leads a choir at a Hindu temple in Flushing, Queens, the day begins quite early.
lead_paragraph: Chandrika Krishnamurthy Tandon, a financial adviser and a New York University trustee, is also a Grammy-nominated musician who released her third album, “Soul March,” in April. Her albums are produced under a nonprofit label that donates the proceeds to various causes. Ms. Tandon, 58, who was born in Madras, India, and came to New York in 1979, lives on the Upper East Side with her husband, Ranjan, 62, a hedge fund manager. They have a daughter who lives in Washington, D.C., and visits often on weekends. On Sundays, Ms. Tandon leads a choir at the Ganesh Hindu Temple in Flushing, Queens.

headline: The Girls Who Haven’t Come Home
keywords: ['Foster Care', 'Children and Childhood', 'Child Custody and Support', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']
abstract: Vernice Hill has fought hard to get two of her daughters out of foster care, but after eight years away, the girls seem more removed from her than ever.
lead_paragraph: The last time they took Vernice Hill’s children away, the time they didn’t give them all back, was the afternoon she went to see her neighbor. Ms. Hill lives in a hulking building on East 188th Street, in a frayed neighborhood in the Bronx. It was May 1, 2005.

headline: Gentrifying Into the Shelters
abstract: Revitalizing poor areas brings rent increases that displace low-income families, who have nowhere else to go.
lead_paragraph: This past week, The New York Post reported on the sale of a two-bedroom loft in Bedford-Stuyvesant in Brooklyn to a couple in exodus from what they regarded as the oppressive trendiness of the Lower East Side. The loft, just under 1,600 square feet, sold for what the paper said was a record-setting $1 million, the highest price, apparently ever, for the sale of an apartment in a neighborhood that two decades ago could claim one of the highest murder rates in the city.

headline: What’s On Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 7:20 P.M. (Starz) PREMIUM RUSH (2012) A New York bicycle messenger (Joseph Gordon-Levitt, above) races from uptown to down on a “fixie,” with only a single gear and no brakes, while avoiding cars, buses, trucks and pedestrians — and a very crooked cop (Michael Shannon) — in this thriller from the director David Koepp. “Pushing pedal to the mettle and its breezily thin, goofy story to the breaking point, ‘Premium Rush’ provides just about all the late summer air-conditioned relief you could hope for,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “It’s buoyant dumb-fun, a ticking-clock thriller,” she added. “Stuffed with zingers and zippy stunts, it comes with pretty young things of all hues and hair types” — few prettier than Mr. Gordon-Levitt — “and start-to-finish clever special effects, none more clever or special than Michael Shannon. If you want to see a political undertow in its urban band of multicultural renegades, there’s that for the taking too.”

headline: Korean Pact on Factories Could Lead to Reopening
abstract: North and South Korea agreed to allow factory managers from the South to return to a jointly operated industrial park in the North for the first time in two months.

lead_paragraph: At Barboursville Vineyards, an 870-acre vineyard and winery in Barboursville, Va., an Italian winemaker is bent on making world-class wines.

headline: Virginia Wines: In the Old Dominion, a New Terroir
abstract: Putting Virginia on the world’s wine map will take persistence, in the vineyards and the marketplace.
lead_paragraph: ON a humid afternoon in late May, Luca Paschina, a winemaker born in northern Italy, made his pitch to the owner of a wine shop on Long Island. Pouring a cabernet franc reserve and a Bordeaux-style blend, he described how the red wines were aged for more than a year in French oak. And he recounted the history of Barboursville Vineyards, the 870-acre property in central Virginia where the wines were made.

headline: Player Ratings: U.S. (6) vs. Guatemala (0)
abstract: Rating the performance of American players in Friday’s friendly match against Guatemala in San Diego.
lead_paragraph: In its only exhibition before Tuesday’s Gold Cup opener, the United States national team cruised to a lopsided win over Guatemala in a game that was a tale of two halves Friday night in San Diego.

headline: Mexico’s Election Violence Is Said to Be Worst in Years
abstract: The killing of candidates during local election season has proved an embarrassment for the government of  President Enrique Peña Nieto, who has promised to control violence.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Running for public office in Mexico has long been perilous, with threats, assaults and sometimes outright killings by criminal gangs, political rivals and other opponents.

headline: A Popular Reds Owner (It’s About Time)
abstract: After years of suffering because of the Reds owners Marge Schott and Carl Lindner, the team’s current boss, Bob Castellini, has given fans something to cheer about.
lead_paragraph: Some fans never get to choose their favorite baseball team, and that means they never get to choose their favorite team’s owner. My father grew up in southern Indiana, rooting for the squad on the other side of the Ohio border, the Cincinnati Reds. My mother grew up in a suburb of Cincinnati, convinced she would one day marry Johnny Bench.

headline: All-Star Wonder Is Not All Fun and Games
abstract: Baseball tries hard to convince fans that the All-Star Game is all about effort. But mainly, players come to enjoy the spectacle and revel in their status as the best of the best.
lead_paragraph: Justin Verlander squirmed in his chair at the AT&T Park interview room Oct. 23. He was there to talk about his assignment the next night in Game 1 of the World Series. He did not want to rehash his poor start in the All-Star Game, which was a big reason his Detroit Tigers were opening the World Series on the road in San Francisco.

headline: Software and iPad Put Video and Statistical Database a Tap Away
abstract: A growing number of players are spending less time in front of a desktop computer and instead are preparing nearly anywhere else by using their iPads and software created by Bloomberg Sports.
lead_paragraph: One of the many routines that baseball players follow before a game is to wander into the video room at a stadium. There, hitters can watch video of their recent at-bats, and pitchers can get a look at the tendencies of coming opponents.

headline: An Orange Blossom in the Devil’s Den
abstract: A New York company gets trapped in the most horrific fighting at Gettysburg.
lead_paragraph: Nancy and George Hoover looked on as rebels traipsed through the couple’s modest Pennsylvania farm during the days immediately following the Battle of Gettysburg. The disappointed, yet still defiant, Confederates camped in the fields around the Hoover homestead near Waynesboro, about 20 miles west of the battlefield.

headline: Variety: Marching Bands
abstract: Brendan Emmett Quigley has us going in circles.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — You don’t need me for this.

headline: Train Derails and Explodes in Canada
abstract: A train carrying petroleum products derailed and exploded Saturday morning in a town in Quebec.
lead_paragraph: A train carrying petroleum products derailed and exploded Saturday morning in a town in Quebec. Videos, apparently shot by witnesses, show billowing flames and secondary explosions.

headline: Weighing Changes to the Business Side After Doping Scandals
abstract: Calls to reform the business side of cycling have started a debate over revenue sharing, a new racing calendar and changes to the sport’s governing body.
lead_paragraph: NICE, France — When cycling was still a provincial affair in which riders changed clothes behind middle schools before races, the news that its most recognizable star had doped to win the Tour de France would probably not have mattered. And it would have been unthinkable to imagine an investigation, undertaken in the United States, no less, revealing the sport to be in structural disarray, ruled by dysfunctional leadership and a code of silence.

headline: Bartoli Vanquishes Nerves and Lisicki in Wimbledon Final
abstract: Marion Bartoli, the No. 15 seed from France, won her first Grand Slam title, beating Sabine Lisicki in the women’s singles final at Wimbledon.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — There are many ways to count how long Marion Bartoli waited for her first Grand Slam title. This year’s Wimbledon was her 47th major tournament. She reached her first Grand Slam final here six years ago but did not play another until Saturday. She had not won a tournament since October 2011.

headline: July 6: Where the Candidates Are Today
abstract: The candidates’ daily campaign schedule at a glance.
lead_paragraph: Planned events for the mayoral candidates, according to the campaigns and organizations they are affiliated with. Times are listed as scheduled but frequently change.

headline: Trying to End Rifts, Syria Opposition in Exile Elects President
abstract: The group’s new president, Ahmad Jarba, is a tribal sheik from northeastern Syria and is seen as close to the government of Saudi Arabia.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The main Syrian exile opposition group elected a new president on Saturday, the body’s latest bid to end months of squabbling and show that it can unite, organize and arm the fighters battling Syria’s president, Bashar al-Assad.

headline: The Search for Clues in the Yarnell Hill Fire
abstract: Investigators in the Yarnell Hill fire are now beginning the months-long task of unraveling the deadliest day for wildland firefighters in 80 years.
lead_paragraph: Investigators in the Yarnell Hill fire are now beginning the months-long task of unraveling the deadliest day for wildland firefighters in 80 years.

headline: Hernandez Among Many Who Found Trouble at Florida in the Meyer Years
abstract: There have been dozens of arrests of members of the Gator football teams coached from 2005 to 2010 by Urban Meyer.
lead_paragraph: As the University of Florida dominated college football for the better half of a decade under Coach Urban Meyer, the Gators accumulated numbers — of victories and accolades and championships — at dizzying rates. In six seasons, they won 65 games, two Southeastern Conference championships and two national titles.

headline: Morsi Spurned Deals, Seeing Military as Tamed
keywords: ['United States International Relations', "Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat", 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: The abrupt end of Egypt’s first Islamist government was the culmination of months of escalating tensions and ultimately futile American efforts to broker a solution to keep President Mohamed Morsi in office.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — As President Mohamed Morsi huddled in his guard’s quarters during his last hours as Egypt’s first elected leader, he received a call from an Arab foreign minister with a final offer to end a standoff with the country’s top generals, senior advisers with the president said.

headline: The Athletics’ Sweet Smell of Victory
abstract: To the Oakland A’s, cloaked in low-budget anonymity, a sewer blockage was just one more thing to laugh about in a season in which they have compiled the club’s best start since 1990.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — The Oakland Athletics do not stink. But their stadium did. On a Sunday last month, the A’s and the Seattle Mariners ended a game to find that sewage had backed up through the drains of the team clubhouses and the offices of coaches and umpires, who surely called it foul.

headline: New Zealand Skipper Adapts and Thrives in a Multihull World
abstract: The first round-robin sailing race of the Louis Vuitton Cup in San Francisco is Sunday as three challengers begin the battle to face Oracle for the America’s Cup.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Dean Barker has been the helmsman for Team New Zealand in the America’s Cup. He has been the helmsman for New Zealand in the Louis Vuitton Cup. He has raced in the MedCup, the Congressional Cup, the world match-racing championships, even the Olympics.

headline: Donovan Hopes to Play His Way Onto a Fourth World Cup Team
abstract: Landon Donovan has not played for the national team since last summer and was passed over by Coach Jurgen Klinsmann after Donovan took a sabbatical from soccer.
lead_paragraph: What a difference two years makes.

headline: Ken Lombard, on Staying a Student of Business
abstract: The former business partner of Magic Johnson advises business school students to be “hungrier than you’ve ever been” after graduation, because competition will be intense.
lead_paragraph: This interview with  Ken Lombard, partner at Capri Capital Partners, a real estate investment and development firm, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Rationality and the Euro
abstract: It actually happened — once.
lead_paragraph: Simon Wren-Lewis, for once, has a happy story to tell. He looks back at Britain’s fateful decision, ten years ago, not to join the euro, and argues that the decision was made on the basis of — gasp! — actual analysis. Gordon Brown (who deserves a much better rap than he gets) brought in real economic experts, who used a real economic framework — optimum currency area theory — and concluded that the case for euro membership was not good.

headline: Letters to the Sports Editor
abstract: Readers sound off on the latest sports headlines.
lead_paragraph: At Ballpark, a Hefty Price Tag

headline: From the Fed, Mixed Signals for Main Street
keywords: ['Mutual Funds', 'Quantitative Easing', 'United States Economy', 'Interest Rates', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Many mutual funds slumped near the end of the second quarter amid signs that the Federal Reserve might pull back on its bond-buying. For investors, the future now looks harder to read.
lead_paragraph: PRICES of stocks, bonds and other investments sank toward the end of the second quarter as the Federal Reserve signaled that it might begin what Wall Street has called “the taper” — the reduction and then the possible reversal of bond purchases that the Fed has used for years to support the economy and markets.

headline: The Yarnell Hill Fire
abstract: A group of firemen perish while trying to contain the Yarnell Hill fire.
lead_paragraph: A group of firemen perish while trying to contain the Yarnell Hill fire.

headline: Yarnell Flyover
abstract: An aerial view of the Yarnell Hill Fire.
lead_paragraph: An aerial view of the Yarnell Hill Fire.

headline: When Weak Balance Sheets Outperform the Strong
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Mutual Funds', 'Credit and Debt', 'Interest Rates', 'Quantitative Easing']
abstract: In the first half of the year, the market richly rewarded investors in many companies with weak balance sheets — those with relatively high debt loads.
lead_paragraph: MANU DAFTARY, manager of the Quaker Strategic Growth fund, says he learned a valuable lesson in 2009. He avoided companies like the American International Group, Bank of America and Citgroup, which, to one degree or another, were damaged by the subprime mortgage crisis and benefited from the help of the Federal Reserve. His portfolio’s performance suffered, though, as he minimized investments in such companies.

headline: In Brazil, a Reminder of Emerging-Market Risks
keywords: ['Mutual Funds', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Brazil has seen its economic growth slow, while protests have flared nationwide. And its stock market, a powerhouse over the last decade, has recently turned much lower.
lead_paragraph: THE protests in Brazil last month were the latest vivid reminder of the perils of investing in emerging markets. Tens of thousands of demonstrators thronged the streets of São Paulo, Rio de Janeiro and other cities, incited partly by a rising cost of living and a slowing economy. Cars burned. Tear gas billowed. And the Brazilian stock market sank.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: Cycling in the City
abstract: Readers discuss the pleasures and problems of bike sharing.
lead_paragraph: Readers discuss the pleasures and problems of bike sharing.

headline: Want Your Data Back? Pay Me
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Privacy']
abstract: Hmm. If the government can spy on my online life, maybe I should be able to profit.
lead_paragraph: A COUPLE of weeks ago, my laptop died. My stomach churned as I realized that a full day’s worth of work had vanished.

headline: The Song of the Suburbs
abstract: Out the window of that ’47 Mercury, my father’s dreams rolled by.
lead_paragraph: WHEN I was a boy growing up in Mississippi, my father liked to “drive around looking at houses.” That was his expression. We lived in the very center of Jackson, a block from the Capitol building; it was the ’50s, I was 6 and on. I don’t know what my father felt about owning the small red-brick duplex in the older part of town — if he liked it much or didn’t. It is the inner city now, but it was our home then, a place he’d bought so I could be born in it. It was what he could afford.

headline: Slowly, Cuba Is Developing an Appetite for Spending
abstract: A small, but increasingly visible, consumer class in Cuba has a taste for luxuries, albeit modest ones by American standards, which has caught the eye of the island’s entrepreneurs.
lead_paragraph: HAVANA — When a 3-D movie theater opened in his neighborhood two months ago, Manuel Alejandro snapped up tickets. It was no IMAX, just a small lounge in a converted apartment with a 55-inch television and an M&M’s dispenser in the corner. But for $3 a person, Mr. Alejandro and his friends donned special glasses and watched the movie of their choice.

headline: Robert A.G. Monks, Crusading Against Corporate Excess
abstract: The founder of  corporate-governance organizations may have a courtly style, but he is hard-charging in his efforts to make companies more transparent and democratic.
lead_paragraph: AT age 79, many people who can afford to do so are done working. Not Robert A. G. Monks. He is still hard at work, trying to change corporate America.

headline: PETA Finds Itself on Receiving End of Others’ Anger
abstract: The high-profile group still euthanizes most of the animals at its shelter in Virginia, even as a “no-kill” movement that promotes adoption grows rapidly.
lead_paragraph: NORFOLK, Va. — Even some supporters do not know what to make of it.

headline: PETA Under Fire From ‘No Kill’ Groups
abstract: People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals euthanizes an average of about 2,000 dogs and cats in its Virginia animal shelter every year, but the trend nationwide is to reduce shelter kills.
lead_paragraph: People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals euthanizes an average of about 2,000 dogs and cats in its Virginia animal shelter every year, but the trend nationwide is to reduce shelter kills.

headline: Gold’s One Certainty: Its Decline Has Been Swift
keywords: ['Gold', 'Inflation (Economics)', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Mutual Funds', 'Asset Allocation (Personal Finances)', 'Interest Rates']
abstract: Anxieties about the economy have waned, hurting gold prices. But a lack of clarity on the recovery’s momentum is also dogging the metal.
lead_paragraph: GOLD and trouble go together, because the metal is often seen as a haven in times of economic distress.

headline: A Dimming Outlook for Bonds May Require Some Rethinking
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Interest Rates', 'Government Bonds', 'United States Economy', 'Junk Bonds', 'Mutual Funds']
abstract: In the long or the short term, challenges appear to be ahead for fixed-income investors.
lead_paragraph: FOR three years, the warnings that bonds were primed for a downfall smacked of crying wolf. Bond funds generally did just fine, thank you. That is, until May.

headline: Stuck in Traffic, Dying of Thirst
abstract: I don’t drive. Which gives me the freedom not to be stuck in traffic.
lead_paragraph: I DO not know how to drive a car.

headline: A Painful Mix of Fire, Wind and Questions
abstract: Investigators are beginning the task of unraveling how a routine afternoon of cutting fire lines along the edge of a community in Arizona became the deadliest day for wilderness firefighters in 80 years.
lead_paragraph: PRESCOTT, Ariz. — They trained their eyes on the mountain that smoldered in the distance as they carved a path through a forest choked by fire and drought. The ground crackled underfoot. Packs sagged from their backs, heavy with the gear frontline firefighters must carry: pickaxes, temperature gauges, spades, radios, plenty of water.

headline: Trouble on Wheels
abstract: Driving gave me a license to perpetrate all manner of pranks.
lead_paragraph: IT was after midnight, the summer of 2002, and I had just casually placed a hundred eggs and a pineapple in front of the register at a 24-hour grocery in metro Atlanta. The eggs were for throwing at houses. The pineapple was for throwing off the cashier. A hundred eggs by themselves lead one to suspect impending delinquency. Add in a pineapple and all one suspects is an interesting omelet.

headline: In New Books,  Paths to Investing and Spending
abstract: One new personal-finance book provides advice for unearthing undervalued stocks. Another offers a method for spending your money smartly.
lead_paragraph: FINDING good, out-of-favor stocks can make you rich. But how do you find those stocks — and, assuming that you can, how can you best spend your newfound riches to make yourself very happy?

headline: Mutual Funds That Made Sense of a Confusing Market
abstract: Managers of some of the better-performing mutual funds in the second quarter found strength in diverse holdings.
lead_paragraph: IN a hurly-burly quarter, with some stock-market sectors sagging and others surging, managers of three of the top-performing mutual funds managed to find rising returns in places as varied as restaurants, roadsters and robots.

headline: Ahead of the Market
abstract: How three of the top performers of the second quarter of 2013 fared against the market — and against their peer groups of funds.
lead_paragraph: How three of the top performers of the second quarter of 2013 fared against the market — and against their peer groups of funds.

headline: Train Blast Kills at Least One and Forces Evacuations in Canada
abstract: Four petroleum tankers exploded in a fireball in the center of Lac-Mégantic, Quebec, near Maine. Officials could not get close enough to determine casualties.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — A runaway train exploded Saturday, killing at least one person and forcing more than 1,000 people to evacuate from a town in the province of Quebec, the police said. The 73-car train, which included tank cars carrying petroleum, destroyed much of downtown Lac-Mégantic, a town of about 6,000, in a blaze that continued through the day.

headline: A New Anti-American Axis?
abstract: The Sino-Soviet split is ancient history. Russia and China are closer than ever, and that’s bad news for the United States.
lead_paragraph: THE flight of the leaker Edward J. Snowden from Hong Kong to Moscow last month would not have been possible without the cooperation of Russia and China. The two countries’ behavior in the Snowden affair demonstrates their growing assertiveness and their willingness to take action at America’s expense.

headline: Java Jive, 2013
abstract: Your reward for an 11th drink: we will refrain from hatefully scowling at you.
lead_paragraph: The coffee you are about to enjoy was brewed the old-fashioned way, in a slow-drip machine powered by a mustachioed man pedaling a penny-farthing bicycle. Stop for a moment to admire the sumptuous curvature of our coffee maker’s gold-hued cylinders, crafted by Japanese artisans who reside, for reasons unknown, within the central vent of an active volcano. Have you witnessed such glory outside the walls of a major city’s museum?

headline: Fighting Wildfires, Processing Death
abstract: Firefighters are taught to be self-reliant, but it is dangerous to emphasize individual behavior.
lead_paragraph: WHY young men from the country become firefighters is hard to explain to people who are not from the country. For most of us, it’s not about the rush, which fades with time, or the paycheck. We could earn more working for the railroad or a car dealership. I figure it’s about the land. It’s what we know best — these woods, dirt roads, small towns — and if given the chance to make a living outside with our backs, under a blue, hot sky, then by God yes we’re going to take it.

headline: A Hidden Consensus on Health Care
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The employer mandate should go, and everyone knows it.
lead_paragraph: TO follow what’s happening with the new health care law right now, you have to understand that for all the deep divisions on the issue, there’s actually a real bipartisan consensus about how the American health care system ought to be reformed.

headline: The Church’s Errant Shepherds
abstract: Cardinal Dolan and other Catholic leaders have responded to the abuse crisis the way the cunning chieftains of a corporation might.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, Philadelphia, Los Angeles. The archdioceses change but the overarching story line doesn’t, and last week Milwaukee had a turn in the spotlight, with the release of roughly 6,000 pages of records detailing decades of child sexual abuse by Roman Catholic priests there, a sweeping, searing encyclopedia of crime and insufficient punishment.

headline: Can Egypt Pull Together?
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: To get Egyptians on a more positive path, America needs to play marriage counselor.
lead_paragraph: ANYONE who has followed Middle East politics knows that this is a region where extremists tend to go all the way and moderates tend to just go away.

headline: Goodbye Old World, Bonjour Tristesse
abstract: The French are in such bad mood that they don’t even have the energy to be rude.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — VERSAILLES lived again at haute couture week, as designers paraded their let-them-eat-cake creations, hand-stitched with gilt embroidery and trimmed with guiltless fur — frousfrous that no real women can wear and few can afford.

headline: Letting Go of Our Nukes
keywords: ['ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Much of our thinking about nuclear weapons is a hangover from a different era and is inappropriate to the security demands of the present world.
lead_paragraph: TEMPE, Ariz. — PRESIDENT OBAMA recently called on Russia to join with the United States in negotiating a mutual reduction in strategic nuclear warheads that would leave each country with slightly more than 1,000. The number would be up to one-third less than what both countries agreed to deploy in the New Start treaty, reached in the president’s first term.

headline: Susan Kare
abstract: The digital designer on Al Green, cactuses and Mexican blankets.
lead_paragraph: Susan Kare is an independent digital designer whose ubiquitous on-screen icons are clicked by countless users every day. Known for her minimalist, intuitive and often witty designs, she started her career at Apple when Steve Jobs selected her to create the graphics and fonts for the original Macintosh computer.

headline: Has ‘Caucasian’ Lost Its Meaning?
abstract: An obsolete term survives, often as a last resort for people who are uncomfortable talking about race.
lead_paragraph: AS a racial classification, the term Caucasian has many flaws, dating as it does from a time when the study of race was based on skull measurements and travel diaries. It has long been entirely unmoored from its geographical reference point, the Caucasus region. Its equivalents from that era are obsolete — nobody refers to Asians as “Mongolian” or blacks as “Negroid.”

headline: Eyeball of Providence
abstract: I’m in pain. The doctor’s about to stick a needle in my eye. Here’s why that’s a good thing.
lead_paragraph: “Oh, that’s very nice,” I say, as the mild sedative takes hold just before Dr. Nagel performs cataract surgery on my left eye in the ambulatory-surgery facility at Mount Sinai Hospital. “I can see why people become addicts,” I add, beginning the Sedative Gabble, which I will approximate here. “Do you know where the word ‘cataract’ comes come — from?” I mumble. “Probably from the Latin cataracta, but not what thu yink. You think. Not for like a waterfowl — fall. From” — and here the sedative makes me pause for at least 30 seconds and then take a deep breath — “from a meaning of Latin of gate meaning ‘portcullis’ like a castle thing that you can see through a little but barrier.”

headline: The Joy of Old Age. (No Kidding.)
abstract: At 80, I often feel life is about to begin, only to realize it is almost over.
lead_paragraph: LAST night I dreamed about mercury — huge, shining globules of quicksilver rising and falling. Mercury is element number 80, and my dream is a reminder that on Tuesday, I will be 80 myself.

headline: To Tennis Fans, From Djokovic and Del Potro
abstract: The longest semifinal match in Wimbledon history was a gift to fans from two top players.
lead_paragraph: That’s as good as it gets.

headline: Why I Donated My Stool
abstract: Transplanting the stool from one person into the digestive tract of another seems, well, repulsive, but sometimes it makes a lot of sense.
lead_paragraph: This spring I saved a friend from a terrible illness, maybe even death. No, I didn’t donate a kidney or a piece of my lung. I did it with my stool.

headline: Qaeda Rebels Are Gone. Death Isn’t.
abstract: An Islamist coup grabbed headlines in Mali, which is the first stop on this year’s win-a-trip. But the real threat to Malian children is extreme malnutrition.
lead_paragraph: TIMBUKTU, Mali — IT’S time for my annual win-a-trip journey, in which I take a university student with me on a reporting trip to Africa. So I’m here in Timbuktu, the ancient crossroads of the Sahara, with Erin Luhmann, a journalism student from the University of Wisconsin, navigating roadblocks and jittery soldiers in a city that Islamist militants ruled until early this year.

headline: Bryans Capture Missing Piece at Wimbledon
abstract: Bob and Mike Bryan, the world’s pre-eminent doubles team, rallied from a slow start to defeat Marcelo Melo and Ivan Dodig, 3-6, 6-3, 6-4, 6-4.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — Their strings and nerves were tighter than Bob and Mike Bryan would have liked at the start of the Wimbledon men’s doubles final on Saturday, but there was ample time to make the necessary repairs.

headline: Rising Dangers of Hunger
abstract: Many Malians are on the edge of starvation, and the fighting and insecurity have pushed some over the bring.
lead_paragraph: Many Malians are on the edge of starvation, and the fighting and insecurity have pushed some over the bring.

headline: Murray Has Won a Tournament at Wimbledon, but Not This One
abstract: Andy Murray, who won the gold medal at the London Olympics, would be the first British man to win the British Grand Slam event in 77 years.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — As is now well established, it has been a through-the-looking-glass Wimbledon.

headline: 2 Die and Many Are Hurt as Plane Crashes in San Francisco
abstract: An Asiana jetliner from South Korea crashed and caught fire, killing two people and injuring more than 180 others.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — An Asiana Airlines passenger jet traveling from Seoul, South Korea, crashed while landing Saturday at San Francisco International Airport, smashed into pieces and caught fire, killing at least two people and injuring more than 180 others.

headline: A New Education Mayor
abstract: Michael Bloomberg’s successor faces a herculean reform challenge: the New York City school system.
lead_paragraph: The next mayor of New York City will assume control of the country’s largest school system at an especially challenging moment. That person will oversee installation of the rigorous new Common Core learning standards. This ambitious set of academic goals, which has been adopted by all but a handful of states, is intended to move schools away from rote learning and memorization toward a writing-intensive curriculum that cultivates reasoning skills required by the new economy.

headline: Bencic Adds Wimbledon Title to Successful Season
abstract: Belinda Bencic topped Taylor Townsend in three sets to win the girls’ singles title a month after she captured the French Open girls’ final.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — For a while Saturday afternoon at Wimbledon, Belinda Bencic’s dream ticket appeared to be slipping away. She won the French Open girls’ title last month, but that final was played on a back court at Roland Garros in front of a smattering of spectators. Wimbledon, on the other hand, offers the juniors a bigger stage, and a slightly star-struck Bencic, 16, walked out onto a packed Court 1 to face the big hitting 17-year-old Taylor Townsend.

headline: Payback on the L.I.R.R.
abstract: The Long Island Railroad disability scandal has an infuriating coda.
lead_paragraph: For a working schlub who commutes from the suburbs, the Long Island Rail Road disability scandal of 2008 was powerful evidence that the game of life is rigged.

headline: Europe’s Delayed Banking Union
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Editorials']
abstract: The Continent’s economic crisis will not end until its leaders fix its troubled banks.
lead_paragraph: Last year, European officials laid out an important proposal for a banking union that would resolve failed institutions; provide strong, central supervision of banks; and give depositors a solid guarantee that their money was safe. If carried out fully, the plan could help restore health to the Continent’s depressed economy.

headline: From Gypo to Whitey
abstract: At his trial, James (Whitey) Bulger seems stung by the witnesses who say he was an F.B.I. informer.
lead_paragraph: Is there such a thing as Irish omertà? The insistence that there is a code of honor for an Irish-American hoodlum that would stop him from ever becoming an F.B.I. informer is the most intriguing part of the criminal defense being offered by James (Whitey) Bulger in his trial in Boston. Mr. Bulger stands accused of a raft of violent crimes from his years as an underworld boss, including involvement in 19 murders. Yet it is the prosecution’s spelling out his role as an alleged informer who turned on his own kind in South Boston that seems most stinging for him — to the point of his snarling expletives at people who say so on the witness stand.

headline: The Farm Drawer
abstract: A collection of past bills and invoices means all of my mistakes are on record.
lead_paragraph: The other day, a question arose: How deep is my well? That’s the kind of number I should know by heart, if only because it’s so interesting to talk about wells with other well owners — a conversation that barely gets off the ground if you don’t know how deep your well is. I remember having work done on my well ages ago when a check valve failed. Surely on the bill someone had written the depth in feet. All I had to do was find the bill.

headline: Going the Distance, With Sports Analogies
abstract: Sometimes it’s hard to avoid sports terms in the workplace, as the manager of a hotel restaurant (and former soccer player) can attest.
lead_paragraph: MY boss, Edward Mady, general manager of the Beverly Hills Hotel, can’t get enough of sports. His office walls are lined with souvenir baseballs and photographs of him posing with famous athletes. His corporate lingo is laced with sports metaphors and analogies.

headline: A Writer’s Mommy Guilt
abstract: I’m, at very best, 77 percent focused on entertaining my kids.
lead_paragraph: “I’m reading your book, and now I’m worried about you,” an acquaintance told me about my (fictional) novel, which concerns the (fictional) misadventures of a (fictional) depressed mother. My whole head flushed. My immediate response was anger, then denial, then guilt. I was practically going through stages of mourning, and maybe I was in mourning, mourning for the simpler vision of myself I was able to project on Facebook, or you know, in person or whatever.

headline: What’s on Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (13, 49) ENDEAVOUR, SERIES 1: GIRL In this new “Masterpiece Mystery!” series, created as a prequel to “Inspector Morse,” Shaun Evans plays the young Detective Constable Endeavour Morse, a rookie police officer on the Oxford force in the 1960s who immediately makes enemies when the inspector Fred Thursday (Roger Allam, above right, with Mr. Evans, center) chooses him for a position that should have gone to a sergeant. In this first of four episodes, Morse and Thursday investigate burgled gas meters, a dead secretarial student, a string of post office robberies and a love child. “The lead actors do good work, even though their job, to some extent, is to make themselves part of the period décor,” Mike Hale wrote in The New York Times. “In the course of Sunday’s episode Morse develops one of his patented hopeless crushes on a suspect, and it gets him busted down from bagman to general duty. You’re a good detective but a poor policeman, Thursday tells him, and something similar could be said of ‘Endeavour’: it’s a poor mystery, but it’s not a bad meal.”

headline: Terror on Jet: Seeing Water, Not Runway
abstract: The pilot at the controls on Asiana Flight 214 was said to have had only 43 hours of experience flying a Boeing 777, and an airline spokeswoman said that it was his first time piloting a 777 into San Francisco.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The nearly 11-hour trip across the Pacific had gone smoothly as Asiana Flight 214 approached San Francisco International Airport — an uneventful flight for the 291 passengers, including dozens of Chinese teenagers who were arriving for a summer camp to study English and tour colleges.

headline: Interpreter Accused of Torturing and Killing Afghan Civilians Is Arrested
abstract: Afghan officials have accused the suspect, Zakaria Kandahari, of torturing and killing civilians while working for an American Special Forces unit.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Afghan officials confirmed Sunday that they had arrested and were questioning Zakaria Kandahari, whom they have described as an Afghan-American interpreter responsible for torturing and killing civilians while working for an American Special Forces unit.

headline: Series of Explosions Rocks Buddhist Temple in India
abstract: The attack on the Mahabodhi Temple in eastern India, one of Buddhism’s holiest sites, was quickly labeled an act of terror by officials. Two people were wounded in the blasts.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — A series of explosions rocked one of Buddhism’s holiest sites in eastern India on Sunday morning, an attack that officials called an act of terrorism.

headline: Guardiola’s Delicate Task: How to Make a Great Team Greater
abstract: Pep Guardiola knows both the microscope and overwhelming success from his years at Barcelona. Now he faces a similar challenge as the new coach of Bayern Munich.
lead_paragraph: Pep Guardiola is back on the treadmill. A Spaniard who took a year’s sabbatical after winning 14 trophies in four years with Barcelona, he is now holding a retreat in the Dolomites in northern Italy.

headline: That Terrible Taper
abstract: Real damage is being done.
lead_paragraph: One of the odd things about the people arguing that we must raise interest rates to head off bubbles — Raghuram Rajan, Martin Feldstein, the BIS, and so on — is the near-universal assertion among this group that just a little rate increase can’t do any real harm. (Just a thin little mint). After all, rates are so low!

headline: App Smart Extra: What Else to Pack on a Camping Trip
abstract: Turning your smartphone into a handy camping tool.
lead_paragraph: For those of you about to make the most of summer’s warmer days and venture out on a camping vacation, a recent App Smart column covered a bunch of apps that turn your smartphone or tablet into a camper’s companion. But, as ever, there are many different apps available in the various app stores that claim to do similar jobs.

headline: Don’t Make Your Children the Exception to Every Rule
abstract: Raising conscientious children is definitely not the most fun part of parenting, but protecting them from the consequences of every failure is the biggest parental failure of all.
lead_paragraph: While teaching at a Midwestern university about 15 years ago, I came across a clear case of plagiarism in a student paper. I invited the young woman who had turned in the paper to meet with me to discuss the university’s policies on plagiarism and my concerns about her work. The meeting was pleasant enough until I turned my attention to her paper. She promptly soured, grabbed her bag, left my office and could hardly have been out of the building before my desk phone rang. It was her father, calling from New York, threatening legal action.

headline: Live Analysis: Wimbledon Men’s Final
abstract: Novak Djokovic takes on Andy Murray in their fourth meeting in a Grand Slam final.
lead_paragraph: Andy Murray ended 77 years of British waiting, becoming the first British man to win the Wimbledon singles title since Fred Perry in 1936 by defeating No. 1 Novak Djokovic, 6-4, 7-5, 6-4, in a straight-sets final that lasted three hours and nine minutes.

headline: Bomb Blasts at India’s Buddhist Mecca in Bihar
abstract: Two Buddhist monks were injured after a series of low intensity blasts went off at the Mahabodhi Temple complex in Bodh Gaya on Sunday morning.
lead_paragraph: Nine low intensity bombs went off within fifteen minutes early Sunday morning inside the Mahabodhi temple complex, a Unesco World Heritage site, and one of the holiest sites associated with the life of Buddha in Bodh Gaya in the northern Indian state of Bihar. India’s Home Secretary, Anil Goswami told reporters that four explosions occurred inside the temple complex, three others shook a nearby monastery and an eighth exploded near a statue of Buddha. Two other bombs were defused, Mr. Goswami added.

headline: A Maritime Beauty, Possibly Gone Forever
abstract: Nina, a 70-foot schooner that was a racer, a flagship, a training vessel for aspiring mariners and the unrequited love of so many sailors, went missing with seven people aboard.
lead_paragraph: John Rousmaniere remembers the last time he saw Nina in top form. It was 1962, and it was dazzling its way to Bermuda, leaving a bunch of younger and sleeker challengers in its wake.

headline: Disruptions: How Driverless Cars Could Reshape Cities
abstract: While driverless cars might still seem like science fiction, people are considering what they could mean for the city of the future. The short answer is “a lot.”
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — By now, seeing one of Google’s experimental, driverless cars zipping down Silicon Valley’s Highway 101, or parking itself on a San Francisco street, is not all that unusual. Indeed, as automakers like Audi, Toyota and Mercedes-Benz make plans for self-driving vehicles, it is only a matter of time before such cars become a big part of the great American traffic jam.

lead_paragraph: Former President George W. Bush, who normally stays out of current political issues, waded briefly into the immigration debate in an interview broadcast on Sunday, urging Congress to pass legislation to overhaul the system.

abstract: Gannett and the Tribune Company have recently purchased groups of TV stations in locations where political advertising can be highly lucrative.
lead_paragraph: When Allbritton, the media company that owns Politico, put its seven television stations up for sale this spring, analysts quickly singled out one as the most attractive: WJLA, the company’s ABC-affiliated station in Washington, D.C. It is the biggest of the bunch, the best known and, perhaps most important, a magnet for political spending.

lead_paragraph: When the winds change, a ferocious forest inferno can make a sharp turn, and the fire crews battling it may need to depend on their eyes and instincts to tell them whether they are in danger.
