headline: Misreading ‘Eichmann in Jerusalem’
keywords: ['ANTI-SEMITISM', 'Books and Literature', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Jews and Judaism', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: Hannah Arendt’s dispatches from Adolf Eichmann’s trial did not portray him as a robotic bureaucrat, but as a fanatical ‘joiner’ convinced he was serving a higher good.
lead_paragraph: The movie “Hannah Arendt,” which opened in New York in May, has unleashed emotional commentary that mirrors the fierce debate Arendt herself ignited over half a century ago, when she covered the trial of the notorious war criminal Adolf Eichmann. One of the pre-eminent political thinkers of the 20th century, Arendt, who died in 1975 at the age of 69, was a Jew arrested by the German police in 1933, forced into exile and later imprisoned in an internment camp. She escaped and fled to the United States in 1941, where she wrote the seminal books “The Origins of Totalitarianism” and “The Human Condition.”

headline: Castle Denizens Spring to Life (Some More So)
abstract: With some standout moments, American Ballet Theater concluded its New York season with seven performances of “Sleeping Beauty.”
lead_paragraph: Because American Ballet Theater’s annual eight-week New York spring season occurs at the huge Metropolitan Opera House and presents an impressive selection of stars, this block of performances has a prestigious spot on the international dance calendar. It’s not unusual, however, for the company to squander large parts of the season on works that degrade ballet itself; and so again it proved this year.

headline: Love Hurts, and I’ve Got the Moves and Movie Scenes to Prove It
abstract: “Drenched,” choreographed by Luke Murphy, addresses love’s many facets with movement and snippets from film and television history.
lead_paragraph: The La MaMa Moves! festival concluded over the weekend with an attempt at romance, which afforded little in the way of surprises. A man and a woman? References to romantic films? They’re both prominent parts of “Drenched,” a work choreographed by Luke Murphy that included snippets from “Gone With the Wind” and “The Bachelor.” Instead of a rose ceremony, this dance incorporated petals — red ones, of course — which fell from the ceiling like rain.

headline: A Chamber Ensemble’s Passionate Swan Song
abstract: The Tokyo String Quartet, which is disbanding, said farewell to its longtime association with the Norfolk Chamber Music Festival with a program of Haydn, Debussy and Bartok.
lead_paragraph: NORFOLK, Conn. — Many string quartets start out as a family and then over time morph into an institution. As long-serving members retire, new players join in, subtly altering the sound and style until only the name remains unchanged. The Tokyo String Quartet decided to retire as a family rather than continue with further changes in its lineup. On Saturday evening, the quartet, which was founded in 1969, gave a passionate and emotionally charged performance here at the Norfolk Chamber Music Festival that the ensemble says will be its last.

headline: Spinning Through Space, With Help From NASA
abstract: The English composer Gustav Holst’s orchestral suite “The Planets” was wedded with imagery of the solar system at a Summertime Classics concert by the New York Philharmonic.
lead_paragraph: Outside of Avery Fisher Hall on Friday evening, hopeful would-be New York Philharmonic audience members held up signs requesting tickets for the concert at hand. Inside the auditorium, empty seats were scarce. The scene wasn’t unfamiliar; a week earlier, tickets for “A Dancer’s Dream,” a lavish multidisciplinary event built around two Stravinsky ballets, were in similarly high demand.

headline: Sharp Hefner Continues a Monthlong Turnaround
abstract: Jeremy Hefner allowed two hits and struck out eight batters, tying his career high, in seven innings as the Mets beat the Brewers.
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — Jeremy Hefner was never hyped and hardly ballyhooed. For him, success and job security as a ballplayer were not guaranteed.

headline: An Italian in Paris: How a New Stage Lifted Verdi
abstract: While Verdi thought little of the Paris Opera, he wanted to prove himself there. So he composed “Les Vêpres Siciliennes,” performed Saturday at Caramoor in Katonah, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: KATONAH, N.Y. — Verdi’s operas for the French stage have become rarities, but in honor of his 200th birthday in October, “Verdi in Paris” is the focus of this year’s installment of the invaluable Bel Canto at Caramoor series, which opened here on Saturday evening with a concert performance of “Les Vêpres Siciliennes.”

headline: ‘Monkey’ Missionaries Find Their Flocks
abstract: The Lincoln Center Festival is using an unusual multipronged marketing campaign for its centerpiece production, “Monkey: Journey to the West.”
lead_paragraph: The New World Mall in Flushing, Queens, is a busy place. Customers pass through its chrome and glass doors in a steady stream that can swell to a torrent, then shop its dozens of boutiques or cruise the aisles at J-Mart, a huge supermarket that, like the businesses around it, caters primarily to Chinese-Americans from Flushing, Elmhurst and Long Island.

headline: In Cranking Up Heat, Nature Offers a Head Start
abstract: Speedy Ortiz performed on Friday night at Death by Audio, in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, to celebrate the release of its full-length debut album, “Major Arcana” (Carpark).
lead_paragraph: There are indignities to being a small band playing a small show. Maybe the crowd will be small, too, or uninterested. The pay might be peanuts. Maybe you will be burdened by other circumstances beyond your control. The hand you’re dealt is just that.

headline: Avidly Lighting the Way as a Partner Saws Along
abstract: The choreographer Michelle Boulé and the cellist Okkyung Lee presented an immersive performance piece at the Mount Tremper Arts festival in the Catskills.
lead_paragraph: MOUNT TREMPER, N.Y. — When the cellist emerged from a bathroom with her instrument, sounding like a swarm of bees, the performance was already under way. Michelle Boulé, the dancer and choreographer, had entered through another door of the pristine studio, nestled here in the Catskills at the annual Mount Tremper Arts festival. Ms. Boulé had brought illumination: pushing and dragging a utility light, she threaded among audience members who were sitting in the dark in scattered folding chairs facing in various directions. They were ready for whatever might happen in Saturday’s American premiere of “BREAK>Urge>Imprint,” a 40-minute collaboration between Ms. Boulé and the cellist Okkyung Lee.

headline: One Passenger’s Story: ‘We Had to Help Each Other Out’
abstract: Inside the battered jetliner, passengers helped other passengers to scramble out to safety.
lead_paragraph: Inside the battered hull of Asiana Airlines Flight 214, the screaming had ceased.

headline: Hypocrisy, Thy Name Is (Duh!) Washington
abstract: “This Town,” by Mark Leibovich, the national political correspondent for The New York Times Magazine, is a blistering look at the egos and machinations of Washington’s insider culture.
lead_paragraph: Of all the irritating things about Washington — the phoniness, the showy cars, the utter inability of a metropolitan area of 6.9 million people to produce a single decent slice of pizza or a passable submarine sandwich with oil and not mayonnaise — none is more infuriating than the local insider habit of referring to the place as “this town,” as in “He’s the most important power broker in this town” or, more likely (and worse), “The way to get ahead in this town is to seem not to be trying to get ahead.”

headline: There Are Pillows and a Lot of Touching, but, Really, It’s a Dance Work
abstract: Jody Oberfelder Dance Projects performed the installation “4Chambers” at Officers’ House No. 15 on Governors Island.
lead_paragraph: On a blisteringly hot afternoon, it’s hard to suppress that moment of horror when a choreographer announces that the participatory work you’re about to see involves physical touch. But really, pity the dancers. They are the ones who must manipulate and interact with overheated bodies. They are those who, in the case of Jody Oberfelder’s performance-installation “4Chambers,” have the responsibility of turning a science project into a dance. It’s a thankless task.

headline: Teasing and Gradual, Then a Dash to the Finish
abstract: The Boston Symphony Orchestra opened its summer festival at Tanglewood with an all-Tchaikovsky program conducted by Rafael Frühbeck de Burgos.
lead_paragraph: LENOX, Mass. — Meteorologists, astronomers and schoolchildren may disagree. But for a substantial crowd of music lovers, summer officially began on Friday when the Boston Symphony Orchestra opened its summer festival at Tanglewood with an all-Tchaikovsky concert under the baton of Rafael Frühbeck de Burgos. The concert took place in the Koussevitzky Music Shed, which celebrates its 75th year this season, and, like that structure, aimed for a happy medium between solidly grounded and breezy.

headline: Publisher Objects to Sequel to Sendak’s ‘Wild Things’
abstract: A Kickstarter campaign to raise money for a sequel to Maurice Sendak’s “Where the Wild Things Are” has been suspended over a copyright dispute.
lead_paragraph: A Kickstarter campaign to raise money for a sequel to Maurice Sendak’s “Where the Wild Things Are” has been suspended over a copyright dispute. The project, a poem written by Geoffrey O. Todd with illustrations by Rich Berner called “Back to the Wild,” was to chronicle a new adventure in which Max travels with his daughter, Sophie, to see the Wild Things for the first time in 30 years. In the original Kickstarter post, published in May, the authors said they hoped to raise £25,000 (about $37,270) to publish the work and had “been very careful not to impinge on Mr. Sendak’s copyright and have taken the necessary legal advice around this whole project.” HarperCollins Publishers, which published the original book, felt differently. In a legal notice sent to Kickstarter on July 3, the company said, “Any such unauthorized ‘sequel’ would clearly violate the estate’s right to create derivative works.” Before Sendak died last year, at 83, he spoke out against writing a sequel to his 1963 classic in a 2011 video interview with the Web site for the Tate museums in Britain: “Go to hell,” he said. “I’m not a whore. I don’t do those things.”

headline: Seemingly Mad
abstract: For everything there is a season, and this is the season of the return of Randy Sowell.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — We haven’t seen Randy Sowell since 2010, but he returns today with a puzzle that might have you feeling a bit dizzy after you’re done solving.

headline: ‘Dark Knight Returns’ Cover Art Goes for Sale
abstract: The original art for the cover of Issue No. 2 of “The Dark Knight Returns,” right, will be sold next month by Heritage Auctions for an estimated price of more than $500,000.
lead_paragraph: The original art for the cover of Issue No. 2 of “The Dark Knight Returns,” right, will be sold next month by Heritage Auctions for an estimated price of more than $500,000. “The Dark Knight Returns,” written and illustrated by Frank Miller, was published in 1986, and it, along with “Watchmen,” by Alan Moore and Dave Gibbons, ushered in a new sophistication in comic books. “The Dark Knight Returns” imagines a future Gotham City, where crime and corruption are rampant and Batman comes out of retirement to save it. He also recruits the first female Robin, Carrie Kelley. “The Dark Knight Returns” prompted a Batman revival that led to a series of movies in the 1980s and ’90s and more recently to Christopher Nolan’s three blockbusters about the character. “For fans of modern comics, this drawing is where everything really begins,” Todd Hignite, the vice president of Heritage Auctions, said in a statement. He noted that the cover of “The Dark Knight Returns” No. 3, with Batman and the new Robin, sold for $448,125 in 2011. The market for original comic book art, as well as for Golden Age comic books, continues to boom. In 2011 a copy of Action Comics No. 1 sold for $2.16 million.

headline: A Country Concert for Tornado Victims
abstract: More than 60,000 country music fans gathered on Saturday at the University of Oklahoma in Norman to watch a concert and help raise money for tornado relief.
lead_paragraph: More than 60,000 country music fans gathered on Saturday at the University of Oklahoma in Norman to watch a concert and help raise money for tornado relief, The Associated Press reported. Toby Keith headlined a lineup that also included, among others, Garth Brooks and his wife, Trisha Yearwood (both at right); Willie Nelson; Sammy Hagar; and Carrie Underwood, in a satellite performance. Proceeds from the sold-out seven-hour show went to a fund established by the United Way of Central Oklahoma designed to help the victims of the tornadoes that struck the state in May. The concert was organized by Mr. Keith, who grew up in Moore, Okla., one of the towns most affected by the storms. It was the first live performance for Mr. Brooks in Oklahoma since 1997, and he did not hesitate to play his hits. But according to The Tulsa World, he also hinted that “new music feels like it’s on the horizon.” Mr. Brooks has not released a studio album of new material since “Scarecrow” in 2001.

However, if a test is developed by a clinical laboratory for use at its own facilities, it can be sold without a premarket review.

headline: Another Couture Myth Buster
abstract: Bouchra Jarrar belongs to the modern couture camp.
lead_paragraph: Bouchra Jarrar belongs to the modern couture camp. Her day clothes tend to be masculine-influenced, with long, sleeveless jackets and Perfectos with black trousers, while she returns again and again to sparingly cut dresses in silk. The refinement showed this season in dresses that beautifully combined blush pink, ivory and beige, and skimmed over the body. What perhaps isn’t obvious is the texture of her original fabrics, like a heavy silk woven from multiple shades of cream and ivory for her jackets. A black-and-white silk weave, used for sharp jackets, suggests an industrial material. Her clothes demand that you look close — at the amount of asymmetry in her designs, at the careful way she sets a zipper, so that the silver teeth become the merest line of decoration.

lead_paragraph: It may not lead to the creation of a science-fiction saga with a great jazz and R&B score, or an operatic aria about the life of America’s 16th president, but George Lucas, Herb Alpert, Allen Toussaint, Renée Fleming and Tony Kushner will be among the artistic dignitaries invited to gather on Wednesday at the White House to receive the National Medal of Arts, it was announced on Monday. The award,  managed by the National Endowment for the Arts, is regarded as the nation’s highest honor for artistic excellence, and its winners are selected annually “based on their contributions to the creation, growth, and support of the arts in the United States,” the organization said in a news release.

headline: Weekend Gun Report: July 4th Edition

lead_paragraph: It was a holiday weekend, which, as we’ve sadly learned in the months since we began the Gun Report, means an even more gruesome list of gun deaths and injuries than usual. Here is the one we want to highlight, however: On the evening of July 4, in Midlothian, Va., Brendon Mackey was walking with his father in the parking lot of a local restaurant where they had gone to see the fireworks. He suddenly fell to the ground. Nobody understood why at first; even after they saw blood, they thought he must have hit his head from the fall.

headline: New Dior Jewels from Victoire de Castellane

lead_paragraph: When a fashion sensibility changes, so do the jewels. Victoire de Castellane has whipped up a lovely, delicate collection of new designs for Dior that puts attention on brilliant colors. In the past, her calling card was the crazy and sensational, as befitting the decade of John Galliano. But now, closer to the spirit of Raf Simons, her work emphasizes different values. The jewels in her Cher Dior collection seem drenched in pure color: pink, yellow, blue and purple sapphires, rubies, diamonds, garnets and Paraiba tourmalines. “There is certainly a red for everyone,” Christian Dior wrote in his “Little Dictionary of Fashion.” In stones, Ms. de Castellane makes that abundantly clear.

headline: Research Shows the Physiological Stresses of Stock Car Racing
abstract: Auto racing is often derided as a nonsport, but new physiological research shows that driving stock cars is tough on the human body.
lead_paragraph: BIDDEFORD, Maine — For anyone who does not think that the Nascar drivers sweltering inside their cars at Daytona over the weekend were participating in a real sport, there’s new research that supports racing’s athletic cred.

headline: Urp Versus Derp
abstract: To urp is human, to derp is not.
lead_paragraph: Jared Bernstein writes from Europe about the complete unwillingness of European policy makers to learn from their mistakes; call it Euroderp. And it is indeed a remarkable thing: despite overwhelming evidence that austerity doesn’t work as advertised, there has been essentially no relaxation of the orthodoxy, and no admission of error.

headline: At Navy Installation, Sexual Assault Prevention Begins at Boot Camp
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Sex Crimes', 'Sexual Harassment', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A pilot program that combines training, intervention and prevention at a Navy base in Illinois seems to have reduced the incidence of sexual assault.
lead_paragraph: NAVAL STATION GREAT LAKES, Ill. — On Day 3 of Navy boot camp here, recruits sat through a two-hour session on sexual harassment and sexual assault — including a warning that alcohol often plays a significant role, but is never a defense.

headline: McDonagh Remains a Ranger
abstract: After they re-signed defenseman Ryan McDonagh, the Rangers will now try to negotiate with forwards Derek Stepan and Carl Hagelin.
lead_paragraph: The Rangers fulfilled perhaps their biggest off-season priority Monday, re-signing Ryan McDonagh, their best young defenseman, to a six-year contract. But two of the club’s key restricted free agents remain unsigned.

headline: Soldier’s Lawyers Ask Judge to Acquit on Aid to Enemy
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Courts-Martial']
abstract: Pfc. Bradley Manning’s lead lawyer presented witnesses and evidence to try to prove that the soldier who gave classified documents to WikiLeaks had not sought to help the enemy.
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md. — Defense lawyers for Pfc. Bradley Manning asked a military judge on Monday to acquit him of the most serious charge he faces — aiding the enemy by providing classified information to WikiLeaks — as they began to present their witnesses at his court-martial.

headline: The Nostalgia Playlist
abstract: Music has the power to transport people to another time and place. Invited to name a song that evokes moments of nostalgia, New York Times readers offered more than 150, from Frank Sinatra to Guns N’ Roses. Here is a selection.
lead_paragraph: Music has the power to transport people to another time and place. Invited to name a song that evokes moments of nostalgia, New York Times readers offered more than 150, from Frank Sinatra to Guns N’ Roses. Here is a selection.

headline: What’s Not to Like About 13-0?
abstract: While wins do not always tell the whole story, Tigers pitcher Max Scherzer’s 13-0 start deserves the attention of even the most jaded fans of sabermetrics.
lead_paragraph: Of baseball’s pitching statistics, none are more polarizing than victories. Some tradition-minded fans still hold wins in the highest regard while proponents of newer statistics are ready to eliminate them from their evaluations.

headline: What Does Birth Cost? Hard to Tell
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Hospitals', 'Medicine and Health', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth']
abstract: Hospitals do not have to tell you their prices, and often they keep them secret — until they send the bill.
lead_paragraph: We’re continually told that when it comes to health care, we need to be savvy and shop around for the best prices. To that end, policy experts and politicians promote health care savings accounts, saying they make “health care consumers” (a k a patients) more conscious of prices, bringing down the cost of medical care.

headline: What Is Nostalgia Good For? Quite a Bit, Research Shows
abstract: Nostalgia, long considered a disorder, is now recognized to counteract loneliness, boredom and anxiety — making life seem more meaningful and death less frightening.
lead_paragraph: SOUTHAMPTON, England — Not long after moving to the University of Southampton, Constantine Sedikides had lunch with a colleague in the psychology department and described some unusual symptoms he’d been feeling. A few times a week, he was suddenly hit with nostalgia for his previous home at the University of North Carolina: memories of old friends, Tar Heel basketball games, fried okra, the sweet smells of autumn in Chapel Hill.

headline: Woman Is Stabbed on Subway in Apparently Random Attack
abstract: A staring match between strangers, the police said, ended with one woman wounded in a subway car at the Bloomingdale’s stop in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: A knife-wielding woman riding an uptown subway train on Monday morning stabbed a 39-year-old Manhattan woman multiple times at the 59th Street and Lexington Avenue station, a violent conclusion to what began, the police said, as a staring match between strangers.

headline: Spitzer Quickly Hits Establishment Headwind
abstract: Former Gov. Eliot Spitzer began his effort to run for city comptroller, while mayoral hopefuls and New Yorkers debated whether he deserved a second chance.
lead_paragraph: From corporate boardrooms to the headquarters of the city’s Democratic political campaigns, phone lines lighted up and strategy sessions were organized on Monday with a single mission in mind: stopping Eliot Spitzer.

headline: Science of Nostalgia, Soothing Robots
keywords: ['Memory', 'Research', 'Science and Technology', 'Medicine and Health', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: John Tierney talks about why nostalgia is good for your brain; Science Times reporters and editors share their nostalgic science memories; a robot helps children forget the sting of vaccination shots.
lead_paragraph: John Tierney talks about why nostalgia is good for your brain; Science Times reporters and editors share their nostalgic science memories; a robot helps children forget the sting of vaccination shots.

headline: A Triumph for Scotland, Too, and Perhaps a ‘Sir’ for Murray
abstract: Andy Murray’s breakthrough at Wimbledon not only ended the long winless skein of British men, it represented a point of Scottish pride and began immediate talk of a knighthood.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — Andy Murray still looked the same Monday morning after a Wimbledon title and 90 minutes of sleep. He still sounded the same, too, with his droll drone of a voice, which, come to think of it, always sounds a bit groggy.

headline: Wall Street’s Disgraced Sheriff Seeks to Saddle Up Again
abstract: Hurdles remain for a political comeback, so the financial industry may not have reason to fear a return of Eliot Spitzer, at least not quite yet.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street’s former sheriff could be saddling up again.

headline: Image of the Day: July 8
abstract: Jaguar Land Rover Limited launched its new F-Type two-seater car on Monday in Mumbai, Maharashtra.

headline: Understanding the Protective Side of Dengue Virus
abstract: People infected with one strain of the dengue virus gain protection against the other three types for about two years, a study shows.
lead_paragraph: Infection with one strain of the dengue virus gives people protection against the other three strains for about two years, a new biostatistics study has found.

headline: Pondering a Drought in Merger Deals
abstract: A report from Ernst & Young released on Monday proposes that the deal-making slump may be more than just a passing phase.
lead_paragraph: Such is the optimism of the deal maker that, even with the downturn in activity in the first half of the year, some say a recovery in mergers and acquisitions is just around the corner.

headline: The Poorest Kid in a Rich Town
abstract: What lessons about money are there to learn for a child in a family that has less money than nearly every other one in the community?
lead_paragraph: The New York Times journalist Ron Lieber is on leave from the Your Money column and at work on his forthcoming book, “The Opposite of Spoiled” (on “producing grounded young adults with financial habits that are mature beyond their years”). He’ll join Motherlode as a biweekly columnist this fall, but meanwhile, he posed a question on Facebook that I had to raise here:

headline: The Long Chain of Responsibility Behind an Oily and Deadly Train Wreck
keywords: ['Accidents and Safety', 'Explosions', 'Keystone Pipeline System', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Oil Sands', 'Pipelines', 'Railroad Accidents and Safety', 'Railroads', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The deadly derailment of an oil train in a small Quebec town says much about the unaccounted costs of humanity’s appetite for crude.
lead_paragraph: Around the smoldering, oil-soaked crater in the heart of Lac-Mégantic, a small Quebec town where an unmanned train with 72 tank cars carrying crude oil derailed and exploded early on Saturday, killing at least 13 people*, the search for victims and causes is still on.

headline: Lesson in Air Safety: 90 Seconds to Get Out
abstract: Asiana flight attendants have won wide praise for quickly getting passengers off the plane that crashed in San Francisco on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Next time you’re on a plane at takeoff or landing, watch the flight attendant in the jump seat, seemingly lost in thought. Is she idly wondering where she parked her the car at the airport or what’s for dinner?

headline: The Chelsea Hotel Had Its Own Eloise
abstract: How Gaby Hoffmann survived child stardom.
lead_paragraph: According to family legend, there was a snowstorm on the night in 1982 when Gabrielle Mary Antonia Hoffmann — Gaby — was taken home from the hospital to her mother’s apartment at the Chelsea Hotel. Of course Hoffmann did not yet know she had been born into downtown New York artistic royalty. Her mother, Viva (née Janet Sue Hoffmann), is an actress who appeared in Andy Warhol’s movies and who lived at the Chelsea with Gaby’s 11-year-old half-sister, Alexandra, her daughter with her ex-husband, Michel Auder, the French video artist who later married the photographer Cindy Sherman. Later, Hoffmann came to call Auder her dad and Sherman her stepmother.

headline: Obama Administration Rules Out Suspension of Aid to Egypt in Near Term
abstract: The White House plans to study the events in Egypt to determine whether the military seizing of power constitutes a military coup d’état under law.
lead_paragraph: The White House on Monday ruled out an immediate suspension of American assistance to Egypt after the military seized power. It hoped to use its financial leverage to press for the prompt restoration of a democratic government and to head off further violence.

headline: Pollution Leads to Drop in Life Span in Northern China, Research Finds
abstract: Widespread coal use in the north has led in recent decades to an average decrease in life span of more than five years, research indicates.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Southern Chinese on average have lived at least five years longer than their northern counterparts in recent decades because of the destructive health effects of pollution from the widespread use of coal in the north, according to a study released Monday by a prominent American science journal.

headline: Cruz Remaining With Giants; Contract Is Extended Until 2018
abstract: The Giants keep their fan-favorite receiver Victor Cruz in the fold with a five-year contract extension worth $43 million.
lead_paragraph: Disregarded as a high school player, spurned by his college team twice and unwanted in the N.F.L. draft just three years ago, Victor Cruz, the charismatic, salsa-dancing Giants wide receiver, continued his improbable career ascent Monday when he signed a five-year, $43 million contract extension that will tie him to the team until at least the 2018 season.

headline: My Monthly Trip to Ladakh
abstract: When I want to get out of the office, I go to Ladakh, India.
lead_paragraph: Whenever I’m feeling too rooted, which is most of the time, the only antidote usually at hand is clicking on a video posted on Vimeo: “Trip to Ladakh, India 2009.” It’s not my trip. I don’t know the people in the video, who, I think, are a group of seven friends from Singapore. I probably watch it once a month, and it always has the odd effect of making me tear up. Maybe there’s a name for that feeling. Projected nostalgia?

headline: Science of Nostalgia
abstract: It was first thought to be a “neurological disease of essentially demonic cause,” but it turns out that nostalgia is good for your brain. And there’s science to prove it.
lead_paragraph: It was first thought to be a “neurological disease of essentially demonic cause,” but it turns out that nostalgia is good for your brain. And there’s science to prove it.

headline: A Jam-Band Experiment in Live Hi-Fi
abstract: Umphrey’s McGee, a well-known ensemble on the jam-band circuit, will rent fans headphones that let them hear what the musicians hear.
lead_paragraph: Umphrey’s McGee, a well-known ensemble on the jam-band circuit, is engaged in an experiment that may change the way we listen to live music – or at least the way a percentage of the audience does.

headline: Trayvon Martin’s Father Says Screams on 911 Call Were His Son’s
abstract: The defense’s witnesses on Monday in the George Zimmerman trial included Trayvon Martin’s father, and a close friend of Mr. Zimmerman.
lead_paragraph: SANFORD, Fla. — Who yelled “help”?

headline: He Will Have Vengeance (Again): New York Philharmonic to Present ‘Sweeney Todd’
abstract: The New York Philharmonic will present a new staged production of “Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street,” Stephen Sondheim’s musical about a murderous hair-cutter, starring the bass-baritone Bryn Terfel in the title role.
lead_paragraph: Sharpen your razor, protect your jugular vein and prepare to re-attend the tale of Sweeney Todd: The New York Philharmonic will present a new staged production in March of “Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street,” the dark and gory Stephen Sondheim-Hugh Wheeler musical about a murderous hair-cutter with a thirst for vengeance, it was announced on Monday.

headline: In Performance: ‘Choir Boy’
abstract: Tarell Alvin McCraney’s new play features the spiritual “Motherless Child,” sung by the cast members Kyle Beltran, Wallace Smith, Jeremy Pope, Nicholas L. Ashe and Grantham Coleman.
lead_paragraph: Tarell Alvin McCraney’s new play features the spiritual “Motherless Child,” sung by the cast members Kyle Beltran, Wallace Smith, Jeremy Pope, Nicholas L. Ashe and Grantham Coleman.

headline: Perry Says He Won’t Seek Governorship Again in Texas
abstract: Rick Perry, the longest-serving governor of Texas, said he would instead “pray and reflect and work to determine my own future path.”
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — Rick Perry, the longest-serving governor of Texas and an unsuccessful Republican presidential candidate last year, announced on Monday that he would not seek another term but would instead “pray and reflect and work to determine my own future path.”

headline: Office Advancement vs. Home Duties
keywords: ['Careers and Professions', 'Child Care', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Men and Boys', 'Parenting', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Fewer parents today say they want more responsibilities in their jobs than did so in 1992. Perhaps changing gender roles are at play.
lead_paragraph: In an article on Monday, I wrote about the choices faced by middle-class working mothers, who typically don’t have the resources to hire nannies and other support to help them “lean in” at the office. But one of the striking things I came across in my reporting was that a majority of working parents, men as well as women, don’t actually want more responsibilities at the office.

headline: Playing, and Losing, as a Medical Team
abstract: When something goes wrong in medicine, it can be hard to know where blame lies — and in the long run, it may not matter.
lead_paragraph: One of my patients died last month, a man I was particularly fond of. I had known him for almost 20 years. I had come to know his wife in person, the children in his frequently exasperated anecdotes and his grandchildren in blurry cellphone photos. His wife left a message with the unexpected news on a Monday morning.

headline: New From Paris, a Label With Surprises
abstract: Atto, a new ready-to-wear label in Paris, quietly made its debut during the couture shows.
lead_paragraph: Atto, a new ready-to-wear label in Paris, quietly made its debut during the couture shows. Designed by Julien Dossena, formerly at Balenciaga, with Lion Blau, Atto seems born out a twin respect for French ’60s fashion (Cardin and so forth) and Japanese minimalism. Not that the clothes look the least bit retro, but the designers don’t shy away from fabrics that lend structure to their tailoring, like neoprene and jersey.

headline: 60: Behind Every Second, Millenniums of History
abstract: The number of seconds in a minute — and minutes in an hour — comes from the base-60 numeral system of ancient Mesopotamia.
lead_paragraph: The number of seconds in a minute — and minutes in an hour — comes from the base-60 numeral system of ancient Mesopotamia. Developed around 3100 B.C., the sexagesimal system, as it is known, has fallen out of favor but is still used (with slight adjustments) to measure time and angles.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | July 2 – July 8, 2013
abstract: We’re testing a new idea: a weekly news quiz. Let us know what you think!
lead_paragraph: Answer the 10 questions below to see what you know about the people and events that made news this week.

headline: The Impact of Adding a Teenager to Your Auto Policy
abstract: “Good student” discounts can lessen the financial hit from adding a teenage driver to a car insurance policy.
lead_paragraph: Most parents watch their children learn to drive with trepidation. But the stress of watching them get behind the wheel is compounded by the financial shock of adding a teenager to an automobile insurance policy.

headline: Rick Perry Won’t Run
abstract: The longest-serving governor in Texas history did more than say “oops” at a presidential debate.
lead_paragraph: It’s not shocking that Gov. Rick Perry of Texas has decided against seeking a fourth term in office. Even three — as Dorothy Parker said about martinis — can be too many. Your constituents get pretty tired of hearing from you (think Mayor Michael Bloomberg and former Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York).

headline: High Disability Rates Persist in Old Age
abstract: We are paying for extended life spans with a high rate of late-life disability, a new study finds.
lead_paragraph: Weird berries. Capsules of unpronounceable supplements. Yoga or tai chi. Crossword puzzles. Such amulets, we’re told, may ward off disability — which is the real fear that accompanies aging, isn’t it? Not the sheer number of years that will have passed, but the things we’ll no longer be able to do.

headline: Tokyo on the Seine
abstract: Parisians have been fascinated with Japan since the 19th century, and a tour of the city today reveals that the eastern influence is still strong.
lead_paragraph: Van Gogh collected and painted imitations of Japanese woodblock prints. Baudelaire gave them to his friends. Monet painted his wife in a kimono. A popular cafe and concert hall called Le Divan Japonais — the Japanese Divan — was decorated in a Japanese style and immortalized in a poster by Toulouse-Lautrec. France’s fixation with things Japanese became so intense in the 19th century that the French gave it a name: “Japonisme.”

headline: ‘Jerusalem’ Fans: What’s Your Favorite Recipe From the Book?
abstract: If you’re a fan of the cookbook “Jerusalem,” by Yotam Ottolenghi and Sami Tamimi, tell us which recipe you’d like to see featured in this month’s Recipe Lab.
lead_paragraph: A dozen new cookbooks flood my cubicle every day, and most of them go right back out, never to be heard from again. But one cookbook has kept making noise this year: “Jerusalem,” by the chefs Yotam Ottolenghi and Sami Tamimi, has gone viral among food lovers since it was published in the United States last fall.

headline: Judge Orders N.F.L. Concussion Case to Mediation
abstract: The federal judge overseeing the case said she would not rule on the N.F.L.’s motion to dismiss until Sept. 3 to give the mediator time to bring the sides closer.
lead_paragraph: The federal judge overseeing the case brought by thousands of former N.F.L. players who have accused the league of hiding the dangers of concussions ordered both sides to mediation Monday.

headline: The Case Against Fabrice Tourre
abstract: Fabrice Tourre was the only individual at Goldman Sachs and across Wall Street sued by the Securities and Exchange Commission for helping to sell a mortgage-securities investment. The case against him was bolstered by colorful e-mails he wrote.
lead_paragraph: Fabrice Tourre was the only individual at Goldman Sachs and across Wall Street sued by the Securities and Exchange Commission for helping to sell a mortgage-securities investment. The case against him was bolstered by colorful e-mails he wrote.

headline: Dining Calendar
abstract: A selection of events for this week.
lead_paragraph: Various food and drinks specials at French restaurants in the Forgeois Group (which includes Café Noir, Jules Bistro, Cercle Rouge and Le Singe Vert) across the city will be offered for a week leading up to the Bastille Day celebration on July 14 at Bar Tabac, 128 Smith Street in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, which features Pétanque tournaments, live music and food vendors from the neighborhood. Thirty-seven restaurants will also be participating in French Restaurant Week at the same time between Monday and July 14, offering various specials for $17.89 (the year of the French Revolution). A full list is available online.

headline: Listening for Clues to Mind’s Mysteries
abstract: “The Examined Life,” by Stephen Grosz, describes the process of psychoanalysis and how the ways people connect the past, present and future reflect their capacity to change.
lead_paragraph: Freud’s famous case studies, like Dora, the Wolf Man, Little Hans and the Rat Man, are psychoanalytic readings, suspenseful detective stories and elliptical narratives that have all the drama and contradictions of modernist fiction. Not only is Freud a powerful writer, but his methodology and insights also have a lot in common with literary criticism and novelistic architecture. His patient portraits showcase his skills both as a critic, intent on deconstructing his subjects’ lives, and as a masterly storyteller, adept at using unreliable narrators to explore the mysteries of love and sex and death. It’s no coincidence that he liked to write about characters from Shakespeare, Goethe, Ibsen and Sophocles (yes, Oedipus), or that he paid so much attention to the language and imagery employed by his patients.

headline: Cars, Birds and Premieres
abstract: Summergarden, at the Museum of Modern Art’s Sculpture Garden, begins its 2013 offerings with four New York premieres from Joel Sachs and the New Juilliard Ensemble.
lead_paragraph: The annual series of free Summergarden concerts, presented in the sculpture garden of the Museum of Modern Art, opened on Sunday night with players from the New Juilliard Ensemble performing four contemporary works. The garden, as a concert site, is both inviting and exasperating.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Pulling the Plug on MSN TV, and Computers Guessing Emotions
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Monday’s selections include a suggestion that software could analyze facial expressions and help students learn better, and Microsoft closing the former WebTV.
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: Madoff Case Puts Focus on Duties of Custodial Banks
abstract: A lawsuit brought by investors who lost $60 million in Bernie Madoff’s Ponzi scheme claims that Westport National Bank failed to protect their money.
lead_paragraph: Among the far-flung feeder funds, brokerage houses and institutions interconnected in the vast Ponzi scheme perpetuated by Bernard L. Madoff, one little-known local bank is now in the spotlight.

headline: Recognizable Guys You Might Not Recognize
abstract: Mikhail Baryshnikov and Willem Dafoe star in “The Old Woman,” an adaptation of short stories by Daniil Kharms.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, England — Consider the immortal twosomes of combative, wisecracking comedy: Bob and Ray, Laurel and Hardy, Hope and Crosby. Now think about adding to that list the names Baryshnikov and Dafoe.

headline: She Has a Prayer, and a Ritual, for the Sky
abstract: Antonella Rana is communications director for the international pasta brand Giovanni Rana.
lead_paragraph: I FLY all the time. Our business is pasta, and since we are an international brand, I have to travel to make sure that everything is going well. When I was younger I loved to travel, but now that I’m a wife and mother I like it a little less. I want to be with my children, so I’m happy when my business trips are done, but I do love seeing new things and meeting new people.

headline: Old Tactic in New Climate Campaign
abstract: Students are urging their colleges to divest from fossil-fuel companies as a way of forcing climate change higher onto the agenda.
lead_paragraph: It was a single word tucked into a presidential speech. It went by so fast that most Americans probably never heard it, much less took the time to wonder what it meant.

headline: Something Wicked This Way Runs
abstract: Kenneth Branagh returns to Shakespeare in a fast-paced “Macbeth” at the Manchester International Festival.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, England — The road to hell is a speedway in the exciting new production of “Macbeth” now at the Manchester International Festival, with Kenneth Branagh in the title role. Staged in a deconsecrated Romanesque church here by Mr. Branagh and the American director Rob Ashford, this intermissionless two-hour production creates a world in which everybody seems to be running — and I mean running — scared, not least its homicidal protagonist.

headline: The iPhone Hasn’t Saved T-Mobile USA Yet
abstract: There is no question that finally being able to sell the iPhone was good for T-Mobile USA. But the company still has a long way to go to regain market share.
lead_paragraph: There’s no question that finally being able to sell Apple‘s iPhone was good for T-Mobile USA, the struggling carrier that bled many subscribers to its rivals over the last few years, partly because it lacked the iPhone. Now the question is when — or if — adding the phone will help lead the company to a meaningful comeback.

headline: For Some Lizards, First Meal Can Be Life-Altering
abstract: Showing the big effects of a small event, researchers found that newborn lizards fed first in the lab were less likely to roam and harder to recapture and had smaller litters.
lead_paragraph: The very first meal a newborn lizard eats can change its life, influencing whether it leaves its birthplace and how many offspring it will have, according to a new study.

headline: Genetic Differences That Let Octopods Flourish
abstract: Hemocyanin, a protein that delivers oxygen to the tissues of octopods, has different genetic properties in different climates, researchers find.
lead_paragraph: Thanks to a protein that delivers oxygen to their tissues, octopuses live as comfortably in the tropics as they do in the Antarctic. Now it turns out that the protein, a blue pigment called hemocyanin, has different genetic properties in different climates.

headline: Culprits in a Child’s Headaches
keywords: ['Babies and Infants', 'Children and Childhood', 'Headaches', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: A full story and a careful exam can determine which pains may indicate serious illness.
lead_paragraph: My patient was missing a lot of middle school because of headaches. Her physical exam was completely normal, and the symptoms sounded like migraine — she had a throbbing sensation on both sides of her head, was more comfortable when the room was dark, and felt much better if she took ibuprofen.

lead_paragraph: Photos from Egypt, Syria, India and Canada.

abstract: Video recorded Monday morning by Ibrahim el-Sheikh, a Cairo resident who witnessed firing by Egyptian soldiers at Islamists during clashes that left dozens of dead.
lead_paragraph: Video recorded Monday morning by Ibrahim el-Sheikh, a Cairo resident who witnessed firing by Egyptian soldiers at Islamists during clashes that left dozens of dead.

headline: For a TV Ratings Lift, Try a Naughty Trend
abstract: “Drunk History,” on Comedy Central, is the latest example of a trend to win viewers by promising a little scandal.
lead_paragraph: Let’s be clear: as a general concept, the making of television shows while drunk must be condemned in the strongest terms. The potential for inflicting harm on viewers — incoherence, idiocy, general distastefulness — increases exponentially when the people creating programming are intoxicated, and television already has more than enough incoherence, idiocy and general distastefulness.

headline: New Season of Hard Hits (Maybe in Court)
abstract: The big business of college sports may change because of a pending lawsuit, which was brought because of video games like EA’s NCAA Football, the newest version of which comes out on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Sometime this summer, a federal judge in California is expected to decide if a lawsuit brought by current and former college athletes against the N.C.A.A. can be certified as a class action. Should the judge rule that the suit can proceed, the big business of college sports could face a jury trial in 2014 with potential damages that could reach billions of dollars.

headline: Pope Offers Mass on Island Beacon for Refugees

abstract: With a service before 10,000 people, Francis seeks to call attention to a humanitarian problem at what has become a gateway for thousands of migrants.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Pope Francis traveled on Monday to Lampedusa, the tiny Mediterranean island that has become a gateway to Europe for thousands of desperate asylum seekers and migrants, as well as an unknown number of others who have died during the perilous crossing from North Africa.

headline: Digging Into the Dirt
abstract: The urge to eat substances like clay and chalk is not unique to humans and has some cultural and medicinal components.
lead_paragraph: If you want to eat dirt, Sera L. Young can tell you where to get it online, why it might have some benefits and some risks, and perhaps give you a new idea about why you, and many other people crave it.

headline: Reality Show Contestants Pay a Real-World Price
abstract: Some “Big Brother” contestants who are using ethnic and sexist slurs have stirred up viewers and the CBS network.
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 2000, when CBS first locked people in a fishbowl of a house and televised almost every second of their lives, there was a spate of bad press when a newspaper discovered that a participant had ties to the New Black Panther Party. The network quickly issued a statement that said it “will not tolerate nor permit any hate speech on the program,” called “Big Brother.”

headline: 10 Questions for Obama’s Chief Technology Officer
keywords: ['Science and Technology', 'Start-ups', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Todd Park, a former Silicon Valley entrepreneur, spoke to John Harwood about how the government is using data and the “lean start-up” model.
lead_paragraph: Todd Park, a former Silicon Valley entrepreneur, serves as President Obama’s chief technology officer. His role has taken on heightened importance after several recent developments, including the implementation of the new health care law, efforts to reduce the backlog in Department of Veterans Affairs claims processing, and privacy issues raised by disclosures about data collection by the National Security Agency. headline: Canada: Storm Floods Toronto
abstract: An intense thunderstorm flooded expressways in and around Toronto, shut down the city’s transit system, closed one of its airports and led to power failures.
lead_paragraph: An intense thunderstorm flooded expressways in and around Toronto, shut down the city’s transit system, closed one of its airports and led to power failures that affected hundreds of thousands of customers on Monday evening. More than three inches of rain, about the average rainfall the city receives in all of July, fell in about one hour during the evening rush hour. Passengers were trapped on the upper level of a double-decker commuter train for about four hours before the Toronto police marine unit arrived in boats. Motorists fled from cars that had become inundated on expressways. More rain was expected through the night, and there were fears that the banks of at least one river in the city might collapse.

headline: Wren Pays Tribute to the Iconic Minnetonka Moccasin
abstract: To celebrate the launch of its updated version of a classic moccasin, the womenswear designer Wren commissioned a video from the indie band Guards, on view exclusively at T.
lead_paragraph: “If I think about Coachella, I think about people wearing Minnetonkas,” said Melissa Coker, the designer behind Wren, the Los Angeles-based line of feminine, festival-chic womenswear. Coker, who has previously partnered with brands like Claire Vivier and The Lake & Stars, recently unveiled a collaboration with the Minnesota-based moccasin brand — in which she riffs on the company’s classic thunderbird style, reimagining the iconic beaded toe detail in a range of solid metallics. To celebrate the collaboration, she also tapped the director Maximilla Lukacs to film the Brooklyn indie band Guards performing an acoustic rendition of their song “Not Supposed To” while traipsing around the sort of sun-dappled field that mocs are made for. “Their style is very vintage inspired,” Coker said of the band, which happened to play the Coachella festival in April. “I think of them as sort of sixties Americana, free spirit vibe. It just seemed perfect.”

headline: Wines for Savory, Pungent Sausages
abstract: A list of wines to take to your summer rental.
lead_paragraph: What wine goes with sausages? What wine doesn’t? Savory, pungent sausages seem to bond instantly with countless wines. Simply look for ones that are as elemental, casual and juicy as the sausages themselves. With Italian sausages, you’ll most likely want a red, and for warm-weather grilling it ought to enjoy a light chill. Translation: avoid tannins and oaky flavors. What does that leave? Only much of the low-priced red wine universe. Allow me to make a list, beginning in Italy: barbera, dolcetto, Valpolicella, Chianti, Montepulciano d’Abruzzo, to name a few. If grilling French sausages, you might start with Beaujolais, or an easygoing Chinon or Bourgueil. But no need to get hung up on ethnicities. Look for an American gamay noir, or one of the good reds from the Canary Islands, or a dry rosé. For summer rentals, don’t rely on local selections — B.Y.O.B.

headline: Secret Diplomatic Cable Sheds Light on Libyan Arms Deals
keywords: ['Arms Trade', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: A Belgian memo suggests that those making arms deals knew, even 40 years ago, that Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s weapons would not be retained by Libya’s government.
lead_paragraph: Thirty-eight years ago, a largely forgotten Belgian ambassador serving in Libya sent a secret cable from Tripoli to his home office in Brussels. Now declassified, the contents of the cable, “Libyan Arms from the Soviet Union and Yugoslavia,” offered one diplomat’s baldly undiplomatic take on a theme common at the time among analysts trying to assess the activities of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi: What was the colonel up to as he placed order after order for more weapons?

headline: The Money Side of Driverless Cars
abstract: Revenue from parking tickets, car insurance and more could dry up if cars can drive themselves and traffic accidents become largely a thing of the past.
lead_paragraph: In Washington, an average of six parking tickets are issued every minute of a normal workday. That is about 5,300 tickets on each of those days. Those slips of paper have added up to $80 million in parking fines a year, according to a report by AAA Mid-Atlantic.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Many major emerging economies have weakened since the spring, the International Monetary Fund said on Tuesday in the latest update to its economic forecasts, while advanced economies, including the United States and Europe, continue to trudge along with subpar growth and the euro area remains mired in recession.

headline: Beyond Goulash and Dumplings in Prague
abstract: For travelers who tire of local flavors in the Czech capital, new restaurants are serving global fare that can reset the palate.
lead_paragraph: Doff hats to the invincible dumpling. All due respect to the noble spud. But for those accustomed to more flavorful fare, the traditional dishes of Central Europe — and especially the Czech Republic — can turn quite tiresome even just halfway through a trip, at which point the plates of meat and starchy vegetables really start to stack up. Fortunately, the Czech capital of Prague is now home to an unexpected variety of new restaurants, including authentic Japanese, Mexican, Vietnamese and even dressed-up American-style joints, providing plenty of flavors beyond potatoes.

headline: Restaurant Report: Ametsa With Arzak Instruction in London
abstract: The father and daughter team behind a famed Basque restaurant helped open this spot in March. Here’s an early take on what it’s like to eat there.
lead_paragraph: It has taken only four generations for the Arzaks to expand beyond Spain’s Basque Country, where the family opened a tavern in 1897. Since the 1970s, the three-Michelin-starred restaurant Arzak, in San Sebastián, run by the father and daughter team of Juan Mari and Elena Arzak, has been a center of modern Basque cooking. In March, with a team from their consultancy Arzak Instruction and the chef Sergio Sanz, the pair oversaw the opening of Ametsa — Basque for “dream” — in London’s sleek Halkin hotel.

Nothing unusual about that, but Mr. Wynne was parked and on his way in when his wife pointed out that he could have plugged the Volt into the restaurant’s E.V. charger. It’s right out front.

headline: A Modern Fable: Pirates and Furries Converge
abstract: In Pittsburgh this past weekend, a perfect alignment of misunderstood subcultures.
lead_paragraph: I was in Pittsburgh over the Fourth of July weekend, walking along Penn Avenue in what is now called the “cultural district” of downtown. Having grown up in Pittsburgh in the 1970s, I was struck by two sights. First, an unusually large number of people wearing Pirates gear. The Pirates haven’t had a winning season since 1992, which happens to be the year after the team traded Barry Bonds. It seems like a lot longer since I’ve seen so many adults in Pirates jerseys and caps on the streets of Pittsburgh.

headline: An African Eco-Resort With a Greater Sense of Purpose
abstract: At Segera, a 50,000-acre ranch on Kenya’s Laikipia Plateau, guests can relax in style — while giving back to the place they’re visiting.
lead_paragraph: The former Puma C.E.O. Jochen Zeitz is dining under the stars at Segera, his 50,000-acre ranch in the middle of central Kenya’s Laikipia Plateau, when he pauses over his steak and squints out into the sprawling savanna. “Sometimes you think there nothing’s there, but take a minute,” he says. “See how the bush comes to life.” Sure enough, as we peer through the inky blue twilight, what had appeared to be tall tree trunks start to move, and soon we can make out the silhouettes of giraffes grazing amid the shadowy acacia trees, and hear the elephants lumbering through the undergrowth toward the nearby river.

What about single parents who don’t have much of a support network? Are companies demanding more from childless employees to accommodate employees with children? Should men be encouraged to be more active co-parents so it’s not so challenging for women to remain in the work force?

headline: A Scandal in Bohemia
abstract: Bribes and the misuse of power? For Czechs, it could be worse.
lead_paragraph: PRAGUE — A MIDDLE-AGED man sits in a cafe, sipping absinthe, the newspaper before him untouched. He stares at a shapely young woman perched mysteriously on the corner of his table. Naked as Eve, she is a translucent green. A waiter hovers nearby. Painted in 1901, Viktor Oliva’s “Absinthe Drinker” hangs in the venerable Cafe Slavia, which opened in 1884 and was a redoubt of dissident artists, from Vaclav Havel to Jiri Kolar, during the Communist era. Its temptress seems a fitting muse for a city where the absurdities of the public realm have often encouraged a retreat into the alcoholic and the erotic.

headline: A Nice First Half, but the Pirates Know They Can Do Better

The Pirates traded outfielder Nate McLouth, an All-Star the previous summer, and were roundly criticized. They had earned the doubts.

headline: What Does It Take to Stop Crips and Bloods From Killing Each Other?
abstract: A plan for peace in gangland.
lead_paragraph: I first met Cynthia Mendenhall two hours before the funeral of her nephew, Frank Evans Jr. We were seated in the booth of a Denny’s on the edge of Watts, eight miles south of downtown Los Angeles. I expressed my condolences. She received them with a nod. Her sister-in-law, she said, was taking it hard. In fact, she nearly refused to come to the funeral. Even though it had been almost two weeks since Frank was shot, she still couldn’t accept that he was dead.

headline: Income, Race and Voting
abstract: Not all whites are the same.
lead_paragraph: Still thinking about the new GOP idea — hey, let’s go for white voters! Why didn’t we think of that before? And I thought I’d do a cleaner version of some stuff I did a while back. I’m venturing into political science territory here,and would be happy to have real experts weigh in; but I’m pretty sure I have the basics right here.

headline: A Passion Born in Stolen Glimpses
abstract: A childhood love for television propelled a reporter on the road to a critic’s job.
lead_paragraph: I once met a gallery owner who told me that he fell in love with art by watching “I Dream of Jeannie.” This refined man grew up in a sterile suburb in the Southwest and was raised entirely on sitcoms. He recalled the jolt of pleasure he felt when the show took viewers inside Jeannie’s bottle, to a sumptuous décor that — as he remembered it — included a Chinese vase next to an oil painting.

headline: Wrong About Tamarrod?
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Constitutions', 'Fasting', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Ramadan']
abstract: The leaders of the Egyptian grassroots movement are good at revolution, but now they must negotiate with the generals.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — After 10 action-packed days of regime toppling and bloody clashes, Cairo is hunkering down for Ramadan, the month of fasting when Muslims forgo food, drink and tobacco from dawn to dusk. Traffic is thin in my downtown neighborhood but I can hear televisions blaring the latest developments. People are talking about Egypt’s new interim government, amid a general feeling that, at least today, the first day of Ramadan, everyone can relax.

headline: Frequent Flier Changes, for Better or Worse
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Frequent Flier Programs', 'Customer Loyalty Programs', 'Customer Relations']
abstract: A number of recent changes to airline loyalty programs could affect your costs and benefits. Here’s how.
lead_paragraph: Change is in the air: Over the last few weeks a number of United States airlines — American, Delta, JetBlue, United — have announced new programs or modifications to existing programs that will have an impact on their frequent fliers. Some changes could be for the better (earning miles on partner airlines, converting hotel stays into airline miles, access to more lounges); others, not so much (higher award ticket fees, minimum annual spending requirements, disappearing bonuses). If you’re a member of an airline loyalty program, here’s what you need to know.

headline: We’re Having a Pink Wave
abstract: Everywhere you look, pink is this summer’s standout color.
lead_paragraph: Is pink the official color of summer? Tables at street cafes are peppered with glasses of blush-colored rosé (is it more popular than ever?), cheeks are flushed from the heat (and maybe the wine), and at the European fashion shows just ended, a slew of stylish showgoers worked pink shades into their looks. At the men’s shows, the blogger Linda Tol wore a raw-edged pink maxidress with a matching camera case, no less; and the model Jamie Bochert wore a grungy pink Saint Laurent cardigan to the SL show. At couture, the stylist Natalia Alaverdian was quirky in her boxy pink jacket and dangling earrings; Jennifer Lawrence was daring in a cropped pink lace top from the Dior resort collection; and Natalia Vodianova was terribly correct in pink Chanel. And doesn’t the pale pink bag carried by Leighton Meester, in Los Angeles for a premiere, look fresh? As these pack leaders prove, a little pink, styled in nuanced ways, is just the right amount of sweet.

headline: A Travel Boom in Myanmar

headline: Why Italy Could Be Fertile Ground for Deal Makers
abstract: Italy’s shaky state should not be an insurmountable obstacle to foreign investment, the author writes. Foreign deal makers just need to find ways to coax Italy’s aging entrepreneur-owners to the table.
lead_paragraph: Overseas buyers should look again at Italy. It is hardly surprising that deal-making is slow east of the Alps. But Italian firms excel in fields from fashion to engineering. The country’s parlous state is not an insurmountable obstacle to foreign investment. Foreigners just need to find ways to coax Italy’s aging entrepreneur-owners to the table.

headline: A Pop-Up Shop in Honor of Bastille Day
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Lingerie and Underwear', 'Pop-Up Stores and Restaurants']
abstract: Shopping to celebrate the French national day.
lead_paragraph: Fleur du Mal, the lingerie and ready-to-wear label from Jennifer Zuccarini, a founder of Kiki de Montparnasse, is going all out to celebrate Bastille Day. For two weeks, starting July 10, the company will honor the French national day with a pop-up shop inside Clic Gallery in SoHo. Among the treats you’ll find there are these flirty lace bits (bra, $148; high-waist panties; $138, and bodysuit, $295); chic striped knit underpinnings, $120 to $145; and a ruffled white lace jumpsuit, $1,250 — not to mention custom tulle panties embroidered with Eiffel Towers and phrases like “plat du jour” by LQQK Studio in Brooklyn. There is also jewelry from the Parisian designer Yazbukey and vintage goods, including Jane Birkin records and French photography magazines. Francophiles and lingerie nuts: this one is for you. Check the Web site, fleurdumal.com, for news of special events at the pop-up.

headline: Etnia Barcelona Gives its Aviator Sunglasses Flight Numbers

lead_paragraph: The Paris-Tokyo line of sunglasses from the creative young Spanish label Etnia Barcelona comes in cool color combos, each style named for the flight number of an airline the serves the Paris-Tokyo route. The JL406, for a Japan Airlines flight (above), is a Wayfarer shape with rocker appeal. Another, the rounded AF280, for Air France, is a 1960s shape, inspired by Yoko Ono. The glasses have acetate frames and photochromic lenses that darken in sunlight. And with the contrast colors on the brow line, they’re a fun midsummer pick-me-up.

headline: Nets Are Optimistic and Expensive
abstract: Close to finalizing the trade for Paul Pierce and Kevin Garnett, Nets General Manager Billy King likes his team’s prospects but has little cap room left.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — The names slipped out before Billy King could catch himself. “Kevin,” he said in passing. “Paul,” he said in his next breath. All he could do was smile a wry smile and move on.

headline: In Clinton Hill, a High Tolerance for Hammering
abstract: Brett Masterson and Amaranta Medina-Seabright were in the market for a fixer-upper.
lead_paragraph: Five years ago, with the help of his parents, Brett Masterson bought a fixer-upper in Roxbury, Mass. The price was in the high $300,000s.

headline: Pilots Delayed Evacuation to Talk to Tower, Official Says
abstract: After the Asiana Boeing 777 crash, investigators are examining a dangerous practice in which the cockpit crew adjusts the plane’s position or controls while close to the ground.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When the battered Asiana Boeing 777 skidded to a stop after its crash-landing here on Saturday, two flight attendants went to the cockpit to ask the three pilots inside what to do, and the pilots told them to delay evacuating the airplane while they communicated with the tower, the chairwoman of the National Transportation Safety Board said on Wednesday.

headline: De Blasio Arrested, Just as He Wanted
abstract: Anthony D. Weiner and John C. Liu stood aside as Bill de Blasio and others were handcuffed at a demonstration against a hospital’s possible closing.
lead_paragraph: Bill de Blasio, a candidate for mayor, was slapped into plastic cuffs on Wednesday and driven off in a white police van from outside the Midtown Manhattan offices of the State University of New York chancellor, where Mr. de Blasio led a demonstration against the possible closing of Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn.

headline: J. Cole Reaches No.1, Finally
abstract: His album has held up better than Kanye West’s “Yeezus,” reaching the top of the chart with sales of 58,000 copies.
lead_paragraph: These days, if an album makes it to No. 1, it usually does so right out of the gate. When one reaches the top after having started lower down the chart, it is often because the album has held strong against its competition, or because sales have sunk all around. In the case of J. Cole’s “Born Sinner” (Roc Nation/Columbia), both scenarios apply.

headline: Public Opinion Shifts on Security-Liberty Balance
abstract: A new Quinnipiac poll has found a significant shift in public opinion on the trade-off between civil liberties and national security.
lead_paragraph: A new Quinnipiac poll has found a significant shift in public opinion on the trade-off between civil liberties and national security. In the new survey, released on Wednesday, 45 percent of the public said they thought the government’s antiterrorism policies have “gone too far in restricting the average person’s civil liberties” — as compared with 40 percent who said they have “not gone far enough to adequately protect the country.”

headline: What Is Bank Capital, Anyway?

abstract: Though capital is a centerpiece of Wall Street regulation, it resists a simple definition.
lead_paragraph: Regulators are butting heads with banks this week over capital, with new rules on the table that could force banks to hold more of it. But what exactly is capital, and why is it so important?

headline: Working Parents, Wanting Fewer Hours
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Men and Boys', 'Parenting', 'Part-Time Employment', 'Women and Girls', 'Work-Life Balance', 'Working Hours']
abstract: Why an article focused on the work-family balance challenges for working mothers, and what working fathers face as well.
lead_paragraph: On Monday I wrote an article (the first in a series about work-life balance) profiling a middle-class working mother who persuaded her employer to give her a more flexible schedule. I’ve gotten a lot of questions about why the article focused on mothers and not fathers.

abstract: Four hundred young immigrants held their own version of a citizenship ceremony, as part of a campaign to push legislation through the House that would offer citizenship to millions of undocumented immigrants.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON – Four hundred young immigrants gathered near the Capitol on Wednesday to hold their own version of a citizenship ceremony, kicking off a nationwide campaign to push legislation through the House of Representatives that would offer eventual citizenship to millions of undocumented immigrants.

abstract: John Eccles’s one-act Baroque “Judgment of Paris” was the centerpiece at the Washington Square Music Festival.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes losing is temporary. In 1955, Judy Garland may have had the Best Actress Oscar stolen from her by Grace Kelly for “The Country Girl,” but Garland’s performance, in “A Star is Born,” is the one that has endured.

headline: Artful Defense at 6th European Open in Belgium
abstract: Zia Mahmood was the third United States medal winner at the European Open Championships.
lead_paragraph: Zia Mahmood was the third United States medal winner at the 6th European Open Championships in Ostend, Belgium, last month. He finished second in the open pairs with Jan Jansma from the Netherlands. (The two United States winners were Janice Seamon-Molson in the women’s pairs with Catherine d’Ovidio from France, and Roy Welland in the open pairs with Sabine Auken from Germany.)

headline: What’s Wrong With a 20-Week Abortion Ban?
abstract: Why new restrictions on abortion aren’t just “common sense” safety measures.
lead_paragraph: The Texas House today passed the abortion restriction bill that State Senator Wendy Davis derailed last month.

headline: S.E.C. Lifts Advertising Ban on Private Investments
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Hedge Funds', 'Private Equity', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Start-ups']
abstract: The new rule will fundamentally change the way that hedge funds, buyout firms and start-up companies raise money in the private marketplace.
lead_paragraph: Federal regulators on Wednesday lifted an 80-year-old ban on advertising by hedge funds, buyout firms and start-up companies seeking capital, a move that will fundamentally change the way that many issuers raise money in the private marketplace.

headline: Romantic Blades of Grass Get a Toe Touch of Baroque at River to River
abstract: The latest installment of Wally Cardona and Jennifer Lacey’s “Set Up,” at South Street Seaport as part of the River to River Festival, was inspired by French Baroque dance.
lead_paragraph: The setup of “The Set Up,” an eight-part project by the choreographers Wally Cardona and Jennifer Lacey, involves their consulting with dance artists considered to be masters of a particular form. Much as these exchanges pull the choreographers into foreign territory — Okinawan folk dance, Cambodian classical dance — the works that result pull the forms out of their cultural context.

lead_paragraph: Riders seek fashionable shoes to go with New York City’s bike-sharing program.

headline: Intrigue Behind Bars: More ‘Gossip Girl’ Than ‘Oz’
abstract: “Orange Is the New Black,” a new dramedy series, centers on a well-educated young woman who is sent to prison for a drug crime committed long ago.
lead_paragraph: First with “Weeds” and now with “Orange Is the New Black,” the television writer and producer Jenji Kohan has proved herself the master of an odd but successful narrative ploy: putting well-behaved middle-class white women in the middle of stories that typically feature rough nonwhite men.

headline: iExit: No Directions, but Much Guidance
abstract: iExit, an app that works with a car’s GPS, doesn’t give directions, but does give drivers a comprehensive list of services at exits up ahead.
lead_paragraph: You may be familiar with the two-screen experience through TV, where viewers are encouraged to use a computer, phone or tablet during a show to see video extras.

headline: New York Gun Rights Group Plans Freedompalooza
abstract: The organizers of the concert, set for late August outside Albany, hope to find support and money among country music fans.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Hoping to find support and money among country music fans, a group of gun rights supporters and other grass-roots organizations in New York have announced a new addition to the summer festival circuit: Freedompalooza.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Instagrams From the T.S.A., and Facebook Father
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Wednesday’s selections include photos taken by the Transportation Security Administration when employees met people who just couldn’t stand to fly unarmed, and a Facebook executive’s report on his four-month paternity leave.
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: The Nerd Is Rich Yet Still at a Loss
abstract: In Gabriel Roth’s “Unknowns,” the narrator knows more about writing code than he does about women.
lead_paragraph: If only all social misfits were as stealthily charming as Eric Muller, the nerdy narrator of Gabriel Roth’s sparkling debut novel. If Eric means to make himself sound unappealing to the reader, he fails miserably in his mission. Who could resist the kind of tech-oriented guy who calculates his exact reasons for arriving at a party at 10:32 p.m., because at that relatively early stage “it’s possible to imagine that this party will live up to the promise inherent in the notion of a party”? Or who would notice, a little later, that “the population has increased, but not to the Malthusian degree it would take to make the party memorable”?

headline: Bombing Kills Top Security Aide to Pakistan President
abstract: President Asif Ali Zardari’s Pakistan Peoples Party portrayed the attack in Karachi  as a warning to the president.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — President Asif Ali Zardari’s chief security officer was killed in a bombing in the port city of Karachi on Wednesday, raising concerns about the vulnerability of even senior officials to attack by militants.

headline: Ciara, Not Quite at the Center of Her Newest Album
abstract: The R&B singer lets her voice blend with effects and with other singers on her new self-titled album, her fifth.
lead_paragraph: Ciara sings as if singing were dancing. She stretches syllables out into long arcs. She accelerates and then decelerates. She’s almost never staccato, moving fluidly from one word into the next and then through.

headline: Former South Korean Spy Chief Charged With Bribery
abstract: Won Sei-hoon, who served as director of the National Intelligence Service, is the latest in a series of former spy chiefs who have faced criminal indictments after leaving office.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — A former national intelligence chief of South Korea was arrested on bribery charges on Wednesday, further tarnishing the image of the country’s spy agency, which has already been accused of meddling in the presidential election in December.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Bosnia and Herzegovina and Elsewhere

lead_paragraph: Photos from Bosnia and Herzegovina, China, Indonesia and Spain.

headline: AIDS in New York: Being Alive Was Beyond Belief for Some
abstract: Florent Morellet, an AIDS survivor, remembers the crisis and marvels at the way life went on.
lead_paragraph: As he entered the second-floor gallery at the New-York Historical Society on a hot summer afternoon, Florent Morellet paused, closely studying the timeline that started the museum’s current exhibition, “AIDS in New York: The First Five Years.” As he stood there, dressed boyishly in shorts and Converse sneakers, Mr. Morellet silently ticked off such time-defining moments as the initial meeting of the Gay Men’s Health Crisis in 1982 and the Food and Drug Administration’s approval of an antibody test to detect H.I.V. in 1985.

headline: At Sentencing, Victim Describes Rape and Its Aftermath
abstract: Lawrence Elliot, 50, received 13 years to life for attacking a City College student in 2010 in the Hamilton Heights section of Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: As the hulking stranger held her down by the throat and sexually assaulted her, the young woman stopped thinking about being rescued, about breaking free, or even about surviving.

headline: Bicycle Helmets as Fashion Statements
abstract: As more riders take to the streets, bicycle helmets gain their own level of fashion.
lead_paragraph: Unlike motorcycle helmets, bicycle helmets have historically had zero cool factor on city streets.

headline: Cameron Russell, a Model, Puts Looks Aside
abstract: Ms. Russell, as a founder of the webzine Interrupt, is trying to share the limelight with “some women who really are doing fantastic things.”
lead_paragraph: Cameron Russell, like most fashion models, knows how to pose for the camera, a skill she demonstrated on a recent Friday at the Brooklyn studio of her media consulting company.

headline: The Immigration Battle Explained
abstract: With Congress back in session and expected to address immigration, the question is whether members of the House will take up the Senate’s bill, or go their own way.
lead_paragraph: With Congress back in session and expected to address immigration, the question is whether members of the House will take up the Senate’s bill, or go their own way.

headline: Wait, Mermaids Live How Long?
abstract: And why did the Little Mermaid get hitched at age 15?
lead_paragraph: “We all hate that it’s her 15th birthday. . . . It’s like, who gets married at 15? Why can’t she be at least 18 or 20? None of us are 15 anymore.”

headline: A Guide to Personal Weather Stations
abstract: Backyard weather stations have become more sophisticated, yet easier to set up and use.
lead_paragraph: Have you ever checked the local weather report and been told it was sunny out when rain was pelting your window? There’s a reason for that: weather updates depend on the location of the monitoring equipment, often at airports, where conditions can be quite different from where you are.

lead_paragraph: On a recent afternoon, Jocelyn Steiber zipped across Prince Street on a bright blue Citi Bike: blond hair loose, floral print Ella Moss sundress parachuting like Marilyn Monroe.
