lead_paragraph: As more pedestrians take to the pedals, it was perhaps inevitable that the helmet evolve from hair-flattening safety necessity to accessory.

headline: ‘Suitable Boy’ Author Renegotiating $1.7 Million Contract After Unsuitable Delay

lead_paragraph: Vikram Seth, the author of the 1,300-plus page doorstop of a novel “A Suitable Boy,” is in negotiations with his London publisher over his failure to deliver the manuscript of a sequel on time for release this fall.

abstract: The “Hippie Chic” exhibition, opening next week at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, features the hippie culture as fashion designers saw it.
lead_paragraph: FINALLY, AN ANSWER to one of fashion’s most puzzling riddles may be within reach: Who was more stylish, punks or hippies?

headline: Tip of the Week: Test-Drive Android Apps Online
abstract: Amazon’s store for Android apps has a Test Drive feature that lets you see an app in action before you buy or download it.
lead_paragraph: Want to preview a mobile app on your Amazon Kindle Fire or other Android device before you install the software? Thousands of programs in the Amazon Appstore for Android include a Test Drive feature that lets you fire up a version the app in your browser window to try before you buy.

headline: 8 Strings, More Hands
abstract: Paola Prestini organizes another collaborative work, as “The Violin” is performed at Federal Hall with multimedia components.
lead_paragraph: Paola Prestini is probably best known as a composer, but her business card might more accurately read “human resources alchemist,” such is her gift for bringing together disparate artists, technicians and other creative professionals to produce cross-disciplinary works greater than the sum of their parts. As the guiding force of VisionIntoArt, a collective she helped to found in 1999, she has facilitated flamboyant, confounding and enticing collaborations among choreographers, visual artists, actors and composers, including her own well-traveled “Oceanic Verses.”

headline: Federal Reserve’s Easing of Stimulus Could Hamper a European Recovery
keywords: ['Government Bonds', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Interest Rates', 'Credit and Debt']
abstract: Signals by the Federal Reserve have prompted investors to drive up interest rates around the world, putting business loans further out of reach.
lead_paragraph: VLOTHO, Germany — The European economy has many problems. One is out of the region’s control: the United States Federal Reserve.

headline: State Regulations for Abortion Clinics
abstract: Apart from limiting the timing of abortions, many states are imposing new regulations on abortion facilities and doctors. Proponents of the laws say the rules will make abortions safer. But clinic directors and professional societies say that many of the laws have no medical value and are intended to raise costs or force clinics to close.
lead_paragraph: Apart from limiting the timing of abortions, many states are imposing new regulations on abortion facilities and doctors. lead_paragraph: Sweat and sunblock have us looking for supercharged facial cleansers. Below, four new choices.

headline: All Lenses Turn to Sweden
abstract: Princess Madeleine of Sweden, 30 and newly married, attended the Valentino couture show in Paris.
lead_paragraph: Forget Kate. Now that the Duchess of Cambridge is about to enter the largely private state of doting motherhood (the word out of London is that the birth of her and Prince William’s first child is expected this weekend), the royals-obsessed European press needs someone else to focus on.

headline: Apps for Digital Note-Taking
abstract: Popular choices for writing on tablets include Noteshelf and Papyrus Natural Note Taking.
lead_paragraph: Years before Steve Jobs introduced the iPad to the world, tablet computers made regular appearances in science fiction shows. Fans of “Star Trek” will remember ensigns tapping on digital tablets or asking an officer to scribble a signature on one. Lots of those fictional machines had one thing in common: they worked with some sort of stylus and were digital equivalents of a traditional notepad.

headline: Attaboy on the Lower East Side
abstract: Milk & Honey closed on New Year’s Eve 2012, but two longstanding bartenders from Milk & Honey rechristened the bar as Attaboy.
lead_paragraph: When Milk & Honey closed on New Year’s Eve 2012, disciples of the neo-speakeasy were left without a place of worship. No longer. In March, two longstanding bartenders from Milk & Honey — Sam Ross and Michael McIlroy (tending bar above) — rechristened the bar as Attaboy.

headline: Not Going Gentle Into That Good Night
abstract: Susanne Bartsch, the Swiss Miss of New York night life since the Koch era, presides over four parties every week as part of a late-career flowering.
lead_paragraph: Susanne Bartsch frowned into a ceiling-high mirror, lifting her left breast with her palm. “This one looks droopy,” she said, in her Swiss-German accent. She turned and examined her svelte profile, adding proudly, “They’re only a year old.”

headline: Theatrics and Acrobatics Commingle
abstract: Pilobolus, the dance company founded in the early ’70s, opened its summer season at the Joyce Theater with works ranging from 1972 to this year.
lead_paragraph: Pilobolus, long a popular institution, is now 42. The publicity for the company’s current New York season says it wouldn’t be summer without Pilobolus at the Joyce Theater. Sure enough, on Tuesday’s opening night the Joyce audience stood to cheer through the curtain calls. At this rate, who knows? Pilobolus may be with us for another 42 years. This is an amazement to those of us who loved the first generation of Pilobolus in the 1970s. It was popular then, too. But it didn’t feel like an enduring institution. It was its own species, and seemed set to be fabulously ephemeral.

headline: Yankees’ Cutoff Man in the Booth
abstract: In this fictional sequence, John Sterling and Suzyn Waldman, the Yankees’ radio broadcasters, are something sort of grandish.
lead_paragraph: In which the Yankees radio personality Suzyn Waldman again finds herself trapped in a Fenway Park broadcasting booth with the announcer John Sterling, Broadway musical fan and proud creator of distinctive home run calls.

headline: Young, Ecstatic and on the Cusp
abstract: The first national youth orchestra in the United States, whose players are 16 to 19, rehearsed this week with the conductor Valery Gergiev.
lead_paragraph: PURCHASE, N.Y. — Many countries have excellent national youth orchestras. The most famous in recent years, the Simón Bolívar Youth Orchestra of Venezuela, graduated to become the full-fledged, internationally known Simón Bolívar Symphony Orchestra.

lead_paragraph: Mary Going, 46, a former nonprofit consultant in Oakland, Calif., wanted to wear a suit to her same-sex wedding in 2008, but found the shopping process demoralizing.

headline: He’s Acting Out; It’s on Purpose
abstract: Listening to “Beach House 2,” a new mixtape from Ty Dolla Sign.
lead_paragraph: It’s inevitable that we’ll have to get to a definition of “ratchet,” so let’s dispense with it quickly. To act ratchet is to act foolish, or trashy, to behave in a way that makes others shield their eyes. It is the opposite of decorous. There are plenty of places one can act ratchet — in the club, in the bedroom — but it’s always about behavior that’s dubious at best, that makes people point fingers in slack-jawed astonishment and discomfort.

headline: Manipulating Perverse Love
abstract: The Complicite production of “Shun-kin” uses puppetry, traditional performance, music and design to convey coolly a steamy Japanese tale at the Lincoln Center Festival.
lead_paragraph: A distant world of ceremony, secrets and furtive sexual desire is conjured with shadow-strewn grace in “Shun-kin,” the latest production from Complicite and the director Simon McBurney. An adaptation of a 1933 short story by Junichiro Tanizaki, the production blends puppetry, traditional performance, music and design with the combination of daring and delicacy that Complicite has become known for in its previous visits to the Lincoln Center Festival.

headline: Antiquity Exhibit at Cleveland Museum Is Canceled
abstract: The Cleveland Museum of Art will not host an exhibition of ancient treasures from Sicily this September, as had originally been planned.
lead_paragraph: A traveling exhibition of ancient treasures from Sicily that was scheduled to open at the Cleveland Museum of Art in September was canceled on Wednesday after officials from the Italian island complained that the art loan was hurting its economy, The Plain Dealer in Cleveland, Ohio, reported.

headline: New York Public Library Is Sued Over Book Plan
abstract: A group of writers and scholars filed a lawsuit Wednesday to stop the New York Public Library from demolishing the stacks in its flagship 42nd Street building or moving books off-site.
lead_paragraph: A group of prominent writers and scholars filed a lawsuit on Wednesday to stop the New York Public Library from demolishing the stacks in its flagship 42nd Street building or moving any books off the site. The complaint, filed in New York State Supreme Court, formalizes concerns about the Central Library Plan, which would replace the stacks with a circulating library and is expected to cost at least $300 million.

lead_paragraph: Mothers who report symptoms of depression are more likely to display obesity-promoting practices and have children who are overweight or obese than mothers who say they are not depressed, according to a new study.

headline: Making Art, Sneaking Bacon
abstract: A conversation with Klaus Biesenbach, the director of MoMA PS1, about the Colony, a temporary art camp set up in its courtyard.
lead_paragraph: It was raining lightly on the Colony the other day. That’s the name of the temporary art camp set up in the courtyard of MoMA PS1 in Long Island City, Queens. The campers stayed dry, thanks to the silvery sunscreen curtains donated by a French company that hung atmospherically over the makeshift campsite put together by a77, an Argentine architectural firm. There were trailers and tents, a solar shower, a hydroponic garden and a kitchen presided over by Anne Apparu, a chef and food-performance artist originally from Corsica. She is a former roommate of Jenny Schlenzka, an associate curator at PS1 and one of the organizers of “Expo 1: New York,” an extended art happening exploring the planet’s environmental challenges.

headline: Lenovo Is Top Supplier as Global PC Sales Fall
abstract: Two cheers for Lenovo. The Chinese personal computer maker has taken global leadership of PC sales from Hewlett-Packard. The market is saturated in many areas, analysts say, and personal computers last longer than before, so replacement cycles are slowing.
lead_paragraph: Move over, Hewlett-Packard. You’ve just lost pride of place in an increasingly dubious tech category.

headline: Curves Ahead, Alpaca Crossing
abstract: A furniture collection by Jiun Ho upholstered in the alpaca textiles of Sandra Jordan.
lead_paragraph: When the San Francisco-based interior designer Jiun Ho met Sandra Jordan at a design event in 2008, kindred spirits collided. The Malaysian-born Mr. Ho makes minimalist furniture inspired by his global travels. Ms. Jordan, the Peruvian-born daughter of a diplomat, heads a company that distributes luxury alpaca textiles. The result is the Jiun Ho IV Collection, 13 pieces inspired by the designer’s journeys in South America and upholstered in Ms. Jordan’s fabrics.

headline: Connect the Blocks
abstract: The QuaDror system of blocks is devilishly difficult to explain but easy to play with.
lead_paragraph: R. Buckminster Fuller coined the term “tensegrity,” for “tensional integrity,” a construction principle that led to a popular toy. Similarly, Dror Benshetrit, the designer of the Peacock chair from Cappellini, came up with a new truss that doubles as a diversion: four pieces of any material (like wood, metal or plastic) and four connectors of any kind (like screws, pegs or glue) that fold flat but open up to create four triangles. The QuaDror system of blocks is devilishly difficult to explain but easy to use; so easy, that prototypes disappeared. Thus was born a toy. Donald Rattner, the owner of the Module R art and design shop in Brooklyn, was strolling the International Gift Fair in New York in January and found the QuaDror blocks. The set ($36) consists of 10 trusses that can be assembled into anything in a child’s (or adult’s) imagination. Module R is at 141 Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn. Information: (877) 360-3660 or module-r.com.

headline: The Shark Sonic Duo Restores Tired Rugs and Floors. No, Really.
keywords: ['Home Repairs and Improvements', 'Carpets and Rugs', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Home Appliances', 'Vacuum Cleaners']
abstract: This carpet-and-floor cleaner is put to the test and lives up to the hype.
lead_paragraph: A couple of red flags made me wary of the Shark Sonic Duo ($249.99), a machine that cleans carpets and hard floors. First were the self-important capitalized references on its Web site to “Sonic Trap and Remove Technology” and “Airglide Maneuverability.” Then there were the ominous words “As Seen on TV.”

headline: ‘1950s: Building the American Dream’ at the Ohio History Center
abstract: Celebrating the fab in prefab, ’50s style.
lead_paragraph: For a prefab dwelling made of porcelain-enamel steel and sold to Americans after World War II as a cheap housing solution, the Lustron has become quite celebrated. In 2008, a Lustron home was erected inside the Museum of Modern Art for a show on factory-produced architecture. Now, the same home is the star attraction of “1950s: Building the American Dream,” an exhibition at the Ohio History Center in Columbus.

headline: The SoHo Digs of the Restaurateur Luke Ostrom
abstract: When he’s not busy opening lower Manhattan hot spots (Lafayette, The Dutch, Locanda Verde), Luke Ostrom enjoys cooking in his spare, stylish Greene Street bachelor pad.
lead_paragraph: In his restaurants and at home, Luke Ostrom exudes a style that is both practical and chic. The New York chef-turned-restaurateur (Locanda Verde, the Dutch and the just-opened Lafayette) Ostrom, 35, lives simply. “I love focused, clean design,” he said, “but more than anything, I like a utilitarian connection to what I collect, whether it’s vintage, industrial or modern.”

headline: Quick Route From Juilliard to Jail
abstract: Danielle Brooks, 23 and fresh from Juilliard, plays the imprisoned Taystee Jefferson on the new Netflix series “Orange Is the New Black.”
lead_paragraph: Growing up in South Carolina, the daughter of a minister and a deacon, Danielle Brooks never planned on a stint in federal prison. In middle school, she visited a juvenile justice complex. “They gave us a tour of the jail,” Ms. Brooks recalled. “The handcuffs, the walking in a straight line, the smell. I was like: This is totally not a place for me.”

headline: China and Russia, in a Display of Unity, Hold Naval Exercises
keywords: ['International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Ships and Shipping']

lead_paragraph: BEIJING — An armada of Chinese and Russian warships sailed in ceremonial formation in the Sea of Japan, off the port of Vladivostok, on Wednesday in what was the high point of joint naval exercises intended to show the growing unity between two countries with a historically uneasy relationship.

headline: Egyptian Journalist Was Killed by Army Sniper He Filmed, Family Says
abstract: The family of a photographer for an Islamist newspaper who was killed on Monday, moments after recording an image of a sniper aiming a rifle at him, told The Lede that legal action is planned against the soldier.
lead_paragraph: As The Lede reported on Monday, one of the most widely viewed images of the clashes in Cairo that morning, which left more than 50 dead, was a harrowing snippet of video that appeared to show an army sniper firing down at Islamist protesters from a rooftop, before turning his gun to take aim at the camera.

headline: Japanese Nuclear Plant May Have Been Leaking for Two Years
keywords: ['Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant (Japan)', 'Japan Earthquake and Tsunami (2011)', 'Water Pollution', 'Oceans and Seas', 'Nuclear Energy']
abstract: The finding brings into sharp relief the precariousness of the cleanup at the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant, where three of the six reactors suffered core meltdowns.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — The stricken nuclear power plant at Fukushima has probably been leaking contaminated water into the ocean for two years, ever since an earthquake and tsunami badly damaged the plant, Japan’s chief nuclear regulator said on Wednesday.

headline: Greek Yogurt, by the Tangy Tub or Bucket
abstract: Twenty-seven years ago, Fotini Kessissoglou, a Greek immigrant, had trouble finding yogurt like the kind she had back home. So she started making her own, opening Kesso Foods in 1986.
lead_paragraph: When Fotini Kessissoglou opened Kesso Foods, a pint-size Greek yogurt factory and shop in East Elmhurst, Queens, in 1986, she had no way of knowing that her country’s ultrathick, strained staple would someday become an American obsession.

headline: Study Finds Benefits in Delaying Severing of Umbilical Cord
abstract: An analysis found that delaying clamping for at least a minute after birth significantly improves iron stores and hemoglobin levels in newborn babies.
lead_paragraph: In most hospital delivery rooms, doctors routinely clamp and sever the umbilical cord less than a minute after an infant’s birth, a practice thought to reduce the risk of maternal hemorrhaging.

headline: In Managing Harvey’s Innings, the Mets Make an All-Star Allowance
abstract: Before the Mets beat the Giants behind a strong start from Zack Wheeler, Manager Terry Collins discussed the decision to rest Matt Harvey before the All-Star break.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Ensuring a young pitcher’s vitality remains an inexact science. When the Mets decided this week that Matt Harvey, their best pitcher, would not make his final scheduled start before the All-Star break, the move seemed to raise as many questions as it answered. Organizational impulses seemed placed at odds.

headline: Tightening Siege by Syrian Rebels Stirs Anger

abstract: Syrian rebels tighten a siege on government-held areas of Aleppo to get civilians to go elsewhere, but it seems to be undermining support for their cause.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syrian rebels have tightened their siege on government-held districts in the divided city of Aleppo, choking supply lines and depleting staple foods at the onset of the Muslim holy month of Ramadan, traditionally a time of festive meals to break the daily fast.

headline: Some Trees Use Less Water Amid Rising Carbon Dioxide, Paper Says

lead_paragraph: The fate of the world’s forests on a warming planet has long been one of the great unanswered questions about climate change. Now, new research is complicating the picture further, suggesting that big shifts are already under way in how forests work.

lead_paragraph: WHILE not generally appreciated by bankers or crossing guards, impulsiveness is highly valued by marketers, who encourage spur-of-the-moment purchases. And separate stunts this week by Heineken and Hilton Worldwide are rewarding consumers for spontaneity with far-flung trips — but only if they depart with little or no forethought.

headline: Taliban Spokesman Is Ousted for ‘Creating Mistrust’

headline: Deaths Climb From Disaster in Quebec
abstract: The police reported that the remains of 20 people had been found.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — The death toll in the fiery derailment of a train in a Quebec town over the weekend rose Wednesday, with the police reporting that the remains of 20 people had been found. The police also said that 30 more people were still missing, and it is widely assumed that they are dead.

headline: Hopes Rise for Appeal of Ex-Marine Held in Iran

abstract: Improvements in prison life for Amir Hekmati, incarcerated for nearly two years on spying accusations, strengthened his family’s hope that Iran’s judiciary would favorably review an appeal for his release.
lead_paragraph: Prison life has markedly improved in recent weeks for Amir Hekmati, the former Marine incarcerated for nearly two years in Iran on spying accusations. His sister said he was now allowed weekly visits from three Iranian relatives, books, daily exercise and a regular correspondence of letters with family in the United States.

headline: Serving Two Life Terms, Mob Boss Who Became Informer Wins Release

lead_paragraph: When Joseph C. Massino took the witness stand in 2011, becoming the first official boss of one of New York’s five crime families to break the code of silence and testify against a former confederate, he offered a succinct explanation for his departure from mob tradition.

headline: My Life, Post Exposure
abstract: If the drugs worked, I would never know if I might have been infected with H.I.V. or not.
lead_paragraph: I grew up in a Modern Orthodox Jewish family in New Jersey, where my “sex talk,” at 13, came in the form of my mother handing me a book of anatomical comics. Inside it, she placed post-it notes to indicate her feelings. In the masturbation section: “God does not approve of this.” In the gay sex section: “Definitely not.”

headline: Hunger Strike by California Inmates, Already Large, Is Expected to Be Long
abstract: A hunger strike over solitary confinement and other conditions that continued for a third day Wednesday could become the largest in state history.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Nearly 29,000 inmates in California state prisons refused meals for the third day Wednesday during a protest of prison conditions and rules. The protest extended to two-thirds of the 33 prisons across the state and all 4 private out-of-state facilities where California sends inmates, corrections officials said.

headline: Israel Reopens Inquiry Into Activist’s Injury
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The Israeli police on Wednesday agreed to re-investigate the 2009 injury of an American activist during a clash between Israeli security forces and protesters.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli police on Wednesday agreed to re-investigate the 2009 injury of an American activist during a clash between Israeli security forces and protesters against the extension of Israel’s separation barrier in the West Bank. The activist, Tristan Anderson of Oakland, Calif., then 38, was hit in the head by a tear-gas canister in the village of Nilin, and remains partly paralyzed and blind in one eye. Yesh Din, an Israeli human rights organization, appealed to Israel’s High Court of Justice after the police closed the investigation without indicting any of the soldiers involved, and the court’s justices urged the police to reopen the case.

headline: North Korea Repeats Call for Talks
abstract: A senior North Korean diplomat said Wednesday that his country was willing to have “any kind of talks” to ease tensions on the Korean Peninsula.
lead_paragraph: A senior North Korean diplomat said Wednesday that his country was willing to have “any kind of talks” to ease tensions on the Korean Peninsula, while at the same time repeating its call for the United States to dismantle its military command in South Korea. In the second news conference on the subject staged by the North’s senior diplomats in less than three weeks, So Se-pyong, North Korea’s ambassador to the United Nations in Geneva, called for the dissolution of the United Nations military command led by the United States as a prerequisite for calming the situation on the peninsula. The alliance is called the United Nations Command, although the United Nations plays no role. If the United States made a “bold decision” on the issue, the North would also be in favor of taking confidence-building measures, Mr. So said, setting out the same case presented by North Korea’s ambassador to the United Nations in New York last month.

headline: D.C. Council Passes Wage Bill Despite Wal-Mart’s Threats
abstract: A bill would require Wal-Mart to pay a starting wage that is several dollars above the city’s minimum.
lead_paragraph: Even in urban areas where Wal-Mart has faced stiff opposition, little has slowed its expansion. But the City Council in the District of Columbia is trying to do so, as its passage of a bill that would require the world’s largest retailer to pay a starting wage that is several dollars above the city’s minimum on Wednesday showed.

headline: To Save Egypt, Drop the Presidency
abstract: Parliamentary rule would force Islamists to reach across the aisle and govern with secularists. It could have averted the current crisis.
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN — AS violence escalates, Egypt’s military is trying to bridge a widening political gap by promising a rapid return to civilian rule. But its gesture of accommodation does not get to the heart of the problem: the presidential system, inherited from the Mubarak era, virtually guarantees a repetition of the tragic events of the past year. A democratic breakthrough requires a more fundamental constitutional redesign, in which the contending sides compete for power in a European-style parliamentary system.

headline: The Cost of Compromise
keywords: ['ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'AFFIRMATIVE ACTION', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Constitution (US)', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)']
abstract: Accommodation in the pursuit of unanimity on the Supreme Court can be perilous.
lead_paragraph: In his 2011 memoir, “Five Chiefs,” the retired Supreme Court Justice John Paul Stevens offered a mildly eyebrow-raising reflection on Brown v. Board of Education. The landmark school desegregation decision is celebrated not only for its outcome but also for the unanimity that Chief Justice Earl Warren extracted from his wary colleagues. But the price of unanimity may have been too high, Justice Stevens suggested. He observed that the court’s compromise order to desegregate “with all deliberate speed,” rather than immediately, turned into a recipe for hardly any speed at all.

headline: Beyond the Courtroom
abstract: The George Zimmerman trial has started a valuable discussion about race and justice.
lead_paragraph: Whatever happens in the George Zimmerman trial, it has produced a valuable and profound dialogue in America about some important issues surrounding race and justice, fear and aggression, and legal guilt and moral culpability.

headline: Broken Promises
abstract: I believe that American Indian children are the country’s most at-risk population, and sequestration is hurting them even more.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — WHEN I retired in 2011 after serving 30 years in Congress, there was one set of issues I knew I could not leave behind. I donated $1 million of unused campaign funds to create the Center for Native American Youth at the Aspen Institute, because our country has left a trail of broken promises to American Indians.

Sexual assaults have been epidemic at the station, where about 40,000 recruits complete boot camp each year. But crimes at the station’s Training Support Center, where about 16,000 sailors receive specialized training, and where most of the assaults occur, have fallen about 60 percent over two years.

headline: Illinois: Lawmakers May Miss Payday
keywords: ['Wages and Salaries', 'State Legislatures', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans']
abstract: Gov. Pat Quinn suspended lawmakers’ paychecks on Wednesday, saying they did not deserve compensation until the state’s escalating pension crisis was solved.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Pat Quinn suspended lawmakers’ paychecks Wednesday, saying they did not deserve compensation until the state’s escalating pension crisis was solved. The move came a day after the General Assembly ignored a deadline Mr. Quinn set to pass a bill addressing the state’s $100 billion in unfunded pension liability. The governor’s line-item veto of a state budget measure withholds legislators’ $67,836 salaries, as well as additional stipends for those in leadership positions. “They must have that alarm bell ringing in their ears,” Mr. Quinn said at a news conference. “And the best way to do that is to hit them in their wallet.” Judy Baar Topinka, the Illinois comptroller, said a legal review of the decision would be completed before lawmakers were scheduled to receive their next paychecks on Aug. 1.

Dinosaurish creatures as big as skyscrapers do battle with equally gigantic robots on land and sea, pulverizing familiar cities and churning up geysers of spume. Human characters (some of whom are actually inside the giant robots) bark out catchphrases, spout fake science and express noble sentiments as they fight to save the planet. headline: Humanities and the Intellect
abstract: Any educational institution at the post-high school/university level should emphasize the importance of the humanities in terms of expanding a student’s intellect.
lead_paragraph: Regarding “Resilience of the humanities” (July 5): Scott Saul states that, “Many of our students struggle to think and write with precision, and we struggle to teach them the mechanics of good writing.” I respectfully suggest that any educational institution at the post-high school/university level in any country should emphasize the importance of the humanities in terms of expanding a student’s intellect, by reference to the study of philosophy in particular, and the application of philosophical methods to any academic discipline, be it the study of medicine or law or business, indeed any faculty that requires critical and analytical thinking and the forensic critique of information. Perhaps such an approach would be helpful to students, and also assist educators in their attempts to successfully teach students how to think and write with precision?

headline: As Labor Dispute Drags On, Minnesota Orchestra Cancels Summer Concerts
abstract: The continuing labor dispute at the Minnesota Orchestra, which had already caused the cancellation of the 2012-13 season, now claims a series of summer concerts as well.

headline: 50 Years Later, a Break in a Boston Strangler Case
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Serial Murders', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)', 'Sex Crimes']
abstract: Boston police officers said DNA found at the home of the woman thought to be the final victim of the notorious killer has been matched to Albert DeSalvo, who confessed to the crimes.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Investigators said Thursday that they had linked the man believed by many to have been the Boston Strangler to DNA found in the home of a woman thought to be the Strangler’s last victim in a string of unsolved murders that petrified this city in the early 1960s and has perplexed it ever since.

headline: Philip Caldwell, First Nonfamily Member to Head Ford, Is Dead at 93
abstract: Outsiders were stunned when Henry Ford II dismissed Lee Iacocca as president of Ford Motor in 1977 and elevated Mr. Caldwell, who was nearly unknown outside the company.
lead_paragraph: Philip Caldwell, the button-down manager chosen over Lee A. Iacocca to become the first head of the Ford Motor Company who was not a member of the Ford family, died on Wednesday at his home in New Canaan, Conn. He was 93.

headline: Video, Yes; High-Def, No
abstract: The director Andrew Bujalski and his cinematographer, Matthias Grunsky, discuss how old technology was employed to capture the 1980s ambience of “Computer Chess.”
lead_paragraph: Andrew Bujalski likes it vintage. He has been making small, talky 16-millimeter films for the past decade, even as the industry has become progressively more digital. Over the years, Mr. Bujalski was asked why he hadn’t joined much of the indie world in shooting his movies on digital video. This contrarian responded with his latest feature, “Computer Chess,” which is about as video as video gets, but not in the way his questioners may have had in mind.

headline: Layhmond Robinson Jr., Who Paved Way for Black Journalists, Dies at 88
abstract: Mr. Robinson, one of the first black reporters at The New York Times in the 1950s and a local television news correspondent, inspired the next generation of black journalists.
lead_paragraph: Layhmond Robinson Jr., one of the first black reporters at The New York Times, who later became a local television news correspondent, died on June 29 in Queens. He was 88.

headline: William Morris to Invest in Droga5, an Ad Agency

headline: Introducing the New TimesMachine
abstract: We are very pleased to offer a preview of our TimesMachine redesign. Before we completely replace the original TimesMachine, we’re hoping to get some feedback by releasing a prototype of the new experience.
lead_paragraph: We are very pleased to offer a preview of our TimesMachine redesign. Our subscribers can, for the first time, read complete issues of The New York Times in their original context. For each issue that is available in the new TimesMachine, every article, every letter and every advertisement is included in a legible, linkable and shareable fashion.

headline: Mumblecore Masters, Enunciating Clearly

lead_paragraph: When Andrew Bujalski, 24 at the time, was directing his first feature, “Funny Ha Ha,” initiating a movement in American independent film was the last thing on his mind.

abstract: Exactly a month after Greece closed the state broadcaster ERT in a cost-cutting move, a bare-bones version of the service is back on the air.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Exactly a month after Prime Minister Antonis Samaras of Greece closed the state television network  ERT in a cost-cutting move that almost brought down his fragile coalition government, a bare-bones version of the service was back on the air on Thursday.

lead_paragraph: Randy Travis was in critical condition on Thursday morning after having a stroke and undergoing emergency surgery to relieve pressure on his brain, according to officials at the Heart Hospital at Baylor in Plano, Tex., where he was being treated.

headline: Baseball Needs Its Break
abstract: It has been a vertigo-inducing baseball season so far, with the Biogenesis scandal, the rise of the Pirates, the fall of the Giants and the excitement over Yasiel Puig.
lead_paragraph: The coming All-Star break could not come at a better time for baseball. For the ruling cabal, its corporate-sponsored bacchanalia cannot come often enough, particularly with that nasty Biogenesis scandal percolating in the background and Alex Rodriguez still trying to swing a bat somewhere (in Tampa, in, ahem, rehab). But even the rest of us need a chance to stop and look around. After all, the first half has been downright disorienting.

headline: Holland’s Plan for America’s Slaves
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Civil War (US) (1861-65)', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: New evidence explains why the Netherlands tried to get freedmen to colonize Suriname.
lead_paragraph: In 1863, American blacks were not the only enslaved people with emancipation on the mind. On the northeastern coast of South America, in the Dutch colony of Suriname, some 30,000 slaves also prepared for their day of freedom, which would arrive with the government’s emancipation mandate of July 1, 1863, six months after Lincoln issued the Emancipation Proclamation.

Zombie Industries, an N.R.A. convention vendor also famous for marketing a target that resembles President Obama, has now rolled out a target in the likeness of a zombie gun lobbyist. The clever combinations of texture (lace slip-on sneakers, calf hair backpacks) and graphic prints — on everything from sunnies to hoodies — will appeal to the California beach brigade and city dwellers alike.

Weiner, a scandal-tainted Democratic candidate for mayor whose notoriety has made him a news media magnet, had arrived.

Officials will argue that they will still abide by the law and will ensure that each instance of interception will be authorized.

headline: In Store | Montauk’s New One-Stop Lifestyle Shop
abstract: A cleverly designed jewelry and lifestyle shop comes to the eastern end of Long Island for the summer.
lead_paragraph: “I’ve always wanted to do a little hotel store with cool things that you need and things you didn’t know you need,” explained Lori Leven of her latest venture, Love Adorned: Summer Session, a pop-up shop at Ruschmeyer’s, the summer-camp-like hotel in Montauk, N.Y. While she’d flirted with the idea of opening a location of Love Adorned, her thoughtfully curated jewelry and lifestyle shop, on the eastern tip of Long Island for a while, Leven admitted that the spot posed challenges she hadn’t faced at her Amagansett or Manhattan locations — namely, finding a way to secure the merchandise when the shop was closed but the lobby was still bustling. “We came up with the idea of making cabinets reminiscent of old train cases that we could completely close down and lock at night and easily open to reveal the goods in the morning,” she said. Those goods run the gamut from basic necessities (toothpaste and Tylenol) to RTH sweatshirts, leather bandannas from Japan, children’s moccasins, one-of-a-kind vintage objects like compasses and hand-carved penknives, and, of course, jewelry.

headline: Egypt Calls for New Look at Morsi Prison Escape in 2011

lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Egypt’s new rulers gave new credence to a court case against the ousted president, Mohamed Morsi, and members of the Muslim Brotherhood on Thursday over their escape from prison during the uprising that toppled his predecessor, Hosni Mubarak.

headline: Far-Off Quakes May Cause Temblors at Injection Wells
abstract: A new study suggests a link between earthquakes near injection wells in Oklahoma, Texas and Colorado, and distant magnitude 8 or higher earthquakes.
lead_paragraph: Researchers have known for years that disposing of waste water from oil and gas production by injecting it into deep wells can lead to earthquakes. Now scientists at Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory, a part of Columbia University, have discovered the actual trigger for some of those quakes: the passing seismic waves from much larger, far-off earthquakes.

headline: Explosion in Chinatown Building Leaves 3 Badly Hurt
abstract: The blast was caused by the improper use of an insecticide and led to a partial collapse and a fire in the building, at 17 Pike Street in Lower Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: An explosion caused by the improper use of an insecticide ripped through a beauty parlor in Chinatown on Thursday afternoon, causing a partial collapse of the building and a fire, and injuring eight occupants, three of them critically, the authorities said.

headline: Help the Frugal Traveler Explore the Heartland
abstract: In a twist on the cross-country road trip, Seth Kugel is driving from Louisiana to North Dakota. Problem is, he doesn’t know the territory. That’s why he needs you.
lead_paragraph: It’s an American travel staple: the cross-country road trip. Weeks behind the wheel, heading down highways and rural roads, holing up in motels, pulling into roadside diners, breezing through small towns, taking big cities by storm and, I hope, getting to know this great nation of ours in a way the National Security Agency could only dream of.

headline: In a Town of Hunters, a Maligned Man Falls Prey to Malice
abstract: Mads Mikkelsen plays a teacher suspected of being a pedophile in “The Hunt,” set in a Danish village.
lead_paragraph: In “The Hunt,” Lucas (Mads Mikkelsen), a disgraced kindergarten teacher suspected of being a pedophile, confronts his former best friend Theo (Thomas Bo Larsen) in a church on Christmas Day. “Look in my eyes,” he says to Theo. “What do you see?” Lucas naïvely believes that his true nature will reveal itself: in this case, his innocence.

headline: Small Books With Big Souls
abstract: Handmade poetry books from micro-publishers in Washington state.
lead_paragraph: In poetry, small is often most beautiful: The poignant four-line lyric that bears more emotional weight than an entire novel. Ancient Chinese and Japanese poems that transcend centuries and cultures. And the poetry bungalows — not near large enough to be called publishing houses — that quietly make small-seeming books full of big-souled poems.

headline: To See America, Be a Traveler, Not a Tourist
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Road Trips', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Two acclaimed writers discuss everything from getting off the interstate and slowing down to the importance of recording your trips.
lead_paragraph: The road book has a long and glorious history in the annals of literature, starting perhaps with “The Odyssey” (assuming you’re willing to consider the sea as a road). One of the newest entrants in the genre is “The Longest Road: Overland in Search of America, From Key West to the Arctic Ocean” by Philip Caputo (Holt). Mr. Caputo is a Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist and the author of “A Rumor of War,” a memoir of the Vietnam War. His new book chronicles his trip in an Airstream trailer from one corner of North America to the other.

headline: Mandela’s Kin Face Gray Area on End of Life

abstract: Medical experts say Nelson Mandela, the stricken South African icon, is probably being sustained by equipment, which could present his relatives, doctors and the country with a painful choice.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — The family of Nelson Mandela, who has been lying at the edge of death in a South African hospital for more than a month, might in the days or weeks to come face the same awful decision that has confronted numerous other families in an age of life-sustaining miracle machines: when is it time to say “enough.”

abstract: Walter Saabel and Philipp Hochmair star in “The Shine of Day,” directed by Tizza Covi and Rainer Frimmel.
lead_paragraph: The stage is the world, or so it appears for Philipp, the busy actor in his prime who shuttles between Hamburg and Vienna in “The Shine of Day.” He plays roles in works from “Woyzeck” to “Puss in Boots,” and, as embodied by the European stage veteran Philipp Hochmair, he’s either running lines at home or immortalizing his latest costume in a photo booth when he’s not in front of an audience.

headline: A Simple Swap or Sale? Not Here
abstract: The three tales in “Pawn Shop Chronicles” involve robbery, meth and an Elvis impersonator.
lead_paragraph: “Hee Haw” meets “Pulp Fiction” at the meth lab: That describes the style of “Pawn Shop Chronicles,” a hillbilly grindhouse yawp of a movie that belches in your face and leaves a sour stink. The heart of this carny show posing as a film is General Lee’s Pawn Shop, whose proprietor (Vincent D’Onofrio) and his pal (Chi McBride) while away the afternoons arguing about the possibility of an African-American Santa Claus.

headline: Psychedelic Euphoria Wears Off in the Desert
abstract: In “Crystal Fairy,” two young Americans attend a coke-and-pot-fueled party and go on a road trip with three Chilean brothers.
lead_paragraph: The title character of “Crystal Fairy,” Sebastián Silva’s small, lovely road movie, is the assumed name of a free-spirited latter-day hippie visiting Chile. She attaches herself to another American tourist, Jamie (Michael Cera), after he casually invites her to join him and his friends. Perfectly played by Gaby Hoffmann, Crystal Fairy has all the hallmarks of a professed earth mother holding the keys to truth, peace, love and wisdom. She has her charms, but like many such know-it-alls, she can be overbearing and preachy.

headline: America for Dummies

headline: In Battle Over Dell’s Fate, Don’t Underestimate Carl Icahn
abstract: The latest maneuver by the activist investor Carl Icahn to try to get a higher payout for his shares in Dell Inc. may not work out. But don’t write him off just yet.
lead_paragraph: Negotiation gurus say that if you think your opponent is foolish or stupid, it may well be you who is out-negotiated. I generally shrug off this type of pop business advice, but when we are talking about Carl C. Icahn, the investor whom I have likened to a Wile E. Coyote, it may be a wise adage.

headline: When a Finder’s Fee Is M.I.A.
abstract: Questions about  favoritism among friends, competitive behavior and other social situations.
lead_paragraph: An acquaintance promised my friend $20,000 in cash if my friend found her a house to buy in our neighborhood without using a broker. After some effort, my friend came through and found a house. The acquaintance will be closing on it soon, having negotiated a much better price with the seller in the absence of a broker’s fees. She thanked my friend with a Bundt cake and three dozen cookies. But the acquaintance hasn’t mentioned the $20,000 in months, and my friend hasn’t, either. Any tips on getting this woman to live up to her promise?

headline: Portugal’s President Calls for Early Elections

abstract: “Julius Caesar,” a calypso “Taming of the Shrew” and short plays by Bertolt Brecht are among the free theater productions being presented outdoors this weekend in New York City.
lead_paragraph: When even air-conditioning can’t beat the city heat, outdoor activities are essential to staying sane. Spurred by a younger, baseball-crazed housemate, the Miser has been frequenting the ballparks of the Brooklyn Cyclones and Staten Island Yankees. But for those more interested in soliloquies and social criticism than in balks and bunts, and lacking the time or energy to wait in line for Shakespeare in the Park tickets, plays from both the classical and modern canons are available in affordable outdoor productions all over the city this weekend.

headline: Fields of Expertise
abstract: Some straying is OK, but this is ridiculous.
lead_paragraph: One of the more annoying kinds of comment that pops up sometimes on this blog is the complaint that I’m violating some kind of principle whenever I write about anything that isn’t strictly economics — because that’s my only job, right? And it’s why David Brooks and Tom Friedman, for their part, never, ever write about economic issues, do they?

headline: Narrow Space in Society, if Any, for Anonymity

headline: Powder Room in Parliament? Israelis Scoff
keywords: ['Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Women and Girls', 'Cosmetics and Toiletries', 'Social Networking (Internet)']
abstract: Outrage erupted on social media after a female politician suggested that a room be set aside so that the record number of women in Parliament could freshen up.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — At first blush, it seemed simple enough: With a record number of women recently elected to Israel’s Parliament, one of them suggested, why not set aside a room for them to freshen up during long days of lawmaking, perhaps pooling personal funds to engage a makeup artist so they could look their best on TV?

lead_paragraph: The list of departures from the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden in Washington grew longer this week when Constance R. Caplan, the chairwoman of the board of trustees handed in her resignation Monday, The Washington Post reported.

lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — One of the last Hollywood studios without a Broadway division, 20th Century Fox, is diving into the live theater business by teaming with Kevin McCollum, a producer of hits like “Rent,” “Avenue Q” and “Motown.”

abstract: Nathan Silver’s “Exit Elena,” a take on the life of a service economy worker, is also touched by heartbreak.

headline: How Much Will Juan Manuel Fangio’s ’54 Mercedes Racecar Bring at Auction?
abstract: The 1954 Mercedes-Benz W196 grand prix racecar driven by Juan Manuel Fangio was found in a warehouse, but a number of factors make its potential auction sale price a mystery.
lead_paragraph: The Bonhams auction on Friday at the Goodwood Festival of Speed in England has been highly anticipated, in particular because the 1954 Mercedes-Benz W196 grand prix racecar driven to victory by Juan Manuel Fangio of Argentina will be crossing the block.

headline: It’s Bosnia in Appalachia
abstract: A soldier bent on revenge tracks down his target in “Killing Season.”
lead_paragraph: “Killing Season,” a mano-a-mano action thriller as subtle as its title, is so pretentious that you may wonder, at least briefly, if its antiwar metaphors are conning you while the film is purposefully wallowing in bathos. How else to explain its improbable story? More improbable is that an early draft of its screenplay was lauded on an industry watch list for best unproduced scripts.

headline: Political Brutality Sets a Running Champion on His Path
abstract: This Bollywood biopic trails Milkha Singh from his military training through noteworthy competitions in the 1950s at home and abroad.

headline: On Floods and Rising Insurance Premiums
abstract: Until redrawn maps are finalized, and the rates revised, neither homeowners nor lenders can accurately estimate the affordability of future premiums.
lead_paragraph: Uncertainty about the future cost of flood protection is hampering the housing recovery in coastal communities hit hardest by Hurricane Sandy.

headline: A New Year, and a Last Day Alive
abstract: “Fruitvale Station,” based on the true story of a Bay Area black man shot by a white police officer on a subway platform, examines the subject with a steady, objective eye.
lead_paragraph: In the early hours of Jan. 1, 2009, Oscar Grant III, unarmed and lying face down on a subway platform in Oakland, Calif., was shot in the back by a white Bay Area Rapid Transit police officer. The incident, captured on video by onlookers, incited protest, unrest and arguments similar to those that would swirl around the killing of Trayvon Martin in Florida a few years later. The deaths of these and other African-American young men (Mr. Grant was 22) touch some of the rawest nerves in the body politic and raise thorny and apparently intractable issues of law and order, violence and race.

headline: On Long Island, Billy Crystal Assists Storm-Struck Hometown
abstract: Mr. Crystal, who was born and raised in Long Beach, N.Y., is starring in commercials that aim to attract more people to visit the city for a day or a weekend.
lead_paragraph: When a beach haven is struggling to recover from the devastation of a hurricane, it helps to have a famous favorite son to make a pitch.

headline: Digital Dogma, Deconstructed
abstract: Simon Denny’s “All you need is data,” an exhibition of inkjet paintings at the Petzel Gallery, takes an ironic step back from the slogans and verities of today’s digital culture.
lead_paragraph: Simon Denny, a young neo-Conceptualist from Berlin, is having his second show at the Petzel Gallery, and it’s one of the bright spots of the summer season. “All you need is data: the DLD 2012 Conference REDUX rerun” is a mind-expanding installation of 90 sizable inkjet paintings that cleverly deconstructs the 2012 incarnation of Digital Life Design, or DLD, an elite invitation-only media conference that has been held annually in Munich since 2005.

headline: Hillary Clinton Taps Speechmaking Gold Mine
keywords: ['Speeches and Statements', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The events are giving Hillary Rodham Clinton large captive crowds as she considers a run for president in 2016.
lead_paragraph: Just a few months after leaving the State Department, Hillary Rodham Clinton has plunged into the lucrative world of paid speechmaking, joining a branch of the family business that has brought the Clintons more than $100 million since her husband left the White House in 2001.

headline: Chamber Made
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: A reporter provides an account of the passage of the Dodd-Frank financial reform bill.
lead_paragraph: Congress has long been one of the country’s most establishmentarian institutions. Unlike the presidency, which periodically comes under the control of outsiders, Congress rewards sheer longevity, mastery of obscure rules and inoffensiveness to colleagues. Unlike Supreme Court justices, who live in what passes for monklike isolation by Washington standards, most congressmen circulate among a permanent klatch of pundits and lobbyists. Few who serve more than four or six years can hold out against the sheer brain-deadening blandness this ­encourages.

headline: Stardust Memories
abstract: Two new books unearth vintage conversations with two Hollywood legends: Ava Gardner and Orson Welles.
lead_paragraph: The amateur magician and the magical beauty. Their first names alone conjure a time when the words Hollywood and glamour still held hands.

headline: Mash-Ups Star in a Homage to American Indians
abstract: “Jeffrey Gibson: Said the Pigeon to the Squirrel” embodies two sweeping trends in contemporary art: feverishly bright geometric abstraction and the creative reuse of found objects.
lead_paragraph: “Jeffrey Gibson: Said the Pigeon to the Squirrel” is the type of show that’s perking up the once-sleepy National Academy Museum. It inaugurates a new biennial program of solos by emerging artists, expanding on smaller efforts to highlight young, living artists (Phoebe Washburn’s spiraling nest of scrapwood in the rotunda, for example).

headline: Mercedes-Benz Leases Huge Southern California Aircraft Plant
abstract: Mercedes-Benz USA is expected to take over an old aircraft manufacturing plant in Long Beach, Calif.
lead_paragraph: Mercedes-Benz USA has signed a long-term lease on a huge, historic but closed aircraft manufacturing plant in Long Beach, Calif., according to local government officials and agents for the property owner.

abstract: Nicholas Brooks, the son of a Grammy-winning songwriter, was convicted of murdering his girlfriend at the exclusive club in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: A jury in Manhattan on Thursday found Nicholas Brooks, the son of a Grammy-winning songwriter, guilty of murdering his girlfriend in 2010 in a hotel room at the Soho House, an exclusive club in the meatpacking district.

headline: Still Kids at Heart (Just Ask Their Wives)
abstract: “Grown Ups 2” features many of the same former “Saturday Night Live” stars as “Grown Ups,” but they’ve moved to New England from Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: “The party’s over, fellas,” says Adam Sandler’s character, Lenny, to his buddies in “Grown Ups 2.” “We’re irrelevant.” And though the box office may disagree, his words aren’t far from the truth. The first “Grown Ups,” in 2010, grossed more than $271 million worldwide; the sequel will probably rival that amount, reaping lavish dividends for Mr. Sandler and his co-stars, many of them his fellow “Saturday Night Live” alumni. Once again Mr. Sandler milks middle age for lucre, nostalgia and clunky, ham-fisted humor. But he has cause for concern.

headline: Safety Board Reconstructs Crew Actions Before Crash
abstract: The National Transportation Safety Board is looking at the flight crew’s inputs into the autopilot and other cockpit automation systems during Asiana Flight 214’s final minutes.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In a critical period of nearly 30 seconds shortly before impact, none of the three pilots in the cockpit of the Asiana jet that crashed here on Saturday mentioned the airspeed of their Boeing 777, the chairwoman of the National Transportation Safety Board said Thursday.

headline: It’s Never Too Late for Hoop Dreams
abstract: In “The Hot Flashes,” a group of plucky middle-aged Texas women form a basketball team to raise money for breast cancer prevention.
lead_paragraph: “The Hot Flashes,” an agreeably silly buddy comedy with a positive message, belongs to the chipper school of Southern-fried entertainment in which can-do gals of a certain age band together for community service and self-empowerment. In the fictional town of Burning Bush, Tex., Beth (Brooke Shields), who is experiencing early signs of menopause, forms a women’s basketball team to raise money for a mobile breast-screening unit. She pressures her out-of-shape friends to compete with the town’s championship high school team in a charity tournament.

headline: Rascals and Heroes, Before the Babe
abstract: Jefferson R. Burdick collected 30,000 baseball cards from the sport’s early years to take his mind off his arthritis. Now, 600 of them are on display at the Met.
lead_paragraph: THE annual All-Star Game is scheduled to take place on Tuesday at that crime scene in Queens known as Citi Field, where the New York Mets routinely commit misdemeanor assaults on the heart. A night of celebrity baseball, neatly wrapped in red, white and blue bunting, might be just the thing to clean the slate and help the Mets see the light, and maybe a fastball or two.

headline: Apartment Buildings, the Latest in French Ideas
abstract: The Stuyvesant Apartments, opened in 1870, offered New Yorkers a newfangled living arrangement.
lead_paragraph: The gold standard for the New York apartment house is the big, lumbering 1884 Dakota, often called the first real apartment house in the city. But to cognoscenti, another building makes a run for that distinction, the 1870 Stuyvesant Apartments at 142 East 18th Street, an oddball little five-story walk-up with an impeccable pedigree, demolished half a century ago. But instead of the Stuyvesant, should it have been named the Rutherford?

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Memories of a Computer Shopper World, and Picture Language
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Thursday’s selections include a look at making a new language out of pictures (it would be very complicated), and a look back at a world where print magazines displayed the wonders of new computer technology.
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: The Bows of Summer Are Back
abstract: The New York Philharmonic opened its annual concert tour in New York City parks on Wednesday, playing Dvorak and Tchaikovsky in Prospect Park.
lead_paragraph: Despite earlier fears of a rainstorm, the weather was clear and breezy, if muggy, on Wednesday night for the New York Philharmonic’s concert in Prospect Park, the “most beautiful park in these United States,” in the effusive words of Marty Markowitz, the Brooklyn borough president, who addressed the estimated crowd of 17,000 people. Alan Gilbert, the Philharmonic’s music director, conducted the program, which offered a majestic account of Dvorak’s great Cello Concerto with Carter Brey, the orchestra’s principal cello, as soloist, followed by an assured and stirring performance of Tchaikovsky’s Fifth Symphony after intermission.

headline: Even Young Rebels Can Float a Retrospective
abstract: The Bruce High Quality Foundation, made up of evidently young, anonymous art rebels, looks back at its first 12 years in a messy, cacophonous Brooklyn Museum show.
lead_paragraph: The collective of anonymous young artists who go by the name Bruce High Quality Foundation has generated much buzz in the New York art world and some puzzlement since emerging in 2004. They’ve been celebrated as a breath of fresh air and suspected of self-entitlement and covert careerism. Who are they? Where did they come from? Are they insiders or outsiders?

headline: Romantic Puzzles in Need of Solving
abstract: The characters in “Viola” are artistically inclined, financially insecure and sexually free young people who live in Buenos Aires.
lead_paragraph: The mischievous paradox of Matías Piñeiro’s “Viola” is that it is at once devilishly complicated and perfectly simple. The characters belong to a recognizable, transnational urban tribe; their Buenos Aires could be Austin or Edinburgh, Brooklyn or Prague or any other city with a significant population of artistically inclined, financially insecure, sexually free young people.

He won 162 games, was selected to two All-Star teams and was a member of two World Series championship clubs. In 1996, he pitched the first no-hitter in the Marlins’ history.

lead_paragraph: Balkan Music and Film (Saturday) In August, a trumpet festival in the small Serbian village of Guca draws fans and musicians from around the world and fills the town with music, dancing and merriment. It is the subject of “Brasslands,” a 2013 documentary by the Meerkat Media Collective, an American group, that will be screened at 8:30 p.m. at a free event at Brookfield Place Plaza, 220 Vesey Street, near West Street, Lower Manhattan. (Below, Demiran Cerimovic, a Roma trumpeter, in a scene from the movie.) Presented by Arts Brookfield and Rooftop Films as part of the River to River festival, the evening — also called “Brasslands” — begins at 6:30 p.m. with music by four American brass bands, including Zlatne Uste, which also appears in the film. (In an event, above, featured in the movie, fans surround musicians at a Balkan music festival last year at a Brooklyn ballroom.) Doors open at 6 p.m. Although some seating will be available, spectators are encouraged to provide their own. More details can be found at rooftopfilms.com. There is sure to be dancing in the aisles.

headline: French Fare With Enticing Vistas
abstract: At Westport’s Rive Bistro, which faces the Saugatuck River, the water views are just one reason to visit.
lead_paragraph: Few things are more pleasant than a water view while dining, especially in summertime. And at the new Rive Bistro in Westport, it’s almost impossible not to have a water view, no matter where you are seated. Not only does the restaurant face the Saugatuck River, with wide windows on three sides, but the screened patio, with a long banquette, also has a head-on river view. If you happen to be there in the early evening, you may have the pleasure of watching scullers skim past.

headline: A Life That Can Fracture a Relationship
abstract: Working in the oil fields two weeks at a time isn’t conducive to a long-term relationship, but still men try, talking on their cellphones in their pickup trucks, and avoiding long goodbyes.
lead_paragraph: We live in the world of hydraulic fracturing, the dozen of us, for two weeks at a time, 14 hours a day, shuffling the heavy iron in the Rube Goldberg maze of six-inch pipes connecting a two-acre artificial pond to eight natural gas wells. Five times a day the pond is drained by 10 huge diesel-powered pumps and then refilled by an endless line of water trucks.

headline: Miranda July and Jonah Peretti on Reading Other People’s E-Mail
abstract: The multi-hyphenate artist and the Buzzfeed founder chat about how people interact, share content and present themselves online.
lead_paragraph: For her latest project, We Think Alone, the filmmaker, artist and author Miranda July took other people’s e-mail as her raw material. Earlier this month, she launched a service that compiles personal e-mails sent by noteworthy figures to other people in their lives. The e-mailers, all chosen by July, include the NBA legend Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, the “Girls” creator Lena Dunham, the actress Kirsten Dunst, the writer Sheila Heti, the Rodarte designers Kate and Laura Mulleavy and the photographer Catherine Opie. Their correspondence arrives in subscribers’ inboxes every Monday for 20 weeks, grouped around a single topic; so far, they’ve dealt with money and advice. Reading these one-sided missives one after the next offers a voyeuristic, occasionally enlightening portrait of the ways people use e-mail to communicate in 2013.

headline: Israeli Army Clears Soldiers Who Detained Child for Throwing Rock at Settler’s Car
abstract: Seven Israeli soldiers who detained a 5-year-old Palestinian boy for rock-throwing this week in the West Bank city of Hebron have been cleared of any wrongdoing by their superiors, after a review of video of the incident.
lead_paragraph: Seven Israeli soldiers who detained a 5-year-old Palestinian boy for rock-throwing this week in the West Bank city of Hebron have been cleared of any wrongdoing by their superiors, after a review of video of the incident published on Thursday by the Israeli rights group B’Tselem.

lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Valiant Capital Management, a San Francisco-based hedge fund started by Chris Hansen, and Aberdare Ventures have jointly acquired a 45 percent stake in a pharmacy benefits company, ePharma.

headline: 36 Hours in Edinburgh
abstract: Walk up the Royal Mile, browse portraits of famous Scots and pop in for a pint during a weekend in Scotland’s capital.
lead_paragraph: Tourists descend on Edinburgh every August for the Edinburgh International Festival, a citywide celebration of theater, music, opera and dance performances; the nearly 3,000 Festival Fringe shows; and the Royal Edinburgh Military Tattoo — military bands playing pipes and drums followed by fireworks. But the Scottish capital’s historic sites and winding walks offer a different charm at quieter times of the year, and its restaurants are the highlight of any visit. Haggis and fish and chips now share menu space with local, organic and sustainable fare, and there is a cafe, restaurant or bar on practically every block. That means you can happily eat and drink your way through the city if the weather is wet — which is not unlikely, so plan your outdoor activities around the daily forecast. Before your trip, check The List (list.co.uk) for restaurant reviews and a guide to exhibitions, shows and events.

lead_paragraph: Hamptons regulars — particularly those under the age of, say, 10 — have gawked at it a hundred times through their car windows: the old military tank beside the Montauk Highway in East Hampton, its gun aimed at the nonstop summer traffic. Now there is reason to take note of the rather unremarkable building next to it: The Highway Diner and Bar, the latest restaurant to lease the space from the Veterans of Foreign Wars Post 550.

abstract: Radovan Karadzic will once again be facing two genocide charges for much of the brutal campaign across Bosnia during the 1992-1995 war.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Appeals judges at a United Nations war crimes tribunal in The Hague on Thursday reinstated a genocide charge against the wartime leader of the Bosnian Serbs, Radovan Karadzic, reversing a decision by a lower court last year.

headline: Merkel Appears to Weather Anger Among German Voters Over N.S.A. Spying
abstract: The revelations about N.S.A. surveillance has done little to dent Angela Merkel’s comfortable lead ahead of September elections.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Attempts by Chancellor Angela Merkel’s opposition to leverage public anger over reports that Germany’s intelligence services collaborated with the United States’ enormous surveillance program have done little to dent her comfortable lead in the polls ahead of elections in September.

headline: A Signature Moment for Citi Field, a Ballpark Still Without One
abstract: The Mets have struggled since Citi Field opened in 2009, and the All-Star Game will bring the ballpark major national exposure for the first time.
lead_paragraph: As he took batting practice before the first game ever played at Citi Field, in 2009, Jody Gerut felt small. Soon he would inaugurate the Mets’ new ballpark as the first batter for the San Diego Padres, and he never expected to hit a home run. Even his slugging teammate, Adrian Gonzalez, struggled to clear the faraway outfield walls.

headline: Pastries Filled Every Which Way
abstract: Empanadas have become more and more popular, and New Jersey chefs are experimenting with dozens of different varieties.
lead_paragraph: Kenny Candelaria of Hackensack recently vacationed in Greece. headline: Mayor of San Diego Apologizes Over Treatment of Women
abstract: Mayor Bob Filner refused to resign in response to sexual harassment accusations leveled by prominent allies.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bob Filner of San Diego apologized Thursday for his treatment of women who had worked in his office, but he refused to resign in response to sexual harassment accusations leveled by prominent allies. “I am embarrassed to admit that I have failed to fully respect the women who work for me and with me, and that at times I have intimidated them,” Mr. Filner, 70, a Democrat in his first year in office, said in a video statement. “I have begun to work with professionals to make changes in my behavior and approach,” he said, adding that he and his staff will participate in training about sexual harassment. Donna Frye, a former city councilwoman who worked for Mr. Filner until April, had asked him to resign, saying she had credible evidence he had sexually harassed numerous women. KPBS, a public radio affiliate, reported that women in Mr. Filner’s office said they had been groped, kissed and grabbed.

lead_paragraph: International students make up 70 percent of the full-time electrical engineering graduate students in the United States, 63 percent of those in computer science, and more than half in industrial engineering, economics, chemical engineering, materials engineering and mechanical engineering, according to a new report by the National Foundation for American Policy. The report said the American economy would benefit from welcoming such students and allowing them to remain in the United States when they complete their studies. Stuart Anderson, the executive director of the foundation, said policy makers spend “too much time talking about who we don’t want to come to this country” and not enough about who should be welcomed.

lead_paragraph: 9:30 A.M. (Showtime 2) LIBERAL ARTS (2012) Josh Radnor (“How I Met Your Mother”), who wrote and directed this film, stars as Jesse, a 35-year-old admissions counselor at a New York City university who returns to his Ohio alma mater, where he encounters his two favorite teachers. The first is Judith (Allison Janney), a bitter, cynical professor of romantic literature, who seduces him, then throws him out of her bed. “You didn’t think we were going to cuddle while I read you Wordsworth,” she says. “Put some armor around that gooey little heart.” The second is Peter (Richard Jenkins), who is ending a 37-year career at the place he describes as a prison. Then Peter introduces Jesse to Zibby (Elizabeth Olsen, above with Mr. Radnor), an intellectually precocious 19-year-old drama student, and something clicks over the strains of Beethoven, Wagner, Vivaldi and Massenet. “ ‘Liberal Arts’ is a much stronger, more deeply felt film than Mr. Radnor’s debut, ‘Happythankyoumoreplease,’ ” Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times, but, “to quote the hard-boiled Judith, Mr. Radnor’s Jesse is gooey. The harder Mr. Radnor strains to make you love his alter ego, the more resistant you become. The last thing in the world you want to hear is Jesse congratulating himself for growing up, but toward the end of the movie that’s exactly what he does, with a gooey happy ending in sight.”

lead_paragraph: Vasudeva Panicker, 61, is a mild-mannered watchman of a shelter for the mentally challenged at Punnapra, in Alappuzha district in southern Kerala. In his youth, Mr. Panicker was a soldier in the Indian Army. One day he returned home from his battalion to discover that his wife had run away with a lover. Enraged, Mr. Panicker stabbed his mother-in-law to death. He served 14 years in prison for the murder.

On Monday, ABB, the Swiss electric engineering and power grid company, announced that it would install a national network of 201 fast-charging stations in the Netherlands.

Districts represented by Democrats are, together, only slightly more than half white and nearly one quarter Hispanic. lead_paragraph: I recently had a conversation with a man from Spain whose wife runs an e-commerce company that is based here in the United States but serves the Spanish market. The business sells car accessories. He was telling me about a time when she ran out of a particular item and called up her competitors, who supplied the inventory she was missing.

headline: Confessions From the Cultural Revolution
abstract: Some former Red Guards are spontaneously admitting their crimes under Mao — rare admissions in a country that shuns its past.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — He beat his teachers, terrorized his neighbors, spat on his enemies. But last month, nearly four decades later, the former Red Guard Liu Boqin published in a progressive magazine an apology to nine of his victims. Liu was in junior high school at the start of the 1966-76 Cultural Revolution and, like the rest of the nation’s youth, was encouraged by Mao’s government to turn on intellectuals, teachers and others in positions of authority.

headline: If Gulliver Were a Conceptualist ...
abstract: Robert Therrien’s solo exhibition at the Albright-Knox Art Gallery in Buffalo surveys his surreal and understated works.
lead_paragraph: Buffalo — On a recent afternoon at the Albright-Knox Art Gallery here, workers were struggling to mount a huge metal sculpture high on a wall. The piece looked like a Looney Tunes black cloud, with oversize spigots poking out of its sides. You’d imagine it raining bad luck on Porky Pig. It seemed to be jinxing its installers as well, as time and again their forklift refused to heave it to the right spot.

headline: How the Rich Get a Big Real Estate Tax Break
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Luxury Goods']
abstract: A tax abatement established to spur construction during the financial crisis of the 1907s could benefit owners at some of New York’s most expensive new buildings.
lead_paragraph: The rarefied few who can afford to shell out tens of millions of dollars for an apartment in one of the gleaming new condominiums being built across New York City may be searching for luxury, but in some cases they will find an unexpected perk: a break on real estate taxes that can mean tax bills as low as $96 a month.

headline: Those Wordy Contracts We All So Quickly Accept
abstract: Consumers rarely read the standardized language for online terms and conditions, and experts disagree on their significance.
lead_paragraph: THIS past month I’ve been agreeing to contracts like crazy. I clicked “yes” on Verizon’s terms and conditions when I paid my bill; ditto on iTunes when I was installing it on my computer. I even signed a waiver agreeing not to sue a white-water rafting company if anything went wrong when I spent a day on the Hudson.

headline: Napolitano Stepping Down as Homeland Security Chief
abstract: Janet Napolitano, who has overseen an expansive portfolio as President Obama’s secretary of homeland security, plans to become president of the University of California system.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Janet Napolitano, the secretary of homeland security, announced Friday that she was stepping down, setting off a search to fill one of the most challenging positions in government at a time when the Obama administration is struggling to get a team in place for the president’s second term.

headline: In Jersey City, First on the Block With a Rooftop Lounge
