abstract: Lawmakers on Tuesday reached a deal to preserve the delaying tactic in exchange for Senate confirmation of President Obama’s long-sought nominee for consumer protection chief.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate leaders reached an agreement on Tuesday to preserve the filibuster in exchange for confirmation votes on President Obama’s stalled nominees, ending, at least for now, months of partisan warfare that threatened the stability of several federal agencies and a generation of procedural traditions.

headline: July 16: Where the Candidates Are Today
abstract: The candidates’ daily campaign schedules at a glance.
lead_paragraph: Planned events for the mayoral candidates, according to the campaigns and organizations they are affiliated with. Times are listed as scheduled but frequently change.

headline: What if No Day Care Will Take Your A.D.H.D. Child?
keywords: ['Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder', 'Child Care', 'Children and Childhood', 'Day Care Centers', 'Parenting']
abstract: A child is defined by his label, and kicked out of three day care centers. How can his working parents find child care, and how can they find him a place to succeed?
lead_paragraph: It’s rare for us to label a child here at Motherlode. They’re children first, with the modifiers after — a child with Attention Deficient Hyperactivity Disorder; a child who uses a wheelchair. Language matters.

headline: The Gun Report: July 16, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Much attention has been paid, and rightly so, to the stalking and killing of 16-year-old Trayvon Martin, who was unarmed, in a residential neighborhood in Sanford, Fla., last year, as well as the disproportionate rate at which people (and children) of color are losing their lives to gun violence. And though the George Zimmerman trial has concluded, another is about to begin.

headline: Kidd Settles a Court Case but Still Faces a Suspension
abstract: Jason Kidd, the Nets’ new coach, was placed on interim probation and agreed to speak to Long Island high school students about the dangers of drunken driving.
lead_paragraph: Jason Kidd pleaded guilty to a drunken-driving charge on Tuesday, exposing him to a likely suspension from the N.B.A. that could postpone his coaching debut with the Nets this fall.

headline: Ex-Broker Charged in Libor Case Responds
abstract: A lawyer for Terry J. Farr, a former trader who has been charged by Britain’s Serious Fraud Office with conspiracy to defraud, said he had no responsibility for setting Libor.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Terry J. Farr, a former broker who was charged on Monday as part of an investigation into manipulation of global benchmark interest rates, was “a minnow in a very large pond,” his lawyer said on Tuesday.

headline: Leaker Files for Asylum to Remain in Russia
keywords: ['Asylum, Right of', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: Edward J. Snowden submitted an application that seemed aimed at insulating President Vladimir V. Putin from United States pressure and blame.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Edward J. Snowden, the former intelligence contractor on the run from the American authorities, on Tuesday formally requested temporary asylum in Russia, submitting an application that seemed aimed at insulating President Vladimir V. Putin from United States pressure and blame.

headline: LaBeouf and ‘Orphans’ Producers Settle Over Firing
abstract: Shia LaBeouf and the producers of “Orphans” reached a settlement in response to a grievance Mr. LaBeouf filed with the Actors’ Equity union.
lead_paragraph: The actor Shia LaBeouf has reached a settlement with the producers of the Broadway play “Orphans” over his firing from the show in February, which came after Mr. LaBeouf clashed during rehearsals with the director, Daniel Sullivan, and its star, Alec Baldwin. The producers, Robert Cole and Frederick Zollo, and Mr. LaBeouf announced the settlement in a statement on Tuesday; the terms were not released, though the producers did offer words of praise for Mr. LaBeouf.

headline: Joblessness to Keep Rising, O.E.C.D. Forecasts
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Unemployment', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Young people and the low-skilled will continue to be affected the most, according to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The social impact of the European economic crisis shows little sign of abating, with unemployment in Spain, Greece and other southern European economies expected to continue to rise through the end of next year, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said in a study published Tuesday.

headline: Why French Women Don’t Get Promoted
abstract: Family-friendly socialism and its discontents — and the lessons thereof for America.
lead_paragraph: Last fall, the expat writer and new mother Claire Lundberg wrote an essay for Slate about how much she loved France’s pro-family socialism, with its government-funded crèches and ecoles maternelle, and how the French model suggested that with sufficient public support for the career-family juggle, working mothers really might be able to “lean in,” “have it all,” and so forth.

headline: The Online Defamation of Oday Aboushi
abstract: There’s been more attention paid to his background as a Palestinian-American than his skills on the football field.
lead_paragraph: If Oday Aboushi were just any Jets football recruit, New Yorkers and sportscasters would be discussing what contributions the fifth round draft pick might bring as an offensive lineman to the NFL team.

headline: The Boston Draft Riots
keywords: ['Civil War (US) (1861-65)', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Draft and Recruitment (Military)']
abstract: In July 1863, New York wasn’t the only city to get hit by mob violence.
lead_paragraph: Maj. Stephen Cabot must have expected the worst when he assumed command of the Massachusetts militia unit stationed at the Cooper Street Armory, in Boston’s North End, on the evening of July 14, 1863. Earlier that afternoon, federal officials trudging through neighborhoods around the city had delivered the first round of conscription notices to the homes of drafted men. Cabot, like many in Boston, was probably aware that rampaging crowds of draft resisters had stormed across New York City the previous day, looting, burning and killing along the way. There was a good chance, he knew, that Bostonians might greet their nation’s call to service in the same way.

headline: Ladies and Gentlemen: Walnut Surprise!
abstract: Can you match the made-up pop group to the novel or movie in which it appears?
lead_paragraph: This past weekend’s Riff examines the allure of books and movies that only exist in books or movies. This put us in mind of some of our favorite bands, which happen to be entirely fictional. Can you match the made-up pop group to the novel or movie in which it appears?

headline: For Global Drug Manufacturers, China Becomes a Perilous Market
abstract: Rising Chinese demand for drugs is a boon for foreign companies, but bribery allegations against GlaxoSmithKline underscore the risk of scrutiny from officials.
lead_paragraph: Multinational drug companies now employ more sales agents in China than they do in the United States, their largest market. Several, including Merck and GlaxoSmithKline, are making huge scientific investments in the country, including building research and development centers. Within the next few years, China is poised to surpass Japan as the world’s second-largest pharmaceutical market.

headline: Israel Condemns New European Union Rules on Territory Seized in 1967 War
abstract: New guidelines explicitly ban the financing of and cooperation with Israeli institutions in territory seized during the 1967 war, reflecting increasing tension between Israel and Europe.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — In a move Israeli leaders quickly condemned as undermining Secretary of State John Kerry’s push to revive peace talks, the European Union issued guidelines this week that for the first time ban the financing of and cooperation with Israeli institutions in territory seized during the 1967 war.

headline: Stevie Wonder Says He Won’t Play in Florida Because of Stand Your Ground Law
abstract: The singer said he won’t perform in any state or part of the world that has a Stand Your Ground self-defense law like Florida’s.
lead_paragraph: Protesting the acquittal of George Zimmerman in the killing of the black teenager Trayvon Martin, Stevie Wonder said on Sunday that he will not play a concert in Florida until the state repeals its Stand Your Ground law, which makes it harder to prosecute people who claim they killed someone in self-defense, NBC reported.

headline: A Ghost Story That Lacks an Ending
abstract: Robert Kolker’s first book, “Lost Girls,” explores how five young prostitutes lost their lives since the Internet changed the sex trade.
lead_paragraph: Robert Kolker’s “Lost Girls: An Unsolved American Mystery” is, physically, a well-made book. Its cover image is crisp and haunting. Someone has paid close attention to this volume’s many maps. They are stylish and, a rarity, actually helpful.

headline: Chopped Salad Has Become the Lunch of Choice in the Northeast
abstract: Salad chains, Subway and even Duane Reade are catering to ravenous weekday demand for a chopped-up meal.
lead_paragraph: The Duane Reade drugstore on lower Broadway is a busy place. The weekday crush, with the stock exchange just around the corner, guarantees a steady stream of customers pushing through the doors of the two-level store, which opened last year in the landmark American Surety Building.

headline: Ask Well: Trying to Avoid Statins
abstract: Gina Kolata answers readers’ concerns about cholesterol-lowering statin drugs.
lead_paragraph: Question:

headline: Kerry Returns to Middle East in Bid for Peace Talks
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry was in Jordan to try to bolster the prospects for renewed negotiations between Israel and the Palestinians.
lead_paragraph: AMMAN, Jordan — Making his sixth trip to the Middle East as secretary of state, John Kerry arrived here Tuesday to try to bolster the prospects for renewed peace talks between Israel and the Palestinians.

headline: A Bakery Is Relieved to Have the Employer Mandate Delayed
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Small Business']
abstract: So far, the insurance plans Rachel Shein has reviewed have not seemed terribly attractive for her business.
lead_paragraph: With President Obama pushing back an important start date for the Affordable Care Act, giving companies with 50 or more full-time employees an extra year before they are required to offer health insurance to their workers, we decided to check in with Rachel Shein and her wholesale bakery, Baked in the Sun.

headline: Britain Said to Step Back From Push to Arm Syrian Rebels
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The reluctance reflects a similar attitude in Washington toward the idea of sending small weaponry to the splintered Syrian insurgents, raising broader questions about the destiny of the rebels.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — After leading a determined push with France to remove legal hindrances to arming Syria’s rebels, Britain is apparently signaling a more cautious approach, even as British newspaper reports say Prime Minister David Cameron has retreated from the idea altogether.

headline: ‘Sex on Campus’ Writer Responds to Questions and Complaints
abstract: An article on college “hookups” in the Styles section generated close to 800 comments and became the most e-mailed on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: With its photo illustration of a bare thigh and dark-painted nails amid the bedsheets, Kate Taylor’s nearly 4,800-word “Sex on Campus” article dominated the Styles cover on Sunday.

headline: With a Virtual Tour, Preserving the History of East Harlem
abstract: A nonprofit center is creating an app intended to celebrate the culture of a neighborhood that is undergoing gentrification and that those involved in the project say is often overlooked.
lead_paragraph: Celia Cruz and Tito Puente, two legendary Latin musicians, may not have had superpowers, but an artist from Williamsburg, Brooklyn, plans to tap the popularity of comic book heroes to celebrate the significance of these and other figures in the cultural history of East Harlem.

headline: Go East, Old Man: Talking To Myself
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Camps and Camping', 'Motorcycles, Motor Bikes and Motorscooters', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas']
abstract: In part two of his journey, Dexter Ford drives his tiny motorcycle through Utah and into Wyoming.
lead_paragraph: Dexter Ford is traveling from Southern California to upstate New York along mostly obscure roads, on a motorcycle that, by American standards, is quite tiny. This is the second of his occasional reports from the paths less traveled.

headline: Rules of Style | Carla Bruni-Sarkozy on the Allure of the Pantsuit and the Importance of Staying Hydrated
abstract: The effortlessly elegant singer-songwriter and former First Lady of France shares her tips for formal dressing, healthy skin and more.
lead_paragraph: “My personal style’s never really changed,” Carla Bruni-Sarkozy explained recently. Wearing a striped pantsuit and worn brown leather men’s brogues, the former model and onetime first lady of France was sitting on a sofa in her suite at the London Hotel in New York City, puffing an e-cigarette. In town to promote her fourth album, the simple, easygoing “Little French Songs,” she showed no ill effects from a late night performing at the Royalton Hotel the previous night — her only American gig this year, though she does plan to tour the United States in 2014. Here, the effortlessly elegant 45-year-old shares a few of her timeless style maxims.

headline: Possibly Unfair, but Not Necessarily Fraudulent
keywords: ['Consumer Confidence (Economic Indicator)', 'High-Frequency and Flash Trading', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Although it is natural to think that having access to information that influences the markets before others is always wrong, the laws on fraud do not go that far.
lead_paragraph: When someone has access to a service that is not equally available to others, the immediate response is often to say, “That’s not fair!” And when the securities markets are involved, the first thought seems to be that any informational advantage is not only unfair but potentially fraudulent.

headline: John Galt and the Theory of the Firm
abstract: Getting to know the weirder side of Sears.
lead_paragraph: Via David Atkins at Digby’s place, Bloomberg Businessweek has a great piece about how an Ayn Rand-loving hedge fund guy is driving Sears into the ground.

headline: Breweries Not Too Big for Their Barrels
abstract: Tiny craft-beer outfits, or nanos, stick to do-it-yourself.
lead_paragraph: Every other Friday at 2 a.m., Rich Castagna walks out to the one-car garage behind his home in Maspeth, Queens, and fills a 55-gallon stainless-steel barrel with water. While his wife and three daughters are asleep inside the house, he fires up a burner and slowly brings the water to a boil, turning the 150-square-foot room into a sauna.

headline: LAN Offers Low Fares on Connecting Flights in South America
abstract: LAN and its affiliate TAM are offering low fares on connecting flights to destinations like Salta in Argentina and Punta Arenas in Chile.
lead_paragraph: LAN Airlines and its affiliate TAM Airlines are putting South America on sale in North America.

headline: Inventive, at Least in Court
abstract: The head of Federal Trade Commission is singling out companies that engage in “a variety of aggressive litigation tactics,” like hiding behind shell companies when suing.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — To its defenders, Intellectual Ventures is a revolutionary company unfairly viewed, in the words of its co-founder Peter N. Detkin, “as the poster child of everything that is wrong with the patent system.” To its critics, it is a protection racket otherwise known as a patent troll.

headline: Living in Belle Harbor
abstract: A sense of normalcy has returned to this community on the Rockaway Peninsula, which is rebuilding after being hard hit by Hurricane Sandy.
lead_paragraph: A sense of normalcy has returned to this community on the Rockaway Peninsula, which is rebuilding after being hard hit by Hurricane Sandy.

headline: Belle Harbor, Queens: The Good, the Bad and the Beach
abstract: Hurricane Sandy flooded homes and destroyed beachfront properties in this seaside enclave, though midrange home sales are strong these days.
lead_paragraph: Normalcy seemed to reign in Belle Harbor during a recent patch of hot, steamy weather. Children rode bikes and played ball on quiet streets. Residents, carrying folding chairs and towels, headed out to swim at the public beach, which runs the length of the neighborhood.

headline: New Pussy Riot Video Asks Where Russia’s Oil Wealth Goes
abstract: In a new song released online Tuesday, the Russian protest group Pussy Riot claims that billions of dollars of the nation’s oil wealth have been looted by President Vladimir Putin and his allies.
lead_paragraph: Last Updated, Wednesday, 9:50 a.m. In a new song released online Tuesday, the Russian protest group Pussy Riot claimed that billions of dollars of the nation’s oil wealth have been looted by President Vladimir V. Putin and his allies.

headline: Prominent Gay Rights Activist Is Found Dead in Cameroon
abstract: Eric Ohena Lembembe was found dead in his home in Yaoundé, shortly after he wrote about attacks on organizations that support gay rights. Cameroon is one of 38 African countries that criminalize homosexuality.
lead_paragraph: Eric Ohena Lembembe, a prominent activist in Cameroon for the rights of lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender and intersex people, was found dead in his apartment in the capital of Yaoundé, soon after he wrote about attacks in the country on organizations that support homosexuals, Human Rights Watch said in a statement on Tuesday.

headline: Estimating Ackman’s Odds of Success at His Next Target
abstract: The hedge fund manager William A. Ackman would have a pretty good shot at agitating for change at a company like ADT, according to an analysis. A company like FedEx would be a harder target.
lead_paragraph: As the activist investor William A. Ackman hunts for his next target, a favorite guessing game on Wall Street is to see what company he will pick next to agitate for change.

headline: Turkish Police Detain 30 in Crackdown on Demonstrators
abstract: The police, citing terrorism laws, issued a temporary order withholding legal assistance to the detainees, the Istanbul Bar Association said.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Antiterrorism police units in Istanbul on Tuesday raided dozens of residences, including several college dormitories, in a crackdown on those who participated in widespread antigovernment demonstrations in June, detaining at least 30 people, the semiofficial Anatolia news agency said.

headline: Video of San Diego Mayor Explaining Why He Will Not Resign Amid Sexual Harassment Allegations
abstract: As more details of sexual harassment allegations emerge against him, Mayor Bob Filner of San Diego said he is confident he will be vindicated.
lead_paragraph: Updated | Wednesday, 6:45 a.m. Mayor Bob Filner of San Diego denied allegations that he sexually harassed and assaulted women at City Hall, describing himself in a television interview as a “very demonstrative person” who was perhaps unaware of how his actions may be perceived as inappropriate.

headline: True Cinnamon, the Royal Sister of a Commoner
abstract: A trip to Sri Lanka reveals the spice that inspired King Solomon to send explorers to the Indian subcontinent.
lead_paragraph: On a trip to Sri Lanka earlier this year, I inhaled the heady aroma of cinnamon almost everywhere I went: in the lobby of my hotel, at roadside food stands, and on a plantation that has been processing cinnamon bark, lotion and oil for three generations.

headline: Q. and A.: Orville Schell and John Delury on China’s Quest for Rejuvenation
abstract: Talking to the authors of “Wealth and Power: China’s Long March to the Twenty-First Century.”
lead_paragraph: BEIJING – Last November, after ascending to the top position in the Chinese Communist Party, Xi Jinping led the other six members of the new Politburo Standing Committee to an outing at the National Museum, on the east side of Tiananmen Square. The men stood in dark jackets at an exhibition on modern Chinese history titled “The Road to Rejuvanation,” or 复兴之路. This was their first appearance together outside the Great Hall of the People, and so it was loaded with meaning.

headline: The Decline of North Carolina, Continued
abstract: So much for the state’s public financing program for judicial elections.
lead_paragraph: An editorial last week lamented North Carolina’s abandonment of progressive policies in the seven months since Republicans took control of both the executive and legislative branches in the Tar Heel State for the first time since reconstruction.

headline: Disney Encourages Readers to Create Their Own Stories
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Reading and Writing Skills (Education)', 'Mobile Applications']
abstract: Several digital initiatives promote reading and storytelling for children from preschool age to young adult.
lead_paragraph: After decades of telling a wide variety of stories, like those about mice that pilot steamboats and monsters in college, Disney wants to give children and young adults the chance to create their own.

headline: Goldman’s Not the Leader of the Wall Street Pack
abstract: Profit of $1.9 billion in the second quarter sounds like a return to the good old days at Goldman Sachs. But the firm hasn’t managed to solidly outpace rivals.
lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs isn’t yet the envy of Wall Street again. The investment bank generated $1.9 billion of profit in the second quarter, twice the figure of a year ago and beating the estimates of analysts by a third. Though it sounds like a return to Goldman’s good old days, it hasn’t managed to solidly outpace rivals.

headline: A Worldwide Tour for ‘Hamlet’
abstract: Shakespeare’s Globe plans to tour “Hamlet” to every country on earth starting in 2014.
lead_paragraph: “All the world’s a stage,” wrote Shakespeare. Now Shakespeare’s Globe is putting those words into action. The London theater company announced on Tuesday an ambitious plan to perform “Hamlet” in every nation on earth. A cast of eight is expected to tour with a modest production of the tragedy for two years, starting April 23, 2014, the 450th anniversary of what is believed to be Shakespeare’s birth, and ending on April 23, 2016, the 400th anniversary of his death.

headline: A Tablet Keyboard With a Few New Angles
abstract: The Zagg iPad Mini Folio, a keyboard cover, makes an iPad Mini seem more like a laptop.
lead_paragraph: Connecting a keyboard to a tablet goes a long way toward making the tablet more like a laptop. But one keyboard, the Zagg iPad Mini Folio, takes it a step further with one small refinement: a hinge that allows you to set the screen to any angle, just as you would with a laptop.

headline: Beautiful Minds
abstract: Nate Silver of the FiveThirtyEight blog reviewed two children’s books, “The Boy Who Loved Math” and “On a Beam of Light,” in Sunday Book Review.
lead_paragraph: In The Times’s Sunday Book Review, FiveThirtyEight’s Nate Silver reviewed “The Boy Who Loved Math” by Deborah Heiligman and “On a Beam of Light” by Jennifer Berne, two children’s books about youth and mathematics. “Together,” he wrote, “the books constitute something of an It Gets Better Project for mathematically precocious children, offering the same sort of affirmation that is now being given to gay and lesbian adolescents.”Read more.

headline: Capture the Hours With a Time-Lapse App
abstract: Triggertrap uses a smartphone as a shutter timer for a digital single-lens reflect camera.
lead_paragraph: Those moving images in which night falls on a city within seconds, or clouds zoom past overhead, are created using time-lapse photography.

headline: Piper Perabo’s Party for the Residents of Medellín, Colombia
abstract: After she shot the premiere of the new season of her TV show “Covert Affairs” in the South American metropolis, the actress thanked the folks who helped her out with an advanced outdoor screening.
lead_paragraph: When Piper Perabo landed in Medellín, Colombia, in March, to film the fourth season of the C.I.A. drama “Covert Affairs,” which premieres tonight on USA, she had never been to South America before and was surprised to be traveling to a city she knew only as the hometown of Pablo Escobar. But she was instantly impressed by Medellín, which has transformed itself from a battleground for warring drug cartels into a model of 21st-century urban planning. “The city itself is shaped like a bowl,” Perabo explained. “The downtown is on the flat part at the bottom, and then on the steep sides on the mountain rim are all what’s called the communas. Those are sort of ghettos or favelas, built in pretty steep tiers up the side of the mountain and numbered into districts.” One of Medellín’s recent innovations: a government-built escalator that safely carries passengers 1,300 feet from the communas down into the city.

headline: Spitzer Reveals Income, but Not the Tax Returns a Rival Sought
abstract: Eliot Spitzer, who plans to finance his campaign for New York City comptroller using his family’s wealth, disclosed 2012 earnings of $4.2 million
lead_paragraph: Eliot Spitzer, who plans to finance his campaign for New York City comptroller using his family’s considerable wealth, disclosed on Tuesday that he earned more than $4.2 million in 2012 and paid about $2.1 million in federal, state and city taxes. The year before, he had an adjusted gross income of more than $3.7 million and paid about $1.5 million in combined taxes.

headline: Frail Union Chief Adds Firm Voice in Drug Case
abstract: Michael Weiner, who has brain cancer, is facing a showdown with the commissioner’s office over players linked to the Biogenesis drug investigation.
lead_paragraph: Michael Weiner wanted no sympathy when he met with the All-Stars this week at Citi Field. Weiner, the executive director of the players’ association, has brain cancer, and his symptoms have worsened in recent weeks. He cannot walk. He has lost the use of his right arm. His speech is slower.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: The Myth of ‘Race’
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Discrimination']
abstract: A reader says the idea of “race” is false and not supported by science. Readers are invited to reply.

headline: The Senate Clings to the Filibuster
keywords: ['Filibusters and Debate Curbs', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials']
abstract: A simple-majority vote to determine confirmation of executive appointments should be the rule, not a one-time deal.
lead_paragraph: For Richard Cordray, who has waited for two years to be permanently appointed as director of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, the wait is over. He was confirmed on Tuesday,  after a deal was reached to avoid a ban on filibusters on presidential nominations. Senate Republicans agreed to allow the up-or-down vote on his nomination, as well as on six other appointments.

headline: Chrysler to Issue Recall for Commercial Trucks and Grand Cherokees
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Automobiles', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: About 1,000 Ram trucks will be recalled for a potential steering problem, a number of Grand Cherokees are being recalled for a parking light problem, and N.H.T.S.A. is investigating reports of fuel leaks on BMW motorcycles.
lead_paragraph: Chrysler will recall about 1,000 of its 2013 commercial Ram 4500 and 5500 trucks because of a possible steering problem, along with about 4,500 Grand Cherokees from the 2014 model year for a parking-light problem, according to reports posted Tuesday on the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration Web site.

headline: Dueling Paellas
abstract: Two cooks. Two recipes. One rule: have fun.
lead_paragraph: Two cooks. Two recipes. One rule: have fun.

headline: Paella, by Land and Sea
abstract: In an outdoor contest, two cooks square off over flavor, fish and fowl.
lead_paragraph: Westport, Mass. — It all began innocently enough. “Valerie and her sister make the best paella ever,” my friend Ihsan Gurdal said. Even though Ihsan happens to be Valerie’s husband, no one who had ever tasted her paella had any reason to doubt him.

headline: What Goes Up at the Tour Descends Dangerously Fast
abstract: Alberto Contador lost control on a descent at the Tour de France on Tuesday, forcing Chris Froome off the road, but a descent on Thursday promises to be even more treacherous.
lead_paragraph: GAP, France — The road descending from la Rochette into Gap is picture-book pretty. A valley dotted with red-tile roofs and tawny wheat fields opens before it. The snowy crags of the high Alps rise behind. Rustic farmhouses and purple wildflowers line its shoulders.

headline: Dinkins, in Book, Blames Racism for Re-election Loss
abstract: Former Mayor David N. Dinkins says his small margin of victory in 1989 and his loss four years later were because of his skin color.
lead_paragraph: Delivering his most explicit and candid appraisal yet, David N. Dinkins says in a forthcoming memoir that he barely won the New York City mayoral election in 1989 and lost four years later for one reason: because he is black.

headline: New Chapters in ‘Life and Times’ Will Be Part of Crossing the Line Festival
abstract: The multidiscplinary festival will include two more episodes in the show from Nature Theater of Oklahoma, as well as several other performances that rely on audience participation.
lead_paragraph: Much as the opening bell signals the start of trading on Wall Street, Steve Lambert’s “Capitalism Works for Me! (True/False)” – an illuminated scoreboard, to be set up in Times Square at noon on Sept. 20 – will help proclaim the opening of the seventh annual Crossing the Line Festival.

headline: Universities Face a Rising Barrage of Cyberattacks
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Computer Security', 'Industrial Espionage', 'Intellectual Property', 'Cyberwarfare']
abstract: The hacking attempts, many thought to be from China, are forcing universities to spend more to prevent and detect intrusions and to constrict their culture of openness.
lead_paragraph: America’s research universities, among the most open and robust centers of information exchange in the world, are increasingly coming under cyberattack, most of it thought to be from China, with millions of hacking attempts weekly. Campuses are being forced to tighten security, constrict their culture of openness and try to determine what has been stolen.

headline: A Delayed Ambulance Response Prompts Quinn to Act
abstract: An intern for a member of the City Council fainted outdoors in the heat on Tuesday and it took nearly 30 minutes for an ambulance to arrive.
lead_paragraph: When a young woman fainted in the sweltering heat in Brooklyn on Tuesday, it did not immediately draw much attention, even though the woman, a City Council intern, tumbled to the ground during an outdoor news conference with Christine C. Quinn, the Council speaker.

headline: Microsoft Pushes Harder to Talk About Surveillance Orders
abstract: Microsoft on Tuesday called on the United States attorney general, Eric H. Holder Jr., to give the company permission to talk about how it handles government surveillance requests, an escalation of the company’s campaign to speak more freely about the national security orders it receives.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft on Tuesday called on the United State attorney general, Eric H. Holder Jr., to give the company permission to talk about how it handles government surveillance requests.

headline: For Paella, a Variety of Drink Options
abstract: There’s no single correct choice when it comes to pairing wine with paella.
lead_paragraph: Paella is one of those dishes with as many different interpretations as there are families zealously guarding secret recipes. So it goes with wine. You have many options, and no single correct choice.

headline: If You Like Buddy Holly and the Crickets, Try Vampire Weekend
abstract: The inventive melodies and energetic tempos of the indie rock band Vampire Weekend bring to mind Buddy Holly and the Crickets.
lead_paragraph: Each week, Val Haller, a music-obsessed baby boomer and the founder of the Web site Valslist.com, matches tracks from her generation to those of her 20-something sons’ generation.

headline: Charlie Parker, My Sister and Me
abstract: A new biography of the jazz great Charlie Parker fills in some blanks in his early years.
lead_paragraph: When I saw an advance copy of “Kansas City Lightning: The Rise and Times of Charlie Parker,” I assumed the marketing department for the publisher had tapped directly into my iPod. The cultural critic and writer Stanley Crouch has written a human portrait of Parker, the jazz great who died at 34 in 1955. The book, to be published in the fall, is full of novelistic touches, like the image of a 15-year-old Charlie Parker walking to a friend’s house to practice, “Charlie toting his horn in a blue terry-cloth drawstring bag [his mother] Addie had made for him.”

headline: Hog & Hominy
abstract: Inside the Memphis restaurant that reflects both Italian and Southern cooking.
lead_paragraph: Inside the Memphis restaurant that reflects both Italian and Southern cooking.

headline: Google Said to Weigh Supplying TV Channels
abstract: The company has begun talks with major media companies about licensing TV channels, according to people with knowledge of the meetings.
lead_paragraph: If Google has its way, you might someday get cable television the same way you get Gmail: through any ordinary Internet connection.

headline: A Budding Empire Expands: The Bowery Presents Moves Into New Orleans
abstract: The Bowery Presents has a deal to book events at the Civic Theater in New Orleans.
lead_paragraph: The Bowery Presents, a concert promoter in New York, has grown significantly since the 1990s, when its partners ran two clubs on the Lower East Side, the Mercury Lounge and the Bowery Ballroom. These days it is a force in the concert business on the East Coast, with dozens of shows throughout New York each week and a network that runs from Maine to Atlanta.

headline: The Acrobats of Pilobolus, Fiercely Lashing the Air to a Rock Beat
abstract: At the Joyce Theater, Pilobolus is presenting “Licks” — a new work created with Trish Sie — and some other pieces from its acrobatic repertory.
lead_paragraph: What we see today with Pilobolus is really Pilobolus Lite. After all, this company, which tips acrobatics over into various aspects of dance, poetry and drama, was founded in 1971, and all companies evolve. What was and is Pilobolism?

headline: A Sibling Rivalry Worth Jumping Into
abstract: Two Memphis restaurants meld Italian and Southern.
lead_paragraph: MEMPHIS — If I ate more at Hog & Hominy than was necessary from a strictly nutritional point of view, it was not my server’s fault.

headline: Leaving No Survivors but Many Questions
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents and Safety', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Television']
abstract: “TWA Flight 800,” a film on Epix, takes a skeptical look at the crash of a jet in 1996.
lead_paragraph: Plenty of people were unconvinced by the official explanation for the explosion of TWA Flight 800 off Long Island 17 years ago, which killed 230 people. And not all of the skeptics have been willing to let go of their unease as time has gone by.

headline: At Democratic Fund-Raiser, Talk of Politics on Red Carpet
abstract: The “Demmy Awards,” a ceremony for the New York County Democratic Committee, honored politicians and labor leaders, and attracted many mayoral hopefuls.
lead_paragraph: In some ways it was your typical awards show: red carpet interviews, overly long speeches and plenty of internecine rivalries, not just among the award nominees.

headline: Drug Toxicity Caused Death of Cory Monteith
abstract: The “Glee” star died of “a mixed drug toxicity, involving heroin and alcohol,” the coroners service of British Columbia said.
lead_paragraph: Cory Monteith died of “a mixed drug toxicity, involving heroin and alcohol,” the coroners service of British Columbia said on Tuesday.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Egypt, Democratic Republic of Congo, Israel and Pakistan.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Egypt, Democratic Republic of Congo, Israel and Pakistan.

headline: Ravioli With Burrata, Brought Home From Rome
abstract: Stuff ravioli with silky, mozzarella-like cheese, then crown it with dabs of pistachio pesto.
lead_paragraph: The Restaurant Takeaway column is devoted to restaurant dishes you can make in your own kitchen, tested and tweaked for home cooks.

headline: Bothered by Your Bald Baby Girl? Enter ‘Baby Bangs’
abstract: Would anyone really buy a headband with attached bangs to ensure that a bald baby is recognizable as a girl?
lead_paragraph: I have three sons, and they each had a healthy crop of hair at birth. So who am I to judge the thinking behind Baby Bangs, “the first and only Ready2Wear hairstyle hairbands ever made”?

headline: In Japan, Searching for Prized Sea Urchins
abstract: A quest for the freshest uni takes the author to Hokkaido, a seafood lovers’ paradise north of Tokyo.
lead_paragraph: My journey to the Shakotan Peninsula, a scenic corner of Hokkaido known for its sea urchin, salmon, herring and other fish, actually began in New York more than 30 years ago when my father took me for sushi at a Japanese restaurant near his office in Lower Manhattan.

headline: Mitch McConnell Tries to Save Face
abstract: He voted against a filibuster deal, then claimed he was pleased with the outcome.
lead_paragraph: For weeks, the Senate Republican leader, Mitch McConnell, has been railing about the importance of a minority party’s right to block a presidential nomination with a filibuster, as if that were an obvious component of advise and consent. His stubbornness nearly provoked Democrats to ban the filibuster for nominations, but then last night John McCain and a group of other mainstream Republican senators completely undercut his position, cutting a deal to vote on seven contested nominations without further argument.

headline: Restaurant Report: Bar Sajor in Seattle
abstract: At this new spot, opened by an award-winning chef, the food is cooked exclusively by wood flame.
lead_paragraph: At Bar Sajor, which opened in March in Pioneer Square, a stone’s throw from Seattle’s waterfront, food is cooked exclusively by wood flame. Matt Dillon, the chef and owner (and a 2012 James Beard Best Chef award winner at another of his restaurants, Sitka & Spruce), said he likes the challenge of being “at the whim of the fire.”

headline: Hotel Review: Sheraton Delfina in Santa Monica, Calif.
abstract: Located four blocks from the beach, this recently redesigned hotel offers something for both business and leisure travelers.
lead_paragraph: Rates

headline: Front Burner: Pastries at Sullivan Street Bakery, a Breakfast Read and More
keywords: ['Bakeries and Baked Products', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Restaurants', 'Ice Cream and Frozen Desserts']
abstract: Florence Fabricant’s recommendations for the week of July 16.
lead_paragraph: To Nibble: A Baker’s Blueprint for Success

headline: Off the Menu: Trading Post Opens After Sandy and More Restaurant Openings
abstract: The historic granite Greek Revival building dating from 1840 that houses this triplex restaurant was flooded in October as the owners were preparing for its debut.
lead_paragraph: Headliner

headline: Yahoo Reports Sharp Decline in Revenue From  Advertising
abstract: Lower sales from Yahoo’s two primary moneymakers highlight the challenge facing Marissa Mayer, the chief executive.
lead_paragraph: During her first year as chief executive of Yahoo, Marissa Mayer made big strides in changing the company’s culture. But reversing Yahoo’s declining revenue is turning out to be a far stiffer challenge.

headline: Rowling Book Skyrockets to Instant Hit
abstract: Booksellers who struggled to sell a book by Robert Galbraith are now struggling to get hold of the same book, whose author was revealed to be J. K. Rowling.
lead_paragraph: By the end of last week, “The Cuckoo’s Calling,” by the debut mystery novelist Robert Galbraith, was as good as dead.

headline: Despite Fears, Bond Market Is Functioning Fine
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Credit and Debt', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: In the last few days, the three big American bond-trading firms – JPMorgan Chase, Citigroup and Goldman Sachs – all reported second-quarter financial results that were helped by healthy bond trading revenue.
lead_paragraph: There may be less reason to fear the big, bad bond market.

headline: 2 Pianists, One Low-Key, One Fiery
abstract: Andrew Tyson, a rising pianist, and Ilya Yakushev, a seasoned performer, played back to back on Monday evening at the International Keyboard Institute and Festival.
lead_paragraph: The pianists Andrew Tyson and Ilya Yakushev don’t look all that different when they sit at their instrument. Both bow their heads a bit toward the keys and keep their hands on the flattish side.

headline: From Sundance Institute, a New Minifestival for Los Angeles
abstract: The lineup at Next Weekend, an offshoot of the famed Utah festival, plays up boundary-pushing films from mostly first-time directors.
lead_paragraph: New pictures about lesbian hookers and cancer. A short film about a guilt-ridden young adult. A panel discussion about guerrilla movie marketing.

headline: Gaining Voices and Losing Inhibitions
abstract: In London, John Doyle has made an honest musical out of “The Color Purple,” and an academic makes a deal with the Devil in “The Strange Undoing of Prudencia Hart.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In one of this summer’s most surprising marriages, John Doyle has made an honest musical out of “The Color Purple.” This minimalist director’s take on the stage adaptation of Alice Walker’s novel, which opened on Monday night at the Menier Chocolate Factory here, is so lithe and muscular that at first it’s hard to detect even remnants of the big, bloated show that “The Color Purple” once was.

headline: Where You Can’t See the Forest for the Egos, Fairies and Complicated Love Triangles
abstract: A “Midsummer’s Night” production by the Classical Theater of Harlem in Marcus Garvey Park has piquant multicultural touches.
lead_paragraph: No, Daddy, I won’t marry that man, the young woman says. Her best friend has romantic problems, too; she adores a man who considers her a hideous loser. A group of untalented blue-collar guys are rehearsing a play for the city’s elite. A supernatural being uses a magic herb to make people want to ravish those they would ordinarily find repulsive.

headline: When an Executive Turns Buyout Adviser, Alarm Bells Go Off
abstract: In its bid to buy Gardner Denver, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts hired the company’s former chief, Barry Pennypacker, to provide advice, raising questions of fairness.
lead_paragraph: Here’s one way to gain an edge in deal-making: hire the former chief executive of the company you want to buy to advise you.

headline: Code-Writing Pioneers, It’s Your Turn
abstract: “Computer Chess” is set in 1980 at a gathering where computer programs created by nerds face human competition.
lead_paragraph: What was the world like before? That is the question every period movie contemplates and seeks to answer by means of historically appropriate props, costumes and habits of speech. An accurate depiction of the past will also involve a certain amount of subtraction, since one of the differences between us and our ancestors is that they didn’t have a lot of the stuff that we take for granted. Part of the fun for viewers lies in imagining (or remembering) how anyone managed without our helpful gadgets and gizmos.

headline: Johnson & Johnson Profit Rises on Strong Prescription Sales
abstract: The health care giant reported earnings of $3.8 billion in the second quarter, aided in part by the sale of the company’s stake in Elan of Ireland.
lead_paragraph: Johnson & Johnson reported on Tuesday that its earnings more than doubled in the second quarter of this year, buoyed by strong sales of prescription drugs and an influx of cash from the sale of its stake in the Irish drug manufacturer Elan.

headline: Snail’s Pace Can Win the Race
abstract: A snail who thinks he can do great things is supercharged by ambition in “Turbo,” but there is a trail of big commercial interests in the story.
lead_paragraph: “Turbo” is a new movie from DreamWorks Animation Studios about a little snail with a big dream. It is also the latest animated feature to use an animal’s frustration with the limitations of his species as a metaphor for human aspirations. Much as the rat Remy in “Ratatouille” did not want to eat garbage, and Mumble the penguin in “Happy Feet” wanted to dance, so does Turbo — given name Theo, voice courtesy of Ryan Reynolds — long to move fast.

headline: Feeling For | Nike’s Limited-Edition Free Flyknit Sneaker Celebrates New York City
abstract: The brand’s latest slick, technologically sophisticated line of running shoes includes a special model that pays tribute to the Big Apple.
lead_paragraph: New Yorkers tend to wear their city pride on their sleeves, but only to a point. Proving that showing one’s affection for the Big Apple can be less conspicuous than donning an “I Love NY” T-shirt, Nike unveiled today a limited-edition New York City version of its new Free Flyknit running shoe, which comes with a subtle yet slick monogram of Gotham’s famous initials stretched across the laces. The Flyknit is a hybrid of the company’s ergonomic Nike Frees, which are favored by many dedicated runners, and the state-of-the-art, socklike Nike Flyknit Racer, which was introduced in April at the Salone Internazionale del Mobile in Milan. The black-soled New York City edition (all the better for pounding New York’s not-so-sanitary pavement) will be available in early August. Nike is also rolling out additional variations celebrating other international cities, including London, Tokyo, Paris, Shanghai and Rio de Janeiro. For specific availability dates for each city, please visit nikestadiums.com.

headline: Reader Reactions to the George Zimmerman Verdict
abstract: Thousands of New York Times readers responded to the not-guilty verdict for the man who killed Trayvon Martin with emotionally charged comments.
lead_paragraph: When George Zimmerman, the neighborhood watch volunteer who fatally shot an unarmed black teenager, Trayvon Martin, was acquitted of all charges, thousands of New York Times readers responded with a wide range of emotionally charged comments.

headline: Upstart Roils Nerves in a Packed TV Race
abstract: On the eve of the announcement of the Emmy Award nominees, some are betting that Netflix is poised to change the landscape.
lead_paragraph: The nominations for the Emmy Awards will be announced on Thursday in Los Angeles, and it is widely expected that, for the first time, the headlines will be all about Netflix.

headline: Rare, but Real, a Racial Divide in Prime Time
abstract: This season, “Big Brother” offers a rare opportunity to watch white privilege and unconscious racism in the field.
lead_paragraph: Thirteen years ago, on the first season of the CBS reality competition “Big Brother,” one houseguest was William Collins, also known as Will Mega, an intensely political black man who proved polarizing in the house for his sometimes confrontational talk about race. It was a novelty, this sort of conversation, in network prime time, and in the eyes of Americans, perhaps not a welcome one: the audience voted Mr. Collins off the show first.

headline: An Interview With Jonathan Martin
abstract: Richard L. Berke talks with The New York Times’s new national political correspondent about the issues he will be covering in his new job, with a special focus on Hillary Rodham Clinton.
lead_paragraph: Richard L. Berke talks with The New York Times’s new national political correspondent about the issues he will be covering in his new job, with a special focus on Hillary Rodham Clinton.

headline: An Architect of the Tourre Case to Depart S.E.C.
abstract: Kenneth R. Lench, who oversaw the Securities and Exchange Commission’s case against Goldman Sachs and Fabrice P. Tourre, announced his departure from the agency just as Mr. Tourre’s trial was beginning.
lead_paragraph: Kenneth R. Lench oversaw the Securities and Exchange Commission’s case against Goldman Sachs and Fabrice P. Tourre, a trader at the bank.

headline: Its Bubble Popped, Hirshhorn Takes Stock of the Future
abstract: As the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden approaches its 40th anniversary, there are questions about whether the cancellation of its inflatable pavilion project signals the end of its troubles or is a new dip in a downward slide.
lead_paragraph: In 2009, when Richard Koshalek, the new director of the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden first proposed building a 15-story inflatable balloon to bubble out of the museum’s inner courtyard twice a year, it was hailed as a visionary plan to put the Hirshhorn at the center of the nation’s cultural conversation.

headline: Texas Man Arrested Across From White House
abstract: The Secret Service arrested Christopher Briggs, who was armed with a pistol and two knives, in Lafayette Park on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Secret Service officers arrested a Texas man armed with a pistol and two knives on Tuesday afternoon in Lafayette Park, across the street from the White House.

headline: Video: Interview With Jonathan Martin
abstract: The Times’s new national political correspondent about the issues he will be covering in his new job, with a special focus on Hillary Rodham Clinton.
lead_paragraph: Richard L. Berke talks with The New York Times’s new national political correspondent about the issues he will be covering in his new job, with a special focus on Hillary Rodham Clinton.

headline: Youth League Tantrums, but Not by the Kids
abstract: In “Dealin’ With Idiots,” Jeff Garlin lampoons the obsessions of adults with children on a baseball team.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Garlin, who plays Larry David’s affable manager-sidekick in “Curb Your Enthusiasm,” knows his own strengths: watching and listening patiently to more colorful performers and then responding with resigned, understated outrage. In “Dealin’ With Idiots,” which he also directed, Mr. Garlin surrounds himself with a quirky, seemingly improvisational ensemble of comic actors (in the manner of, say, Christopher Guest’s usual players) to lampoon the obsessions of adults with children on a baseball team. The results are amusing if predictably mild.

headline: Girls Behaving Badly at a Film Festival
abstract: “Les Coquillettes” follows the fictional exploits of the film director Sophie Letourneur and her two friends at the Locarno Film Festival in Switzerland.
lead_paragraph: “Les Coquillettes” could be described as an effervescent and pastel-colored version of John Cassavetes’s “Husbands.” Or it could be thought of as a French version of the “Girls” episode directed by Jody Lee Lipes, in which the women head to Bushwick, Brooklyn, for what promises to be “the best party ever.” But perhaps the most accurate comparison for this film, written, directed and also starring Sophie Letourneur, is to Renata Adler’s novel “Speedboat.”

headline: Images of Latest Deadly Clashes in Cairo
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Images and video posted online by reporters and witnesses offered detailed views of clashes late Monday around a train station in central Cairo.
lead_paragraph: As my colleagues Kareem Fahim and David Kirkpatrick report from Cairo, hours before Egypt’s new interim government was sworn in, “at least seven people were killed and more than 200 were injured in overnight clashes between Islamists and Egyptian riot police, health officials said Tuesday.”

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Dark Side of a Taxi App, and Language Cats
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Tuesday’s selections include a woman’s bad experience with a Lyft driver, and an app that tries to teach foreign language with cat photos.
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: Statement From GlaxoSmithKline
abstract: An e-mailed statement from GlaxoSmithKline responding to allegations that the company funneled payments through travel agents to doctors and officials in China to bolster drug sales in the country.
lead_paragraph: This statement was provided to The New York Times by a GlaxoSmithKline spokesman in an e-mail on Monday, responding to allegations that the company funneled payments through travel agents to doctors, hospitals and government officials in China to bolster drug sales in the country.

headline: Worried About Defeat for Dell Offer, Board and Bidders Prepare Maneuvers
abstract: A special committee of Dell’s board is poised to adjourn the vote on Thursday morning because it is concerned that the offer may be defeated by shareholders, people briefed on the matter said on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: July 17, 5:05 p.m. | Updated

headline: Liz Cheney to Challenge Senator Michael Enzi of Wyoming
abstract: Ms. Cheney, the older daughter of former Vice President Dick Cheney, announced an intent to run, setting up a Republican primary clash next year that party officials had hoped to avoid.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Liz Cheney, the older daughter of former Vice President Dick Cheney, announced Tuesday that she intended to challenge Senator Michael B. Enzi of Wyoming in a Republican primary clash in next year that national and state party officials had hoped to avoid.

headline: Ruins in a Center of Syria’s Uprising
abstract: After a year of siege, the city of Homs in central Syria may well be the site of the most concentrated destruction in the country.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Little by little, the central Syrian city of Homs is losing its infrastructure and its landmarks. The national hospital lies in ruins. Rebel-held neighborhoods stretch for blocks without an intact building. Many government offices are closed. The silver-domed mosque of Khalid bin al-Waleed — named for an early Islamic warrior particularly revered by Sunnis — stands pockmarked and perforated.

headline: His Ship Still Aground, Captain Goes on Trial
abstract: Francesco Schettino, accused of abandoning his ship after it ran aground and capsized off the Tuscan coast, could face up to 20 years in prison.
lead_paragraph: ROME — He was the focus of Italians’ rage and embarrassment 18 months ago, when he was accused of abandoning his ship after it ran aground and capsized off the Tuscan coast, killing 32 people. On Wednesday the ship’s captain, Francesco Schettino, will finally appear in a courtroom.

headline: Widow of Sept. 11 Pilot Seeks More Cockpit Security
keywords: ['September 11 (2001)', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Security and Warning Systems', 'Pilots', 'Aviation Accidents and Safety']
abstract: Ellen Saracini wants airlines to have to install a second security door to the cockpit, but the airline industry says that isn’t necessary.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The widow of a United Airlines pilot who died on Sept. 11, 2001, is lobbying for legislation that would require airlines to install a second security door to prevent would-be hijackers from rushing cockpits. But the move is opposed by the airline industry, which says the existing security measures are good enough.

headline: As Spitzer Pursues a Comeback, His Wife Chooses to Stay Offstage
abstract: Silda Wall Spitzer has so far been all but invisible as her husband, former Gov. Eliot Spitzer, runs for New York City comptroller, a stark contrast from his earlier days in politics.
lead_paragraph: Eliot Spitzer spent this past weekend hopping from coast to coast, flying to Los Angeles to appear on “The Tonight Show,” then catching a red-eye back to Manhattan where he huddled for strategy sessions and hit the Sunday morning talk-show circuit.

headline: The President of Venezuela Weds His ‘First Combatant’
abstract: After resisting formally tying the knot for about two decades, President Nicolás Maduro and Cilia Flores were married on Monday, Mr. Maduro announced.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — President Nicolás Maduro refuses to refer to his longtime companion, Cilia Flores, as Venezuela’s first lady, preferring to call her by the more ideologically resonant title “first combatant.” Now he can also call her something else: his lawfully wedded wife.

headline: A Parade of Stars With a Met in Front
abstract: The Mets’ young ace, who started for the National League, was at the front of a procession of All-Star players in Midtown Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: The first sign that things might finally be looking up for the Mets appeared at the very start of the parade of major leaguers in Midtown Manhattan on Tuesday afternoon before the All-Star Game at Citi Field.

headline: Supplements Called Risky Are Destroyed
keywords: ['Dietary Supplements and Herbal Remedies', 'Dimethylamylamine (DMMA)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: At the government’s behest, the supplement manufacturer USPlabs destroyed $8 million worth of Jack3d and OxyElite Pro, workout boosters that contained a stimulant believed to be harmful.
lead_paragraph: Under pressure from federal health regulators, the manufacturer of two popular sports supplements has voluntarily destroyed the inventory of the products, the Food and Drug Administration said on Tuesday.

headline: Pran Sikand, Villain of the Bollywood Screen, Dies at 93
abstract: During the height of Mr. Sikand’s fame, his sneers and snarls on film had such an indelible influence that mothers in India were said to be reluctant to name their sons Pran.
lead_paragraph: Pran Sikand, a beloved Bollywood character actor who for much of his career specialized in playing villains, died on July 12 in Mumbai. He was 93.

headline: Glassboro, N.J., Gambles on a University Partnership
keywords: ['Area Planning and Renewal', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: The struggling borough has tied its fortunes to Rowan University and a $300 million downtown revitalization.
lead_paragraph: GLASSBORO, N.J. — Glassboro’s downtown has been dying for decades, with shops struggling to compete with nearby strip malls and students from the local university showing little interest in the run-down Main Street. Now, borough officials hope that a $300 million makeover will draw shoppers to the downtown stores and revive its flagging image.

headline: Marc Simont, Classic Children’s Book Illustrator, Dies at 97
abstract: Mr. Simont, a recipient of the Caldecott Medal, was admired for his delicately spare, but expressive, style.
lead_paragraph: Marc Simont, an acclaimed illustrator whose work, embodying both airy lightness and crackling energy, graced some of the foremost titles in children’s literature, died on Saturday at his home in Cornwall, Conn. He was 97.

headline: As Woods Stepped Back, the Field Surged Forward
abstract: Whether because of health, self-confidence or something else, Tiger Woods has not won in the past 20 majors after winning six titles in the previous 20-major span.
lead_paragraph: GULLANE, Scotland — The first time Tiger Woods played at Muirfield, in 2002, he was stopped on his way to the practice range by a security guard because he did not have his credential. On Monday, in his first trip back, Woods was stopped on his way to his practice round by a security guard when he arrived at the 10th tee a few minutes before the course’s official 7 a.m. opening.

headline: Another Measure of Fast Growth in China
abstract: In the five years from 2006 to 2011, health care spending and the pharmaceutical market in China more than doubled. And the top-10 drug makers have more the tripled their sales staff there.
lead_paragraph: In the five years from 2006 to 2011, health care spending and the pharmaceutical market in China more than doubled. And the top-10 drug makers have more the tripled their sales staff there.

headline: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
keywords: ['Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: Notable properties that have been recently listed for sale, sold or leased.
lead_paragraph: Recent Sale

headline: The Pros and Cons of a Surveillance Society
keywords: ['Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Privacy', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Wearable Computing']
abstract: As we prepare to enter a world of wearable, camera-equipped computers, do we want to live under a system that might ensure justice for all, yet privacy for none?
lead_paragraph: Here are three topics much in the news these days: Prism, the surveillance program of the national security agency; the death of Trayvon Martin; and Google Glass and the rise of wearable computers that record everything.

headline: 2 Hospital Networks Agree to Merge, Raising Specter of Costlier Care
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Hospitals']
abstract: The merger of  Mount Sinai Medical Center and Continuum Health Partners will result in the largest hospital system in New York City outside of the public hospital system.
lead_paragraph: Two major New York City hospital networks have agreed to merge, creating the largest private hospital system in the city, raising the prospect of higher prices for consumers, and positioning the new system to take advantage of coming changes under the federal health care law.

headline: Sudan’s President One Step Ahead of a Suit and a Warrant
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: President Omar Hassan al-Bashir of Sudan left an African Union meeting in Nigeria after human rights groups filed a suit calling for his arrest on a warrant accusing him of genocide.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Sudan’s president, Omar Hassan al-Bashir, made a brief appearance at an African Union summit meeting in Nigeria but vanished after human rights groups filed a lawsuit calling for his immediate detention on an international arrest warrant for charges of genocide.

headline: David J. Maundrell III
keywords: ['Real Estate Brokers', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: Mr. Maundrell is the founder and president of aptsandlofts.com, a residential real estate brokerage firm that specializes in properties in Brooklyn, and, more recently, Long Island City, Queens.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Maundrell, 38, is the founder and president of aptsandlofts.com, a residential real estate brokerage firm based in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, that specializes in properties in Brooklyn, and, more recently, Long Island City, Queens.

headline: Aiding Baseball Dreams, but Knowing the Reality
abstract: Dusty Wathan spent 14 years in the minors for one short stint in the majors, which makes him ideally suited to pass on what he knows to the prospects he now manages.
lead_paragraph: READING, Pa. — The buzz surrounding Alex Rodriguez’s cameo this week with the Trenton Thunder has had little effect on Dusty Wathan, the manager of the Reading Fightin Phils. Amid all the hoopla, Wathan has stuck to routine: coaching, teaching, counseling.

headline: When Prisoners Protest
keywords: ['Solitary Confinement', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Hunger Strikes']
abstract: Why we should all be concerned about the inhumane conditions of prolonged solitary confinement.
lead_paragraph: THERE aren’t many protests in prison. In a world where authorities exercise absolute power and demand abject obedience, prisoners are almost always going to be on the losing side, and they know it.

headline: Fired for Being Beautiful
abstract: Discrimination based on beauty rests on the same sexist principle as discrimination against the ugly. And both rest on the power of the male gaze.
lead_paragraph: MOST everyone knows by now about “lookism” — the preferential treatment given to those who conform to social standards of beauty. Research suggests that people who are judged physically attractive are seen as more competent and more socially graceful than those who aren’t; they have more friends and more sex; and they make more money. One economic study found a 5 percent bonus for being in the top third in the looks department (as assessed by a set of observers), and a 7 to 9 percent penalty for being in the bottom 9 percent.

headline: If Churchill Could See Us Now
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The G.O.P. aversion to an immigration bill is costing us dearly.
lead_paragraph: Whenever we go into political drift as a country, optimists often quote Winston Churchill’s line that Americans will always do the right thing, after they’ve “exhausted all other possibilities.” I don’t think that’s true anymore. Churchill never met the Tea Party, and he certainly never met today’s House Republicans, a group so narrow-minded and uninterested in governing — and the necessary compromises that go with it — that they’re ready to kill an immigration bill that is manifestly in the country’s economic, social and strategic interests.

headline: A Parade of Advertising, Starring Ballplayers
abstract: Major League Baseball’s All-Star parade paralyzed parts of Midtown Manhattan for stretches of the day, though many people seemed befuddled by exactly what it was.
lead_paragraph: Barricades were set up in Midtown to keep hordes of people from surging onto the street as the Major League Baseball All-Star Parade of Pickup Trucks and Ballplayers moved at a stately pace toward 42nd Street.

headline: Battery Seen as Way to Cut Heat-Related Power Losses
abstract: Large-scale batteries of various types are being tested by some big utilities that want to store power for times when it is needed most.
lead_paragraph: As scorching weather envelops the Northeast and the Midwest, electric utilities are scrambling to keep the power on while air-conditioners strain utilities’ capacity. By Tuesday afternoon in New York City and Westchester County, for instance, Consolidated Edison had logged nearly 7,700 interruptions since the heat arrived on Sunday, and it had dispatched crews to restore almost all of the power.

headline: Like Giddy Youngsters, Seeking Out Rivera With Pens and Pads
abstract: Many of the players gathered for baseball’s All-Star Game at Citi Field were intent on becoming autograph hounds for a night.
lead_paragraph: Mariano Rivera, in his final All-Star Game, said he had been asked to sign more autographs from players than ever before. The reason for all the interest, of course, is that Rivera was participating in his 13th All-Star Game in his 19th and what he said will be his final season.

headline: Summer’s Beast Is Loose
abstract: As the sun becomes almost predatory, the conversation this year suggests this may be more than a temporary discomfort.
lead_paragraph: On clear, mild summer mornings, whatever those are, the sun rises fat and woozy out of the East, shimmering in a pool of its own rays. But this past month, here and across the country, there has been something blunt and almost predatory about the sun the moment it frees itself from the horizon.

headline: Jobs and the City
abstract: The candidates aiming to succeed Mayor Michael Bloomberg seek pro-growth policies for uncertain times.
lead_paragraph: Opportunity and prosperity in New York City are spread thickly but unevenly. For too many New Yorkers, paychecks are too small and the rent too high. Life is uneasy, and recent economic and natural disasters have made it feel only more perilous, even as a luxury-apartment boom and gentrification have turned parts of the city into enclaves of prosperity and graciousness. People want jobs they can live on, in neighborhoods they can live in, but they don’t know how that is supposed to happen — or how the next mayor is going to make sure that it does.

headline: China: Four Officials Detained Over Mine Explosions
abstract: Four local officials are being investigated for “dereliction of duty” in two coal mine blasts that killed 53 people last spring.
lead_paragraph: Four local officials are being investigated for “dereliction of duty” in two coal mine blasts that killed 53 people last spring, according to a report on Tuesday by Xinhua, the state news agency. The double blasts, in Jilin Province of northeast China, were among the worst recent coal mine accidents. The Xinhua report named the officials as Li Shijun and Zhang Yuzhong, both former officials with the Work Safety Bureau in Baishan City, and Xu Shengxue and Wang Yuxi, former officials with the Baishan branch of the provincial Bureau of Coal Mine Safety.

headline: Last Day for Surgeon General

abstract: Surgeon General Regina Benjamin left her job on Tuesday and said she would return to work at the clinic she founded in Bayou La Batre, Ala.
lead_paragraph: Surgeon General Regina Benjamin left her job on Tuesday and said she would return to work at the clinic she founded in Bayou La Batre, Ala. Dr. Benjamin, 56, gave no reason for her departure when she announced it last month, fueling speculation that she might run for Congress. Her departure leaves the administration without one of its most visible public liaisons as it prepares Americans for crucial provisions of the health care law that are set to take effect next year. Dr. Benjamin was widely praised for her efforts to prevent diseases and promote physical fitness. She has been mentioned as a possible Democratic candidate in a special election in Alabama’s First Congressional District, where Representative Jo Bonner, a Republican, is stepping down next month.

abstract: As a bioethicist, Peggy Battin fought for the right of people to end their own lives. After her husband’s cycling accident, her field of study turned unbearably personal.

headline: Daily Report: Batteries May Provide Relief From Summer Blackouts

lead_paragraph: Air-conditioner use during recent hot weather has strained the capacity of power companies across the Northeast and Midwest. Several utilities, including Con Edison, National Grid and the large European utilities Enel and GDF SUEZ, have signed up to fine-tune and test what they hope could lead to an answer — a battery half the size of a refrigerator from Eos Energy Storage, the company said Tuesday. If the testing goes well, the batteries hold the promise of providing storage that until now has been unaffordable on a large scale, Diane Cardwell reports in The New York Times.

headline: Talking Female Circumcision Out of Existence
abstract: How a pro-women’s group used a strategy of “community conversations” to effectively end the practice of genital cutting in an Ethiopian village.
lead_paragraph: Like every other girl of her era in her part of southern Ethiopia — and most girls in the country — Bogaletch Gebre was circumcised. In some regions girls are circumcised as infants, but in her zone it happened at puberty. It was around 1967, and she was about 12. A man held her from behind, blindfolded her and stuffed a rag in her mouth, and with his legs held her legs open so she could not move. A female circumciser took a razor blade and sliced off Gebre’s genitals.

headline: Bank of America Profit Surges

Dell is engaged in last-minute maneuvers over the company he founded. | Hiring a company’s former executive as a buyout adviser can present problems, the Deal Professor writes. | Paolo Pellegrini gets testy on the witness stand in the trial of Fabrice Tourre.
lead_paragraph: Bank of America reported on Wednesday that its second-quarter net income rose 63 percent to $4 billion, or 32 cents a share, compared with $2.5 billion, or 19 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Revenue increased to $22.7 billion from $22 billion in the period a year earlier. A conference call to discuss the results is being held at 8:30 a.m.

Bernanke, emphasized on Wednesday that the central bank remains committed to bolstering the economy, insisting that any deceleration in the Fed’s stimulus campaign will happen because it is achieving its goals, not because it has lowered its sights.

headline: Woody Allen, Standup Guy
abstract: Woody Allen explains how Louis C.K. and Andrew Dice Clay came to be cast in his new film, “Blue Jasmine,” and how recent experiences have got him thinking about revisiting his old nightclub act.
lead_paragraph: Among the more unexpected screen combinations that result from Woody Allen’s new movie, “Blue Jasmine,” are the sights of Cate Blanchett facing off with the risqué standup comedian Andrew Dice Clay as a man who has been laid low by her character’s deceptions; and the British actress Sally Hawkins pairing up with the comic and television star Louis C.K. as a potential suitor who becomes (in his words) “one of those awful stories that women carry around.”

headline: I.M.F. Tells China of Urgent Need for Economic Change
abstract: China’s domestic economic balance is precarious, the International Monetary Fund said, largely because of too little consumer spending and too much government spending.

headline: A Conversation With: Literary Critic and Novelist Shamsur Rahman Faruqi
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Poetry and Poets', 'Urdu Language', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: Literary critic Shamsur Rahman Faruqi speaks about his debut novel, British colonialism, and Indian history.
lead_paragraph: India’s literary establishment is abuzz about the recently published novel “The Mirror of Beauty,” a 984-page fictional account about the life and times of Wazir Khanam, the mother of the famed Urdu poet Daag Dehalvi, set mostly in Delhi and its environs during the 19th century. A beautiful and spirited woman, Wazir mingles with the noblemen of the Mughal court of Emperor Bahadur Shah Zafar, the English officers of the East India Company, the poets of the age and a whole panorama of other unforgettable characters.

headline: Wake-Up Call for New Yorkers as Police Seek Abducted Boy

headline: No Smoke in the Neighborhood
keywords: ['Consumer Behavior', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: When Myanmar was a closed society, there were suffocating moments of poverty and repression. But there were also moments of grace.
lead_paragraph: YANGON — I delight at the sight of my 60-year-old mother gingerly taking her first rides up and down the escalators of the new glitzy shopping malls downtown. In a sarong, her face smeared with thanakha (a traditional cream-colored paste made from bark) she and other women walk with their young daughters in tight jeans or miniskirts, visiting expensive supermarkets and Mango and Prada stores. Most just window-shop, simply to bask among symbols of modernity.

lead_paragraph: “Prototype: Opera/Theater/Now,” a festival that presents avant-garde chamber opera, will offer its second slate of productions at Here, the cozy arts center in Greenwich Village, in January. The festival, produced by Here and Beth Morrison Projects, will include five works, among them the world premiere of “Thumbprint,” a 90-minute work by the composer and singer Kamala Sankaram and the playwright Susan Yankowitz, and “Angel’s Bone,” a work-in-progress by Du Yun, with a libretto by Royce Vavrek. The festival runs Jan. 8 to 18.

headline: Making Travel Connections Online
abstract: Whether you want to split a hotel room, share a meal or meet up with friends of friends in a foreign city, these new social Web sites could help.
lead_paragraph: Taking their inspiration from Web sites like Facebook and OkCupid, a flourishing category of social sites is aiming to connect travelers and their friends — especially those going solo — to help them save money, stay safe and enjoy more authentic cultural experiences. Sites like Couchsurfing, Airbnb and Planely have led the way. Now add to the genre a handful of newcomers striving to make touring a city full of strangers a little more friendly and a little less costly. (All of the sites are free to join unless otherwise noted.)

headline: Rivera’s Perfect All-Star Appearance
abstract: The All-Star Game on Tuesday night provided enough memorable moments for a video edition of Leading Off.
lead_paragraph: The All-Star Game had its moments, of course. That’s never its problem. It’s the gaps between them that get long, commercial-filled and occasionally filled with Tim McCarver reciting song lyrics during an at-bat. But Tuesday night’s version scrubbed all thoughts of that by producing a moment that will go down in time: Mariano Rivera, all quiet dignity and majestic athleticism, trotting onto the field for a final All-Star Game appearance.

headline: Opposites Attract
abstract: Two stylish new books for the preschool set play with ideas of difference.
lead_paragraph: The first few years of childhood seem marked by contrasts: babies are unequivocally small, adults are unquestionably large, and the area in between goes unexplored. But a little later in child development, those stark oppositions give way to more subtle comparisons. “Pomelo’s Opposites” and “Is It Big or Is It Little?,” two stylish new books for the preschool set, play with ideas of difference in ways that are sure to provoke thought and giggles.

headline: With Sales Collapsing, an Owner Turns to a Consultant

lead_paragraph: Last year, my custom conference table business suffered a collapse in sales that caused me a great deal of anguish and led me to try a number of solutions. Most important, I hired a sales consultant to provide a critical evaluation of our selling methods, to suggest changes and to work with us to carry out those recommendations. This was expensive, costing almost $38,000, but the knowledge we gained from a fresh look at our sales operation provided a number of important benefits.

headline: Every U.S. Game Is a Critical Audition for Holden and Donovan
