abstract: An overview of exhibitions and installations at New York museums and galleries.
lead_paragraph: Art

headline: The Making of a (Fake) Rock Band
abstract: In “Colossus,” the director, Mark Hendrickson, creates a vérité documentary about an “artificial band” that is all about manipulation.
lead_paragraph: A mindblower of a mockumentary, “Colossus” will leave you reeling in the best of ways, dizzy from a rock ’n’ roll Tilt-A-Whirl that swirls with duplicity and hilarity. At its core is a vérité documentary by a Cockney-spouting producer, Clark Larson, about his “artificial band” of mostly Americans, living for three months in a house in Russia.

headline: He Didn’t Save the World, Just 669 Children
abstract: “Nicky’s Family” documents how Nicholas Winton, now 104, gave up a 1938 skiing holiday to answer a friend’s request for help in Prague and didn’t stop helping until the war’s beginning stopped him.
lead_paragraph: In 1988 a BBC talk show, “That’s Life,” invited Nicholas Winton, then 79, to sit in the front row of the studio audience while his good works were praised. He had saved the lives of 669 children, most of them Jewish, in Nazi-occupied Czechoslovakia with his own personal Kindertransport. The woman sitting next to him at the show was one of them. And if you don’t feel teary when Mr. Winton learns on the air that virtually everyone in the audience that day had been one of those children, you have no heart.

headline: Spare Times for Children for July 19-25
abstract: A listing of cultural events for children, teenagers and families.
lead_paragraph: CITY OF WATER DAY

headline: Comic-Con: What Channel Are They Promoting Again?
abstract: The stars on a TV Land panel at Comic-Con make it clear they’re there to discuss new shows, not, say, a certain beloved science-fiction series that boldly went where no program had gone before.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO – As always, the good ship Comic-Con comes with a lot of barnacles – offerings that really don’t belong at a convention dedicated to science fiction and fantasy but nonetheless come along for the ride. A good promotional opportunity has a way of making shame evaporate.

headline: Spare Times for July 19-25
abstract: A listing of walking tours, cultural events and more in New York.
lead_paragraph: ‘Bronx Rising!’: Screening and Discussion (Friday) For those with ties to Puerto Rico, the pre-Lenten Carnival in Ponce, which is several centuries old, is as joyous a celebration as Mardi Gras in New Orleans. And while Carnival is not such a big deal in New York, the Puerto Rican Day Parade is. Scattered among the marchers at the annual parade in New York are devilish figures known as vejigantes, wearing colorful and often fierce-looking masks similar to those found in Ponce.

headline: Plans for a Messy Fight Spur Concern of Harm, to the Battlefield
abstract: It’s called Tomato Battle, and it involves thousands of people paying for the chance to splatter one another with, yes, tomatoes. But the national park where it will be held has its own defenders.
lead_paragraph: On Friday, 40,000 pounds of tomatoes will be delivered to Floyd Bennett Field, the old municipal-airport-turned-park by Jamaica Bay in Brooklyn. There are no plans for a giant salad or a record-setting pasta sauce; these tomatoes will meet a more violent end, when up to 5,000 people are expected to pay $50 for the chance to hurl the fruit of the Solanum lycopersicum at one another.

headline: From Diapers to Throne
abstract: The BBC documentary “Born to Royalty” uses archival images of the royal family, going back to Queen Victoria, ostensibly to tell a story about changing royal parental styles.
lead_paragraph: Is there such a thing as a birth vulture? If there is, then that is both the subject and the format of the BBC documentary “Born to Royalty.” The film’s release this week was timed to coincide with Kate Middleton’s due date for the latest heir to the British throne.

headline: Tributes and Celebrations for Mandela
abstract: Across the country, South Africans spent 67 minutes helping others on Nelson Mandela’s 95th birthday as a tribute to his 67 years of public service.
lead_paragraph: Across the country, South Africans spent 67 minutes helping others on Nelson Mandela’s 95th birthday as a tribute to his 67 years of public service.

headline: Protests Ignite After Putin Critic Is Sentenced to Jail
abstract: Alexei Navalny, an opposition figure and fierce critic of President Vladimir V. Putin, was sentenced to five years in jail for theft.
lead_paragraph: Alexei Navalny, an opposition figure and fierce critic of President Vladimir V. Putin, was sentenced to five years in jail for theft.

headline: Feeding on Memories
abstract: There’s nothing flashy about the subjects of “The Romeows” — Retired Older Men Eating Out Wednesdays — but what they’ve created matters.
lead_paragraph: “There’s something historical about us,” says one of the Romeows, a crew of septuagenarians that generally meets every Wednesday in Brooklyn for dinner and conversation. He’s right, and history should record their weekly — but rare — achievement more often. Thank goodness this gentle, affectionate documentary does it.

headline: Death as a Youthful Mystery
abstract: Gustavo Ron’s “Ways to Live Forever” is a forthright and surprisingly buoyant drama about facing death before you have really lived.
lead_paragraph: A little wan but a lot likable, Gustavo Ron’s “Ways to Live Forever” is a forthright and surprisingly buoyant drama about facing death before you have really lived.

headline: An Ocean Theme, From Dishes to Décor
abstract: Porthole sconces and starboard lanterns complete the picture at Eastchester Fish Gourmet.
lead_paragraph: Eastchester Fish Gourmet, the restaurant affiliate of the fish market of the same name, is merrily bobbing on the swells of 26 successful years. Known by regular patrons as E.F.G., this soignée seafood house excels at turning fresh catches into beautiful plates of food for a crowd, seven days a week, under pressure.

headline: Winery for Sale in Cutchogue
abstract: Specializing in hard cider, the Peconic Bay Winery, including a tasting room and 25 acres of planted vineyards, is on the market.
lead_paragraph: In 2010 the Peconic Bay Winery in Cutchogue, having some empty tanks on hand, used them to make hard cider experimentally. Today about 50 accounts carry the ciders in Suffolk and Nassau Counties, according to James Silver, the general manager. Production has grown to 18,000 in 2012-13 from 960 bottles in 2010.

headline: HPV Vaccine Found to Help With Cancers of Throat
keywords: ['Head and Neck Cancer', 'Human Papilloma Virus (HPV)', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Women and Girls', 'Cervarix (Vaccine)']
abstract: A vaccine that protects women against cervical cancer also appears to protect them against throat cancers caused by oral sex, according to a study released Thursday.
lead_paragraph: A vaccine that protects women against cervical cancer also appears to protect them against throat cancers caused by oral sex, and presumably would protect men as well, according to a study released Thursday.

headline: An Abundance of Options
abstract: Fresh Hamptons offers customized meals, for those with particular appetites.
lead_paragraph: Fresh Hamptons, in Bridgehampton, is an East End homecoming of sorts for Todd Jacobs, who first gained renown with a six-year stint as executive chef at the American Hotel in Sag Harbor, starting in 1988. He went on to open his own restaurant, Tierra Mar, in Westhampton (since closed), then owned the Atlantica restaurant, first at the Westhampton Bath and Tennis Hotel, then at the Allegria Hotel in Long Beach.

headline: The Sun, the Moon, the Tapas
abstract: The Solun Tapas Bar and Restaurant in Woodbridge, Conn., which opened in March 2012, specializes in Spanish cuisine with a twist.
lead_paragraph: Solun Tapas Bar and Restaurant is the sort of place that makes a great first impression. Its brick red color scheme, with splashes of mango yellow and a pair of wall panels partitioned into yellow, blue and red, presents a cheerful, festive air. Then there’s the can-do quality of the staff, from the welcoming hostess to the service crew. And the food, if not quite on the level of fine dining, is often prepared well enough to put diners in a good mood.

headline: Monte dei Paschi, Venerable Italian Bank, Yields to Change
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Hoping to attract new capital, shareholders in the bank, based in Siena, Italy, voted to end a longstanding tradition of local control and patronage.
lead_paragraph: SIENA, Italy — Ending a five-century tradition of local control and patronage, shareholders of the troubled bank Monte dei Paschi di Siena voted on Thursday to lift ownership restrictions and encourage new outside investors, in a move that may lead to similar changes at Italy’s other big banks.

headline: This Week’s Movies: July 19, 2013
abstract: The New York Times movie critics on “The Conjuring,” “The Act of Killing” and “Computer Chess.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times movie critics on “The Conjuring,” “The Act of Killing” and “Computer Chess.”

headline: The Bigger Picture
abstract: Philip Galanes answers questions about social situations.
lead_paragraph: I am a single guy and online dater. My profile lists my attributes honestly, and I include pictures taken only within the last year. I often get responses from women who have read my profile, looked at my pictures and want to meet me. But their profiles don’t include any pictures of themselves. They claim that, for professional reasons, they do not want to include photographs in their profile. How does this strike you?

headline: A Slice of Jamaica, in Vibrant Flavors
abstract: Blue Marlin Restaurant, recently reopened in Bradley Beach by Roy Reid, is not a fish house but offers island cuisine.
lead_paragraph: Blue Marlin Restaurant, despite its name and its proximity to the Jersey Shore, is not a fish house. Instead, it is a culinary playground for Roy Reid, who in March reopened the restaurant that he ran with his family on this same spot in Bradley Beach from 1991 to 2003.

headline: Old Friends Confront Dreams Deferred
abstract: “Big Words” is a wistful tapestry of male disaffection that explores weighty themes like race, class, sexual orientation, politics and the evolution of rap music.
lead_paragraph: Unfolding in Brooklyn on the night of President Obama’s 2008 election, “Big Words” explores weighty themes with a very light touch.

headline: Navalny on Putin, Being Bugged and Revolution
abstract: Aleksei A. Navalny rose to prominence as an anticorruption blogger with a special knack for turning a memorable phrase.
lead_paragraph: Aleksei A. Navalny rose to prominence as an anticorruption blogger with a special knack for turning a memorable phrase.

headline: Prosper and Live Long: Health-Minded Manhattan Leads in Increased Life Span
abstract: A new analysis attributed the increase to gentrification and to a healthier lifestyle.
lead_paragraph: Since 1985, the life expectancy for Manhattan residents has increased more than that of any other county in the country, according to a new analysis, which attributed the increase to gentrification and to a healthier lifestyle.

headline: Wendy Davis and the Odds She’s Facing
keywords: ['Elections, Governors', 'Filibusters and Debate Curbs', 'ABORTION', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: After gaining the spotlight in her filibuster of legislation to restrict abortions, Senator Davis, a Fort Worth Democrat, is being urged to enter the uphill race for governor.
lead_paragraph: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: Promoting Health Insurance Exchange, With No Help From State
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Local Government']
abstract: Private organizations are working to educate Texans about coverage options through the federal health insurance exchange, which opens on Oct. 1.
lead_paragraph: Texas officials have declined to establish a state-based health insurance marketplace, a major provision of the federal Affordable Care Act. So private organizations are working to educate Texans about coverage options through the federal health insurance exchange, which opens on Oct. 1.

headline: In ‘RED 2,’ Retired Special Ops Agents Can’t Relax
abstract: In the action-comedy “RED 2,” retired agents and mercenaries aren’t content to kick back; they load their guns to save the world from nuclear disaster.
lead_paragraph: The gag, or one of three, in Dean Parisot’s action-comedy sequel “RED 2” is that its killer oldsters are unflappable not because they’re too cool but because they’re seen-it-all semi-retirees. And after surviving the adventures of “RED,” these comfortably recognizable agents and mercenaries are now doubly experienced and casual. Sociopathic assassins drop in like son of a guns, and fusillades of bullets come and go like passing showers, but Bruce Willis, John Malkovich and Helen Mirren will still trade relationship advice and in-jokes like old friends on a package tour.

headline: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
abstract: The Department of Defense has identified 2,233 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Defense has identified 2,233 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: Rifts Over Fees and Taliban Sour Afghanistan Exit
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: There is a growing willingness by Afghan officials, from the president’s office down through the ministries, to publicly counter what they see as American arrogance.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — If the ease of the American exit from Afghanistan is based on the supply of Afghan good will, it has been a troubling and potentially very costly week for the United States.

headline: Discussing Furlough Concerns at Military Bases, Hagel Has ‘No Good News’
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions']
abstract: Over three days visiting military bases across the southeastern United States this week, Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel told everyone that compromise in Washington was unlikely.
lead_paragraph: JOINT BASE CHARLESTON, S.C. — Sandra Walker used respectful tones as she spoke, but there was iron in her voice when she confronted Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel about sacrificing 11 days of pay because Congress and President Obama could not agree on taxes and spending.

headline: Scissors, Shaver and Salvation for a Young Barber
abstract: The job of custom barber is a Colombian teenager’s ticket to a world beyond his poor family and rough past in “La Playa D.C.”
lead_paragraph: Tomas, the slim teenager from Bogotá, Colombia, in Juan Andrés Arango García’s film “La Playa D.C.,” has a few options for rising above his financially struggling family and rough past. He could continue unloading goods at a market, shine hubcaps on parked cars or just hop a bus out of town. But what captures his imagination is an unlikely-sounding vocation: custom barber. For a young Afro-Colombian like Tomas, who is harassed by security guards at the mall, it’s a way of finding strength in a heritage that is all too often used against him.

headline: A Race Without a Finish Line
abstract: In 24-hour racing, the goal for runners is not to shave off seconds toward a finite distance, but to push themselves a few miles more before the time runs out.
lead_paragraph: Steven Ireland’s first race was not exactly a predictor that he would become an amateur ultramarathoner.

headline: Romanian’s Tale Has Art World Fearing the Worst
abstract: Ashes from the oven of a Romanian woman contain paint and nails, indicating that she may have burned seven works stolen from a Dutch museum. Her son has been arrested in the theft.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — To Olga Dogaru, a lifelong resident of the tiny Romanian village of Carcaliu, the strangely beautiful artworks her son had brought home in a suitcase four months earlier had become a curse.

headline: Vivendi Declined SoftBank’s Lucrative Offer for Universal
abstract: The Japanese phone carrier’s proposal of $8.5 billion for Universal Media Group was believed by some analysts to represent a $2 billion premium over its value.
lead_paragraph: Vivendi, the French media and telecommunications conglomerate, rejected an $8.5 billion cash bid from SoftBank for the Universal Music Group, even though it represented a premium of at least $2 billion more than some analysts’ estimates of Universal Music’s value, according to a person briefed on the offer.

headline: Art World Fears Fate of Missing Masterpieces
abstract: A Romanian gang behind the theft wants to cut an unspecified deal with the authorities so the artwork can be returned.
lead_paragraph: A Romanian gang behind the theft wants to cut an unspecified deal with the authorities so the artwork can be returned.

headline: $55 Billion: The Cost of Summer 2013
abstract: When you add up the camps, sports, programs, pool memberships and child care, how much will summer cost your family this year?
lead_paragraph: In 2012, a survey of American families from the American Express Spending and Saving Tracker found that parents expected to spend an average of $601 per child on summer fun (which can also mean child care). Affluent families, defined as those with household incomes of $100,000 or more, expected to spend nearly double that: $1,116 per child.

headline: Cuban Jews Find an Israeli Olympics With a Higher Purpose
abstract: Cuba is one of 21 countries participating for the first time in the 19th Maccabiah Games, a quadrennial international sporting event known as the Jewish Olympics.
lead_paragraph: RISHON LeZION, Israel — Roxana González, 25, and her brother Rafael, 24, had barely picked up a bow and arrow since their days as champion high school archers in Cuba. So when they arrived here two weeks ago, they began practicing five hours a day at a dusty archery range, preparing to compete in the Maccabiah Games, a quadrennial international sporting event known as the Jewish Olympics.

headline: New Jersey Supreme Court Restricts Police Searches of Phone Data
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Police', 'Cellular Telephones', 'Supreme Courts (State)', 'Search and Seizure']
abstract: The state’s top court said that, in most instances, the police must obtain a warrant before they can obtain tracking information about a suspect.
lead_paragraph: Staking out new ground in the noisy debate about technology and privacy in law enforcement, the New Jersey Supreme Court on Thursday ordered that the police will now have to get a search warrant before obtaining tracking information from cellphone providers.

headline: Frolicking in a Musical Metropolis Playground

headline: Lawsuit Against Ex-President of Mexico Is Dismissed
abstract: The suit was filed against former President Ernesto Zedillo by 10 anonymous plaintiffs who said they were survivors of a 1997 massacre.
lead_paragraph: A United States District Court judge in Connecticut on Thursday dismissed a civil lawsuit against former President Ernesto Zedillo of Mexico that was filed by 10 anonymous plaintiffs who said they were survivors of a 1997 assault. Judge Michael P. Shea said he was deferring to a request for immunity for Mr. Zedillo submitted by the State Department last year. The two-year-old lawsuit had sought $50 million in damages against Mr. Zedillo, who now leads a research institute at Yale University. Members of the indigenous group that was the target of the assault, known as Las Abejas, or the Bees, said they did not know the plaintiffs and disassociated themselves from the suit. Mr. Zedillo was president in 1997 when paramilitary gunmen fired on members of the group taking refuge from fighting in the southern state of Chiapas and killed 45 people, including 18 children.

lead_paragraph: Though he has long cultivated an image as a strong man, President Vladimir Putin of Russia actually seems weak and insecure, a judgment reinforced every time he manipulates the system to crush a potential political rival. Mr. Putin did so again on Thursday. A Russian court convicted Aleksei Navalny, a lawyer and charismatic opposition leader who was running for mayor of Moscow, of stealing $500,000 from a state-controlled timber company and sentenced him to five years in prison. The charges and heavy punishment were a transparent retaliation for Mr. Navalny’s campaign against public corruption and Mr. Putin’s United Russia political machine as a party of “swindlers and thieves.”

headline: No Political Motive Behind Killing of Assad Supporter, Lebanese Officials Say

The motive for the killing of the commentator, Mohammed Darrar Jammo, was personal and not political, Mr. Hajj said. He said Mr. Jammo’s wife left the door to the couple’s home open so the killers could enter. Lebanese authorities forwarded the arrest warrant to Syria, where the wife is believed to have fled after the killing. Mr. Jammo’s public role as a defender of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria prompted suspicions that Mr. Assad’s opponents had killed him. But the Lebanese Army said in a statement that the killing was not politically motivated.

headline: What’s On Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (TCM) FRIDAY NIGHT SPOTLIGHT: THE FILMS OF FRANÇOIS TRUFFAUT A monthlong tribute to this film critic turned director, and mainstay of the French New Wave, continues with “The Soft Skin” (1964). The movie shows Alfred Hitchcock’s influence on Truffaut, and his own preoccupation with the romantic triangle, through the story of a literary scholar (Jean Desailly), his wife (Nelly Benedetti) and the flight attendant (Françoise Dorléac) who comes between them. The lineup continues at 10 with “Jules and Jim” (1962), adapted from Henri-Pierre Roché’s 1953 semi-autobiographical novel and starring Jeanne Moreau as a tempestuous beauty who drives a wedge between college friends (Henri Serre, above center, and Oskar Werner, with Ms. Moreau). In “Two English Girls” (1972), at midnight, a young writer (Jean-Pierre Léaud, who served as Truffaut’s alter ego as a young man) carries on love affairs with two sisters (Kika Markham and Stacey Tendeter). Truffaut shares the directing credit with Jean-Luc Godard in “A Story of Water” (1961), a short film inspired by a severe flood in Paris, at 2:15 a.m. And in “The Woman Next Door” (1981), at 2:30, former lovers (Gérard Depardieu, whom Truffaut chose as his stand-in during his later years, and Fanny Ardant, Truffaut’s real-life love at the time) find themselves unexpectedly reunited after seven years as neighbors in a French village. The marathon wraps at 4:30 with “The Man Who Loved Women” (1977), with Charles Denner as an inveterate womanizer (the beauties are portrayed by Brigitte Fossey, Nelly Borgeaud, Geneviève Fontanel and Leslie Caron, among others) who tries to make sense of his problems by writing his memoirs.

headline: News Quiz | July 19, 2013
abstract: See what you know about the news of the day.
lead_paragraph: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Jobless Rate in New York City Rose Slightly in June
abstract: The unemployment rate rose to 8.4 percent from 8.3 percent in May, though economists said it was a sign of growth and indicated an increase in the number of people wanting to work.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s unemployment rate edged up to 8.4 percent in June even though employers had been steadily adding jobs all year, the State Labor Department reported on Thursday.

headline: Leading Putin Critic Is Freed Pending Appeal After Protests
abstract: A day after his conviction on embezzlement charges incited protests, Aleksei A. Navalny was released from custody.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Not even 24 hours after a judge ordered him handcuffed and imprisoned to begin a five-year sentence for embezzlement, the Russian political opposition leader, Aleksei A. Navalny, walked free — temporarily, at least, pending an appeal.

headline: In Maine, a Growing Heroin Menace
abstract: In 2013, a surge in heroin use in Maine contributed to a rash of fatal overdoses.
lead_paragraph: In 2013, a surge in heroin use in Maine contributed to a rash of fatal overdoses.

lead_paragraph: Take the Quiz

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | On the Cover of Rolling Stone
abstract: Why did the chain stores CVS and Walgreens say they would not sell the latest issue of Rolling Stone magazine?
lead_paragraph: In “CVS and Walgreens Ban an Issue of Rolling Stone,” Noam Cohen writes about criticism that the latest cover of the magazine glamorizes the surviving suspect in the Boston Marathon bombings.

headline: Hong Kong Seizes Smuggled Elephant Tusks
abstract: The seizure of 1,148 tusks underscored the challenges facing Africa’s dwindling elephant populations as rising prosperity in Asia leads to greater demand for ivory.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Customs officials in Hong Kong on Friday announced one of the largest seizures of smuggled ivory ever made in the city — and their fifth since October — highlighting the pervasiveness of a trade that conservationists describe as an all-out crisis for elephant populations in Africa.

headline: Wresting the Narrative From the West
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Photography', 'Social Media', 'Third World and Developing Countries']
abstract: An initiative started in Bangladesh aims to put people around the world in charge of their own storytelling, and challenge the often-shallow portrayals by Western media.
lead_paragraph: As far as Shahidul Alam is concerned, he does not live in the third world or the developing world. While the photographer’s home is in Bangladesh, a decidedly poor country, he thinks of himself as residing in “the majority world.”

headline: Australia Adopts Tough Measures to Curb Asylum Seekers
abstract: A policy to deal with a record number of asylum seekers would deny permission to settle in the country to anyone who arrived by boat without a visa.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Prime Minister Kevin Rudd of Australia moved on Friday to curtail the record number of people trying the dangerous boat journey to claim asylum in the country, pledging that no one who arrives by boat without a visa will ever be granted permission to settle in Australia.

headline: New York Today: Derailed
abstract: What you need to know for Friday: the hottest day yet, commuter woes, and hailing ice cream cones.
lead_paragraph: A messy freight train derailment in the Bronx on Thursday night snarled the morning commute and is likely to disrupt service for days.

headline: Why We Fire Lenders (and Borrowers)
abstract: A loan broker writes that it is important for both parties in a loan negotiation to be forthright in their dealings.
lead_paragraph: As a loan broker, I have to balance the needs and demands of buyers and sellers in order to get deals done. In my world, buyers are small-business owners who want to borrow money, and sellers are firms who want to lend money for a return. Transparency and honesty from both sides always helps us get to the finish line faster.

headline: From Egypt With Love
keywords: ["Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat", 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Egyptians’ relationship with the United States seems as personal as it is political, and I’ve watched it shift from infatuation to disappointment.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Someone hung a large full-color banner in the center of the roundabout near my apartment during the demonstrations on June 30. It featured Anne W. Patterson, the U.S. ambassador to Egypt, with a red “X” across her face and the caption “Spinster, Go Home!” Patterson is married, coincidentally, but her purported bachelorette’s status was meant as a slur: Independent, single women are often viewed with pity or distrust in Egypt’s patriarchal culture. And however ludicrous an insult, “spinster” is more restrained than “pitch,” as the ambassador is frequently called in protest signage — Egyptians often confuse the English letters “p” and “b.”

headline: Summer Reading Contest | What Interested You Most in The Times This Week?
abstract: The sixth week of our Summer Reading Contest will be judged by editors at Edutopia.
lead_paragraph: In The Times this week: Many pieces about the heat and diversions from it, including a front-page story about the wait to see the temporary installation “Rain Room” at the Museum of Modern Art.

headline: Sheik Sells Stake in Barclays
abstract: Sheik Mansour bin Zayed al-Nahyan was part of a group of Middle Eastern investors who helped Barclays avoid a government bailout at the height of the financial crisis.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – More than four years after helping Barclays avoid a government bailout at the height of the financial crisis, Sheik Mansour bin Zayed al-Nahyan of Abu Dhabi has sold his stake in the bank.

headline: Banks Could Be Victims of Their Own Success
abstract: Banks’ strong earnings could end up undercutting their arguments against more regulation. | As it prepares to settle with JPMorgan, an energy regulator is expected to spare a top bank lieutenant. | Dell bought itself six more days to drum up support for the proposed buyout. | A former colleague of Fabrice Tourre was in the spotlight on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: BANKS COULD BE VICTIMS OF THEIR OWN SUCCESS  | The nation’s six biggest banks reported $23 billion of profit in the second quarter, strong earnings that could end up undercutting their arguments against more regulation, DealBook’s Peter Eavis writes. With regulators and lawmakers recently stepping up efforts intended to make the largest banks safer, those banks have warned that more regulations could hurt their ability to compete and curtail their lending. The most pressing concern for banks is a relatively tough new rule that could force banks to build up more capital.

headline: Ex-Brokers Appear in Court in Libor Case
abstract: Two former brokers at RP Martin Holdings made their first court appearance in London on Friday in connection to charges tied to the manipulation of global benchmark interest rates.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Two former brokers at RP Martin Holdings made their first court appearance in London on Friday in connection to charges tied to the manipulation of global benchmark interest rates.

headline: G-20 Backs Plan to Curb Tax Avoidance by Large Corporations
abstract: The plan aims at corporations only and, if widely adopted, would shift some of the global tax burden away from small businesses and individuals.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The world’s richest economies for the first time endorsed a blueprint on Friday to curb widely used tax avoidance strategies that allow some multinational corporations to pay only a pittance in income taxes.

headline: The Straphangers’ Fold
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A subway rider was identified as a veteran New Yorker by the way he folded his newspaper.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: British Open Second Round: Jimenez Weathers Conditions Best
abstract: Live updates of the second round of the 2013 British Open from Muirfield
lead_paragraph: After a steamy first round left players muttering about Muirfield’s linoleum-hard fairways and greens, British Open organizers ordered the greens watered and the pin placements adjusted. But they couldn’t do anything about the shifting wind, and by the end of the day, the course was just as hard and even more misery-inducing.

headline: Dear Parents: Please Ignore the Latest Research
abstract: No matter how earth-shattering that new research study looks, it probably doesn’t have much to do with being a parent.
lead_paragraph: Sometime soon—today, this week, this month—there will be a new and sensational study about small humans. There always is.

headline: Michigan Judge Rules Against Bankruptcy Push
abstract: The officials said the city’s bankruptcy filing gave Detroit “breathing room” to continue operating as it copes with its long-term debts and obligations.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Gov. Rick Snyder of Michigan on Friday defended his decision to force Detroit into bankruptcy as a necessary step to halt its decades-long decline and resolve its spiraling debt crisis. But even as he was pleading for patience during the lengthy process ahead to fix the city’s finances, a state judge was ruling that the governor had overstepped his authority by approving the city’s bankruptcy filing.

headline: NetApp Adds Directors Amid Push for Changes
abstract: The addition of two directors to the board of NetApp at the urging of the activist hedge fund Elliott Management hints at a possible push for a sale.
lead_paragraph: NetApp Inc. quietly announced last week that it planned to add two directors to its board. But their qualifications may hint that the decision to appoint them did not just come out of thin air.

headline: Survey in China Shows a Wide Gap in Income
abstract: The disparities are especially evident when comparing earners in top-tier coastal cities and those in interior provinces.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Results of a wide-ranging survey of Chinese family wealth and living habits released this week by Peking University show a wide gap in income between the nation’s top earners and those at the bottom, and a vast difference between earners in top-tier coastal cities and those in interior provinces.

headline: The Past Is Not Dead, but Faulkner Case Against ‘Midnight in Paris’ Is Dismissed
abstract: In dismissing a lawsuit brought by the rights holders of Faulkner’s novels against the studio that released the Woody Allen film, a judge said he was thankful he was not asked “to compare ‘The Sound and the Fury’ with ‘Sharknado.'”
lead_paragraph: A courtroom face-off between the film studio that released Woody Allen’s “Midnight in Paris” and the rights holders of William Faulkner’s novels did not yield any terrific legal sparks. But it may have produced a noteworthy literary creation in the form of a thoughtful and funny decision from the judge overseeing the case.

lead_paragraph: A Delhi court ruled Friday that Anil D. Ambani, the billionaire chairman of Reliance Group, and his wife, Tina, will have to testify in the investigation of the government’s sale of telecommunications licenses at below-market prices.

abstract: AT&T’s $1.19 billion acquisition agreement with Leap Wireless includes two strong provisions intended to protect the deal from competing bids. Are such merger protections likely to become more commonplace?
lead_paragraph: The $1.19 billion AT&T acquisition of Leap Wireless International is an illustration in how far bidders and acquisition targets can go these days to protect against competing offers.

lead_paragraph: The men of Team America were missing an assault rifle. “Everybody pulled a rifle, right, guys?” Eric asked. A 38-year-old ex-Navy lieutenant, he had blond hair to his shoulders and a few days’ worth of deployment stubble.

headline: A Donation Deal Goes Awry
abstract: The plan was to give $10,000 each to the other’s charity of choice. He cheated.
lead_paragraph: I’m on the art-museum board, so that is my preferred artistic donee. An acquaintance repeatedly called me for a donation to the opera. I don’t like opera. I said he should donate to the art museum. He said he’d give to the museum whatever I gave to the opera. We agreed on $10,000 apiece. He called the next four years and offered to make the same deal. I accepted each year. As I was looking through our donor list for unrelated reasons, I discovered he has been giving only $1,000 a year. I sent him an e-mail telling him of my discovery, and he responded, “Nailed me.” As if it were funny. What is my ethical response? Demand my excess back from the opera? Threaten to sue him if he doesn’t pony up to the museum? Gossip?  T.S., LOCATION WITHHELD

headline: The 7.7.13 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.

headline: Who Made That Hair Dryer?
abstract: The 20th-century tool for 20th-century dos.
lead_paragraph: In 1888, Alexandre-Ferdinand Godefroy, a French coiffeur inventeur  — that’s hairstylist inventor — patented the hair dryer’s earliest ancestor. The contraption was to be hooked up “to any suitable form of heater,” which would send hot air through a pipe to a dome surrounding the woman’s head. The device was impressively multipurpose: to use it for shampooing, Godefroy suggested removing all pieces except one resembling the brim of a sombrero, which fastened around a woman’s head to redirect suds into the sink. (“Still another use to which the device may be applied,” Godefroy wrote, “is that of shaping wig-holders.”)

headline: I Jumped In to Save the Child. But Who Would Rescue Me?
abstract: A haunting summer afternoon in Central Park.
lead_paragraph: In the distance, a small, black triangle rose from the surface of the pond, then shifted slightly. “Look at the turtle,” I said to my son, who was 9 at the time. On that late-summer afternoon, we had ridden our bicycles to one of our favorite spots in Central Park. Just west of Cleopatra’s Needle, and across from the statue of a mounted Polish warrior (arms raised, swords crossed), lies a sylvan vista called Turtle Pond — a small body of water, its rocky shore ringed with greenery. It was perpetually alluring to my urban child, even in that season when the water was covered with a thick carpet of bilious algae.

headline: ‘I’m Good. I’m Really Good. Damn I’m Good.’
abstract: How competitive is too competitive?
lead_paragraph: Five days before my father died, I beat him at Ping-Pong. The table was in the lower level of Toronto’s Art Gallery of Ontario, part of a children’s art center where we could deposit my son for a convenient half-hour. Some administrator at the gallery is obviously a genius: it’s clear to me now that every art gallery in the world should have some means available for playing table tennis. Hitting little white balls with miniature paddles over a waist-high table turns out to be the perfect conclusion to a day spent looking at paintings with rambunctious children in tow.

headline: Following Public Dots to a Missing Phone
abstract: After leaving an iPhone in the backseat of a taxi, a software solution to getting it back.
lead_paragraph: In retrospect, I should have checked the cab seat when I got out. I should have taken the receipt. And maybe I should have had more empathy for those people, like my daughters, who have lost their smartphones.

headline: Litvinenko Inquiry Blocked to Avoid Upsetting Russia, British Official Suggests
keywords: ['International Relations', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Poisoning and Poisons']
abstract: Home Secretary Theresa May wrote that “international relations” had been a factor in blocking a public inquiry into the death of Alexander V. Litvinenko, a former K.G.B. agent.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British authorities said publicly for the first time on Friday that concern for “international relations” had been a factor in blocking a public inquiry into the poisoning death of Alexander V. Litvinenko, a former K.G.B. officer, an apparent reference to their desire to avoid upsetting the Kremlin.

headline: Why the Surface RT Failed and the iPad Did Not
abstract: At first glance, the Apple iPad and Microsoft Surface RT tablet computer look somewhat similar. But the Surface RT has not sold well. Here’s a theory why.
lead_paragraph: At first glance, to most consumers, the Apple iPad and Microsoft Surface RT tablet computer look somewhat similar. They are both rectangular, have crisp screens and can boast a slick and clean design interface.

headline: Metro-North Line Is Tied Up After a Freight Train Derails
abstract: Service on the Hudson line was suspended, disrupting the morning rush for thousands of commuters, after a freight train derailed overnight in the Bronx.
lead_paragraph: Riders on one Metro-North Railroad line slogged through a day of snarled service on Friday, with promises of further disruptions into the weekend, as crews worked to clear a derailed freight train blocking the tracks near the Spuyten Duyvil station in the Bronx.

headline: Feeling For | Lanvin’s Cool Necklace Beats the Heat
abstract: Offering a new take on “statement jewelry,” this piece from Alber Elbaz’s fall collection is available this week at Bergdorf Goodman.
lead_paragraph: This quirky script necklace from Lanvin offers a new take on “statement jewelry.” It caused a stir when it hit the runway back in February, and it’s finally available this week at Bergdorf Goodman. Alber Elbaz presented other pieces in the collection featuring the words “happy,” “love” and “help,” but with temperatures in the 90s in New York right now, this one spells out the best way to crank up your cool factor while beating the heat.

lead_paragraph: What Mexican migrants leave behind once they make it to America.

headline: Kashmir Seethes Under Curfew After Troops Kill Four
keywords: ['Curfews', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Police', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Kashmir is under curfew after four slain protesters were buried in Ramban district of the troubled region.
lead_paragraph: The government in the northern state of Jammu and Kashmir imposed a curfew on Kashmir Valley and some districts of Jammu region on Friday after India’s paramilitary Border Security Force troops and local police killed four protesters and injured over 40 in the Ramban district of the state.

headline: Honda Expands Fit Recall; Honda, Yamaha, G.M. Announce Recalls
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Automobiles', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: Honda announced that it would expand a recall of Honda Fit models due to a problem with the vehicle’s electronic stability control system. Honda, Yamaha and G.M. also announced recalls.
lead_paragraph: Following tests by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, Honda is recalling about 48,000 additional 2012-13 Fit models because the electronic stability control system may not stop a skid as quickly as it should, according to a report posted recently on the agency’s Web site.

headline: Live From the NYPL Announces Fall Season
abstract: Talks at the New York Public Library will feature authors including Margaret Atwood and Alice Waters, and Warren Buffett and Nico Muhly will also appear.
lead_paragraph: Margaret Atwood, Lorrie Moore, Alice Waters, Michael Connelly, Toni Morrison and Warren E. Buffett will be among the headliners in the fall season of the Live From the NYPL series, which begins Sept. 17 at the Celeste Bartos Forum of the New York Public Library.

headline: How Interval Training Can Make You Incredibly Efficient at Work
abstract: Just as runners find that short, intense workouts are a good way to train, bursts of single-minded tasks can help us be far more efficient with work, the author writes.
lead_paragraph: As a runner, I’ve spent most of my adult life training aerobically, meaning I run for extended periods of time – 30 to 60 minutes – at a pace I find challenging but perfectly tolerable.

headline: Video Reviews of ‘The Conjuring,’ ‘The Act of Killing’ and ‘Computer Chess’
abstract: Times critics on “The Conjuring,” “The Act of Killing” and “Computer Chess.”
lead_paragraph: In this week’s video, Times critics offer their thoughts on “The Conjuring,” “The Act of Killing” and “Computer Chess.” Read all of this week’s reviews.

headline: Amy Arbus’s One-Woman Show With a View
abstract: The photographer makes her home in a high-rise in Greenwich Village.
lead_paragraph: It’s the amenities more than her particular apartment that have kept the photographer Amy Arbus living in a banal beige-brick doorman building in the heart of Greenwich Village for 20 years. “I love the staff,” she said of the “Mad Men”-era behemoth with Barcelona chairs and a hotel-like concierge desk in the airy, glass-walled lobby. “I love the gym. I love the swimming pool on the roof!”

headline: Russian Government Decides Against Recreating Museum Shut by Stalin
abstract: The decision comes after a dispute between museums that hold paintings that were in the Museum of New Western Art.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The Russian government has decided against reuniting two prerevolutionary art collections that include works by Picasso and Matisse. The decision sets to rest, for now at least, a dispute that was addressed directly to President Vladimir V. Putin on live national television and prompted a monthslong war of words between the State Pushkin Museum of Fine Arts in Moscow and the State Hermitage Museum in St. Petersburg.

headline: 007 Goes Rogue
abstract: William Boyd, the author of a forthcoming novel starring James Bond, says the literary character is “a far more complex, nuanced and intriguing figure than his celluloid counterpart.”
lead_paragraph: William Boyd, who reviews Henning Mankell’s latest novel in this issue, was a teenager when he first read Ian Fleming’s James Bond novels. “The thrill of reading them was almost illicit — they seemed so glamorous and daring,” he told me in an e-mail interview. “The feeling I experienced was that you were being given access to a world known and enjoyed by a very, very few. The ‘members only’ sign had been removed.”

headline: Kill Your Darlings
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers', 'Hunting and Trapping']
abstract: A writer relies on skills he learned as a hunter.
lead_paragraph: As an avid big-game hunter and a professional writer, I’m often asked how I reconcile these seemingly contradictory passions. It’s easy to imagine what people have in mind: the contemplative author in a lamp-lit study juxtaposed with the wilderness brute, arms sunk to the elbows in animal viscera. While I recognize the gulf that separates these two images, the skills required for hunting and writing are remarkably similar, even complementary.

headline: Kerry Achieves Deal to Revive Mideast Talks
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry said Israel and the Palestinian Authority had agreed to join him in Washington in hopes of resuming formal talks for the first time since 2010.
lead_paragraph: AMMAN, Jordan — Israeli and Palestinian leaders have “established a basis” to resume direct peace negotiations for the first time in three years, Secretary of State John Kerry announced Friday, after an intense round of shuttle diplomacy aimed at reviving the dormant Middle East peace process.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: MY LUNCHES WITH ORSON: Conversations Between Henry Jaglom and Orson Welles,  edited by Peter Biskind. (Metropolitan/Holt, $28.) These chummy, rambling chats, recorded in Welles’s twilight, roam from chicken salad to chic romantic capers.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: SHINE SHINE SHINE,  by Lydia Netzer. (St. Martin’s Griffin, $14.99.) For the picture-­perfect couple in Netzer’s finely textured first novel, “normal” is an illusion. Maxon Mann, a Nobel Prize-winning scientist, is on a mission to populate the Moon with robots, but his safe return is far from certain. Meanwhile, back home, Maxon’s conflicted (and heavily pregnant) wife, Sunny, has been left to care for their autistic 4-year-old son and her dying mother.

headline: Watery Graves
abstract: Ivy Pochoda’s “Visitation Street” is a mystery about a disappearance, set against the changing neighborhood of Red Hook, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: People can never tell the exact moment their old neighborhood disappears. One day, everybody knows where you came from and where you’re going; the next, you don’t recognize a soul. VISITATION STREET (Dennis Lehane/Ecco/HarperCollins, $25.99), a powerfully beautiful novel by Ivy Pochoda, lingers on the moment the ­working-class neighborhood of Red Hook, Brooklyn, changed forever: the night 15-year-old June Giatto went out into the Upper Bay in a pink raft with her best friend, Val Marino, and never returned. Nothing was the same after that: developers discovered the historic waterfront, initiating a gentrification that was swift and unstop-pable. Even the longshoremen’s bars had their history “buffed and polished away.” But on the night June disappeared, families still lived in the shabby row houses and worked at blue-collar jobs while their children dreamed of sailing away on a pink raft.

headline: They’ve Got a Secret
abstract: The Bank for International Settlements, a central bank for bankers, operates without disclosure.
lead_paragraph: Adam LeBor’s history of the Bank for International Settlements, “Tower of Basel,” reads a little like a financial version of “Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead,” the Tom Stoppard play that places two minor characters in “Hamlet” in the forefront of the action while the drama’s major events unfold incomprehensibly in the background. In LeBor’s telling, the B.I.S., an obscure “bank for central banks” set up in Basel, Switzerland, in 1930 to facilitate World War I reparations payments from Germany, has been a critical, if secretive, actor in the global economy for more than 80 years. Today, he writes, it is “the most important bank in the world,” an institution with virtually no accountability, and yet “for decades it has stood at the center of a global network of money, power and covert global influence.”

headline: Who She Knew
abstract: The formidable doyenne of 19th-century expatriate Florence.
lead_paragraph: Janet Ross was one of those Lady Bracknell-like dragons for whom the word “formidable” was practically invented. Born in London in 1842, she spent the last six decades of her life — from 1867 until her death in 1927 — as an increasingly commanding personage in the Anglo-Tuscan colony around Florence, where she was known (and feared) as Aunt Janet. Ben Downing freely acknowledges near the beginning of “Queen Bee of Tuscany” that Ross “had her limitations. Though intelligent and learned, especially for an autodidact, she was by no means brilliant. She had little imagination or inner life, and she made no towering contribution to humanity.” Thus the biog­rapher throws down his own gauntlet: Why, then, are we reading about her?

headline: Exit, Voice
abstract: The life of the oddly obscure economist Albert O. Hirschman.
lead_paragraph: The life that the economist Albert O. Hirschman lived in the 1980s and early ’90s was the stuff of an intellectual’s most self-aggrandizing daydreams. There were honorary degrees (at least a dozen), prestigious prizes (wouldn’t you want a Thomas Jefferson Medal from the American Philosophical Society?) and conference after conference held in his honor. It’s customary for a distinguished professor to get a “Festschrift” of writings by students and disciples; Hirschman got four.

headline: Baser Instincts
abstract: Rebecca Lee’s characters are driven, and confounded, by their desires.
lead_paragraph: I could spend this entire review pulling beautiful lines out of Rebecca Lee’s textured and nuanced new story collection, “Bobcat.” There are the piquant ones, echoing Flannery O’Connor: “In my experience, you would no more expect to find peace within a family than you would expect to find it in yourself.” Or the perceptive descriptions, as pert as Lorrie Moore’s: “She went twice a week to a tanning salon and bleached her hair frequently, so that it looked like radioactive foliage growing out of dark, moody sands.” The collection has so many good passages — whole paragraphs that move into pages with never a misstep — that any linguaphile could spend a great afternoon in a little spasm of dazzle.

headline: July 19: Where the Candidates Are Today
abstract: The candidates’ daily campaign schedule at a glance.
lead_paragraph: Planned events for the mayoral candidates, according to the campaigns and organizations they are affiliated with. Times are listed as scheduled but frequently change.

headline: Low Vitamin D Tied to Aging Problems
abstract: A new study has found that low vitamin D levels in people over 55 are associated with an inability to perform ordinary tasks of daily life.
lead_paragraph: A new study has found that low vitamin D levels in people over 55 are associated with an inability to perform ordinary tasks of daily life.

headline: Academic Affairs
abstract: A graduate student is obsessed with her professor’s wife in Susan Choi’s novel.
lead_paragraph: Susan Choi’s new novel starts out on familiar territory: the attraction between a precocious young woman and an intellectually charismatic older man. Regina is a 21-year-old graduate student taking literature classes at an unnamed East Coast university; Nicholas Brodeur is her celebrated professor, graced with “exceptional, even sinister, attractiveness.” Yet “My Education,” Choi’s fourth book, only feints toward the conventional novel, with the standard affair between student and professor. Just when Regina and Nicholas seem about to sleep together, he is superseded in Regina’s affections by his 33-year-old wife, Martha, on maternity leave from a teaching position at the same university. One night at a dinner party, Regina trails the older woman out the back door and kisses her, and we find ourselves on a less familiar campus than we’d thought.

headline: The Hunted
abstract: Edward Hoagland’s adventure-seeking protagonist is swept up in the chaos of southern Sudan.
lead_paragraph: In the late 1970s, the novelist and travel writer Edward Hoagland spent several months in Sudan, which was then Africa’s largest country and one of its most fragile. There he observed the deepening divide between the Arab north and the black Christian south, exacerbated by “demoralizing poverty” and the influence of militant Islam. His account of his journey, “African Calliope,” wove encounters with government ministers and Dinka cattle herders, expatriate businessmen and Khartoum taxi drivers into a portrait of a country struggling for unity yet tipping toward civil war.

headline: On Their Own Terms
abstract: In Henning Mankell’s novel, a Swedish brothel keeper and her prostitutes confront racism and sexism in Portuguese East Africa.
lead_paragraph: We forget, in these postcolonial times, that until comparatively recently the world was replete with empires. I was born in a corner of the British Empire, in West Africa, in a colony known as the Gold Coast, and the Africa of those days (the early 1950s) was divided among several empires: British, French, Belgian, Spanish and Portuguese (the Germans having been expelled in World War I and their colonies appropriated).

headline: ‘My Favors Cost a Great Deal’
abstract: The life of 19th-century Paris’s most famous kept woman belies the legend.
lead_paragraph: In 1847, shortly before 23-year-old Marie Duplessis, one of 19th-century Paris’s most celebrated courtesans, died of consumption, she told her maid, “I’ve always felt that I’ll come back to life.” Her prophecy came true: she found enduring fame in the work of a former conquest, Alexandre Dumas fils, “La Dame aux Camélias” (there’s a newly translated version by Liesl Schillinger, a regular contributor to the Book Review), as well as in “La Traviata,” the opera Verdi based on Dumas’s novel and play.

headline: No Honeymoon
abstract: The women behind the men of NASA’s early years.
lead_paragraph: The most iconic telling of our great national myth of space conquest, Tom Wolfe’s book “The Right Stuff,” opens with a scene of a wife frantically imagining that her husband has died. The woman, Jane Conrad, has been informed by a growing chorus of fellow officer wives that something has happened at the Jacksonville Naval Air Station, where her husband, Pete, is a test pilot. Jane knows what something means. She can all but see Pete’s mangled, charred remains lying amid the palmetto grass, the smoking wreckage of his aircraft strewn about. As the minutes tick by, she grows increasingly panicked and calls the office of Pete’s squadron. They refuse to answer her questions. She hangs up and waits for her doorbell to ring, now certain of her fate. Her husband is dead. (We learn on the next page that he is, in fact, alive. A decade and a half later, Pete Conrad walks on the moon.)

headline: Through Enemy Lines
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: A biography of Christine Granville, one of Britain’s most daring and highly decorated World War II special agents.
lead_paragraph: Christine Granville was one of the bravest, toughest and strangest secret agents of World War II. Her feats of derring-do included acting as a courier in Nazi-occupied Europe, parachuting into France in support of the Allied invasion and rescuing three of her comrades from certain execution. She was said to be Winston Churchill’s favorite spy — a considerable accolade given how much Britain’s wartime prime minister liked spies. She may have been the model for Vesper Lynd, the female agent in Ian Fleming’s first James Bond novel, “Casino Royale.” She won medals for bravery from both Britain and France. Men found her irresistible, and she did very little to resist them.

headline: What’s Cooler Than Cool? 78 Degrees on the A.C.

lead_paragraph: For the past several years, I’ve spent some portion of the summer on a lake in the South, where the regularity of high temperatures leaves the heat rarely a subject of discussion. It is not considered a mark of lunacy, for instance, to play golf in the middle of the afternoon when it is 95 degrees with a humidity level that feels Amazonian; country clubs ventilate their greens with huge standing fans. People don’t lament that they aren’t in Brittany or Nova Scotia (as I do in New York nearly every 90 minutes from mid-June to September). Complaining about the heat would be like complaining about having to carry a MetroCard.

lead_paragraph: After distinguished careers, some prominent string quartets disband. Others, like the Emerson String Quartet, replenish their ranks. In its first change of membership since 1979, the cellist Paul Watkins replaces David Finckel (who joined the group that year). On Sunday, the Emerson makes its American debut with Mr. Watkins, who is also music director of the English Chamber Orchestra. It will demonstrate its mettle with a new member with two of Beethoven’s “Razumovsky” string quartets and Britten’s String Quartet No. 3. (4:30 p.m., Venetian Theater, 149 Girdle Ridge Road, Katonah, N.Y., 914-232-1252, caramoor.org; $15 to $40.)

headline: Fighting the ‘White Man’s War’
abstract: The Battle of Honey Springs was one of the only Civil War engagements where the majority of the combatants were non-white.
lead_paragraph: Three miles down a gravel road near Rentiesville, Okla., sits a portable building that, for now, serves as the headquarters for the Honey Springs Battlefield State Historic Site. Here, on July 17, 1863, one of the Civil War’s most unique, consequential — and forgotten — battles took place. The Battle of Honey Springs was one of the few engagements in which the majority of the combatants were nonwhite, and it played an outsize role in the future of the Indian Territory, long after the war ended.

headline: Let’s Shake Up the Social Sciences
abstract: It is time to create new social science departments that reflect the breadth and complexity of the problems we face as well as the novelty of 21st-century science.
lead_paragraph: TWENTY-FIVE years ago, when I was a graduate student, there were departments of natural science that no longer exist today. Departments of anatomy, histology, biochemistry and physiology have disappeared, replaced by innovative departments of stem-cell biology, systems biology, neurobiology and molecular biophysics. Taking a page from Darwin, the natural sciences are evolving with the times. The perfection of cloning techniques gave rise to stem-cell biology; advances in computer science contributed to systems biology. Whole new fields of inquiry, as well as university departments and majors, owe their existence to fresh discoveries and novel tools.

headline: Reveling in a Bookstore’s Smell
abstract: The young-adult fiction writer Brittany Geragotelis spends her Sundays with her husband and their cats in a combination of work and play.
lead_paragraph: After 10 years of rejection by the publishing industry, Brittany Geragotelis, a writer of young-adult fiction, turned to the Internet. In 2011 she uploaded her paranormal action novel, “Life’s a Witch,” to the writing site Wattpad, and things started looking up. The book generated 19 million reads, which led to a deal for a book series with Simon & Schuster. It published the first book in the series in January; the second, a retooled version of “Life’s a Witch,” was released this month. For Ms. Geragotelis, 34, Sundays involve gluten-free foods, books, television and one-on-one time with her husband, Matt Gielen, 30. The couple share an apartment on the Upper East Side with their cats, Murray and Cohen. They are newlyweds, married this year on April Fools’ Day.

headline: My Mademoiselle Summer
abstract: Like Sylvia Plath and Joan Didion before her, Meg Wolitzer spent the summer as a guest editor at Mademoiselle. A look back at a time both heady with promise and tinged with the sadness of an era about to end.
lead_paragraph: As I lay drowsing in bed at the Barbizon Hotel for Women, the maid began slamming her fist against my door like a D.E.A. agent, and I popped up, briefly disoriented, taking in the grim, narrow room, the orange and yellow bedspread, the clothes I’d laid out on the armchair the night before. Slowly, I rose from my bed and took my shower caddy down the hall, nodding to a few of the other girls — or were we women now? I wasn’t sure.

headline: Scenes From Maine, and an Artist’s Life
abstract: An exhibition shows Frederic Edwin Church’s passionate engagement with the transcendental in nature while also revealing unexpected sides of the artist.
lead_paragraph: In his long, globe-trotting career, the great American landscape painter Frederic Edwin Church (1826-1900) depicted icebergs, jungles, deserts and, of course, the Hudson River, which he could see from his hilltop estate. But before any of that, in 1844, he was newly apprenticed to Thomas Cole, the most eminent artist of the Hudson River School. And he was probably paying close attention as Cole filled several canvases with scenes from a recent trip to Maine.

headline: Panama: Former Spy Returns to U.S.
abstract: Italy’s justice minister protested saying that the request for the extradition of the former C.I.A. officer, Robert Seldon Lady, based on an Interpol warrant, “has been disregarded without plausible explanations.”
lead_paragraph: A former Central Intelligence Agency officer who was detained in Panama on Thursday in connection with a criminal conviction in Italy was released and flew to the United States on Friday, American officials said. Italy’s justice minister, Anna Maria Cancellieri, protested, saying in a statement that Italy’s request for the extradition of the former C.I.A. officer, Robert Seldon Lady, based on an Interpol warrant, “has been disregarded without plausible explanations.” Mr. Lady is a former chief of the agency’s station in Milan, and one of 26 agency employees and contractors charged in the 2003 abduction in Milan of a radical Muslim cleric, Hassan Mustafa Osama Nasr, also known as Abu Omar. The cleric was taken to Egypt, where, he said, he was tortured, and the case fueled a public debate over the American practice of extraordinary rendition.

headline: Surveillance Court Renews Order for Phone Call Data
abstract: The Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court has approved a new order for collection of bulk data on phone calls in the United States.
lead_paragraph: The Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court has approved a new order for collection of bulk data on phone calls in the United States, allowing the National Security Agency to continue a practice that has been criticized by some members of Congress and the public. In a statement Friday, the office of the director of national intelligence announced that the court, which operates largely in secret, had permitted the N.S.A. to continue to collect phone logs, which do not include the actual contents of the calls. The original order disclosed last month by Edward J. Snowden, an N.S.A. contractor, expired Friday.

headline: Massachusetts: DNA Match Made in Strangler Case
abstract: The remains of a man who confessed he was the Boston Strangler match the DNA profile of bodily fluids found at the last of the crime scenes attributed to the serial killer.
lead_paragraph: Law enforcement officials in Boston on Friday announced that the remains of a man who confessed he was the Boston Strangler match the DNA profile of seminal fluid found at the last of the crime scenes attributed to the serial killer. Although Albert DeSalvo, a convicted rapist, confessed to the strangler murders, he was killed in prison and never prosecuted for them. Scientists recently extracted a DNA profile from seminal fluid found on and near the body of Mary Sullivan, who was strangled in 1964. After finding a familial match between that sample and one taken from a nephew of Mr. DeSalvo, investigators last week exhumed Mr. DeSalvo’s body to confirm the match.

headline: What’s On Saturday

lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (HBO) THE BOURNE LEGACY (2012) Jeremy Renner (above), replacing Matt Damon as the lead in this fourth installment, stars as the superspy Aaron Cross, on the run when the secret intelligence campaign (code name: Outcome) that produced him is compromised, leaving Cross and his fellow operatives to be eliminated under orders from a retired Air Force Colonel (Edward Norton). Rachel Weisz plays the geneticist who helped to create Cross and who may be his only hope for staying alive. While the director Tony Gilroy “retains some of the Bourne bequest, he’s also created a tricky parallel universe with a new agency that has its own clenched-jawed, closed-door complications and a hero who nearly becomes lost among them,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times about these films inspired by the Robert Ludlum novels. But while some of the action here flows nicely, she added, the three previous movies “conveyed a sense of urgency that mirrored Bourne’s shattered being and his propulsive, convulsive journey from unenlightened self-interest to accountability, from the existential question mark of his identity to a hard moral reckoning.” Jason Bourne “was still trying to find the answers,” she said. “Now with Bourne gone, Mr. Gilroy needs to find other questions worth asking.” “The Bourne Identity” (2002), the first film in the series, will be shown on A&E at 8; “The Bourne Supremacy” (2004), the second, will be shown on Starz at 7:05.

headline: Down-Home Fiddling the Way It Really Used to Be
abstract: Howard Rains, 43, is trying to bring back an old-time style of Texas fiddling that was popular between the Civil War and World War II.
lead_paragraph: During the mid-19th and early 20th centuries, a distinctive form of fiddle music emerged in Texas. Known for idiosyncratic timing and phrasing, this style was commonly played with banjos or guitars on front porches or in living rooms, less for show than for social interaction. It reflected the cross-pollination in Texas after the Civil War, with touches of African-American, Appalachian, Cajun, Czech, German, Irish, Mexican, Polish and Scottish musical forms.

headline: What’s on Sunday

(Fox) AXE COP A sneak peak of Animation Domination High-Def, a late-night programming block overseen by Nick Weidenfeld, an alumnus of Adult Swim, begins with this adaptation of the Internet comic created by the brothers Malachai and Ethan Nicolle when they were 5 and 29, respectively, about an ax-wielding hero, above, (voiced by Nick Offerman) who sleeps two minutes a night, subsists on birthday cake and battles villains. “It’s a nonsensical but inventive and purely entertaining takeoff on superhero tales ,” Mike Hale wrote in The New York Times. “The animation is serviceable, and the show gets a vital boost from the voice performance of Nick Offerman, whose mock solemnity works as well for a mildly fascistic superhero as it did for a middle-American bureaucrat in ‘Parks and Recreation.’ ” “High School USA!,” at 9:45, “a broad and dull spoof of the Archie gang” created and written by Dino Stamatopoulos, best known for playing Star-Burns on “Community,” “slides down the wall quickly,” Mr. Hale added. headline: Explaining My Adoption to My Biological Daughter

lead_paragraph: “Mama, what does adopted mean?” my daughter asked me one day last year, to my great surprise. For some reason I was shocked that she even knew the word. Of course she couldn’t know what it meant, because I had never explained the word, or told her I was adopted—even though as an adoptee, my family and my life have been formed by adoption, and knowledge of it is something I have always taken for granted.

headline: Ear for French, and Renewed Reverence for Verdi
abstract: The music festival at Caramoor presented the 1884 version of “Don Carlos” in French, and it glowed with the ideals of the French Revolution.
lead_paragraph: KATONAH, N.Y. — In this bicentenary year, much will be made of Verdi’s status in Italian history. The music festival at Caramoor, with its current focus on Verdi in Paris examines the French connection. On Saturday it presented the 1884 version of “Don Carlos” sung in French, the language in which it was originally written. Blessed with a stellar cast of singers and an impassioned Orchestra of St. Luke’s under the direction of Will Crutchfield, this pivotal masterpiece of Verdi’s glowed with the ideals of the French revolution.

headline: Jeff Goldblum Joins Cast of ‘Domesticated’
abstract: Mr. Goldblum will join Laurie Metcalf in Bruce Norris’s new play this fall at Lincoln Center Theater.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Goldblum will join Laurie Metcalf this fall in the Lincoln Center Theater production of “Domesticated,” a new work by the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright Bruce Norris (“Clybourne Park”), the company announced on Sunday. Commissioned by Lincoln Center Theater, “Domesticated” is about a politician and his wife whose marriage is put in jeopardy by a scandal. The play is to begin preview performances Off Broadway at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater on Oct. 10, with opening night set for Nov. 4. The director will be Anna D. Shapiro (“August: Osage County”), who has directed several of Mr. Norris’s plays, including “The Unmentionables” and “The Pain and the Itch.”

headline: Serenading Isis With the Hypnotic Vibration of the Universe
abstract: The band Om played its rhythmic drones at the Temple of Dendur at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
lead_paragraph: The music of the band Om boils down song to rhythmic drones and chants and ancient scales, played on electric bass and drums with touches of electric guitar and analog modular synthesizer. For a decade, it has been both post-everything and pre-everything — quiet, methodically repetitive, possibly fed by Alice Coltrane and doom metal and Gregorian chant, but directly attached to none of those. It’s not for everyone. It’s either dull or the oneness.

headline: So Many Sons: The Faces of a Nation’s Slaughter

Got off the boat five months ago — just me and me ma.” Turning with military precision, the soldier (Michael Thomas Walker) quietly exits.

headline: Nothing to See Here: Demoting the Uncertainty Principle
abstract: Let’s put an end to the misuse of quantum physics to validate outlandish metaphysical claims.
lead_paragraph: “You’ve observed the robbers. They know it. That will change their actions,” says Charlie Eppes, the math savant who helps detectives on television’s “Numbers.” Eppes claims that this insight follows from quantum physics, in particular, Werner Heisenberg’s infamous “uncertainty principle.” Not all mischaracterizations of Heisenberg’s principle are as innocent as Eppes’s. The film “What the Bleep Do We Know!?” uses it to justify many articles of faith in New Age philosophy. Asserting that observing water molecules changes their molecular structure, the film reasons that since we are 90 percent water, physics therefore tells us that we can fundamentally change our nature via mental energy. Fundamentally inaccurate uses of the principle are also common in the academy, especially among social theorists, who often argue that it undermines science’s claims to objectivity and completeness. As Jim Holt has written, “No scientific idea from the last century is more fetishized, abused and misunderstood — by the vulgar and the learned alike — than Heisenberg’s uncertainty principle.”

abstract: The water will soon flow more freely on the Penobscot River, another step in the nationwide movement to restore native ecosystems.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, a demolition crew will begin removing the Veazie Dam on the Penobscot River just above Bangor, Me. The Veazie is the lowest of the Penobscot dams and closest to the river’s mouth on the Maine coast. It is also critical to the entire Penobscot River watershed, which covers nearly a third of the state. Thanks to the work of the Penobscot River Restoration Trust and its partners, the lower river will be free-flowing once again, allowing the revival of a complex migratory ecosystem once teeming with fish working their way up from the sea.

headline: New York Is Not Detroit. But ...

abstract: This city, too, has made promises that will be hard to keep.
lead_paragraph: In a half-century of public life, Richard Ravitch has been lieutenant governor of New York, head of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, a mayoral candidate, an adviser to many politicians and an instructor of many journalists in the wonkier aspects of governance. headline: Tomatoes Take Center Stage
abstract: Summer brings a bounty of tomatoes. Here are five ways to put them to delicious use.
lead_paragraph: Whenever July rolls around I look forward to testing recipes for what is now my annual Recipes for Health tomato week. My own tomatoes are ripening on the vine, and tomatoes are the main event at farmers’ markets. There is little room in my repertoire at this time of year for dishes that don’t include tomatoes, but this week I kept it pretty simple. headline: Feeling For | A Face Serum With Some Serious Kick
abstract: This British skincare product will rouse you from even the worst summer doldrums.
lead_paragraph: I sometimes have a hard time getting going on summer mornings, an unfortunate byproduct of triple-digit heat indexes and rosé nightcaps. Enter the Revitalise & Glow Serum, an amazing product from the new British skin-care line Aurelia Probiotic Skincare, which opened its first store in England earlier this month. Just two drops of the lightweight hydrating fluid — which smells of creamy mandarin with hints of jasmine, plumeria and tuberose — is enough to wake me up and give my skin a sun-kissed feeling that lasts all day. The immediate economic impact is likely to be small and possibly mildly stimulative, but it does appear to be a sign that a deeper financial overhaul is in the works.

lead_paragraph: Everything new this week was old. Paleontologists in Utah discovered a cowlike species of dinosaur (about 65 million years old), and archaeologists in Scotland found what may be the world’s first lunar calendar (10,000 years old). Meanwhile, astronomers tell us that all of Earth’s gold was formed by ancient stars colliding (more than 4.5 billion years ago) and that there is a moon orbiting Neptune we all somehow failed to notice (also quite old).

headline: Unpacking a New Life
abstract: These backpacks, found not far from Tucson, were discarded by Mexican migrants who used them to carry the clean clothes they would need after they crossed the border into the U.S.
lead_paragraph: Last weekend’s Look featured a wall of backpacks. But they were more than schoolbags or knapsacks, despite all the Adidas and Puma and Nike branding, the cartoon decorations (Bart Simpson, the Tasmanian Devil), the soccer insignia, the corporate trademarks (Levitra, HSBC). They were used by Mexican migrants crossing into the United States to carry the clean clothes in which they hoped to start new lives in America. And, as the photographer Richard Barnes puts it: “Metaphorically, they were a vessel to help get these people across the border, where they strip them away and become new people. They’re also a potent example of globalization. You can see all the logos — like Ralph Lauren and a lot of knockoffs that are sold on the border — and you realize what a small world we live in.”

headline: Fort Tells of Spain’s Early Ambitions

lead_paragraph: In the Appalachian foothills of western North Carolina, archaeologists have discovered remains of a 16th-century fort, the earliest one built by Europeans deep in the interior of what is now the United States. The fort is a reminder of a neglected period in colonial history, when Spain’s expansive ambitions ran high and wide, as yet unmatched by England.

headline: ‘Smile’ and Other Difficulties
abstract: Van Dyke Parks discusses his new “Songs Cycled” compilation, working with Brian Wilson and never quite fitting in musically.
lead_paragraph: It is a quaintly old-fashioned idea, but it suits Van Dyke Parks perfectly. Partly to celebrate his 70th birthday, and partly because he has not released an album of his own in nearly two decades (he has, instead, been producing other musicians’ discs and writing film music), Mr. Parks built his new “Songs Cycled” CD from tracks he has released on 7-inch singles in recent years. In a way the compilation recalls the albums of the 78 r.p.m. days, which often collected five or six singles between cardboard covers.

Violence between supporters and opponents of the ousted president has gripped Egypt since his removal from power on July 3.

headline: Italy’s Artistic Upstart, the Maxxi Museum, Strives to Make a Splash
abstract: Italy’s fledgling national contemporary art museum is struggling to establish a durable presence.
lead_paragraph: ROME — It’s hard enough to be the new attraction in town when you’re up against some of the world’s most famous ancient Roman, Renaissance and Baroque monuments. But Italy’s national museum for art of the 21st century, known as the Maxxi, faces even bigger challenges: attracting a Roman audience, so far largely indifferent, and establishing a reputation on the international scene while the government is sharply cutting financing for the arts.
