lead_paragraph: There’s a performance-art aspect to the strange parliamentary procedure known as the filibuster. As anyone who watched the recent, much publicized filibusters of Senator Rand Paul and the Texas State Senator Wendy Davis knows, viewers eventually lose track of the speaker’s topic, drawn in instead by his cadences, mannerisms and tics. (For the record, Paul’s filibuster was against the theoretical use of drones on American citizens inside the United States; Davis’s against her state’s attempt to ban all abortions after 20 weeks from conception.)

headline: The Complex Story of Race and Upward Mobility
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Income Inequality', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Metropolitan areas with large African-American populations tend to have lower rates of upward mobility. But lower-income whites in those regions also face longer odds of moving up economically.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:35 p.m. |

headline: Revolution Fund Invests $40 Million in E-Commerce Start-Up
abstract: The Revolution growth fund, started by Stephen M. Case and two former AOL colleagues, has invested in Bigcommerce, a start-up whose software helps companies create and manage online stores.
lead_paragraph: Stephen M. Case, the co-founder of AOL, sees a future in helping companies sell goods online.

headline: Pride Stays, Even After the Fall
abstract: Cate Blanchett plays a wealthy woman who has lost her money and her bearings in “Blue Jasmine,” directed by Woody Allen.
lead_paragraph: When Cate Blanchett first cruises into Woody Allen’s “Blue Jasmine,” playing a Park Avenue matron fallen on hard times, she looks like a million bucks. She’s wearing pearls and a white Chanel jacket, with an Hermès bag as big as a Shetland pony hanging off one arm. It’s the sort of important accessory worn by women accustomed to being chauffeured around town. Soon after, though, as she stands with her monogrammed luggage on a nondescript San Francisco sidewalk, she looks frightened, alone — like someone who could benefit from some kindness. Instead, she waves off a stranger and, posing a question that’s as existential as it is practical, demands, “Where am I, exactly?”

headline: Virginia Johnson, Widely Published Collaborator in Sex Research, Dies at 88
abstract: Ms. Johnson and William H. Masters helped make the frank discussion of sex in postwar America possible if not downright acceptable.
lead_paragraph: Virginia E. Johnson, a writer, researcher and sex therapist who with her longtime collaborator, William H. Masters, helped make the frank discussion of sex in postwar America possible if not downright acceptable, died on Wednesday in St. Louis. She was 88.

headline: Online Marketer Settles Privacy Charges
abstract: PulsePoint agreed to pay $1 million to settle charges that the company had circumvented certain users’ privacy settings that blocked some targeted ads.
lead_paragraph: Even as digital advertisers and privacy advocates are trying to come to an international consensus that would give consumers more control over online tracking, a well-known advertising technology company has agreed to pay $1 million to settle charges that it circumvented certain users’ privacy settings.

headline: Spanish Train Crash Captured on Video
abstract: Security-camera footage leaked to the public via YouTube captured the moment on Wednesday that a passenger train derailed outside Santiago de Compostela in northwestern Spain, killing at least 78 people.
lead_paragraph: Last Updated, 5:39 p.m. Security-camera footage leaked to the public via YouTube captured the moment on Wednesday that a high-speed passenger train derailed outside Santiago de Compostela in northwestern Spain, killing at least 80 people.

headline: 77 Years Later, Yacht Repeats Win in Trans-Pacific Race
abstract: Dorade, a 52-foot wooden sailboat considered the forebear of modern racing yachts, captured the Los Angeles-to-Honolulu race this week, echoing its 1936 victory.
lead_paragraph: It took a thousand or so miles of sailing with the long, powerful waves of the Pacific Ocean for Hannah Jenner, a rising star in ocean racing, to get comfortable in this year’s Transpacific Yacht Race. Jenner, a 31-year-old from Britain, is used to racing ultralight 40-footers across oceans. But in the Transpac this month, Jenner was sailing Dorade, a 52-foot wooden sailboat from 1930 that is trimmed in varnished mahogany and adorned with polished bronze hardware.

headline: Second Opposition Leader Assassinated in Tunisia
keywords: ['Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: The killing of Mohamed Brahmi, leader of the People’s Party, incited protests blaming the moderate Islamic party that leads the government in Tunisia, birthplace of the Arab Spring.
lead_paragraph: TUNIS — With a brazen hail of bullets, gunmen assassinated a prominent opposition leader on Thursday as his family watched, inciting nationwide outrage and exposing a deepening political divide in Tunisia, the last bastion of relative stability among the Arab countries convulsed by revolutionary upheavals over the past two years.

headline: In the Universe of Printers, One Worth Talking About
abstract: A home laser printer from Hewlett-Packard has a weird name. But don’t let that fool you.
lead_paragraph: Say what you want about the evil of printer companies.

headline: Suspension Is Testing Friendship of Two Stars
abstract: Aaron Rodgers and Ryan Braun are two California natives who found sporting success and friendship in Wisconsin. Until now.
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — Sports brought Ryan Braun and Aaron Rodgers to Wisconsin, Braun as the slugging star of the Milwaukee Brewers, Rodgers as the Super Bowl-winning quarterback who made Green Bay Packers fans forget Brett Favre.

headline: Music Made Visible in Pop Documentaries
abstract: The Film Society of Lincoln Center’s musical documentaries series, “Sound + Vision,” includes a broad variety of subjects, including Cuban rappers and a New Orleans pianist.
lead_paragraph: We’re living in a golden age of music documentaries. Ever more affordable filmmaking tools and the Internet seem to have left few of history’s obscure pop mysteries unexplored.

headline: Weiner Admits to More Lewd Exchanges but Denies an Addiction
abstract: Anthony D. Weiner, who is running for New York City mayor, said he had inappropriate online contact with at least three women after leaving Congress.
lead_paragraph: Anthony D. Weiner’s mayoral campaign entered a dark and chaotic phase on Thursday as he admitted to having explicit online relationships with at least three women since he left Congress, and the woman at the center of the latest scandal appeared on television, remembering him as a “perpetually horny middle-aged man.”

headline: Gotham’s Only Black Millionaire
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Civil War (US) (1861-65)', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: The strange life of Jeremiah G. Hamilton, one of New York City’s first black tycoons.
lead_paragraph: Writing to Frederick Douglass in 1852, the black intellectual James McCune Smith noted Jeremiah G. Hamilton as “the only black millionaire in New York,” disparaging him for the crassness of his pursuit of wealth. But despite Hamilton’s prominence in his own lifetime, modern American historians have ignored him.

headline: Sirius XM Reports Record Revenue, Aided by Auto Recovery
abstract: The satellite-radio company reported $940 million in revenue for the quarter, and an increase of 716,000 in subscribers to 25.1 million.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, Wall Street was closely focused on Netflix’s second-quarter results of 28.6 million subscribers and revenue of roughly $1 billion. On Thursday, another fast-growing subscription media company was in the spotlight: Sirius XM Radio reported $940 million in revenue for the quarter, a record for the company and more than most analysts had expected.

headline: Living With Cancer: A Quilt of Poetry
abstract: Taking inspiration from a number of cancer poets, Susan Gubar pieced together a quilt of poetry to convey the feeling of chaos so common among people with cancer.
lead_paragraph: In her book “My Poets,” Maureen McLane reminded me of a poetic form called the cento. It consists of snippets of verse composed by other writers.

headline: 2 Koreas Fail to Agree on Terms to Reopen Factory Complex
abstract: The sixth round of talks this month over the project ended without a date for further discussions on the Kaesong industrial park.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — South and North Korea threatened to terminate their last remaining joint economic project on Thursday after they failed to narrow differences over reopening the project, a jointly operated industrial complex at Kaesong just north of the border the countries share.

headline: When New York Teetered on the Brink of Bankruptcy
abstract: In October 1975, Mayor Abraham D. Beame signed a formal petition attesting to municipal default, but at the last minute, the city dodged the financial fate that Detroit suffered last week.
lead_paragraph: One by one, guests on the multi-tiered dais of the annual white-tie Alfred E. Smith Memorial Foundation benefit dinner slipped away for secret negotiations to resolve the city’s fiscal crisis. Mayor Abraham D. Beame returned to Gracie Mansion early to confer with fellow formally attired city officials, then slept fitfully, knowing the grave decisions he faced the next morning.

headline: Larry Kramer Is Married in Hospital Ceremony
abstract: The playwright and activist married his longtime partner, David Webster, on Wednesday, days after undergoing surgery at NYU Langone Medical Center.
lead_paragraph: Larry Kramer, the award-winning playwright of “The Normal Heart” and longtime gay rights advocate, married his partner, David Webster, on Wednesday in the intensive care unit of NYU Langone Medical Center, where Mr. Kramer has been recovering from surgery for a bowel obstruction. Mr. Webster, in a telephone interview on Thursday, said the couple had set the wedding date a few weeks earlier, before Mr. Kramer’s health flare-up.

headline: Love and Marriage and Birth and Breakup, All in Mythical Proportions
abstract: In his debut novel, Matt Bell describes the trajectory of a relationship between a man and a woman in an unnamed land.
lead_paragraph: A newly married couple, flush with love and possibility, leave everyone and everything they know to forge a life for themselves. But not long after they move into their new house, their infatuation fades. Carefree youthful courtship is replaced by the burdens of adult responsibility. The wife, who grew up in an abusive household, finds herself subjected to her husband’s abuse. She has multiple miscarriages, but he keeps pressuring her to try to have children. When she conceives again, he convinces himself that she is faking her pregnancy; and when she gives birth, he is certain that the child is not his. As the wife devotes herself to her child, the husband grows jealous. Jealousy and estrangement lead to separation; the husband succumbs to violent and self-destructive impulses and fantasies. Only many years and trials later do the husband and wife arrive at some sort of hard-won reconciliation.

headline: Who Is New York City’s Greatest Parallel Parker?
abstract: Anyone who drives in the Big Apple will eventually have to parallel park, and as we all know, some are better at that skill than others.
lead_paragraph: Everyone who drives in New York City eventually has to parallel park, and often in some pretty tight spaces. To show off their city-savvy 2014 Spark, Chevrolet on Wednesday held the Park-a-Spark Challenge, aiming to crown New York’s best parallel parker. And I was one of the contestants.

headline: The Brutality of ‘Corrective Rape’
abstract: In South Africa, “corrective rape” — the rape of gay men and lesbians to “cure” them of their sexual orientation, is often condoned by family members, and ignored by the authorities.
lead_paragraph: In South Africa, “corrective rape” — the rape of gay men and lesbians to “cure” them of their sexual orientation, is often condoned by family members, and ignored by the authorities.

headline: Discount Elvis in Memphis
abstract: Finding the admission fee for Graceland’s tour beyond his budget, Seth Kugel goes hunting for cheap Elvis souvenirs.
lead_paragraph: Finding the admission fee for Graceland’s tour beyond his budget, Seth Kugel goes hunting for cheap Elvis souvenirs.

headline: Scientists Trace Memories of Things That Never Happened
abstract: Scientists say they have created a false memory in a mouse, providing detailed clues to how such memories may form in human brains.
lead_paragraph: The vagaries of human memory are notorious. A friend insists you were at your 15th class reunion when you know it was your 10th. You distinctly remember that another friend was at your wedding, until she reminds you that you didn’t invite her. Or, more seriously, an eyewitness misidentifies the perpetrator of a terrible crime.

headline: Memphis on the Cheap: Elvis, Barbecue and Baseball
abstract: Part 2 of the Frugal Traveler’s summer road trip takes him to Memphis, where he searches for the tacky and the tasty while (generally) trying to avoid the touristy.
lead_paragraph: “Mawl medium hot?” asked the server at Craig’s Bar-B-Q, a white clapboard shack with church basement furniture, smoke-tinted walls and a cash-only policy in DeValls Bluff, Ark., about an hour and a half west of Memphis, Tenn.

headline: Action Off the Mountains in Salt Lake City
abstract: Thanks to a recent surge of places to eat, shop and explore, downtown Salt Lake City is offering new reasons to visit, even outside ski season.
lead_paragraph: As an occasional Utah visitor, I’ve viewed downtown Salt Lake City like many other travelers who find themselves in the area: as a place to gas up the rental car as I race to the airport after a ski vacation in Park City or Alta. The word “interesting” rarely found itself in the same company with “downtown Salt Lake.” Its urban core was nearly vacant after dark, with few residents and even fewer restaurants and attractions. The double-length blocks and yawning streets hardly welcomed tourists or residents, either — the streets platted so wide, history tells, so pioneers could easily turn around their four-ox teams.

headline: Cancer Risk Increases With Height
abstract: Height is associated with a greater risk of cancer for both men and women, new research shows.
lead_paragraph: A woman’s cancer risk appears to increase with her height, a new study shows.

headline: Stiglitz, Minsky, and Obama
abstract: Inequality or excess leverage?
lead_paragraph: I haven’t commented so far on the president’s economic speech, except to mock the journalists demanding “new ideas” for a very old-fashioned economic crisis. And as many people have pointed out, there weren’t any actual policy proposals.

headline: A Dinner Party at Every Table
abstract: Feast searches for a midpoint between the tasting menu and the humble satisfactions of a smorgasbord.
lead_paragraph: I did not expect the dish described as “bacon and egg” to appear in a tart shell the size of my palm. It was three mouthfuls at most, of pork belly in repose on creamy grits, with a puffy poached quail egg like a stranded cloud on top. Cute, I thought, and then I took a bite. Strike that: it was debauched, a welcome flicker of deviltry in an otherwise rather regimented restaurant.

headline: A Restored Louisiana Plantation and Its Lifeblood
abstract: A plantation being restored in Wallace, La., will encourage visitors to reflect on the daily lives of slaves rather than focus on the grand 1790s house of the onetime owners.
lead_paragraph: WALLACE, La. — John Cummings is restoring a 1790s plantation house as a museum, but he hopes that future visitors will spend only a few minutes there.

headline: Glenn Britt to Retire as Time Warner Cable Chief
abstract: Mr. Britt, 64, will be succeeded by Robert Marcus, who at 48 represents generational change both for the company and the industry.
lead_paragraph: When Glenn A. Britt got started in the nascent cable television business in the 1970s, no one knew whether people would pay a monthly fee for something that was already available free through an antenna. Nowadays, most Americans do pay companies like Mr. Britt’s Time Warner Cable, not just for television, but for broadband Internet, too.

headline: Reaping Profits off Student Loans
abstract: Why is the federal government making money off of poor and middle class students?
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration is championing the student loan overhaul passed by the Senate earlier this week as a wonderful thing. But there are two big problems with the new system. First, it lowers rates only temporarily, raising them in future years so that the government can continue to reap unseemly and unjustified profit from the student loan program. This means that future college students will be bled to pay for the financial break given to the students who preceded them. Senator Elizabeth Warren, Democrat of Massachusetts, likened this plan to the way subprime lenders made money in the run-up to the recession: They enticed borrowers with low “teaser” rates and then hammered them with the real costs later on.

headline: Fallen Idols
abstract: Sometimes your favorite authors are not nice people.
lead_paragraph: Recently, I picked up “Letters to a Young Poet,” by Rainer Maria Rilke, to read for the second time. I had fallen in love with the book when I was 17 and daydreamed about meeting the author, whom I imagined to be a kind, prophetic soul. Realizing now how little I knew about Rilke’s life, I Googled him.

headline: A Confederacy of Lunches
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Mark Leibovich eviscerates the status-obsessed denizens of our nation’s capital.
lead_paragraph: Not to ruin it for you, but: if you already hate Washington, you’re going to hate it a whole lot more after reading Mark Leibovich’s takedown of the creatures who infest our nation’s capital and rule our destinies. And in case you are deluded enough as to think they care, you’ll learn that they already hate you. He quotes his former Washington Post colleague Henry ­Allen: ­“Washington feels like a conspiracy we’re all in together, and nobody else in America quite understands, even though they pay for it.”

headline: War Torn
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'United States Politics and Government', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: “Those Angry Days,” by Lynne Olson, and “1940,” by Susan Dunn, revisit the ferocity of the disputes over America’s entrance into World War II.
lead_paragraph: In July 1939, Franklin D. Roosevelt met with senators from both political parties at the White House in a final effort to persuade them to amend the Neutrality Act preventing America from aiding other countries. After drinks were poured, Roosevelt and his secretary of state, Cordell Hull, argued that the world was approaching a catastrophic war. The 74-year-old Republican senator William Borah, who had led the fight against Woodrow Wilson and American entry into the League of Nations in 1919, shook his head in disgust. “There is not going to be any war in Europe this year,” he said. “All this hysteria is manufactured and artificial.” Two months later Hitler invaded Poland, and England and France declared war on Germany.

headline: Embattled President of American Academy of Arts and Sciences to Resign
abstract: Leslie Cohen Berlowitz had been under fire after reports that she had falsely claimed, on several grant applications and other documents, to have a doctorate.
lead_paragraph: Leslie Cohen Berlowitz, the embattled president of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, will officially depart her post at the end of the month, the academy has announced.

headline: Taliban Claim Deadly Attack on Pakistani Spy Agency

lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Taliban militants claimed responsibility on Thursday for an attack on a regional office of Pakistan’s main spy agency that left at least nine people dead and again highlighted the militants’ ability to strike sensitive targets.

headline: Pool, Lawn and Plinth in a Political Pilgrimage
abstract: Hundreds of people gathered on Wednesday for Lincoln Center Out of Doors, which presented a premiere of Mark Dendy’s “Ritual Cyclical.”
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of people crammed the northeast corner of Hearst Plaza on Wednesday night to see the world premiere of Mark Dendy’s “Ritual Cyclical” at Lincoln Center Out of Doors. Here was a show, with 80 dancers, specializing in simultaneous multiplicity. At one time there were four, perhaps six, group dances happening. No spectator could have seen everything that was going on.

headline: M.&A. Tables Don’t Give Full Score
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Lazard, for example, ended this year’s first half with a 10 percent share of completed deals, leaving it in ninth place. Yet by revenue, the Wall Street firm was in the top five.
lead_paragraph: Lazard’s latest earnings report shows that mergers and acquisitions rankings have few clothes. The Wall Street firm ended this year’s first half with a 10 percent share of completed deals, leaving it in ninth place in industry league tables, according to Thomson Reuters data. Yet by revenue, the company was in the top five.

headline: What’s Next in the Case Against SAC
abstract: SAC has almost no defense against the government’s charges, so the issue of punishment may be the real fight in the case.
lead_paragraph: The indictment of SAC Capital Advisors and three of its internal hedge fund companies on Thursday signals an important shift by the government away from its longstanding fear of charging an organization with a crime. The charges accuse the firms and, at least indirectly, their owner, Steven A. Cohen, of fostering a corporate culture that encouraged analysts and traders to use illegitimate means that resulted in “systematic insider trading.”

headline: When the Patient Is Racist
abstract: Since Hippocrates, physicians have embraced the ideal of caring for all patients, regardless of who they might be. But what does the doctor do when the patient discriminates?
lead_paragraph: After too many drinks, the motorcycle enthusiast in his 30s had driven off the side of the road. As one of the doctors-in-training covering trauma that night, I was responsible for his initial physical exam; but it wasn’t going to be easy. He was enormous, his feet hung over the flimsy emergency room gurney and his neck bulged out of the stiff cervical collar. Moreover, he was what the older nurses called a “mean drunk,” so it was with more than a little apprehension that I began palpating and poking.

headline: Israeli Land Measure Called Discriminatory
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Nomadic People', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Land Use Policies']
abstract: The legislation, which aims to resolve Bedouin landownership claims, could lead to the demolition of villages in the Negev desert.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The United Nations human rights chief, Navi Pillay, urged Israel to reconsider legislation that could lead to the demolition of Bedouin villages in the Negev desert, asserting that Israel was actively pursuing discriminatory policies by forcibly displacing its Arab citizens.

headline: Chinese Rights Advocate Is Detained
abstract: Hu Jia, a human rights activist, was held for several hours by the police in the southern city of Shenzhen, along with his daughter and a lawyer.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A well-known human rights advocate who lives in Beijing, Hu Jia, was detained for several hours on Thursday evening by the police in the southern city of Shenzhen, along with his five-year-old daughter, Qianci, according to Mr. Hu’s wife, Zeng Jinyan.

headline: Blanco Tequila, a Handy Pantry Staple
abstract: A layer of pineapple confit steeped in bracing blanco tequila makes a cake with kick.
lead_paragraph: Blanco (or silver) tequila is almost as handy a pantry ingredient as dry sherry. Long before it hits the cocktail shaker, you can call on it to marinate seafood, like shrimp or red snapper for ceviche; add it to a broth for steamed clams; flame some peppery chorizo in it; or let its alluring vegetal flavor ripple through your next gazpacho. You should also consider it for dessert. Here’s a goat-cheese cake with a layer of pineapple confit that has been steeped in bracing tequila. It’s a cake that does well when made in advance and chilled for 24 hours before serving. But to sip alongside, ditch the silver and opt for a good añejo. FLORENCE FABRICANT

lead_paragraph: After Zack Wheeler needed 31 pitches to get through the first inning on Thursday, he returned to the Mets’ dugout grumbling about one: a slider to Atlanta’s Justin Upton with no balls and two strikes that drifted just a bit too far outside.

headline: Amazon Reports Small Loss as It Focuses on Investments

lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Amazon’s razor-thin profits turned to razor-thin losses in the last quarter, as the Internet commerce giant continued to plow money into warehouses, digital content and other big investments that it says will pay off down the line.

headline: Video, Music and More in the Kitchen’s Fall Season
abstract: Highlights of the Kitchen’s fall season range from video work to a performance piece about Michael Jackon to a dance premiere.
lead_paragraph: The Kitchen, the Manhattan organization that showcases experimental work in many disciplines, announced on Thursday that its fall season would include “Tracking the Thrill,” an exhibition of Gretchen Bender’s video work; “King,” a performance piece by  Neal Medlyn that reconsiders Michael Jackson’s work and persona; and Claire Chase, the flutist, performing work from her new album, “Density.”

headline: At Home in Two Places

lead_paragraph: The stretch of the High Line from 30th to 34th Street, still semiwild and closed to the public except by appointment, is a challenging place to exhibit art. Anything installed there risks being overwhelmed by the beauty of the site itself, with its sweeping arc toward the Hudson and its picturesque weeds sprouting up between splintered rail ties.

headline: Met to Host Conference of Museum Directors
abstract: In an effort to strengthen its global ties, the Metropolitan Museum of Art has organized what it is calling the “Global Museum Leaders Colloquium,” a two-week pilot program scheduled for April.
lead_paragraph: Unlike the Louvre or the Guggenheim, the Metropolitan Museum of Art has no plans to build an outpost in the Middle East. Yet its global reach can be glimpsed not only through its vast collections and traveling exhibitions but also in the many projects it finances around the world, including excavations in the Middle East and conservation initiatives with countries like India.

headline: Ineffable Emptiness, From Dawn to Dusk
abstract: Robert Irwin’s eye-filling yet barely-there mirage at the Whitney Museum makes the other art spectacles of summer seem overwrought.
lead_paragraph: New York has seen its share of art spectacles this summer. The Museum of Modern Art has its Rain Room, where the computerized stop-and-go downpours have attracted mobs. The Park Avenue Armory is filled with Paul McCarthy’s sensurround onslaught of sexual and psychological chaos. At the Guggenheim, lines of people wait to see the immense digital light show that James Turrell has inserted into the soaring rotunda.

headline: Beverly McIver

headline: New York Musical Theater Festival Report: ‘Icarus’
abstract: The Boston-based ensemble Liars & Believers sets the famliar story in a Depression-era traveling sideshow.
lead_paragraph: The ragtag troupe that weaves a tale out of everyday materials is an old theatrical reliable for a reason. As “Peter and the Starcatcher,” to name just one current hit, makes clear, there’s still innocent pleasure to be found in role-switching, hat-doffing, puppet-waving performers who construct their show in plain sight.

headline: Breaking Out of the Box (and Into a Song)
abstract: A revival of the musical “I’m Getting My Act Together and Taking It on the Road” by Encores! Off-Center features some strong songs and some dated concepts.
lead_paragraph: When the sweet, spirited music stops, a smell of stale patchouli oil seems to waft from the stage at City Center, where a loving but creaky revival of the musical “I’m Getting My Act Together and Taking It on the Road” is being presented through Saturday as the last entry in the inaugural season of Encores! Off-Center. This pop-rock chamber musical from 1978, with book and lyrics by Gretchen Cryer and music by Nancy Ford, features a handful of still-vibrant songs about the tensions between the yearning for romance and the itch for self-fulfillment. But the long rap sessions between numbers — I use the term in the antiquated sense, of earnest soul baring — tend to sap the energy from the proceedings.

headline: Claws and Heart Get a Workout in Japan
abstract: Hugh Jackman’s ageless Wolverine returns to the screen, this time in the Land of the Rising Sun.
lead_paragraph: Though I sometimes tire of the sufferings of superheroes, I have a permanent soft spot for the Wolverine, the Marvel mutant whose indestructibility causes him endless physical and existential pain. As played by Hugh Jackman through six “X-Men” features (including one about the Wolverine’s origins), he is a shaggy, soulful, perpetually roughed-up character, and a bit of a misfit even among his peers.

lead_paragraph: A look at the era explored in a new documentary film about black blues musicians.

headline: Met Opera Cancels Staten Island Performance
abstract: Thursday night’s recital performance has been canceled because of expected bad weather and will not be rescheduled.
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Opera recital scheduled for Thursday night in Staten Island’s Clove Lakes Park has been canceled because of expected bad weather, the opera announced Thursday. The recital, part of the Summer Recital Series, will not be rescheduled.

headline: The Clincher, Also Known as Closing
abstract: What to expect when you finally reach the table.
lead_paragraph: For first-time buyers, closing on a home purchase can be like finishing a long and grueling race. There’s the thrill of achievement mixed with relief that it’s over and, often, the weak limbs that can come with handing over a shockingly large check.

headline: Food Matters | Four Monks Walk Into a Bar …
abstract: A group of Buddhist holy men traveled yesterday to Whiskey Soda Lounge Ny, the soon-to-open companion bar to the restaurant Pok Pok Ny, for a house-blessing ceremony.
lead_paragraph: For a man who doesn’t court celebrity, the chef Andy Ricker draws a seriously wide range of admirers to his white-hot Brooklyn restaurant Pok Pok Ny — from Thai-loving plaid-clad hipsters to the four Buddhist monks who traveled yesterday from the Vajiradhammapadip Temple on Long Island to Ricker’s latest establishment, and Pok Pok’s newest neighbor, Whiskey Soda Lounge Ny.

headline: A Summer Place in the South Bronx
abstract: Thomas Hirschhorn has built “Gramsci Monument,” a sprawling, participatory sculpture, on the grounds of the Forest Houses.
lead_paragraph: On last Sunday’s lovely, warm afternoon I visited Thomas Hirschhorn’s “Gramsci Monument,” a sprawling, participatory sculpture built on the grass outside a group of brick apartment buildings in the South Bronx. I left feeling irritable and depressed.

headline: Video of Juror Who Says George Zimmerman ‘Got Away With Murder’
abstract: A second juror in the George Zimmerman trial spoke publicly and said she believed Mr. Zimmerman was guilty of murder in the shooting of Trayvon Martin.
lead_paragraph: Updated | 10:15 p.m. As my colleague Lizette Alvarez reports, a juror in the trial of George Zimmerman told ABC News that she believed Mr. Zimmerman “got away with murder” in the shooting death of Trayvon Martin.

headline: I Remember You Well in the Chelsea Hotel
abstract: A Q. and A. with Jerry Weinstein, who worked at the front desk of the Chelsea Hotel — home to Gaby Hoffmann and other actors — for 30 years.
lead_paragraph: When Jerry Weinstein, a trained social worker, started working the front desk of the Chelsea Hotel — known for its famous (and infamous) artistic guests with a penchant for sex, drugs and rock ‘n’ roll — he planned to stay for a few weeks. He stayed for three decades. “It was like a family there,” he says. “You know?”

abstract: Photos from Spain, Mali, Brazil and India.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Spain, Mali, Brazil and India.

abstract: For Hannah, 14, basketball offered refuge from family problems of drug addiction and domestic assault. When basketball season ends, Hannah's living situation becomes increasingly unsettled.

headline: Its Reign Was Long, With Nine Lives to Start
abstract: A show at the Brooklyn Museum explores the role of cats, big and little, feral and tame, celestial and not, in ancient Egypt.
lead_paragraph: If your dream of heaven is eternity spent with the pets you love, “Divine Felines: Cats of Ancient Egypt” at the Brooklyn Museum is your exhibition. All of its 30 objects, sifted from the museum’s Egyptian collection, are of cats, big and little, feral and tame, celestial and not. Whether cast in bronze or carved in stone, their forms were to outlast time, and so they have.

headline: Facebook’s Stock Soars Amid Rosy Growth Expectations
abstract: Shares in the social network rose 30 percent on Thursday, after the company reported stronger-than-expected revenue and profit growth. Analysts say the company has bright prospects, but there are still some cautionary signs.
lead_paragraph: Facebook’s stock levitated nearly 30 percent on Thursday, to $34.36 a share, after a second-quarter earnings report that was far stronger than Wall Street had predicted.

headline: Some Things You Can’t Learn From a Book
abstract: In “The To Do List,” Aubrey Plaza plays a smart and driven high school graduate who decides that she has been missing something and sets out to lose her virginity.
lead_paragraph: Sure, you can load a lot of overthink involving male-versus-female perspective onto “The To Do List,” a comedy about a girl determined to lose her virginity the summer after high school graduation. But here is all you really need to know: This movie is smarter and better acted and just plain funnier than most of its predecessors in the my-first-time genre, no matter which sex is losing what.

headline: Maggie Carey’s ‘To Do List’
abstract: Images from the film.
lead_paragraph: Images from the film.

headline: Bankrolling the Botnets
abstract: What’s it worth to understand spam?
lead_paragraph: I’m an academic researcher, primarily studying underground economies; as such, my group’s work involves transacting with known criminals, like botnet operators or certain types of spammers. While our research has been reviewed by legal counsel, I’m concerned by the fact that we are knowingly financing criminal organizations (often giving them hundreds or thousands of dollars at a time). Does the benefit of the scientific understanding we gain outweigh the harm that our funds might do? How sure should we be of a positive scientific outcome before entering into these transactions? We have no expectation of anything in return, and we often learn interesting information. NAME WITHHELD

headline: Blacks and Whites Made the Blues
abstract: A new documentary, “Born in Chicago,” looks at an era when blues musicians like Muddy Waters and Howlin’ Wolf took young white neophytes under their wing.
lead_paragraph: LATE in his career, Muddy Waters recorded a song called “The Blues Had a Baby and They Named It Rock and Roll.” That, in a nutshell, is the story told in the new documentary “Born in Chicago” — how he, Howlin’ Wolf and other black blues musicians working in Chicago in the 1960s schooled young white acolytes from that city who went on to play on some of the most influential pop recordings of the era.

headline: Poll Shows Virtual Tie in Comptroller’s Race
abstract: Eliot Spitzer and Scott M. Stringer were within the margin of sampling error, though only a quarter of respondents said Mr. Spitzer’s prostitution scandal should disqualify him from office.
lead_paragraph: Another day, another poll in the 2013 election. Or two of them, actually.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Commitment Issues on Twitter
abstract: The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for important and peculiar items. Thursday’s selections include a question of etiquette in favoriting Twitter posts and an essay on the apparent hubris of Silicon Valley aficionados.
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

lead_paragraph: HUNTINGDON, Tenn. — Miranda learned she was pregnant on her 18th birthday last September. She and her mother soon painted the nursery pink with brown accents, as they had seen in catalogs. Miranda knew it was going to be a girl, and she had a name ready: Akyia Nicole.

headline: An Afrobeat to Celebrate the Eclectic
abstract: Afrobeat was the theme during the Kronos at 40 concert at the Lincoln Center Out of Doors festival.
lead_paragraph: Kronos Quartet isn’t exactly the first thing that comes to mind when the Nigerian bandleader Fela Anikulapo Kuti is mentioned. Afrobeat, funk, protest, defiance and dancing are a lot closer to the top of the list. Afrobeat, the style Fela (who died in 1997) forged from James Brown’s funk, 1960s jazz, African drumming and finger-pointing lyrics about exploitation and corruption, was music for dancing all night in steamy clubs; it was far from the realm of the string quartet. So “Red Hot + Fela,” at Damrosch Park on Wednesday night, made an unlikely starting point for Kronos at 40, five days of free concerts at the Lincoln Center Out of Doors festival celebrating the determined eclecticism of the Kronos Quartet over four decades.

headline: A Flow of French and Italian Influences
abstract: Rooted in two cuisines, the food at Roìa Restaurant is largely traditional, leavened with a bit of contemporary creativity and New England ingredients.
lead_paragraph: A recent dinner at Roìa Restaurant in New Haven prompted the question of how this new operation, barely four months old, could make us feel we were in such good hands. Was it the tasty amuse-bouches that arrived as we considered the menu? The single-page document itself, a listing of simple, sophisticated dishes like a crudo of fluke? Or was it the self-assured maître d’hôtel, designer of the wine list, who ably proposed affordable choices to complement our meal?

headline: The Drug Mule-Cantaloupe Crisis
abstract: John Boehner called out Steve King for insulting the children of illegal immigrants. But can he convince voters that Republicans aren’t hateful?
lead_paragraph: It was obviously not wise, let alone appropriate or correct, for Rep. Steve King to claim in an interview with Newsmax last week that the children of illegal immigrants were more likely to be drug mules than star pupils. “For every one who’s a valedictorian, there’s another 100 out there who weigh 130 pounds and they’ve got calves the size of cantaloupes because they’re hauling 75 pounds of marijuana across the desert,” he said.

headline: Absence of Trust Fuels Yankees’ Melodrama
abstract: Amid a debate over the health of his left quadriceps, Alex Rodriguez grudgingly agreed to a plan for his return to the Yankees during a season of flagging expectations.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — As the Yankees dressed for batting practice Tuesday, a television in the visitors’ clubhouse at Rangers Ballpark blared the latest report of distress between the Yankees and Alex Rodriguez, their $275 million faded star.

headline: Kuroda’s Highlights: No Runs, No Errors

lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — Hiroki Kuroda was left off the American League All-Star team, but his feelings certainly will be soothed if he wins the Cy Young Award.

abstract: Seafood of all varieties rules the tabletops at the newly opened restaurant Buoy One in Huntington.

lead_paragraph: The authentic Thai food served at Bangkok House is far more interesting than either the restaurant’s name or its location, opposite a Dollar General store and next to Eatontown TV and Appliance on Route 35.

headline: (Married) Girls Just Want to Have Fun
abstract: Answers to questions about flirting, dinner guests and more.
lead_paragraph: I am a young newlywed, but my husband and I have been together for seven years. Several of my close friends are still single. When I go to bars or clubs with them, without fail they tell any man I strike up a conversation with that I am married. It’s not as if I’m hiding the fact. My wedding ring is in plain sight. I have a great relationship with my husband, but when I’m out with the girls, I enjoy a little harmless flirting. Why do my friends feel the need to ruin my fun?

This summer, one such space is providing just that. This month, NYCFiveHundred, an arts collective, has presented a photography show and a poetry reading (the poet Safia Elhillo, top, at a recent event) in the former shipping terminal at Pier 57 in Hudson River Park, at 15th Street. Corey Garcia and members of his jazz quartet (including Ethan Cohn, a bassist, above right, with Mr. Garcia at the drums) performed at the opening concert.

headline: Russia for Beginners: A Literary Course for Edward Snowden
abstract: Edward J. Snowden’s Russian lawyer earlier this week left him a shopping bag with books by Dostoyevsky, Chekhov and Nikolai Karamzin to help him learn about Russia.
lead_paragraph: So many of us say, “If only I had the time to read, I would read the classics.”

lead_paragraph: Leslie Cohen Berlowitz, the embattled president of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, will depart her post at the end of the month, the academy announced on Thursday.

headline: Running on Illegal Fuel and Savage Zeal
abstract: The Hong Kong director Johnnie To filmed his high-velocity tale of bad guys and good in China, with no evident softening of unsettling action.
lead_paragraph: “Drug War,” Johnnie To’s ferocious crime story, opens with bilious green smoke darkening the sky and ends with a tsunami of blood spilling onto the ground. The green billows out of an illegal meth lab that has exploded while the red pours from the dead and the dying who, throughout this excitingly directed movie, have chased one another as if to the ends of the earth. If the green smoke suggested “go,” the blood can only mean one thing: “stop,” which, taken with the surrounding human wreckage, serves as an unmistakably fierce authorial commentary.

lead_paragraph: An exhaustingly pretentious heave of artistic self-involvement, “The Time Being” takes an exceptionally handsome journey to nowhere at all.

lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Halliburton has agreed to plead guilty to destruction of critical evidence after the Gulf of Mexico oil spill in 2010, the Justice Department announced on Thursday.

headline: He’s Just a Cave Man in a Modern World
abstract: In “Neander-Jin: The Return of the Neanderthal Man,” a Homo neanderthalensis is in danger of being exploited for a quick buck.
lead_paragraph: Neandertal is a valley in Germany. That meager fact is a spoiler for “Neander-Jin: The Return of the Neanderthal Man,” because there is virtually nothing else of value to be gained from watching this film.

headline: Loss That Lingers, in Memory and Place
abstract: Sophie Calle’s “Last Seen” series of photographs and texts, about the 1990 theft of 13 artworks from Boston’s Gardner Museum, will be shown there this fall.
lead_paragraph: Human behavior isn’t the French conceptual artist Sophie Calle’s only source of inspiration. In 1990, when she was in Boston for a show of her work at the Institute of Contemporary Art, Ms. Calle visited the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum. “It was then that I fell in love with ‘The Concert,’ “ she said of Vermeer’s celebrated canvas from 1658-60 that depicts two women and a man engaged in an at-home musicale. “Every time I had a meeting I would make it in front of that painting so I could see it again,” she recalled.

headline: In Cambodia, Shifting Allegiances Shape a Tougher Than Usual Election
abstract: Despite Prime Minister Hun Sen’s ability to overcome the resistance of even his toughest enemies, he is finding new challenges from other quarters of Cambodian society.
lead_paragraph: ANLONG VENG, Cambodia — A decade and a half after the last remnants of the Khmer Rouge capitulated in this northwestern town, the streets are festooned with images of their erstwhile enemy, Prime Minister Hun Sen, who is seeking to prolong his 28 years in power in an election on Sunday.

headline: Rich American Girl Meets Poor Peruvian Boy
abstract: In Josh Hyde’s “Postales,” a 12-year-old visiting Peru makes a connection with a young postcard seller.
lead_paragraph: Tourism is not simple. You can say that again, and put a dissertation behind it, when wealthy traveling Americans engage with subsistence economies. In “Postales,” a searching and human film directed by Josh Hyde and set in Cuzco, Peru, one grim-faced local woman commodifies herself by donning traditional colorful clothes, pulling a llama along and posing for pictures outside expensive hotels. The cameras snap away. As she says, it’s her job.

headline: Vassar Revives Garden Nurtured by Early Promoter of Native Plants
abstract: The Dutchess County Outdoor Ecological Laboratory was cultivated by botany professors and students in the 1920s, long before native species became a rage.
lead_paragraph: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y. — On a still summer day, a day so warm that even the song sparrows and dragonflies seemed listless, Guillermo Valdez and Will Blum, who are juniors at Vassar College, tugged at the roots of porcelain berry and honeysuckle plants. Sweat trickling down their necks, they were on a mission to expel the invasive vines from a patch of campus that is better known to birders in the area than students, and replace them with native species like marsh marigolds, swamp azaleas and cinnamon ferns.

headline: A Label Mr. Dolce and Mr. Gabbana Don’t Like
abstract: After they were called tax dodgers, the designers Stefano Gabbana and Domenico Dolce went on the offensive, even shutting stores in Milan to protest their treatment.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — In Italy, where burlesque public anger can be its own form of fashion statement, the designers behind the Dolce & Gabbana label made their reaction to an insult high art.

headline: Taliban Seize Police Force in a Hamlet
abstract: An entire local police unit disappeared in a small Afghan village, and the Taliban claimed responsibility.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The few hundred people of Kala Khel, a village in southern Afghanistan, on Thursday got some of the best news they had heard all year: the entire Afghan Local Police unit posted to the hamlet had disappeared the night before, apparently betrayed by two of their own and abducted by the Taliban.

headline: Something Unpleasant Behind Enemy Lines
abstract: “Frankenstein’s Army,” directed by Richard Raaphorst, has a plethora of unsettling — and refreshingly nondigital — zombie robots.
lead_paragraph: With a movie called “Frankenstein’s Army,” you’d have every reason to expect a generous serving of cheese along with abundant helpings of gore and gunplay. And you certainly get it in this frenetic found-footage horror film set in the German countryside in 1945.

headline: A Relentless Prosecutor’s Crowning Case
keywords: ['Insider Trading', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'United States Attorneys']
abstract: The charges against SAC Capital Advisors are the culmination of an investigation of nearly a decade and are a rare and bold step.
lead_paragraph: In recent years, Preet Bharara has prosecuted members of the powerful Latin Kings gang in Newburgh, N.Y., exposed corrupt state politicians and convicted terrorists.

headline: Joking About Murder Can Have Consequences
abstract: In Jamie Babbit’s “Breaking the Girls,” two friends fantasize about offing their enemies, but one turns out to be serious.
lead_paragraph: Jamie Babbit’s golden-hued noir, “Breaking the Girls,” takes inspiration from Hitchcock’s psychological thriller “Strangers on a Train” (itself based on Patricia Highsmith’s novel) and updates it for the texting, it’s-all-about-me generation. But this film goes further, turning the tale into an erotic thriller with too many twists and back stories to count.

headline: Concussion Study Makes Case for Reducing Contact Drills for Youth Players
keywords: ['Interscholastic Athletics', 'Football', 'Concussions', 'Athletics and Sports', 'Youth', 'Children and Childhood', 'Sports Injuries']
abstract: Youth players who took part in a limited number of contact drills in practice were no more likely to absorb head hits during games, a study showed.
lead_paragraph: Youth football players are not more vulnerable to head hits in games if they take part in fewer contact drills during practices, a new study published in the Annals of Biomedical Engineering showed.

headline: Septuagenarian Strut
abstract: Discovered inside a full stadium, a cure for baby boomer self-loathing.
lead_paragraph: Just look at them: the graybeards and grannies smoking pot, the bodies tugged by gravity and wretched excess, all that late-age libido and feeble jump-stepping enabled by Viagra and Lipitor. Baby boomers — a stadium full of them. Is there anything worse?

headline: Underwater Dream, Stymied by Drugs
abstract: Dino J. Gallina’s M.F.A. project, “Red Tide” features unsympathetic characters engaged in uninteresting pursuits.
lead_paragraph: The problems of three little people amount to even less than a hill of beans in “Red Tide,” a tortured-siblings movie set in a depressed town on the west coast of Florida.

headline: Wall Street’s Exposure to Hacking Laid Bare
abstract: Five people were accused of hacking into the servers of major companies and Nasdaq, showing the vulnerability of some computer systems.
lead_paragraph: The indictment on Thursday of a long-running hacking ring is kindling fears that rogue programmers are going beyond theft and developing the capacity to wreak havoc on the broader financial system.

headline: Chinese Search for Infant Formula Goes Global
keywords: ['Infant Formulas', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Smuggling', 'Food Contamination and Poisoning']
abstract: Fueled by distrust of domestic brands, Chinese parents are buying up foreign-made infant milk powder, and that has led to shortages in at least a half-dozen other countries.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The group of 40 mainland Chinese tourists made all the requisite shopping purchases on a recent trip to Europe: silk scarves, Swiss watches, Louis Vuitton handbags.

headline: They’ll Follow Their Pal to the Bitter, Senseless End
abstract: Rowan Athale’s “Wasteland” takes viewers on a tour of a hopeless youth in the north of England before turning into a crime caper.
lead_paragraph: The English heist movie has a history of being cheeky. From “The Italian Job” (1969) through “Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels” (1999), a cool, brazen wit and stylized violence mark some of the best examples of complicated robbery scenarios in British cinema. Rowan Athale does not ignore that inheritance with his dense debut feature, “Wasteland.”

headline: Defense Tries to Show Sympathetic Side of Ex-Trader
abstract: Fabrice Tourre’s legal team worked to rehabilitate his image in court on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Fabrice Tourre has been painted by the Securities and Exchange Commission as one of the great villains of the financial crisis, a smart Goldman trader who duped unsuspecting investors into buying toxic real estate securities he knew were doomed to fail.

headline: Behind Death Sentence, Inmate’s Prison Conduct
keywords: ['Sentences (Criminal)', 'Capital Punishment', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Attacks on Police']
abstract: Before imposing the death penalty on Ronell Wilson for killing two detectives, a federal jury heard testimony about his attacks on guards, gang activity and tryst behind bars.
lead_paragraph: When a defense lawyer pleaded with a federal jury in Brooklyn this week to impose a life sentence on his client, Ronell Wilson, who had killed two undercover detectives, he argued that prison would not be painless for Mr. Wilson.

headline: In Boston, Violence Is Backdrop to Bulger Trial
abstract: A rash of violence, most recently the abduction and killing of a young woman, has hit the old neighborhood of the crime boss James (Whitey) Bulger.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — As the trial of the crime boss James (Whitey) Bulger continues in federal court here, a rash of violence visited his home neighborhood on Tuesday. It was a rare reminder of the terror that gripped the streets of South Boston during Mr. Bulger’s reign in the 1970s and ‘80s — although this time the neighborhood found itself petrified not by the calculated nature of many of Mr. Bulger’s alleged crimes, but by a fear of the apparent randomness of the violence.

headline: U.S. Prison Populations Decline, Reflecting New Approach to Crime
abstract: Tightened state budgets, plummeting crime rates, changes in sentencing laws and shifts in public opinion have helped contribute to the biggest decline in the nation’s history.
lead_paragraph: The prison population in the United States dropped in 2012 for the third consecutive year, according to federal statistics released on Thursday, in what criminal justice experts said was the biggest decline in the nation’s recent history, signaling a shift away from an almost four-decade policy of mass imprisonment.

headline: Under Code, Apps Would Disclose Collection of Data
abstract: Some app developers and consumer advocates have agreed to test a voluntary code that would require participating developers to tell consumers whether their apps are collecting personal information.
lead_paragraph: Like food packages that display nutrition labels, some mobile apps could soon display information that allows consumers to decide at a glance whether the apps are good for them.

headline: Californians Consider a Future Without a Nuclear Plant for a Neighbor
abstract: The closing of the San Onofre nuclear power plant in California has raised some uncomfortable questions for nearby towns that had relied on it as a source of cheap energy and jobs.
lead_paragraph: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif. — Residents of this quiet Orange County beach community often all but forgot about the hulking nuclear plant just south of the city limits.

headline: Fast Food, Low Pay
abstract: Restaurant workers are fighting for basic rights, and getting somewhere.
lead_paragraph: Last November, following the Black Friday protests by Walmart employees, 200 workers at 30 New York fast-food restaurants walked off their jobs.

headline: Wilfork Says Hernandez Case Will Test Patriots’ Chemistry
abstract: Tom Brady and Vince Wilfork did not mention the full name of their former teammate Aaron Hernandez, but they talked about the sadness of a lost life and the need to move forward.
lead_paragraph: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — The Patriots followed the example set the day before by their head coach. They talked about the sadness of a lost life. They talked about the need to move forward. The team captains Tom Brady and Vince Wilfork did not mention the full name of their former teammate Aaron Hernandez — the only topic of conversation when they addressed the news media on Thursday.

headline: European Court Says Russia Did Not Persecute Ex-Tycoon
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: The judges said the charges against Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky were sufficient to explain his prosecution, but added that his rights were violated in other ways.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The European Court of Human Rights ruled Thursday that Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, a former oil tycoon imprisoned in Russia, had not been a victim of political persecution when he was prosecuted for tax evasion and fraud in 2005.

headline: SAC Case Threatens a Wall St. Cash Cow
abstract: What happens on Wall Street now that SAC Capital Advisors has been accused?
lead_paragraph: Wall Street now has to contemplate life without SAC Capital Advisors, the hedge fund that manages billions of dollars.

headline: Meals With a Century-Old View
abstract: After many attempts in Bear Mountain park, Restaurant 1915, which is named for the year in which its building was built, has finally had a successful renovation.
lead_paragraph: A great steak knife is a wonderful thing, and Restaurant 1915 at the Bear Mountain Inn provides a terrific one. Heavy and sharp, it has a stylized bark-like design that fits right in with the Adirondack aesthetic.

headline: A Faustian Pact: Generals as Democrats
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', "Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat"]
abstract: Egyptians’ faith in the military is probably misplaced, but it can be explained by six decades of hopes and disappointments.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — THE luxurious officers’ club of Egypt’s elite Republican Guard sits near downtown Cairo, its pool and patios surrounded by high walls with reliefs and paintings lauding Egypt’s military history, going back to the pharaohs. Where a huge poster of the deposed president Hosni Mubarak once stood, a new one declares: “The Army. The People. One Hand.”

headline: Hopes for a Fish Revival as a Dam Is Demolished
keywords: ['Levees and Dams', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Fish and Other Marine Life']
abstract: The Penobscot River is expected to begin yielding river herring, Atlantic salmon and other fish in numbers not seen in centuries.
lead_paragraph: EDDINGTON, Me. — There is a bend in the Penobscot River here, embanked by an Indian burial ground, through which millions of fish used to make a strenuous journey upstream to spawn before returning to the sea. There were elegant Atlantic salmon, prehistoric-looking sturgeon and, most numerous of all, lowly river herring, a nutrient-rich forage fish prized by ground fish, bears and birds.

headline: Come See Detroit, America’s Future
abstract: We’ve known Detroit was bankrupt for years. Now, suddenly, America notices.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — I KNOW an old woman who hasn’t opened her windows in a decade, afraid that what’s outside will climb inside. Inside, there is the stale odor of dead air.

headline: Republican Health Care Panic
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: Conservatives and others on the right are confronting their ultimate nightmare: that Obamacare is probably going to work.
lead_paragraph: Leading Republicans appear to be nerving themselves up for another round of attempted fiscal blackmail. With the end of the fiscal year looming, they aren’t offering the kinds of compromises that might produce a deal and avoid a government shutdown; instead, they’re drafting extremist legislation — bills that would, for example, cut clean-water grants by 83 percent — that has no chance of becoming law. Furthermore, they’re threatening, once again, to block any rise in the debt ceiling, a move that would damage the U.S. economy and possibly provoke a world financial crisis.

headline: Juror Says Zimmerman ‘Got Away With Murder’
abstract: A juror who said she initially wanted to convict George Zimmerman told ABC News on Thursday that freeing him had been heartbreaking for her.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — A juror who said she initially wanted to convict George Zimmerman told ABC News on Thursday that he “got away with murder” in the shooting death of Trayvon Martin, an unarmed black teenager.

headline: A Bipartisan Warning on Surveillance
abstract: The Obama administration can no longer ignore the growing discomfort with broad spying powers.
lead_paragraph: Lawmakers have given the Obama administration a bipartisan warning: patience is growing thin with its expansive and unwarranted surveillance of Americans.

headline: Inching Forward in the Mideast
abstract: Despite doubters, Secretary of State John Kerry presses forward with a strategy for peace negotiations.
lead_paragraph: The week that Secretary of State John Kerry said could start the revival of Israeli-Palestinian peace talks is passing without visible progress. The naysayers are chortling, but Mr. Kerry, to his credit, is undeterred. His aides insist that plans to resume the dialogue on a two-state solution that collapsed in 2010 are on track; on Thursday, an Israeli minister said that talks could begin next week.

headline: The Gun Lobby Takes Vengeful Aim
abstract: Will voters show up at a recall election to defend two state lawmakers in Colorado who dared to defy the National Rifle Association?
lead_paragraph: One welcome surprise in gun safety occurred this year in Colorado, where the Democratic-led Legislature dared to defy the gun lobby and mandated universal background checks on firearm sales and 15-round limits on ammunition magazines.

headline: Bait and Switch in the House
abstract: The latest bad bill put forth by the Republicans in the majority is just another example of why nothing gets done by this Congress.
lead_paragraph: There is a bill in the House being pushed by the majority leader, Eric Cantor, and many of his Republican colleagues that sounds as innocent and upright as motherhood and apple pie: the Kids First Research Act of 2013. It promises more money for pediatric medical research at the National Institutes of Health.

lead_paragraph: A tainted baby formula scandal in 2008 has Chinese parents obsessed with buying foreign-made milk powder.

abstract: With alarm over the threat of terrorism in slow decline, both political parties appear to be no longer willing to give national security automatic priority over privacy and civil liberties.
lead_paragraph: American intelligence agencies, which experienced a boom in financing and public support in the decade after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks, have entered a period of broad public scrutiny and skepticism with few precedents since the exposure of spying secrets and abuses led to the historic investigation by the Senate’s Church Committee nearly four decades ago.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s choice of a replacement for the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, is coming down to a battle between the California girls and the Rubin boys.

headline: Amid Hospital’s Turmoil, a Lost Man Disappears
abstract: As the debate over the fate of Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn Heights continued, a patient — a man who does not know his own identity — went missing.
lead_paragraph: It began as the odd case of an elderly man found wandering by the side of the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway in June, carrying plenty of cash, a bus ticket, a baseball cap and papers attesting to his name. He seemed well kept, even healthy — apart from the fact that he could not say where, or who, he was.

headline: Taken Before Harvey, Pitcher Faces an Uphill Struggle
abstract: The Diamondbacks took Barret Loux with the sixth pick in 2010, a spot ahead of Matt Harvey, but Arizona pulled its offer. He is now with an affiliate of the Cubs, his third organization.
lead_paragraph: ROUND ROCK, Tex. — The very moment he was drafted, in 2010, Barret Loux was buried. His team, Texas A&M, was waiting out a rain delay at an N.C.A.A. regional game in Miami, and had gathered in the weight room to watch the draft on TV.

headline: Roberts’s Picks Reshaping Secret Surveillance Court
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: As Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. has filled the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court with Republican appointees, critics have voiced concern about their deference to the government on spying.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The recent leaks about government spying programs have focused attention on the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court and its role in deciding how intrusive the  government can be in the name of national security. Less mentioned has been the person who has been quietly reshaping the secret court: Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr.

abstract: Quotation of the day for Friday, July 26, 2013.
lead_paragraph: “This is the beginning of the end of mass incarceration.”

headline: Plane Landed at La Guardia Nose Gear First
abstract: The findings of federal investigators on Thursday raised questions about the Southwest Airlines flight whose touchdown in New York injured at least 11 people this week.
lead_paragraph: The Southwest Airlines flight whose ill-fated landing at La Guardia Airport this week left at least 11 people with injuries hit the tarmac with its nose gear first, federal investigators said on Thursday, raising questions about the aircraft’s final moments above ground.

headline: Soriano Appears Headed Back to Yankees in a Trade
abstract: Nine years after he was traded for Alex Rodriguez, Alfonso Soriano is on the verge of rejoining the Yankees, who desperately need his right-handed bat.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — Nine years after he was traded by the Yankees to the Texas Rangers for Alex Rodriguez, Alfonso Soriano appears headed back to the Bronx, while the injured Rodriguez languishes in Tampa, Fla.

headline: Killer Notes, Low or High
abstract: “Murder for Two,” a new two-performer musical produced by Second Stage Theater’s Uptown series, uses its actor-doubling to daffy effects.
lead_paragraph: In one sense there’s little mystery surrounding the question of who pulled the fatal trigger in the new musical “Murder for Two,” which opened on Thursday night at the McGinn/Cazale Theater as part of Second Stage Theater’s Uptown series. Only two actors are in the show, and one plays the police officer investigating the crime. So it doesn’t take a Hercule Poirot, a Miss Marple or a Jackson Brodie (my current fave, from Kate Atkinson’s wonderful books) to conclude that the culprit is definitely the lanky, bald fellow with popping eyes and pinwheeling limbs.

headline: Dropped a Line
abstract: Friday fabulousness with Brendan Emmett Quigley.
lead_paragraph: Administrivial ‘Win Valuable Prizes’ Alert!: LOLLAPUZZOOLA is the best summertime crossword tournament held annually on a Saturday in August. Enjoy a full day of tournament puzzling — six original crosswords never published anywhere else, constructed by some of the best puzzlemakers in the solar system. There are separate skill divisions for superpro solvers and normal Earthlings, a unique Pairs Division if you’d like to solve with a friend, and our famous At-Home Division for those who can’t make it to NYC. They also have a one-of-a-kind “Google Ticket” system for players who need a little help along the way, an assortment of snacks and beverages, and for just an extra five bucks, you can stay for the fourth annual Ryan Hecht Pizza Social. $25 to pre-register for the whole day, $10 for the At-Home Division. Join co-hosts Brian Cimmet and Patrick Blindauer for a casual yet competitive tournament experience you won’t find anywhere else. Visit bemoresmarter.com for more information.

headline: Changing Makeup of Surveillance Courts
abstract: The chief justice of the United States picks sitting judges to serve extra duty on the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court, as well as on a small review panel that hears any appeals from its decisions.
lead_paragraph: The chief justice of the United States picks sitting judges to serve extra duty on the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court, as well as on a small review panel that hears any appeals from its decisions.

headline: Batik Store, a Vestige of the Hippie Era, Will Fade Away
abstract: The closing of the Melting Pot in Boerum Hill seems to be a coda of sorts to the heady days of hippiedom in Brooklyn’s more raffish quarters.
lead_paragraph: In the hippie-altered world in which Nancy Cogen plunked down her store 41 years ago, batik cloth was still an offbeat novelty.

headline: A Continent Mired in Crisis Coins a Language of Economic Pain
abstract: In country after country in Europe, the economic crisis has spawned its own language, brought exotic financial terms into popular use, and generated a darkly humorous slang.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — The Portuguese have a new word, “grandolar,” which grew out of the euro crisis and means “to subject a government minister to a singing protest using a revolutionary hymn.” But now, after three years of austerity, even Portuguese children “grandolate” their parents if they do not want to take a bath.

headline: Samsung’s Profit Rises, but So Does the Competition
abstract: Samsung said net income in the second quarter rose to $6.9 billion, an increase of 50 percent, but it expected smartphone sales growth to slow down.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Samsung Electronics, the world’s largest maker of smartphones, said on Friday that it expected competition to increase, even as it reported a 50 percent rise in profit for the second quarter.

headline: Remade Jets Open Camp and Practice Restraint
abstract: Coach Rex Ryan said every player would have to earn his way, which is particularly true at quarterback — by far the Jets’ most pressing issue.
lead_paragraph: CORTLAND, N.Y. — Unlike, say, Braylon Edwards, who appeared wearing a T-shirt that read, “Sit Down and Learn From the Master,” Geno Smith favored a decidedly more understated arrival to Jets training camp Thursday. He did not declare himself the favorite in the Great Quarterback Competition of 2013. He did not demand a timetable for an announcement.

headline: Brooklyn Restaurateur Dies, Apparently a Suicide
abstract: Friends said Colin Devlin, whose Williamsburg dining places included DuMont and Dressler, had taken the stresses of the business hard.
lead_paragraph: Before everyone started flocking to Williamsburg, Brooklyn, Colin Devlin was giving people a reason to do so — through his restaurants, first DuMont, and later Dressler.

headline: Return of the Stingy Oddsmaker: A Response
abstract: We are usually taught that the observer is fundamentally important when learning quantum physics. But that is an artifact of history.
lead_paragraph: This is a response by the author to readers of his recent post for The Stone, “Nothing to See Here: Demoting the Uncertainty Principle.”

abstract: Smith Street Tattoo Parlour in Carroll Gardens has become a popular tourist destination for those seeking New York-style tattoos.

headline: Aid to Egypt Can Keep Flowing, Despite Overthrow, White House Decides
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Foreign Aid', 'United States Politics and Government', "Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat"]
abstract: Administration officials have decided they are not legally required to determine whether the overthrow of President Mohamed Morsi of Egypt was a coup.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration has concluded it is not legally required to determine whether the Egyptian military engineered a coup d’état in ousting President Mohamed Morsi, a senior administration official said Thursday, a finding that will allow it to continue to funnel $1.5 billion in American aid to Egypt each year.

headline: Lawmakers, Facing Pressure on Surveillance, Focus on Privacy
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: Leaders of the House and Senate Intelligence Committees have begun negotiating new safeguards and restrictions that they hope to turn into legislation in September.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Facing rising pressure to limit government surveillance programs and provide more information about them, leaders of the House and Senate Intelligence Committees have begun negotiating new safeguards and privacy restrictions that they hope to turn into legislation in September, lawmakers said Thursday.

headline: Touring Slum in Rio, Pope Urges Young to Fight Against Corruption
abstract: By singling out corruption on his first trip abroad as pope, Francis emphasized his aim to refocus the Roman Catholic Church on the neglected margins of society.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Pope Francis on Thursday delivered some of his most politically provocative remarks since his papacy began this year, hopping from his popemobile to walk through a slum in this city before urging young people to fight against corruption, a leading grievance behind the huge street protests that shook dozens of Brazilian cities in June.

headline: Science Lowers Shattering Risk at Home Plate
abstract: In an unusual partnership with Major League Baseball, Forest Service scientists looked deep into maple’s core to find why it was so brittle, and how it could be made less so.
lead_paragraph: Welington Castillo smashed a double for the Chicago Cubs late in a game in the 2010 season, his bat exploding on impact with the ball. A long shard of wood flew at a teammate, Tyler Colvin, sprinting home from third base, impaling him a few inches from his heart. Though Colvin scored, his season was over.

headline: Hamas Closes News Media Outlets
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Freedom of the Press']
abstract: Hamas closed news media offices and a television production company for what it called the spreading of false reports and working for Israeli television.
lead_paragraph: GAZA — Hamas, the Islamist militant group controlling the Gaza Strip, closed news media offices and a television production company on Thursday for what it called the spreading of false reports and working for Israeli television.

headline: In Los Angeles Art Museum Arrival, a Foreshadowing of a Departure
abstract: When Jeffrey Deitch was named in 2010 to lead the Museum of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles, many in the city’s art world expressed guarded optimism. Others urged him to run from the job.
lead_paragraph: When Jeffrey Deitch was named in 2010 to lead the Museum of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles, many in the city’s art world expressed guarded optimism that he could turn around a museum that had come close to foundering only two years earlier.

headline: Obama and Vietnam’s Leader Pledge Deeper Ties
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'United States International Relations', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: President Truong Tan Sang’s White House visit follows Vietnam’s crackdown on bloggers, religious leaders and dissidents, and President Obama gently alluded to the abuses.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Bearing a copy of a letter from Ho Chi Minh to Harry S. Truman, the president of Vietnam met President Obama on Thursday and pledged to deepen trade and military ties with the United States even as they tangled over human rights.

headline: The Battle for the Fed
abstract: President Obama is nearing a decision on who should lead the Federal Reserve for the next four years.
lead_paragraph: President Obama is nearing a decision on who should lead the Federal Reserve for the next four years.

headline: HPV Vaccine Not Reaching Enough Girls, C.D.C. Says
keywords: ['Vaccination and Immunization', 'Human Papilloma Virus (HPV)', 'Women and Girls', 'Cervical Cancer']
abstract: A survey finds that doctors often fail to recommend the vaccination when teenage patients come in for other reasons, sometimes even for other vaccines.
lead_paragraph: The very low vaccination rate for teenage girls against the human papillomavirus — the most common sexually transmitted infection and a principal cause of cervical cancer — did not improve at all from 2011 to 2012, and health officials on Thursday said a survey found that doctors were often failing to bring it up or recommend it when girls came in for other reasons.

headline: California: Outcry Against Mayor Grows
abstract: Four more women said Thursday that they had been subject to unwanted sexual advances by Mayor Bob Filner of San Diego.
lead_paragraph: Four more women said Thursday that they had been subject to unwanted sexual advances by Mayor Bob Filner of San Diego, as the San Diego County Democratic Party joined the chorus of Democrats demanding his resignation. The women — who include a dean at San Diego State University and a retired Navy rear admiral — made their accusations in interviews with KPBS News. A total of seven women have said they were mistreated by the mayor. Despite crumbling support, Mr. Filner has said he would not step down. He has acknowledged inappropriate behavior but has said he is not guilty of sexual harassment.

headline: Growth From the Middle Out, and How It Works
abstract: President Obama is right to assert that reducing income inequality will help spur growth, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: Knicks Re-Sign Martin to a One-Year Deal
abstract: Kenyon Martin will make about $1.4 million next year on a veteran’s minimum contract, which was all the over-the-salary-cap Knicks could offer him.
lead_paragraph: The Knicks re-signed Kenyon Martin to a one-year deal. Martin, a tough, reliable forward throughout his 13-year career, will make about $1.4 million next year on a veteran’s minimum contract, which was all the over-the-salary-cap Knicks could offer him. The move gives the Knicks more frontcourt depth behind Tyson Chandler and Andrea Bargnani.

headline: Activision in $8.2 Billion Deal to Buy Back Stake From Vivendi
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: The deal represents the latest corporate maneuver for Activision’s chief executive, an entrepreneur who built the company into a giant with a market capitalization of nearly $17 billion.
lead_paragraph: Activision Blizzard, the world’s biggest video game publisher, has a reached an $8.2 billion deal to separate from Vivendi and become an independent company.

headline: U.N. ‘Troubled’ by Australia’s New Policy on Asylum Seekers
keywords: ['Asylum, Right of', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'International Relations']
abstract: The U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees said Friday that its review of Australia’s new deterrence-based policy had unearthed “significant shortcomings.”
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — The United Nations said Friday that it was “troubled” by Australia’s new policy to stem the tide of people undertaking dangerous boat journeys to seek asylum there, the latest in a series of public criticisms of the government’s tough new deterrence-based approach.

abstract: Major League Baseball and the Forest Service partnered to determine how maple bats could be made less likely to shatter.
