lead_paragraph: An unconventional program at Harris County Jail in Texas helps female inmates avoid re-entering lives of prostitution and homelessness after they have served their sentences.

headline: With Flick of His Wrists, Jeter Changes the Yankees’ Mood
abstract: Derek Jeter, returning from injury, made his importance to the Yankees immediately apparent, homering on the first pitch he saw. That jolt of momentum helped carry  the Yankees to victory.
lead_paragraph: At his locker early Sunday morning, Derek Jeter said he was no Yankees savior, but a chill went through the dugout three hours later as he homered to right in his first at-bat.

headline: Col. Bud Day, Heroic Pilot in Vietnam War, Dies at 88
abstract: Colonel Day, an Air Force fighter pilot, earned the Medal of Honor for enduring more than five years of brutality without divulging sensitive information to his captors.
lead_paragraph: Col. Bud Day, an Air Force fighter pilot who was shot down in the Vietnam War, imprisoned with John McCain in the notorious “Hanoi Hilton” and defiantly endured more than five years of brutality without divulging sensitive information to his captors, earning him the Medal of Honor, died on Saturday in Shalimar, Fla. He was 88.

headline: A Plan to Save Yosemite by Curbing Its Visitors

Salinger-like writer in the role of Father, and a protagonist who turns out to be as questionable a tour guide as the notoriously unreliable narrator of Ford Madox Ford’s classic “The Good Soldier.”

headline: A Pianist With 176 Keys to Play With
abstract: The French pianist Jean-Efflam Bavouzet played Beethoven and Debussy in the final recital of the International Keyboard Institute and Festival.
lead_paragraph: Some major recitalists seem to arrive at marquee status overnight, their fame achieved — or thrust upon them — in a heated rush. For others, renown comes more slowly, built up through glowing reviews and word of mouth. The French pianist Jean-Efflam Bavouzet, who performed at Mannes College the New School for Music on Saturday night, is a fine example of this second way.

abstract: The JACK Quartet’s concert was part of a free music series at Bryant Park in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: New Yorkers, for whom silence is an elusive luxury, are well aware that noise and music can be tormenting. Sound has long been co-opted as a weapon and used to torture prisoners, a concept that informs Jason Eckardt’s “Subject,” performed by the JACK Quartet on Friday evening at Bryant Park.

headline: A Familiar Role for Muslim Brotherhood: Opposition
abstract: The Brotherhood’s only reliable partners now are other Islamist groups whose members may be more willing to use violent or radical tactics.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Among the muddy, crowded tents where tens of thousands of Muslim Brotherhood members have been living for weeks in a vast sit-in protest, men in Islamic dress can still be seen carrying incongruous signs above the teeming crowd: “Liberals for Morsi,” “Christians for Morsi,” “Actors for Morsi.” It is the vestige of a plea for diverse allies in the Brotherhood’s quest to reinstate President Mohamed Morsi, who was ousted by the military on July 3.

headline: A Genial Comedian With Chatty Sidekicks and PG Patter
abstract: The comedian Terry Fator brought his genial, unusual ventriloquist act to the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — An entertainer can make a decent living and have a lasting impact by pushing the envelope — Richard Pryor, early George Carlin. Or he can ruffle few feathers but make a stupendous living by playing it safe, which means playing to the middle. Perhaps no one is doing that better right now than Terry Fator, who brought his genial, unusual ventriloquist act to the New Jersey Performing Arts Center here on Friday night.

headline: Asia Society to Present Modern Iranian Art
abstract: The new exhibition will showcase the work of 26 artists from the 1950s to the 1970s.
lead_paragraph: A new exhibition of modern Iranian art will showcase the work of 26 artists from the 1950s to the 1970s, when global art movements particularly influenced Iranian artists, the Asia Society Museum in New York is announcing on Monday. The show — coming amid stirrings of hope that Iran’s international relations will relax under its new president, Hassan Rouhani — will include more than 100 works that focus on what the museum calls the little-known pre-Islamic Revolution era.

headline: Found in Translation
abstract: For students of my generation in Iran, translated works opened a wider philosophical imagination, where borders between East and West dissolved.
lead_paragraph: Though it is common to lament the shortcomings of reading an important work in any language other than the original and of the “impossibility” of translation, I am convinced that works of philosophy (or literature for that matter — are they different?) in fact gain far more than they lose in translation.

lead_paragraph: For all of his accomplishments and his renown in Latin American music, Yomo Toro never allowed his fame to take away from his authenticity.

headline: Trespassing on the Proving Ground of the Next Generation
abstract: Festival TBD: Emergency Glitter focused on a new generation of choreographers whose efforts loosely represent a cross section of what is happening in dance today.
lead_paragraph: When is the last time so much new dance crept into a New York summer? At Abrons Arts Center, the producer Ben Pryor gave downtown dance a jolt with his inaugural Festival TBD: Emergency Glitter, which ended Sunday, a five-day event focusing on a new generation of choreographers. Their efforts loosely represent a cross-section of what is happening in dance today: A return to full-bodied movement with toes that aren’t afraid to point. Exploring the objectified body with a feminist eye. Showing the formality of a flexed buttock.

headline: Harlem Stage Prepares to Export Its Own Opera
abstract: Harlem Stage is banking on “Makandal” — its first opera commission and an ambitious, contemporary work revolving around the leader of an 18th-century slave revolt in Haiti — to raise its international profile.
lead_paragraph: Since its founding 30 years ago, Harlem Stage has burnished its reputation by presenting innovative artists like Bill T. Jones and Vijay Iyer and plumbing social issues. Now, the theater is betting that “Makandal” — its first opera commission and an ambitious, contemporary work revolving around the leader of an 18th-century slave revolt in Haiti — will raise its international profile and win it respect as a producer. But the group faces large hurdles.

headline: Old-Time Religion in Modern Guise
abstract: Sinead O’Connor made a foray into traditional religious music with “Gospel Sessions” at Alice Tully Hall as part of the Lincoln Center Festival.

Gospel contains forces such singers might desire access to: virtuosity, resistance, belief, magic. But the picture feels different when the pop singer is, say, a 46-year-old Irish female priest — ordained in 1999 by an independent Catholic group not recognized by the church — with serious interests in Rastafari and Hinduism and serious problems with organized religion.

headline: The Real Rhinemaidens of Route 66

lead_paragraph: BAYREUTH, Germany — Wagner traditionalists incensed by Frank Castorf’s new production of Wagner’s “Ring” here at the Bayreuth Festival, which presents the epic cycle as a story of the global race for oil ricocheting from North Texas to the Caspian Sea, should take some solace: It could have been worse.

headline: Pope’s Trip to Brazil Seen as ‘Strong Start’ in Revitalizing Church
abstract: A visit to the nation with more Catholics than any other shows how the Vatican aims to stem the loss of worshipers.

It was a vibrant display of the Vatican’s ambition of halting the losses of worshipers to evangelical churches and the rising appeal of secularism.

Unlike hers, mine are not written in a code that will not be deciphered until years after my death. My best friend has instructions in the event I die before her, though, to fly across the country immediately and destroy them. They aren’t meant for anyone but me, a reminder of the moments of my life, good and bad.

Will, William Safire and countless other prominent journalists have done it, as have Southern writers, Northern writers, writers of science and of science fiction, novices and old pros.

But their profits are soaring, even as the economy slows, a situation that makes their shopworn anti-regulatory argument all the more threadbare.

headline: New York Film Festival Will Open With ‘Captain Phillips’

lead_paragraph: For a film series that in the first few of its 51 annual programs began with works from directors like Luis Buñuel, Jean-Luc Godard and François Truffaut, the New York Film Festival has more recently used its prestigious opening-night slot to spotlight more visible, mainstream and star-studded efforts. Those descriptions all apply to “Captain Phillips,” a new motion picture with Tom Hanks that will make its premiere as the opening-night selection of this year’s New York Film Festival, its organizers said Monday.

headline: Driving a 1935 Avions Voisin C25 Aérodyne
abstract: This French classic has the look of speed, but not the power to back it up.
lead_paragraph: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — To take a spin in a 1935 Avions Voisin C25 Aérodyne, first one must learn how to get into it. Of course, it has doors – with delicate nickel-plated handles – but you must tug on them with just enough pressure to flex the handles outward. This effort separates a catch from a door-frame latch; there is no mechanical locking mechanism. The door is now free to open. Inside, to coax the door back into its frame, pull on a leather strap that comes out of the door panel, rather like summoning one’s servant.

headline: China Opts for Only Small Steps to Stimulate Economy
abstract: Even as new economic reports signal that China’s economy is slowing, Beijing continues to resist a large stimulus package.

Instead, the government announced a “mini stimulus” that included a tax cut for small companies, a reduction of red tape and costs for exporters, and the opening of investment in railroad construction to private capital.

This is the 10th anniversary of the festival, which for the first time will include two free shows at the Delacorte Theater on Sept. 16 and 17, hosted by the Public Theater.

headline: Harnessing Physics in Grand Spaces to Make Music
abstract: When William Close invents an instrument, experimentation is key. But to create the Earth Harp, an instrument that can span 1,000 feet and attach to mountains, took a feat of physics.
lead_paragraph: From the stage of the Shanghai Grand Theater in China more than a dozen strings stretch from a wooden wing out across the audience and disappear into the darkness of the upper balconies. It’s an instrument unlike anything Bach or Beethoven could have ever imagined. The entire concert hall has been recruited as an echo chamber to create a unique, ethereal sound. But this instrument has turned even grander spaces into music makers. When anchored to the Colosseum in Rome or Seattle’s Space Needle, the world’s largest string instrument is both a powerful sonic experience and an arresting visual image.

(He is also vice chairman of the consulting firm IHS.)

headline: Romney’s Reflections
abstract: Did he really want to run? Does he get why the 47 percent comment was a big deal?

The answers, judging from an excerpt in the Washington Post of Dan Balz’s new book “Collision 2012,” are: Not much, and more than we ever imagined.

headline: Fainting in Heat
abstract: Heat syncope, or fainting, is a risk on hot summer days, and responding properly is necessary to avoid complications.
lead_paragraph: With temperatures in the Northeast often in the 90s this summer — and the heat index sometimes surpassing 100 degrees — just standing on the street or on a steamy subway platform can place the body under excessive stress. In New York City during the week of July 14, 911 calls were up by 9 percent over the previous year, with many related to the heat, the fire department said.

headline: Bryce Pinkham and LaChanze Are Broadway Bound
abstract: Mr. Pinkham joins the cast of “A Gentleman’s Guide to Love and Murder” while LaChanze will appear in “If/Then,” a new musical.
lead_paragraph: Casting additions to two shows scheduled for the coming Broadway season were announced on Monday. Bryce Pinkham, who is playing Longaville in the Public Theater’s Shakespeare in the Park production of “Love’s Labour’s Lost,” will join the cast of “A Gentleman’s Guide to Love and Murder,” the musical by Robert L. Freedman and Steven Lutvak that had a successful run in Hartford last fall and opens on Broadway at the Walter Kerr Theater on Oct. 22. Mr. Pinkham is to play Monty Navarro, who stands to become the Earl of Highhurst once he dispatches the eight better claimants. Those eight heirs are all portrayed by Jefferson Mays, who played the octuple role in Hartford. The show is directed by Darko Tresnjak.

headline: Talks Begin on Mideast, to Doubts on All Sides
abstract: The prevailing narrative among experts is that neither the Israelis nor the Palestinians appear remotely prepared to make the hard calls needed to cement a lasting peace.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For all of the intricacies of issues like the shape of future borders, security arrangements and the status of Jerusalem, the Middle East peace talks that resumed Monday night are dominated by two simple questions: If it took Secretary of State John Kerry countless phone calls and six trips to the Middle East just to get Israeli and Palestinian officials to the negotiating table, how will it be possible to achieve a comprehensive peace agreement? And what will happen if his herculean negotiating efforts fall short?

headline: BMW Unveils i3 Electric Car

lead_paragraph: BMW seems to have stepped into the limelight with confidence where its first all-new electric car is concerned. At its official introduction Monday in New York, London and Beijing, BMW promised that the i3 would be, despite its new architecture and batteries-only powertrain, like every other “ultimate driving machine” in terms of driving quality.

headline: Tracing Germs Through the Aisles
abstract: Overuse of antibiotics has caused growing resistance to drugs, and many scientists say their heavy use on farm animals is a major culprit.

As scientists pushed carts heaped with meat through the aisles, curious shoppers sometimes asked if they were on the Atkins diet.

headline: When Clean Was a New Concept in the Operating Room
abstract: The words “surgery” and “sterile” were not always bedfellows. A short history of advances in the hospital.
lead_paragraph: Today, keeping things clean as a way to ward off germs and infections just makes sense. But before antibiotic-resistant superbugs became a hospital’s biggest concern, there were the bad old days when doctors would move from surgery to surgery without washing. And surprisingly it was only during the 20th century that sterilization evolved from a simple and very new concept into one of the most important life-saving practices in medicine.

headline: The She-Devil of Constitution Avenue
abstract: Beware the female dollar.
lead_paragraph: I’ve spent five years and more watching the inflationphobes, who weren’t particularly sensible to begin with, descend into shrill unholy madness. They could have reacted to the failure of their predictions — the continued absence of the runaway inflation they insisted was just around the corner — by stepping back and reconsidering both their model and their recommendations. But no. At best, we see a proliferation of new reasons to raise interest rates in a depressed economy, with nary an acknowledgment that previous predictions were dead wrong. At worst, we see conspiracy theories — we actually have double-digit inflation, but the BLS is spiriting the evidence away in its black helicopters and burying it in Area 51.

headline: Thompson and de Blasio Vie for Opening as Quinn Rises

headline: Plan to Capture an Asteroid Runs Into Politics

lead_paragraph: It is known, informally, as the asteroid-lasso plan: NASA wants to launch an unmanned spacecraft in 2018 that would capture a small asteroid — maybe 7 to 10 yards wide — haul it closer to Earth, then send astronauts up to examine it, in 2021 or beyond.

headline: War May Be Over, but One House Fills Up With Blood
abstract: “Oresteia,” the 1895 adaptation of the Aeschylus trilogy dealing with the aftermath of the Trojan War, is being revived at Bard College.
lead_paragraph: ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y. — Hardly a newcomer to the summer arts game, Bard College has long attracted cognoscenti to its Bard Music Festival, a two-weekend musicological intensive doubling as a sumptuous smorgasbord of concerts. This year’s festival, devoted to Stravinsky, starts on Aug. 9. Fairly recently, as a prelude to the main event, Bard began to offer a fully staged opera whose composer or theme has been related to the festival. Under the watch of Leon Botstein, the conductor, scholar and Bard president, we have seen memorable revivals of once-esteemed works by Meyerbeer and Schreker, alongside more quixotic resurrections.

headline: A New Shrew and Mice Memory
abstract: Recent developments in health and science news. Also this week: cheetahs’ body temperatures while hunting and the effect of pesticides on honeybees.
lead_paragraph: Scientists discovered a new species of shrew, corrected erroneous beliefs about the body temperature of cheetahs, fed bees polluted pollen with disastrous results and planted a false memory in the mind of a mouse. In the meantime, NASA wants to know why a spacewalking astronaut’s helmet suddenly took on water.

headline: Third Point Takes Aim at Sony in Investor Letter
abstract: Taking out his well-known acerbic pen, the hedge fund tycoon writes of Sony, “keeping entertainment underexposed, undervalued and underperforming is not a strategy for success.”
lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:02 p.m. |  The activist investor Daniel S. Loeb is turning up the heat on Sony.

headline: In a Rainstorm of Brass, the Lightning Struck From Audience Smartphones
abstract: Jacob Garchik’s The Heavens, the Asphalt Orchestra and the Kronos Quartet performed on a rainy Sunday night at the Damrosch Park Bandshell at Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: Musicians and audiences have wilted in the heat at outdoor concerts this summer. But on Sunday evening, a hardy audience sat on wet chairs and huddled under umbrellas for several hours to hear the Asphalt Orchestra and the Kronos Quartet perform as part of the Lincoln Center Out of Doors festival.

headline: Greyhound Rolls Out Streaming Movies and Music for Passengers
abstract: Greyhound offers streaming service for its passengers.
lead_paragraph: Greyhound has begun rolling out a streaming entertainment system that allows its passengers to watch movies and television shows, listen to music, surf the Web and play online games with their own Wi-Fi enabled portable electronic devices.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Iraq and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Iraq, Italy, Kashmir and Thailand.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Iraq, Italy, Kashmir and Thailand.

headline: ‘Gender Undertones’ on Fed Choice Provoke Reader Reaction
abstract: Readers complain, and writers respond, about a front-page article in The Times on the choice of possible candidates to succeed the Federal Reserve chairman.
lead_paragraph: A front-page article on Friday – with its engaging lead paragraph, eye-catching graphic illustration and provocative concept — created plenty of buzz. It quickly garnered nearly 300 reader comments – and some complaints to this office.

headline: Guides to a Journey Into the Brain
abstract: Patricia S. Churchland, a philosopher, probes for the organ’s moral center, while Sally Satel and Scott O. Lilienfeld write to debunk pop neuroscience.
lead_paragraph: A journey into the human brain starts with the usual travel decisions: will you opt for a no-frills sightseeing jaunt, a five-star luxury cruise, or trek a little off the beaten track, skipping the usual tourist attractions?

headline: On the Trail of Germs
abstract: Lance Price is a microbiologist on a mission to precisely match bacteria in the supermarket meat with those in women with urinary infections.
lead_paragraph: Lance Price is a microbiologist on a mission to precisely match bacteria in the supermarket meat with those in women with urinary infections.

headline: Uncovering the Truth Behind a Twisted Anti-Abortion Tale
abstract: In case you missed it, Emily Bazelon wrote an illuminating column on Slate about the so-called evidence behind Todd Akin’s “legitimate rape” comment.
lead_paragraph: In November, the magazine published Emily Bazelon’s profile of Charmaine Yoest, the head of the Americans United for Life, an anti-abortion group, which has been working with Republican state legislators to write laws making access to abortion more difficult. In her article, Bazelon wrote about the controversy that was sparked when Todd Akin, a Republican congressman from Missouri who was running for the Senate, claimed that victims of “legitimate rape” cannot become pregnant. Akin’s comments had apparently been based on, as Bazelon wrote, a“1972 essay by an obstetrician named Fred Mecklenburg, who cited a Nazi experiment in which women were told they were on their way to die in the gas chambers — and then were allowed to live, so that doctors could check whether they would still ovulate. Since few did, Mecklenburg claimed that women exposed to the emotional trauma of rape wouldn’t be able to become pregnant, either.” Mecklenburg’s essay was published in a book financed by the anti-abortion group.

headline: A Complicated Cetacean
keywords: ['Whales and Whaling', 'Cruelty to Animals', 'AMUSEMENT AND THEME PARKS']
abstract: Orcas, known popularly as killer whales, are the subject of a new documentary that hopes to bring attention to problems they face in captivity.
lead_paragraph: Orcas, known popularly as killer whales, are the subject of a new documentary that hopes to bring attention to problems they face in captivity.

headline: A City Invokes Seizure Laws to Save Homes
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Eminent Domain', 'Foreclosures', 'Mortgages', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: With recent gains in home prices doing little for some blighted neighborhoods, Richmond, Calif., is about to become the first city in the nation to try a novel way to stop foreclosures.
lead_paragraph: The power of eminent domain has traditionally worked against homeowners, who can be forced to sell their property to make way for a new highway or shopping mall. But now the working-class city of Richmond, Calif., hopes to use the same legal tool to help people stay right where they are.

headline: A Savior Taking the Reins
abstract: The new American dream, as depicted on CNBC’s reality series “The Profit,” celebrates the big guy, not the little guy.
lead_paragraph: In the American dream as it once was, one person with an innovative idea and a lot of elbow grease could make a difference, and maybe a fortune. It was a myth — sometimes realized, but a myth still — created for the little guy.

headline: Smart, Social and Erratic in Captivity
keywords: ['Whales and Whaling', 'AMUSEMENT AND THEME PARKS', 'Cruelty to Animals', 'Movies', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: A film, a book and a trainer’s death have renewed debate among scientists and animal advocates on the wisdom and morality of keeping killer whales in marine parks.
lead_paragraph: Should some of the most social, intelligent and charismatic animals on the planet be kept in captivity by human beings?

headline: Aspen Music Festival Embarks on New Era
abstract: The Aspen Music Festival is enjoying a revitalization, with new buildings, a new music director and a celebration of Benjamin Britten’s centenary.
lead_paragraph: ASPEN, Colo. — Give the Aspen Music Festival and School full points for resilience. In 2010 the institution was just emerging from several years of turmoil. Alan Fletcher, its president and chief executive (and a composer represented in this season’s programming), had been fired and rehired amid faculty uprisings and administrative disputes. Its board chairman had been voted out. The conductor David Zinman, its music director and a founder of its American Academy of Conducting, had left in a serious huff.

headline: CNN to Produce Documentary on Hillary Clinton
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Movies', 'Television']
abstract: Two days earlier, NBC said it would make a four-hour mini-series on Ms. Clinton
lead_paragraph: The intense focus on Hillary Rodham Clinton, former secretary of state and 2008 presidential candidate, heading toward a potential second run at the presidency was stepped up again Monday as CNN announced that its film division would produce a documentary on her.

headline: A Summer Internship at a Place Where Most People Stay for Good
abstract: Woodlawn has enlisted four University of Pennsylvania graduate students to help clean and restore some of its 1,316 mausoleums and 150,000 monuments and gravestones.
lead_paragraph: Even the best internships can require some degree of menial labor: answering phones, working copy machines, making Starbucks runs.

headline: What’s an Idea Worth?
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'ACCOUNTING AND ACCOUNTANTS', 'Productivity', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: Why the billable hour no longer makes economic sense.
lead_paragraph: Like a lot of accountants, Jason Blumer never really wanted to be an accountant; he wanted to play guitar in a hair-metal band. But like most guys who want to play guitar in a hair-metal band, Blumer eventually realized that there wasn’t much money in touring bars and being paid in beer-smeared $20 bills. So he changed gears and decided to follow his dad into what seemed like one of the more steady businesses around. After college, he bought some suits, joined a midsize firm in South Carolina and processed his clients’ payroll and tax returns. He billed them by the hour. He hated every second of it.

headline: Pivot TV Pitches to Young Viewers
abstract: A channel for young people called Pivot, which will become available in 40 million homes on Thursday, aims for “entertainment that inspires and compels social change.”
lead_paragraph: Toward the end of Evan Shapiro’s semester-long course on television management at New York University, he spends an hour on the topic “Building a Post-Network Channel from the Ground Up.” For the 19- and 20-year-old students — the fickle viewers that advertisers and programmers so desperately want to reach — the final assignment is to pitch some sort of TV innovation, be it a new way to schedule shows, a distribution strategy or even a brand-new network.

headline: Dumpstaphunk, Five Finger Death Punch and Ben Monder
abstract: From New Orleans funk to West Coast metal and labyrinthine guitar-based chamber music.
lead_paragraph: DUMPSTAPHUNK

headline: Hotels Add Libraries as Amenity to Keep Guests Inside
abstract: Hotel chains are joining a trend started by boutiques in stocking books and newspapers in library-style locations for their guests.
lead_paragraph: Reading material in many hotel rooms has become about as spare as it can be — open the desk drawer and it might hold a Gideon Bible and a Yellow Pages.

headline: In Performance: ‘Avenue Q’
abstract: Sala Iwamatsu, as Christmas Eve, and the puppeteer Veronica J. Kuehn, with Kate Monster, sing “The More You Ruv Someone” from “Avenue Q,” which celebrates its 10-year run on July 31.
lead_paragraph: Sala Iwamatsu, as Christmas Eve, and the puppeteer Veronica J. Kuehn, with Kate Monster, sing “The More You Ruv Someone” from “Avenue Q,” which celebrates its 10-year run on July 31.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Emoji Tracking and Spoofing GPS
abstract: The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for important and peculiar items. Monday’s selections include a catalog of which emoji, the more elaborate cousins of emoticons, are popular and which ones aren’t. Plus, a group of students in Texas take control of an $80 million yacht by manipulating its navigation tools.
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: People Who Need Famous People
abstract: “Buyer & Cellar,” whose subject is a really, really big star, considers the great divide of renown that separates the idol from the idolized.
lead_paragraph: When the weather turns hot, Americans crave celebrity. Not for themselves, necessarily. Who wants to work hard at anything, even becoming famous, in July and August? But there’s something about the lives of notorious others, laid out as flat as comic strips, that grips the lazy consciousness that is our summer state of mind.

headline: Senate Backs F.B.I. Chief and Considers Other Picks
abstract: The Senate voted 93-to-1 to confirm James B. Comey, who was President Obama’s pick as director of the agency.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate overwhelmingly confirmed James B. Comey as director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation on Monday even as Republicans and Democrats struggled to hold together the fragile deal that preserved the filibuster for executive branch appointees.

headline: Clashing Titans for Sale
abstract: Two skeletons found in Montana by commercial fossil hunters are to be auctioned in New York, where they could bring an estimated $7 million to $9 million.
lead_paragraph: Many paleontologists agree that two fossilized dinosaur skeletons found in the Hell Creek formation in Montana might be a major discovery.

headline: The Jump to a Composite Plane
abstract: Plane manufacturers have been increasingly using composite materials instead of traditional ones like aluminum. Half of the weight of Boeing’s latest plane, the 787, comes from composites.
lead_paragraph: Plane manufacturers have been increasingly using composite materials instead of traditional ones like aluminum. Half of the weight of Boeing’s latest plane, the 787, comes from composites.

headline: Video of the Pope’s ‘Gay Lobby’ Remarks
abstract: “We must distinguish the fact that a person is gay from the fact of lobbying, because no lobbies are good,” Pope Francis told reporters on Monday. “If a person is gay, and he searches for the Lord and has good will, who am I to judge?”
lead_paragraph: During a news conference on his flight back to Rome from Brazil on Monday, Pope Francis was asked about his much-reported acknowledgment last month that there is a “gay lobby” inside the Vatican hierarchy.

headline: How to Catch an Asteroid
abstract: NASA is proposing an unmanned spacecraft that could capture a small asteroid passing near the Earth.
lead_paragraph: NASA is proposing an unmanned spacecraft that could capture a small asteroid passing near the Earth.

headline: U.S. Accuses JPMorgan of Manipulating Energy Markets
abstract: The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission formally accused JPMorgan Chase of orchestrating trading strategies to turn inefficient power plants into profit centers.
lead_paragraph: The nation’s top energy regulator on Monday formally accused JPMorgan Chase of manipulating energy markets, foreshadowing a multimillion-dollar settlement that is expected as early as this week, according to people briefed on the matter.

headline: Fast Airport Screening Is in Store for More
abstract: The Transportation Security Administration has an ambitious goal of enrolling 25 percent of all passengers in its popular PreCheck initiative by the end of 2013.
lead_paragraph: THE Transportation Security Administration is rushing to greatly expand its popular PreCheck program, with the goal of having 25 percent of all air travelers eligible for a fast-pass through airport checkpoints by the end of the year — and 50 percent by the end of 2014.

headline: Hot Rods and Hot Nights at a Hamptons Party for Kenny Scharf
abstract: An opening for the artist Kenny Scharf, which brought out Cindy Sherman, Calvin Klein, Patrick Demarchelier and others, offered a playful respite from the seriousness of the Hamptons party circuit.
lead_paragraph: Who“I live in space, but I’m on planet Earth,” Kenny Scharf said. “I don’t want to go live in Mars but in my mind I go there all the time.” The painter, who was the roommate of Keith Haring and a friend of Jean-Michel Basquiat during the “anything goes” days of 1980s New York, was in East Hampton, N.Y., on Saturday for an opening at Eric Firestone Gallery that paired photos of the era by the late Tseng Kwong Chi with Scharf’s own paintings. Spotted at the party were downtown veterans like Bob Colacello; Patrick Demarchelier; Vincent Fremont and his daughter Casey; Calvin Klein, Max Levai, Kyle DeWoody, Lisa Marie Fernandez; and Kembra Pfahler. Cindy Sherman remarked that her friendship with Scharf began in the 1980s, “but I don’t remember how or in what context.” As the proverb goes: if you remember it, you weren’t there.

headline: Weinstein and Disney, Together Again
abstract: Putting aside past acrimony, Harvey Weinstein, the prominent producer, will team with Disney to make a movie adaptation of the book series “Artemis Fowl.’'
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Time apparently does heal all wounds: Harvey Weinstein, who bitterly parted ways with the Walt Disney Company in 2005, leaving behind his Miramax Films, will produce a movie adaptation of “Artemis Fowl” for Disney.

headline: Ad Watch: Christine Quinn
abstract: Michael M. Grynbaum, a New York Times Metro reporter, deconstructs Christine Quinn’s first campaign ad.
lead_paragraph: Michael M. Grynbaum, a New York Times Metro reporter, deconstructs Christine Quinn’s first campaign ad.

headline: F.D.A. Strengthens Warnings on Lariam, an Anti-Malaria Drug
abstract: The Food and Drug Administration said an anti-malaria drug, known as Lariam, must update its warning label to show that some of its psychiatric side effects can become permanent.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration announced on Monday that a commonly used anti-malaria drug must carry the so-called black box warning on its label because of the danger that the drug could cause serious neurological and psychiatric side effects, some of which can become permanent.

headline: Six Decades Later, a Second Rescue Attempt
keywords: ['Korean War', 'Pilots', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Missing in Action', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Harsh weather in North Korea prevented a Navy pilot from retrieving the remains of a fellow airman killed 63 years ago in one of the fiercest battles of the Korean War.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — As more than 100,000 Chinese soldiers swarmed over far fewer American Marines and soldiers in subzero temperatures on treacherous terrain in one of the fiercest battles of the Korean War, two United States Navy pilots took off from an aircraft carrier to provide cover for their comrades on the ground.

headline: Despite Two New Studies on Motives for Monogamy, the Debate Continues
abstract: Two teams ended up with opposing conclusions in trying to solve the puzzle of why some mammals choose a single mate.
lead_paragraph: The golden lion tamarin, a one-pound primate that lives in Brazil, is a stunningly monogamous creature. A male will typically pair with a female and they will stay close for the rest of their lives, mating only with each other and then working together to care for their young.

headline: Mediating as French Culture and Economics Collide
abstract: Aurélie Filippetti, a novelist, is finding new kinds of criticism as France’s minister of culture and communication.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Aurélie Filippetti, the granddaughter of an Italian immigrant who worked in France’s coal mines, is finding her own way through the traps and tunnels of austerity and snobbery.

headline: Weiner’s Behavior Prompts a Question: Why Did He Do It?
abstract: Professionals offered a variety of possible explanations for Anthony D. Weiner’s online behavior, including addiction, a mood disorder and feelings of inadequacy.
lead_paragraph: As Anthony D. Weiner tries to repair the damage left by new revelations about his online behavior with women, one question nags at voters and those who once supported him: Why did he do it?

headline: Herb Kaplow, Voice of ABC and NBC News, Dies at 86
abstract: Mr. Kaplow’s resonant voice and craggy face were familiar to generations of viewers of the nightly news broadcast.
lead_paragraph: Herb Kaplow, a longtime Washington correspondent who brought an authoritative voice to his wide-ranging reporting for NBC News and ABC News for more than four decades, died on Saturday in Arlington, Va. He was 86.

headline: Rodriguez Likely to Contest a Ban
abstract: As Major League Baseball prepares to issue a series of suspensions stemming from its investigation of an anti-aging clinic, Alex Rodriguez is planning to fight a potential punishment, his lawyer said.
lead_paragraph: As Major League Baseball prepares to issue a series of suspensions stemming from its investigation of a South Florida anti-aging clinic, Alex Rodriguez is planning to fight a potential punishment, his lawyer said Monday.

headline: Wendi Murdoch Hires a New Lawyer, Suggesting a Divorce May Turn Messy
keywords: ['Divorce, Separations and Annulments', 'Child Custody and Support']
abstract: A month after Rupert Murdoch surprised his wife with divorce papers, Wendi Murdoch has hired a lawyer with a track record of representing women separating from powerful men.
lead_paragraph: Just over a month after Rupert Murdoch surprised his wife of 14 years with divorce papers, Wendi Murdoch has switched lawyers, a move signaling that the separation could take an acrimonious turn.

headline: New Challenges for the Fixers of Boeing’s 787
abstract: The costs and methods for repairing the carbon-composite jet are unclear, and the Dreamliner damaged by fire at Heathrow will be the first test of major work.
lead_paragraph: The thin plastic skin on Boeing’s 787 Dreamliner is an engineering marvel, a mix of carbon fibers and epoxy molded into large barrel-shaped sections that are then baked at up to 350 degrees in giant ovens.

headline: Verdict Is Expected Tuesday for Soldier in Leaks Case
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Courts-Martial']
abstract: A military judge has reached a verdict and will announce it Tuesday in the high-profile court-martial of Pfc. Bradley Manning, the army said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A military judge has reached a verdict and will announce it Tuesday afternoon in the high-profile court-martial of Pfc. Bradley Manning, the former Army intelligence analyst whose release of some 700,000 secret documents to WikiLeaks opened a window into American military and diplomatic activities.

headline: Militants Attack Prison in Northwest Pakistan
abstract: The concerted assault resulted in prisoners escaping, said a senior security official in the town of Dera Ismail Khan, where the prison is, but exact numbers are not known.
lead_paragraph: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — Militants armed with rockets and heavy weapons launched a concerted assault on a major prison in northwestern Pakistan late Monday, triggering a fierce firefight with security forces in an apparent bid to free militant prisoners.

headline: A Region Drenched
abstract: Too much rain in the Deep South has caused up to billions of dollars in crop losses.
lead_paragraph: Too much rain in the Deep South has caused up to billions of dollars in crop losses.

headline: Tunisia Faces More Anger After an Ambush Kills Soldiers
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Terrorism', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations']
abstract: At least eight soldiers were killed on the country’s northwestern border, an attack that comes amid large protests against the Islamist-led government.
lead_paragraph: TUNIS — At least eight Tunisian soldiers were killed Monday in an ambush on the country’s northwestern border, an area where Islamist rebels are known to be active, a presidential spokesman said. The government, increasingly embattled after days of public protests over the assassination of a left-wing politician last week, immediately called for three days of national mourning for the soldiers.

headline: Marlins Trying to Move On After Martinez Resignation
abstract: A day after the Miami Marlins’ hitting coach, Tino Martinez, resigned amid reports that he abused players, the Marlins were gearing up for a series against the Mets.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The Miami Marlins were gathering themselves on Monday and trying to move forward one day after their hitting coach, Tino Martinez, resigned amid reports that he had verbally and physically abused players.

headline: Suspect in Case of Green Paint Vandalism
abstract: The Washington police detained a woman on Monday who they believe defaced property at the National Cathedral with green paint.
lead_paragraph: The Washington police detained a woman on Monday who they believe defaced property at the National Cathedral after green paint was found splashed on a pipe organ and a carved wooden altarpiece.

headline: Navy Officer’s Killing Escalates Fight for Mexican State
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations']
abstract: Two months after Mexico’s president sent troops to Michoacán, gunmen killed one of the Mexican Navy’s most senior officers, raising the stakes in a battle for control of the area.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Two months after Mexico’s president sent troops to the embattled state of Michoacán, gunmen ambushed and killed one of the Mexican Navy’s most senior officers on Sunday, raising the stakes in a battle for control of an area long considered a volcano of rebellion and violence.

headline: Odd Fox News Interview Lifts Reza Aslan’s Biography on Jesus
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: A Fox News interviewer awkwardly questioned the Muslim author on why he had written about Jesus, and sales of his book, “Zealot,” surged once the video caught fire online.
lead_paragraph: Reza Aslan, the author of “Zealot,” a provocative new biography of Jesus, has found an inadvertent ally in generating book publicity: Fox News.

headline: F.B.I. Charges 159 Men With Forcing Teenage Girls Into Prostitution
abstract: A nationwide operation led to arrests in more than 70 cities over the last few days. Some of the victims were as young as 13, the agency said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Bureau of Investigation said Monday that a nationwide operation had led to the arrests over the last few days of 159 men charged with forcing about 105 teenage girls to work as prostitutes. Some of the girls were as young as 13.

headline: 13th-Century Alleyways and a Modern Plague of Illegal Renovations
abstract: Beijing is losing many of its hutongs, the traditional Chinese alleyways that date to the 13th century, and gaining a bevy of illegal, outsize construction in their places.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Wang Xue stood in the middle of his courtyard house, next to a pomegranate tree. It could have been a scene out of a Tang dynasty poem but for the sound of a jackhammer and a layer of construction dust that thinly caked the rows of potted plants and vine-covered awnings.

headline: Merger as a Career Capstone for the Chief of Publicis
abstract: The merger with Omnicom has been widely seen as a coup for Publicis and a career capstone for Maurice Lévy.
lead_paragraph: IN 1972 a fire tore through the Paris headquarters of a small French ad agency named Publicis. Rather than destroying the firm, it laid the foundation for the creation of what could soon be the world’s biggest advertising company.

headline: Killing the Arab Spring in Its Cradle
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: The Arab Spring is under threat in Tunisia, the country of its birth.
lead_paragraph: TUNIS — MOHAMED BRAHMI, the left-wing politician who was assassinated outside his home here last Thursday, was born in Sidi Bouzid, the same town where a desperate fruit vendor set himself on fire in December 2010, triggering the Tunisian revolution — and the Arab Spring.

headline: The ‘Soul Sisters’ in the Kitchen
abstract: An unequal system between African-American cooks and their white employers has been in place and largely unchanged for decades.
lead_paragraph: FORT WORTH — DORA CHARLES and Idella Parker, two black Southern cooks, were born nearly a half century apart and likely never met. But if they did, they would be soul sisters.

headline: Don’t Give Up on Health Care Cost Control
keywords: ['Doctors', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Law and Legislation', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: An obscure law called the S.G.R. is a powerful bargaining chip in getting doctors to agree to payment reform
lead_paragraph: S.G.R. More than 99 percent of Americans have no idea what these three letters stand for. And yet they are extremely valuable: worth about $140 billion. This week, a House committee will finally take up the issue.

headline: Tunnel Vision
abstract: A short impressionistic film shot from New York City subway trains.
lead_paragraph: A short impressionistic film shot from New York City subway trains.

headline: Dispute Blocks Hollywood’s Share of Chinese Box Office
abstract: A disagreement has taken root over whether to apply a new tax in China to the share of movie ticket sales that is owed to American film studios.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — As box-office sales for American films soften in China, Hollywood studios are running up against a new problem: they haven’t been receiving payments for the Chinese screenings of their films, according to reports in Variety and The Hollywood Reporter on Monday.

headline: Angels Pay Heavy Price for Gamble on Pujols
abstract: With Albert Pujols most likely out for the season because of an injury, the Angels are learning a lesson the Yankees already know about 10-year contracts for aging stars.
lead_paragraph: Arte Moreno basked in the spotlight of his own making at Angel Stadium in December 2011. Moreno, the owner of the Los Angeles Angels, was there to announce the signing of Albert Pujols to a 10-year, $240 million contract. Moreno explained that he was motivated partly by a desire to keep up with the Yankees, who had beaten the Angels in the 2009 playoffs.

headline: ‘Tunnel Vision’
abstract: A short impressionistic film shot from New York City subway trains.
lead_paragraph: This movie runs thousands of times every day. It’s in 3D and Sensurround and it’s an entertainment bargain thrown in free with the price of every subway swipe. The best seating is actually standing, at the head or rear of the train, eyes glued to the window.

headline: Al Qaeda in Iraq Scores Big
abstract: Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki is in danger of losing control of his country.
lead_paragraph: Jailbreaks are common in Iraq, but the brazen assaults on the prisons at Abu Ghraib and Taji last week are in a class by themselves. The attacks freed perhaps as many as 800 militants, who are now sought by Interpol as a “major threat” to global security. The attacks showed the fearsome and growing strength of Al Qaeda in Iraq, seemingly on the decline only a few years ago. They also raised new questions about the effectiveness of Iraq’s authoritarian prime minister, Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, as well as the stability of Iraq itself.

headline: Choosing the Next Fed Leader
abstract: Janet Yellen is clearly the best choice. Will President Obama see that?
lead_paragraph: Despite a campaign from allies both inside and outside the White House, the recent drive to install Lawrence Summers as the next chairman of the Federal Reserve seems to be faltering — and with good reason: He is not the best person for the job, as a group of Democratic senators made clear in a letter to President Obama last week calling for the nomination of Janet Yellen, the vice chairwoman of the Fed’s board of governors.

headline: An Escalating Fight Over Military Justice
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials', 'Assaults']
abstract: Support is growing for an important proposal that would give independent military prosecutors the power to decide which sexual assault crimes to try.
lead_paragraph: Despite powerful evidence that the military’s approach to sexual assault needs an overhaul, the resistance to change among military brass and their enablers on Capitol Hill remains fierce.

headline: U.S. Balancing Act With Egypt Grows Trickier
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Foreign Aid', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The Obama administration has prodded Egypt’s generals to restore a democratic government while trying not to jeopardize any future influence on the military or undermine security arrangements.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In four weeks of quiet but intense diplomacy, the Obama administration has engaged in a balancing act, prodding Egypt’s generals to avoid violence and restore a democratic government while trying not to jeopardize any future influence on the military or undermine security arrangements that have been at the heart of a three-decade relationship.

headline: A Bet on Clinton: If They Network, She Will Run
abstract: A new group dedicated to paving the way for a Hillary Clinton campaign in 2016 has recruited dozens of the Democratic Party’s most elite donors.
lead_paragraph: A new group dedicated to paving the way for a Hillary Clinton campaign in 2016 has already recruited dozens of the Democratic Party’s elite donors and bundlers, effectively kicking off the presidential money hunt more than three years before Election Day.

headline: Economic Slowdown Is Expected, but It’s Seen as Fleeting
abstract: The performance of the economy in the second quarter is one of many guides to when the Fed will taper off its bond-buying.
lead_paragraph: It can only get better from here — or at least that’s what economists hope.

keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Legal Profession', 'Gulf of Mexico Oil Spill (2010)']

headline: Tunisia: Prime Minister Calls for December Elections
abstract: Prime Minister Ali Laarayedh announced Monday that elections would be held Dec. 17 and said the government would stay in office to see through the transition.
lead_paragraph: In a concession to opposition groups that have been calling for his Islamist-led coalition to resign, Prime Minister Ali Laarayedh announced Monday that elections would be held Dec. 17. Mr. Laarayedh said the government would stay in office to see through the transition. “We are not clinging to power, but we have a duty and a responsibility that we will exercise to the end,” he said in comments on state television. One of the smaller parties in the ruling coalition, Ettakatol, has joined opposition calls for a government of national unity to replace the current government after the assassination of the legislator Mohamed Brahmi last week.

headline: Iran: Ahmadinejad Granted License to Start University
abstract: President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran, whose tumultuous two-term tenure is in its final few days, will be moving to academia.
lead_paragraph: President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran, whose tumultuous two-term tenure is in its final few days, will be moving to academia. The government’s Islamic Republic News Agency announced Monday that Mr. Ahmadinejad had been granted a license to start an international university in Tehran. It was the first official confirmation of Mr. Ahmadinejad’s postpresidential plans, which had been the subject of speculation for some time. The news agency said the charter of Mr. Ahmadinejad’s university, which apparently has not been named yet, must still be approved by two government ministries. Mr. Ahmadinejad, who could not run for a third term, is to relinquish the presidency on Sunday to the cleric Hassan Rouhani. Mr. Rouhani has promised a less confrontational style than Mr. Ahmadinejad, a conservative whose eight years in office were marked by fewer personal freedoms, more economic problems, fraud accusations and violent protests over his re-election in 2009, and Iran’s increased isolation over its disputed nuclear energy program.

(13, 49) LIFE AND DEATH IN ASSISTED LIVING Nearly 750,000 people reside in assisted-living facilities across the country, with for-profit chains like Emeritus Senior Living — the nation’s largest, with 37,000 residents in 400 compounds — dominating the industry. But standards for care and training vary by state, and, unlike nursing homes, these institutions are not regulated by the federal government. “Frontline” and ProPublica investigate this multibillion-dollar industry, examining alarming incidents involving residents: a Texan who froze to death on Christmas morning when she wandered outdoors, and, in another place, the Hall of Fame football player George McAfee (above, in a photograph held by his daughter Cheryl Morgan), who mistakenly drank dishwashing liquid and died.

headline: For Chicken With Onions and Cardamom Rice, Try a Chenin Blanc
abstract: This wine should leave you refreshed while matching the sweetness of the dish’s fruit, spices and caramelized onions.
lead_paragraph: Chenin blanc wines are among the most glorious and the most underappreciated. I think serving a good demi-sec Vouvray with this chicken dish will offer immediate insight into their deliciousness. Demi-sec indicates that the wine has some residual sugar, but don’t fear a wine that’s not dry. Chenin blanc, like riesling, has such lively acidity that it will balance out the moderate sweetness, leaving you refreshed while matching the sweetness of the fruit, spices and caramelized onions. What’s more, chenin blanc has a beautifully rich texture that not only feels great in the mouth but will also enhance the amplitude of the basmati rice and chicken. A young demi-sec is fine, an older one even better.

lead_paragraph: Sounding at once unimpressed and defiant, Eliot Spitzer on Tuesday pointed to the formation of two “super PACs” that oppose his candidacy as the latest evidence that entrenched interests are afraid of having him in the New York City comptroller’s office.

headline: Park Chases South Korea’s Latest Title, Following Path of Pro Who Won Its First
abstract: Inbee Park, who could sweep this season’s L.P.G.A. majors, follows the path set by the South Korean Ok-Hee Ku in 1988.
lead_paragraph: Inbee Park’s extraordinary season is evidence that new narratives spring from some other narrative’s end. Last month at the United States Women’s Open, Park became the first L.P.G.A. golfer in the modern era to win the first three majors in the same calendar year. Less than two weeks later, the South Korean golfer Ok-Hee Ku was found dead in Japan, apparently of a heart attack, at 56.

headline: On Sleep Research, My Children Didn’t Get the Memo
abstract: When my husband e-mailed me yet another study about the importance of enforcing bedtimes, I realized that our kids seemed to be the ones not getting the message.
lead_paragraph: The subject line of the e-mail from my husband was, “New Study Shows Why You Should Get the Kids to Bed on Time.”

headline: Inside the Bradley Manning Trial

lead_paragraph: A look at the case against the former Army intelligence analyst who leaked hundreds of thousands of secret documents to WikiLeaks.

abstract: Florence Fabricant’s recommendations for the week of July 30.
lead_paragraph: To Savor: Having a Drink the Italian Way

headline: Zuccarello Re-Signs With Rangers
abstract: The power-play and shootout specialist had three goals and five assists in 15 regular-season games last season.
lead_paragraph: The Rangers re-signed forward Mats Zuccarello to a one-year contract Tuesday, continuing General Manager Glen Sather’s off-season push to retain key restricted free agents for Alain Vigneault, the new coach.

headline: A Mixed Verdict on Manning
abstract: Bradley Manning was convicted on many counts, but acquitted on a treason charge that would have set a bad precedent.
lead_paragraph: Lurking just behind a military court’s conviction of Pfc. Bradley Manning, on charges that included multiple violations of the Espionage Act, is a national-security apparatus that has metastasized into a vast and largely unchecked exercise of government secrecy and the overzealous prosecution of those who breach it.

headline: Appeals Court Rules Against Bloomberg Beverage Restrictions
abstract: The judges concurred with a lower court’s ruling that restrictions on the sale of large, sugary drinks went beyond the Board of Health’s legal powers.
lead_paragraph: An appeals court on Tuesday unanimously upheld a decision striking down New York City’s restrictions on the sale of large, sugary drinks, dealing a serious blow to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s hopes of reviving the rule before his term runs out.

headline: ABC Cocina
abstract: Inside the new restaurant by Jean-Georges Vongerichten, where the dishes are influenced by Spanish-speaking countries.
lead_paragraph: Inside the new restaurant by Jean-Georges Vongerichten, where the dishes are influenced by Spanish-speaking countries.

headline: Polar Researchers Explain North Pole ‘Lake’
abstract: Scientists who spend weeks each year camped on North Pole sea ice clarify what’s wrong with reports of a “lake” there.
lead_paragraph: In case you missed it, after a burst of Web confusion last week about a “lake” at the North Pole, I tried on Saturday to help clarify what is, and isn’t, happening on the drifting sea ice near 90 Degrees North with a Dot Earth post and this video:

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Syria, Italy, Iran and India.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Syria, Italy, Iran and India.

headline: Out of the Sea, Into the Air and Onto a Screen
abstract: Several networks, including Syfy and the Weather Channel, have shows this summer featuring sharks.
lead_paragraph: Two questions demand our attention here at the midpoint of the summer: Can the shark hunters, who arrive on Wednesday, mobilize in time to save us from the next sharknado, which is forecast for Friday? And what is it with all the fish on television all of a sudden?

headline: Trade Fight Over Solar Benefits a Bystander
abstract: A U.S. tariff ruling against China created a loophole that has benefited Taiwanese manufacturers.
lead_paragraph: The long-running trade conflicts over solar panels between China and the United States and Europe have sown dissatisfaction all around, leaving many manufacturers of solar materials complaining that the market is still unfair.

headline: All in the (Backbiting, Good-for-Nothing) Family
abstract: TLC’s new show “Surviving the In-Laws” features re-enactments of uneasy family relations.
lead_paragraph: Here’s hoping that TLC’s servers can handle a lot of Internet traffic. Each of Wednesday’s two teaser episodes of “Surviving the In-Laws,” a semi-reality, semi-scripted special, ends with this invitation:

headline: Deciphering and Eating
abstract: Jean-Georges Vongerichten’s newest venture is translated from the Spanish.
lead_paragraph: Apparently there are people who believe that the Internet has made restaurant critics irrelevant. I’d like to direct their attention to this text from the ABC Cocina Web site: “abc cocina & michelin star chef jean-georges vongerichten welcome you to our modern global exchange celebrating local craft and international culture, a fusion of tradition and innovation uniting yesterday and tomorrow.”

headline: How Much Would You Pay for a Big Mac?
abstract: If McDonald’s doubled the salaries and benefits of its employees, the price of a big Big Mac would increase just 68 cents.
lead_paragraph: Fast food workers in New York, Chicago, St. Louis and other cities are walking off their jobs this week to protest their low wages. They’re calling for $15 an hour plus the right to unionize without retaliation.

headline: Springdale, Conn., a Small Town in a High-Rise City
abstract: A self-contained and evolving neighborhood of Stamford has modest homes with tiny, trim lawns, housing a population of about 12,000.
lead_paragraph: The Oz-like clump of high-rises in downtown Stamford, about 45 miles from Manhattan, suggests that the place is urban to its core. Promoters have taken pains to play this up, emphasizing assets like gastro pubs, art-house cinema and Thursday evening concerts in a park.

headline: The Monks Are Asked to Go Natural
abstract: Mark Morris’s hope for his new production of Britten’s “Curlew River” at Tanglewood: More art, less artifice.
lead_paragraph: LENOX, Mass. — Benjamin Britten’s “Curlew River” runs just over an hour.

headline: House Plan on Food Stamps Would Cut 5 Million From Program
abstract: A new report finds that a proposal would increase poverty and illness, resulting in billions of dollars in federal and state health care costs.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Nearly half a million people who receive food stamps but still do not get enough to eat would lose their eligibility for the program under proposed cuts that are expected to be taken up again by Congress. An additional 160,000 to 305,000 recipients who do get enough to eat would also lose their eligibility and the ability to adequately feed themselves.

headline: The Margins of a Form Are, Increasingly, Not Where They Used to Be
abstract: Festival TBD: Emergency Glitter shows how a generation of choreographers is embracing pop culture and pushing dance beyond its conventions.
lead_paragraph: Like any artistic endeavor, Festival TBD: Emergency Glitter, presented last weekend at Abrons Arts Center, had its high and low points. But this brief yet packed event created by the intrepid Ben Pryor came at the right time to show how a generation of choreographers is embracing pop culture and pushing dance beyond its conventions.

headline: Eileen Brennan, Stalwart of Film and Stage, Dies at 80
abstract: Ms. Brennan’s performance  as the gleefully tough Army captain in the  1980 film “Private Benjamin” earned her an Academy Award nomination.
lead_paragraph: Eileen Brennan, a smoky-voiced actress who had worked in show business for more than 20 years before gaining her widest attention as a gleefully tough Army captain in both the film and television versions of “Private Benjamin,” died on Sunday at her home in Burbank, Calif. She was 80.

headline: Karlie Kloss Stops Traffic in Neon
abstract: During her television appearance on ABC, the model took over Midtown Manhattan in a bright dress by Calvin Klein.
lead_paragraph: The Girl: The Victoria’s Secret model headed out into Times Square in a showstopping, body-conscious dress and neutral shoes during her appearance on “Good Morning America” earlier today.

headline: The Roast of the Town
abstract: The Pulley Collective, a warehouse where the city’s coffee shops can roast their own beans and brew new ideas.
lead_paragraph: Usually, a coffee roaster starts small. Whether it’s with an industry giant like Starbucks, or a cult company like Heart Roasters, the trajectory is the same: the roasting grows at the same pace as the company.

headline: A Farewell to Maxwell’s, in Reminiscences
abstract: Todd Abramson, who estimates that he booked more than 200 gigs a year at Maxwell’s, the little music club in Hoboken that is closing on Wednesday, shares some memorable moments.
lead_paragraph: Maxwell’s, the feisty little club in Hoboken, N.J., will close on Wednesday after 35 years. In that time, just about every indie-rock and alternative-rock band has played there, from the Feelies to R.E.M. to Sonic Youth. Todd Abramson has been a near-constant presence since the mid-’80s, first as a booker and then as a part owner. Mr. Abramson, 51, left, has booked more than 200 gigs a year. He reflects fondly here on some memorable moments:

headline: At Toronto Film Festival, a Lineup to Make You Scream
abstract: The Toronto International Film Festival announces its Midnight Madness lineup.
lead_paragraph: In September, the Toronto International Film Festival will celebrate a quarter century of gore, ghouls and goo, also known as the Midnight Madness section, and the programmers have come up with a lineup of suitable fare for the anniversary.

headline: Varied Enrollment of Low-Income Students
abstract: The share of undergraduates receiving Pell Grants vary widely at the 50 most selective private colleges.
lead_paragraph: The share of undergraduates receiving Pell Grants vary widely at the 50 most selective private colleges.

headline: OpenTable Begins Testing Mobile Payments
abstract: OpenTable, the world’s largest online reservation service, lets users book a table at a restaurant with its smartphone app or Web site. Now the San Francisco-based company is getting ready to take the next step and let diners pay for the meal with its app, too.
lead_paragraph: OpenTable, the world’s largest online reservation service, lets users book a restaurant reservation with its smartphone app or Web site. Now the company is getting ready to take the next step and let diners pay for the meal with its app, too.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: The Android State and Turning 2-D Into 3-D
abstract: The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for important and peculiar items. Tuesday’s selections include a breakdown of Android market share and a new algorithm developed by Disney to convert two-dimensional images into 3-D models.
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: Musical Nomads, Escaping Political Upheaval
abstract: The annual Festival au Désert, usually based in Mali, has been forced to go on tour this year because of political turmoil. It comes to Lincoln Center Out of Doors on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: It’s a long way from Timbuktu to Lincoln Center, and not just geographically. For the musicians performing on Wednesday in the Festival au Désert as part of the Lincoln Center Out of Doors series at the Damrosch Park Bandshell, the path from there to here has included an Islamist takeover of their Saharan homeland, followed by a religious war on music and then a French-led military intervention.

headline: Trying to Spice a Recipe for Cinematic Popcorn
abstract: The team behind “Elysium,” starring Matt Damon and Jodie Foster, promises that it has taken an imaginative detour from the familiar blockbuster formula.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — It’s been a dismal season at the box office for Hollywood blockbusters billing themselves as creative, original — anything but the standard summer sequel.

headline: Juan David Ochoa Vásquez, Co-Founder of Medellín Cartel, Dies at 65
abstract: The cocaine trafficker, who started the brutal organization with his brothers and Pablo Escobar, served about five years in prison and then returned to raising horses.
lead_paragraph: Juan David Ochoa Vásquez, a founder of the violent and powerful Medellín cartel in Colombia, which ruled the international cocaine trade in the 1980s, died on Thursday in a medical clinic in Medellín. He was 65.

headline: Video: Bryan Cranston, Vince Gilligan and Others on the End of ‘Breaking Bad’
abstract: The cast and creator of “Breaking Bad” discuss the show and its coming conclusion with Dave Itzkoff, a culture reporter for The Times.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:34 p.m. |  On Tuesday, the cast and creator of the acclaimed AMC drama “Breaking Bad” discussed the show and its coming conclusion with Dave Itzkoff, a culture reporter for The Times. The event was part of the Times Talks series.

headline: Inequality in America: The Data Is Sobering
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Poverty', 'Income Inequality', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Despite its riches, in many areas the United States looks depressingly backward. Addressing that will take more than the president’s words.
lead_paragraph: The good news is that President Obama appears to have decided to devote the rest of his presidency to trying to tackle the forces behind the yawning inequities that have hamstrung social and economic mobility, eroding the living standards of the middle class.

headline: Ossie Schectman, N.B.A.’s First Scorer, Dies at 94
abstract: The 6-foot Knicks guard and captain made history on a layup a minute or so into a game against the Toronto Huskies on Nov. 1, 1946.
lead_paragraph: Long before Magic and Michael, before Kobe and LeBron, there was Ossie, the first scoring leader in the N.B.A. — at least for a few seconds.

headline: Feeling For | A Travel-Size Fragrance Pouch in Monogrammed Leather
abstract: This elegant beauty from Atelier Cologne raises the bar for stylish travel.
lead_paragraph: Many fragrance brands offer complimentary travel-size bottles of perfume along with a larger purchase. But Atelier Cologne ups the ante in the most elegant way imaginable. Perhaps this is no surprise, considering that the three-year-old fragrance house’s founders live in Paris and New York, and surely appreciate the value of traveling in style. When you purchase any 200-milliliter bottle of one of their clean, unisex scents — Orange Sanguine, Grand Néroli, Vétiver Fatal — you get a 30-milliliter travel spray of your choice along with a French leather case that comes with custom hand-engraving. There are seven possible shades of leather — aubergine, turquoise, lilac, red, burgundy, black and gray — and your choice of silver or gold lettering. Simple initials are probably classiest, but the brand offers you up to 20 characters to say what you want. You can also purchase the pouches à la carte.

headline: Pentagon Is Buying 71 More F-35 Fighters
keywords: ['F-35 Airplane', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: The contract for the fifth and sixth batch of fighter jets calls for lower prices than the Defense Department paid in the past.
lead_paragraph: The Defense Department on Tuesday announced an agreement in principle to buy 71 more F-35 fighter jets from Lockheed Martin at somewhat lower prices than last year. Pentagon officials said they would pay 4 percent less for 36 of the radar-evading jets under the new orders and 8 percent less than last year’s price for the other 35.

headline: Measuring Us Against the World
abstract: The United States is one of the richest nations on earth, but on a number of social and economic measures, it is more typical of a developing country.
lead_paragraph: The United States is one of the richest nations on earth, but on a number of social and economic measures, it is more typical of a developing country.

headline: For Quinn, It’s Time for Other Topics
abstract: The front-runner in the mayor’s race once again, Christine C. Quinn has found that a lot of people want to talk about the city’s scandal-scarred candidates.
lead_paragraph: Christine C. Quinn, hopelessly late for her next engagement, was taking questions about health insurance and housing on Tuesday when a woman started shouting in her direction.

headline: Lonely Bipartisan Push to Overhaul Tax Code Finally Gets Noticed
keywords: ['Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Income Tax', 'Taxation']
abstract: For months, the leaders of two Congressional tax-writing committees have struggled to gain traction on their efforts, but events are starting to catch up with them.
lead_paragraph: LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J. — Debbie Schaeffer, the owner of Mrs. G TV and Appliances, probably did not give the answer the two chairmen of Congress’s powerful tax-writing committees were looking for when they pressed her this week for ideas on a fairer, simpler tax code: “Get rid of the deductions that don’t affect me,” she said.

headline: President of Bayern Munich Is Charged With Tax Evasion
abstract: German prosecutors have charged Uli Hoeness, the president of Bayern Munich, with tax evasion after an investigation into his financial dealings with a bank account in Switzerland.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — German prosecutors have charged Uli Hoeness, the president of the soccer juggernaut Bayern Munich, with tax evasion.

headline: House Weighs Iran Measure Amid Doubts on Timing

abstract: Legislation to impose the sanctions, up for a vote in the House on Wednesday, could coerce Iran’s customers to find other oil suppliers.
lead_paragraph: Legislation that would impose the toughest sanctions to date on Iran over its disputed nuclear program has been scheduled for a vote in the House on Wednesday, four days before the inauguration of that country’s newly elected president, a moderate cleric who has made improved relations with the United States an important goal.
