abstract: The mansion, Inisfada, is being sold by the Jesuits to a developer, and local opinions differ on whether it is worth keeping.
lead_paragraph: NORTH HILLS, N.Y. — On the grounds outside the mansion, it looked like the aftermath of a raucous Gatsby-era party: a Wurlitzer baby grand piano lay on its side in the grass, with its legs piled alongside.

headline: Lawyer Who Beat Chevron in Ecuador Faces Trial of His Own
abstract: The oil company has filed a suit against Steven Donziger, who won an $18 billion case over oil spills in the Ecuadorean jungle, accusing him of manipulating evidence and bribing judges.
lead_paragraph: Steven R. Donziger — environmental hero or charlatan, depending on whom you talk to — is one of the toughest lawyers around, or slightly crazy.

headline: Appeals Court Ruling on Using Historic Cell Data
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Cellular Telephones']
abstract: A federal appeals court on Tuesday said that government authorities can extract historical location data directly from telecommunications carriers without a search warrant.
lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court on Tuesday said that government authorities can extract historical location data directly from telecommunications carriers without a search warrant.

headline: Warrantless Cellphone Tracking Is Upheld
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Cellular Telephones', 'Fourth Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Search and Seizure', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: The ruling is the first to address the constitutionality of warrantless searches of historical location data stored by cellphone service providers.
lead_paragraph: In a significant victory for law enforcement, a federal appeals court on Tuesday said that government authorities could extract historical location data directly from telecommunications carriers without a search warrant.

headline: Pfizer Settles a Drug Marketing Case for $491 Million
abstract: The Justice Department announced that the drug maker would settle criminal and civil charges over illegal marketing of the kidney-transplant drug Rapamune.
lead_paragraph: The drug maker Pfizer agreed to pay $491 million to settle criminal and civil charges over the illegal marketing of the kidney-transplant drug Rapamune, the Justice Department announced on Tuesday.

headline: Mugabe Keeps Grip Before Vote, but the Opposition Grows Bolder
abstract: President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe does not appear ready to give up power, but says that he would go if he loses Wednesday’s election.
lead_paragraph: HARARE, Zimbabwe — When the main challengers in Zimbabwe’s presidential election tried to import motorcycles to register voters across vast distances, the government impounded them, forcing the party to use bicycles instead. Then the challengers’ election chief was jailed less than a week before the vote, and denied bail the day before it.

headline: Versace Mansion, a South Beach Star, Faces Auction
abstract: The tenement that Gianni Versace transformed into an opulent palace after he bought it in 1992, signaling the area’s arrival, is being offered at a reduced price as part of a bankruptcy proceeding.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI BEACH — When Gianni Versace bought a deteriorated tenement on Ocean Drive in 1992, transformed it into a figure of opulence and called it home, the increasingly obvious became official: South Beach had arrived.

headline: Three Penn State Officials Are Ordered to Stand Trial
abstract: The three former university officials, including the former president Graham B. Spanier, are charged with perjury, conspiracy and other crimes in the Jerry Sandusky case.
lead_paragraph: Three former high-ranking Penn State officials, including the university’s former president, Graham B. Spanier, were ordered Tuesday to stand trial on charges that they were part of a cover-up related to the child sexual abuse scandal involving the former football coach Jerry Sandusky.

headline: California: San Diego City Council to Sue Mayor
abstract: The San Diego City Council voted to file a lawsuit against Mayor Bob Filner to recover any damages the city may have to pay as a result of a sexual harassment lawsuit.
lead_paragraph: The San Diego City Council on Tuesday unanimously voted to file a lawsuit against Mayor Bob Filner to recover any damages the city may have to pay as a result of a sexual harassment lawsuit that has been filed against him and the city. The mayor’s former communications deputy, Irene McCormack Jackson, sued last week, alleging that he harassed her on the job. Six more women have since accused him of harassment, though no more lawsuits have been filed. The Council’s lawsuit does not admit any liability, but moves to hold Mr. Filner responsible for any damages and legal fees.

headline: Lawyers Present Closing Arguments in Former Goldman Trader’s Fraud Case
abstract: Fabrice Tourre is accused of scheming with a big hedge fund to defraud investors in connection with a 2007 trade.
lead_paragraph: Fabrice Tourre, the former Goldman Sachs trader, was either a greedy scheming liar or a bright young executive just trying to do his job, according to dueling portraits presented during closing arguments Tuesday in the most prominent case from the financial crisis to go to trial.

headline: Ohio State Gives Its Ex-President Another Job
abstract: E. Gordon Gee, who resigned as president of Ohio State University after a series of gaffes, will earn $5.8 million over the next five years under a new contract.
lead_paragraph: E. Gordon Gee, who resigned as president of Ohio State University in June after a series of gaffes attracted media attention, will earn $5.8 million over the next five years under a new contract with the university that calls for him to continue as a tenured member of the law school faculty, conduct research on education policy and serve as president emeritus. Under his previous contract, Mr. Gee would have earned about $6 million over the next four years. Mr. Gee, 69, frequently topped the list of highest-paid college presidents.

headline: $250 Million, a Record Gift, Set for College in Kentucky
abstract: Centre College in Danville, Ky., has received the largest outright gift ever made to a liberal arts college — $250 million of stock from the A. Eugene Brockman Charitable Trust.
lead_paragraph: Centre College, a small rural college in Danville, Ky., announced Tuesday that it had received the largest outright gift ever made to a liberal arts college: $250 million, in stock from the A. Eugene Brockman Charitable Trust.

headline: Political Inquiry Makes Judge a Star, as It Reveals Flaws in Spain’s Courts
abstract: Spanish courts are overwhelmed, easily politicized and prone to debilitating delays, which is eroding the public’s trust.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — At just 34 years old, Pablo Ruz was a surprising choice to replace Baltasar Gárzon, Spain’s most famous investigative judge, when Mr. Gárzon was   suspended for illegal eavesdropping. But Judge Ruz quickly made himself a household name, driving the investigation of payments to Popular Party politicians that now threatens Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy, who is scheduled to appear before Parliament on Thursday to explain his party’s finances.

headline: Plan Aims to Enliven Paris’s Financial District, Long Called Soulless
abstract: La Défense is often seen as sterile and inhospitable, but now at least three office towers are under construction there, spawning hope for a rebound.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — On Bastille Day 1989, when President François Mitterrand inaugurated the Grande Arche, a 40-story postmodern bookend about three miles to the west of the Arc de Triomphe, it seemed its own form of triumph.

headline: Shirking Responsibility in the Gulf
keywords: ['Gulf of Mexico Oil Spill (2010)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: BP is engaged in an aggressive campaign to limit how much it pays for the losses its reckless behavior caused.
lead_paragraph: BILOXI, Miss. — IF you don’t live near the Gulf Coast, you may have the impression that the area has fully recovered from the BP Deepwater Horizon oil spill in 2010, the largest environmental disaster in American history. Sadly, that’s not the case for tens of thousands of gulf residents still trying to put their lives back together.

headline: Missed Connections at La Défense
abstract: La Défense, the business hub of Paris, has long been criticized as dehumanizing and disconnected to the city. Efforts are under way to change that.
lead_paragraph: La Défense, the business hub of Paris, has long been criticized as dehumanizing and disconnected to the city. Efforts are under way to change that.

headline: Neighbors’ Battle With Park Avenue Caterer Goes All the Way to Cuomo
abstract: A fight between the Rose Group and its Park Avenue neighbors over a special exemption for a liquor license has reached the office of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo.
lead_paragraph: It is among New York City’s longest-running food fights, pitting the well-heeled residents of one its most exclusive neighborhoods against an extravagant catering operation that is run out of a Park Avenue church.

headline: Mr. Stringer’s Choice
keywords: ['Zoning', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Editorials', 'Grand Central Terminal (NYC)', 'Real Estate (Commercial)']
abstract: The Manhattan borough president should reject a bad proposal that would rezone a huge area around Grand Central Terminal.
lead_paragraph: By midnight Wednesday, Scott Stringer, the Manhattan borough president, will have to make a crucial decision about the future of New York City. That is the deadline by which Mr. Stringer, who is running for city comptroller, must state his opinion on a proposal to rezone a huge area around Grand Central Terminal. The mayor’s office and the City Council do not have to accept the borough president’s views, but they usually listen. During Mr. Stringer’s six-and-a-half years in office, he has often charted a reasonable middle way for developments in his borough.

headline: Egypt’s Dangerous Slide
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Editorials']
abstract: As Egypt struggles over its future, President Obama needs to state clearly what America stands for.
lead_paragraph: Deadly blundering by Egypt’s military rulers is making a bad situation much worse. Last weekend’s massacre of marchers supporting the deposed president, Mohamed Morsi, will make national reconciliation and a return to democracy far more difficult.

headline: Revenge of the Mistresses
abstract: Corruption in China has a ripple effect. Who knew the account of a government official’s extramarital affair would be a warning sign?
lead_paragraph: Every so often you read a news article so revealing that it triggers this thought: I wonder if we’ll look back on that story in five years and say, “We should have seen this coming. That story was the warning sign.”

headline: Weiner’s Women
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Sex', 'Text Messaging', 'Elections, Mayors']
abstract: Equal participants, not victims, in the arid world of virtual sex.
lead_paragraph: THERE is something missing from the endless moralizing and sophomoric jokes aimed at Anthony D. Weiner. That something is the role of women in a coarse and creepy Internet culture dedicated to the fulfillment of both male and female desires for virtual carnal knowledge.

headline: Success Brings Scrutiny to Chinese Mystic
abstract: Wang Lin, a practitioner of qigong, says Chinese government charges of swindling, dodging taxes and cavorting with criminals are part of a vendetta against him.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Wang Lin, an exponent of the ancient Chinese practice of qigong, claims he has used his powers to cure cancer and has performed other mysterious feats, like conjuring snakes out of thin air. But none of his abilities were enough to ward off the fury of the Communist Party, which has accused him of using superstition to draw in gullible citizens and officials.

headline: A Specialty Brew
abstract: The Pulley Collective, a coffee roasting facility in Red Hook, is serving as a training ground for a new generation of coffee roasters in New York City.
lead_paragraph: The Pulley Collective, a coffee roasting facility in Red Hook, is serving as a training ground for a new generation of coffee roasters in New York City.

headline: Fatal Crash Came While Train Driver Took a Call
keywords: ['Railroad Accidents and Safety', 'Speed Limits and Speeding']
abstract: Data from two “black boxes” show that the driver, Francisco Jose Garzon Amo, was on the phone with a colleague and traveling at almost twice the speed limit.
lead_paragraph: BARCELONA — Preliminary investigations show that the driver of a high-speed train that derailed last week, killing 79 people and injuring 150, was on the phone and traveling at 153 kilometers per hour — almost twice the speed limit — at the time of the accident, a Spanish court said Tuesday.

headline: New Unit to Turn Brands Into Publishers
abstract: Following its own move into automated buying, IPG Mediabrands announced a plan to help clients create content for online platforms.
lead_paragraph: THE creation of the world’s biggest advertising company earlier this week, a merger between the Publicis Groupe and the Omnicom Group, underscored the importance of consumer data and sophisticated technologies like automated buying in advertising.

headline: The One-Day Contract, a Last Hurrah for Athletes
abstract: As Hideki Matsui and Donovan McNabb illustrated this week, the one-day contract has become a rite of passage for modern athletes — a select few, anyway — before they retreat from the spotlight.

headline: Over a Million Are Denied Bank Accounts for Past Errors

headline: Reflections on the Road to Harvard

lead_paragraph: Travis Reginal and Justin Porter were friends back in Jackson, Miss. They attended William B. Murrah High School, which is 97 percent African-American and 67 percent low income. Murrah is no Ivy feeder. Low-income students rarely apply to the nation’s best colleges. But Mr. Porter just completed a first year at Harvard, Mr. Reginal at Yale. Below, Mr. Porter writes about his journey. Click here to read Mr. Reginal’s essay.

A student at Vassar, for example, is three times as likely to receive a need-based Pell Grant as one at Washington University in St. Louis.

headline: It Takes a Thief to Explain Robbery
abstract: The documentary “Smash and Grab” has inside tales of the Pink Panthers, an international high-stakes crime ring.
lead_paragraph: The insider’s level of detail that gives so many good crime movies their bite is also what makes the documentary “Smash and Grab: The Story of the Pink Panthers” guiltily absorbing. In sketching out the story of the Serbian thievery ring of the title, named after the Inspector Clouseau movies, this unpretty but titillatingly informative film from Havana Marking essentially lets two criminals give a master class in high-stakes robbery. Their accounts cover preparation (cast a distracting woman to case the joint), execution (no job should last more than a half-minute) and aftermath (fencing goods is no picnic, and expect a permanent hangover of paranoia).

headline: Cheryl Boone Isaacs Chosen to Head Film Academy

lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Cheryl Boone Isaacs, a veteran film marketer, was named president of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, the Academy said on Tuesday. In the ’80s, however, he sometimes could not find the books he wanted on tape — or maybe he just did not bother. He had three children: Naomi, Joe and Owen. They could read, couldn’t they? All King had to do was press record. Which is how his school-age children came to furnish their father, over the years, with a small library’s worth of books on tape.
