lead_paragraph: TOKYO — NEC, once the leading cellphone maker in Japan, said on Wednesday that it would quit making smartphones, acknowledging that it had failed to keep pace with the likes of Apple and Samsung Electronics.

headline: New Siemens Chief Sees Weakness in China
abstract: Joe Kaeser, who had been chief financial officer of the German engineering giant, said that “the economic reorientation of China will take time.’'
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The newly named chief executive of Siemens has promised to restore stability to the company that symbolizes German engineering and electronics prowess. But he also issued a warning that could bode ill for the euro zone economy: Don’t count on China.

headline: I Do Not Want My Daughter to Be ‘Nice’
abstract: My daughter is kind and compassionate, but she will not smile unless either she is genuinely glad to see you or you’re telling her a joke that has a scatological punch line.
lead_paragraph: My 10-year-old daughter, Birdy, is not nice, not exactly. She is deeply kind, profoundly compassionate and, probably, the most ethical person I know — but she will not smile at you unless either she is genuinely glad to see you or you’re telling her a joke that has something scatological for a punch line.

headline: Milestone Claimed in Creating Fuel From Waste
keywords: ['Ethanol', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Bioenergy and Biofuels', 'Methane']
abstract: In what would be a key breakthrough for renewable fuels, INEOS Bio said it had produced commercial quantities of ethanol from wood waste and other nonfood vegetative matter.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After months of frustrating delays, a chemical company announced Wednesday that it had produced commercial quantities of ethanol from wood waste and other nonfood vegetative matter, a long-sought goal that, if it can be expanded economically, has major implications for providing vehicle fuel and limiting greenhouse gas emissions.

headline: Bell Peddler’s Mobile Carillon Could Be One of the Heaviest Marketing Tools Ever
abstract: Looking for a new way to connect people with the bells he sells, Jeffrey Crook, president of Chime Master, decided a tractor-trailered carillon was just the thing his business needed.
lead_paragraph: STAMFORD, Conn. — Don’t honk your horn at Jeffrey Crook or the unusual cargo stowed atop the 21-foot trailer he’s towing behind his Mack truck. The feeble sound your vehicle emits is no competition for what he has on board.

headline: A Sense of Place
abstract: Home is at the heart of two new picture books, one set in a city that could be New York and the other in a wintry rural landscape.
lead_paragraph: “What would it be like to stay in one place — to have your own bed, to ride your own bicycle?” a little girl named Anna wonders in Maxine Trottier’s 2011 picture book, “Migrant.” “Now that would be something.” Anna’s parents, who are migrant workers, move from one temporary home to another, and Anna imagines herself as a rabbit, living in abandoned burrows, or a bee, flitting from flower to flower. She is effectively homeless, and longs to live a settled life, “like a tree with roots sunk deeply into the earth.”

headline: Revealing a Health Care Secret: The Price
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Hospitals', 'Surgery and Surgeons']
abstract: By clearly posting their prices, The Surgery Center of Oklahoma provides transparency for patients paying their own bills.
lead_paragraph: The Surgery Center of Oklahoma is an ambulatory surgical center in Oklahoma City owned by its roughly 40 surgeons and anesthesiologists. What makes it different from every other such facility in America is this: If you need an anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction, you will know beforehand — because it’s on their Web site — that it costs $6,990 if you self-pay in advance. If you need a tonsillectomy, that’s $3,600. Repair of a simple closed nasal fracture: $1,900. These prices are all-inclusive.

headline: The Ad Campaign: Catsimatidis Calls Quinn ‘Out of Touch’ on Public Safety
abstract: In a 30-second spot, John A. Catsimatidis says he is the most serious candidate about New York’s security.
lead_paragraph: Law and order has been a prevailing theme for John A. Catsimatidis, the billionaire Republican candidate who has repeatedly pledged to keep “hoodlums” off the streets. In a 30-second spot, “Safe,” Mr. Catsimatidis warns that one rival in particular, Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker, could fall short in this arena.

headline: Senate Panel Presses N.S.A. on Phone Logs
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Senators of both parties challenged the collection of records of domestic phone calls, as the latest leak provided new details on the way the agency monitors Web browsing around the world.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senators of both parties on Wednesday sharply challenged the National Security Agency’s collection of records of all domestic phone calls, even as the latest leaked N.S.A. document provided new details on the way the agency monitors Web browsing around the world.

headline: Karachi-upon-Thames
abstract: An exiled politician is still calling the shots in Pakistan — from a middle-class neighborhood of London.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — For many years Pakistanis have joked that their capital, Islamabad, is run from Washington. These days, however, it looks more like Karachi, Pakistan’s financial and business hub, is being run from London — thanks to an exiled Pakistani politician settled in the middle-class neighborhood of Edgware.

headline: McSweeney’s Archive Acquired by Ransom Center in Austin
abstract: The publishing company’s archive, containing manuscripts and correspondence from writers like David Foster Wallace, Rick Moody and Zadie Smith, is headed to the Harry Ransom Center at the University of Texas at Austin.
lead_paragraph: While informal archives of McSweeney’s, the eclectic literary magazine created by Dave Eggers, can be found in living rooms, bedrooms and bathrooms of apartments across New York, a more proper collection of the assets of this prestigious journal and its sibling publications is headed to the Harry Ransom Center at the University of Texas at Austin.

headline: Consumer Spending and Growth: A Rejoinder
abstract: Casey Mulligan may take issue with my view that weak consumer spending undermines economic growth, but he misses some of the nuances of my position, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: An Architect Whose Work Stood Out, Even if She Did Not
abstract: Almost invisibly in her own day, Natalie de Blois, of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, helped guide the design of three of the most important corporate landmarks of the 1950s and ’60s.
lead_paragraph: In architecture’s “Mad Men” era, there was a woman.

headline: Is Google More Like Microsoft or Apple?
abstract: Microsoft has a tech culture that yearns for more features. Apple prizes design and simplicity. Where is Google on the spectrum?
lead_paragraph: Is Google geekier than Microsoft?

headline: Design Advice on Reconfiguring an Emptying Nest
abstract: Danielle Galland, an interior designer, will answer readers’ questions about how to reconfigure living spaces as children head for college.
lead_paragraph: Our next Ask an Expert features Danielle Galland, an interior designer who will answer readers’ questions about two kinds of living transitions that many baby boomers face: the semi-empty nest, with children leaving for college but returning during breaks, and the empty nest geared toward retirement.

headline: July 31: Where the Candidates Are Today
abstract: The candidates’ daily campaign schedule at a glance.
lead_paragraph: Planned events for the mayoral candidates, according to the campaigns and organizations they are affiliated with. Times are listed as scheduled but frequently change.

headline: Nissan and Lotus Issue Recalls
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Automobiles', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: The Lotus recall appears to be for a problem similar to one that resulted in a 5,000-car recall in 2011.
lead_paragraph: In two actions, Nissan will recall about 7,700 Versa Notes from the 2014 model year for problems involving loose or missing bolts that could make the vehicle less safe in a crash, the automaker has informed the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

headline: Seeking a ‘Middle-Aged’ Look
abstract: Women looking for the “right image” often seek out Dr. Macrene Alexiades-Armenakas, a New York dermatologist.
lead_paragraph: In an age when the syringe has practically replaced the scalpel, the phrase “Park Avenue dermatologist” likely calls to mind Real Housewives with unmoving foreheads and plumped lips. But those are not the patients in the waiting room of Dr. Macrene Alexiades-Armenakas.

headline: Seeking Capital, Some Companies Turn to ‘Do-It-Yourself I.P.O.’s’
abstract: A direct public offering describes a public securities offering similar to an I.P.O., but with one big difference: There is no need to hire an investment bank.
lead_paragraph: Flying back to California, empty-handed, after one last investor pitch in late 2011, Brahm Ahmadi was ready to call it quits. Despite a track record, a clear market opportunity and a loan pledge, he had not been able to attract a single investor. He called his lawyer and told her, “We hit a wall.”

headline: Chromecast, Simply and Cheaply, Flings Web Video to TVs
abstract: Using Wi-Fi, the Google Chromecast makes Internet material watchable on a television for $35. Repeat, $35.
lead_paragraph: Ever hear the old saying, “Information wants to be free?” Well, here’s a corollary for you: “TV wants to be à la carte.”

headline: Weighing Choice for Fed, Obama Offers His Party a Defense of Summers
abstract: The president also attended a closed-door meeting with House Democrats, to be followed by a session with party senators.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Facing dissent from Congressional Democrats, President Obama on Wednesday offered a strong defense of his potential choice of Lawrence H. Summers to head the Federal Reserve, though he said no final selection had been made.

headline: The Rock of New Orleans
abstract: Capt. André Cailloux, the first black hero of the Union Army.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, July 29, 1863, an unprecedented crowd of slaves, runaways and free people of color gathered along the downtown streets of federally occupied New Orleans. They did so not only to honor and bid farewell to one of their own, Capt. André Cailloux of the 1st Regiment of the Louisiana Native Guards, who had fallen at the siege of Port Hudson, La., but also to send a message of defiance to white New Orleanians, most of whom favored the Confederate cause.

headline: A Not-So-Great Great Recession
abstract: The Great Recession was not as bad as we thought, and the recovery since then has been a little better than we thought, according to the latest government revisions.
lead_paragraph: Updated | 2:03 p.m.

headline: Your First Crush
abstract: Times readers share the inspiration that made them devote their lives or careers to popular music.
lead_paragraph: This summer, a number of New York Times critics are writing about their cultural first crushes — the moments or works that prompted them to write about the arts. A new essay will arrive each week, paired with stories from readers who work within the given discipline about their own cultural epiphanies.

headline: Perfectly Reasonable Question No. 1: On Direct Quotations in Articles
abstract: The public editor takes on readers’ questions, offering some answers.
lead_paragraph: A reader, Edward Hershey of Portland, Ore., wrote to me some time ago about an article in Sports by the basketball writer Howard Beck. Mr. Hershey, who described himself as “a former sportswriter in the Red Smith-Jimmy Cannon era,” wondered about Mr. Beck’s use of a quotation from the Miami Heat forward LeBron James. It came deep within what he accurately called “a compelling deadline story following the first game of the N.B.A. championship series.”

headline: Debate Over Controversial Delhi “Encounter” Continues
abstract: Debate over the controversial 2008 gun battle in Batla House area of Delhi continues.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI – The questions surrounding the controversial Batla House encounter in New Delhi continue to be unresolved. On Tuesday, a local court sentenced Shahzad Ahmad, 24, the only person arrested after the September 19, 2008 gunfight between Delhi police officials and suspected terrorists in Batla House area of south Delhi, to life imprisonment for killing a police officer. But human rights activists contesting the police version say that the legal battles around the half a decade old episode are far from over.

headline: A Feast for the Eyes Leads to One for the Ears
abstract: The jazz critic Ben Ratliff recalls an introduction to a vast range of music via a book of record jacket designs, “Album Cover Album.”
lead_paragraph: When I was 9 or 10, our family acquired a new book called “Album Cover Album,” a collection of record cover reproductions: 160 pages, with from 1 to 16 records arranged on each page. It was made by Hipgnosis, the English design firm, and Roger Dean, the illustrator of album jackets for Yes and some less savory prog-rock bands.

headline: Resuscitating Chivalry
abstract: Should chivalry die, be brought back, or evolve into a more inclusive ethos that is appropriate for 2013?

headline: The Power Behind the Throne at the Federal Reserve
abstract: Few outside the world of banking regulation understand the influence held by the staff of the Federal Reserve, which includes Scott G. Alvarez, its general counsel.
lead_paragraph: The debate over whether Janet Yellen or Lawrence H. Summers will be the next Federal Reserve chairman — or some dark horse, Timothy F. Geithner perhaps? — is doubtlessly important.

headline: Moon Phases Tied to Sleep Cycles
abstract: Swiss researchers have found evidence that the lunar cycle may affect sleep patterns, with total sleep time lowest at full moon.
lead_paragraph: The lunar cycle has been tied to a range of mysterious powers, from increases in violent crimes and hospital admissions to fertility and blood loss, and scientists consider most such beliefs nonsensical.

headline: Listen Up | Violin Meets Modern Dance in a New Video From Arcade Fire’s Sarah Neufeld
abstract: The mesmerizing clip, which has its world premiere here, marks the debut of Pressur.es, a filmmaking initiative exploring synergies between progressive music and cutting-edge choreography.
lead_paragraph: For the video for her song “Forcelessness,” Sarah Neufeld — best known as the violinist for the Grammy-winning indie collective Arcade Fire — wanted to go outside the bounds of indie rock. The clip for the track from her debut album, “Hero Brother,” which has its premiere here, pairs Neufeld’s hypnotic string arrangement with an intimate routine performed by two dancers in a brick-walled studio, a simple conceit that proves remarkably mesmerizing. It’s the debut project by Pressur.es, a new Brooklyn-based multidisciplinary arts organization and film series dedicated to exploring artistic modern dance and progressive music.

headline: Did Zeus Exist?
abstract: We are in no position to say that he did. But are we really in a position to say that he didn’t?
lead_paragraph: When my children were little, they liked to play “Mother, May I?” At one point, I combined the game with an early introduction to classical culture, changing the key question to “Zeus, May I?” with an imaginary thunderbolt throwing back anyone forgetting to ask permission.

headline: An Easter Egg Hunt With Stephen King and Family
abstract: Members of the literary family — which includes five novelists — leave curious references to one other’s characters and ideas in their books.
lead_paragraph: When Tabitha King, a writer married to Stephen King, wrote a novel about a woman from warmer climes who opens a diner in Maine, she lavished almost two pages of description on the man who taught the novel’s heroine how to cook. “Dick used to work summers in a resort in Colorado,” that character, named Pearl, recalls, in the novel that carries her name. “Summers in Key West, nobody came there back then, except diehard fishermen and drunks like Hemingway, maybe there’s no difference, huh?” Fans of “The Shining” might be surprised to find Dick Halloran, a hero of “The Shining,” showing up in a novel that is essentially a liberated woman’s love story, a novel without so much of a hint of the supernatural (they might also be surprised to learn that the brave and gentle Dick “had a taste for fast women, strippers and dancers and scat singers,” as he is further described in “Pearl”).

headline: Finding a Seat That Fits on a Flight
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: If you’re tired of stuffing yourself into tight airline seats, some digital tools could offer you a little relief.
lead_paragraph: For travelers who are taller or broader or heavier than the average American, who have had their knees bashed, heads bonked and hips squeezed on flights from coast to coast, a little relief is in sight.

headline: From Bocce to a Trolley in a Washington Neighborhood
abstract: H Street NE, near the Capitol, is dotted with restaurants and cultural spaces, with a new trolley line set to open soon.
lead_paragraph: H Street NE, near the Capitol, is dotted with restaurants and cultural spaces, with a new trolley line set to open soon.

headline: ‘Death Sticks’ at Rockaway Beach Will Soon Be No More
abstract: Wooden groins that extend into the surf at Rockaway Beach are being removed to make it safer for the growing number of surfers that the beach has attracted.
lead_paragraph: They lurk just below the surface at high tide, ready to scrape or snarl an unsuspecting surfer. They have shattered boards, ripped open skin and wet suits, impaled unsuspecting bathers and caused at least one death in recent years.

headline: John McCain and the ‘Wacko Birds’
abstract: The senator expressed his frustration with Rand Paul, Ted Cruz and the no-compromise wing of the Republican Party.
lead_paragraph: After Senator John McCain referred to Senator Rand Paul, Senator Ted Cruz and Rep. Justin Amash (all Republicans) as “wacko birds” back in March, he apologized. In an interview with The New Republic’s Isaac Chotiner published this morning, he used much nicer language to explain why he dislikes the avian cohort.

headline: The Mostly Good Old Days: Boris Kachka Talks About ‘Hothouse’
keywords: ['Book Trade and Publishing', 'Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: Mr. Kachka’s new book is a history of the publishing house Farrar, Straus & Giroux.
lead_paragraph: The consolidation of the book publishing industry continues apace, with the recent merger of the two behemoths Penguin and Random House being just the latest development. In this climate, the story of Farrar, Straus & Giroux, the fiercely independent publisher (even after it was no longer privately owned) of authors like T.S. Eliot, Flannery O’Connor and Joan Didion, has particular resonance. In “Hothouse,” Boris Kachka writes about FSG’s star authors, and about the three men — Roger Straus, John Farrar and Robert Giroux — who made the company a success. In a recent e-mail interview, Mr. Kachka discussed what he learned about literary legends, his approach toward reporting gossip, his efforts to resist a nostalgic view of the publishing industry and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

headline: Masks That Stay on and Moisturize the Skin
abstract: Some facial masks do not have to be removed, but have ingredients marketers claim are extra hydrating to the skin.
lead_paragraph: The old-school beauty ritual of slathering on a mask and waiting for 10 to 15 minutes before rinsing it off may be passé. The following formulas are meant to be left on.

headline: Deliberations Start in Goldman Trader’s Case
keywords: ['Mortgage-Backed Securities', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: After nearly an hour and a half of legal instructions, the federal government’s civil lawsuit against a former Goldman Sachs trader went to a jury on Wednesday morning.
lead_paragraph: The federal government’s lawsuit against Fabrice Tourre, a former Goldman Sachs trader accused of misleading investors in a mortgage security six years ago, went to a jury Wednesday morning, setting up the end to one of the most prominent cases to arise from the financial crisis.

headline: Why Republicans Miss The Realists
keywords: ['Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: On foreign policy, the G.O.P. looks increasingly like a party without a center.
lead_paragraph: Chris Christie’s comments attacking Rand Paul and other right-wing civil libertarians, extracted by my colleague Jonathan Martin in an Aspen forum last week, have generally been interpreted as setting Christie up as a spokesman for Republican hawks in a looming 2016 battle over the party’s direction on foreign policy. On Friday, Politico’s Alexander Burns ran down some polling numbers that help explain why the more hawkish perspective is no longer an obvious political winner, even in a G.O.P. primary:

headline: Facebook Shares Touch a Symbolic Threshold
abstract: Shares have risen about 34 percent since the company announced a surprisingly strong earnings report last week.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — It took more than a year, but Facebook’s stock has fought its way back.

headline: U.S. Financial Firm Courts Start-Ups in Brazil
abstract: In recent months, one of SVB Financial Group’s subsidiaries, Silicon Valley Bank, has added venture capital firms and young companies in Brazil as clients. And SVB Capital, another subsidiary, expects to make new investments in South American venture capital firms.
lead_paragraph: SÁO PAULO, Brazil — The SVB Financial Group in California has long been an important banker and investor in American venture capital firms and technology start-ups. Now, the company is testing the waters in South America, particularly Brazil.

headline: Homes for $1,500,000
abstract: A photographic tour includes a home near St. Louis, a Queen Anne in Massachusetts and another in Wyoming’s ski country.
lead_paragraph: A photographic tour includes a home near St. Louis, a Queen Anne in Massachusetts and another in Wyoming’s ski country.

headline: What You Get for ... $1,500,000
abstract: This week’s homes include a contemporary near St. Louis, a Queen Anne in Massachusetts and a house in Wyoming’s ski country.
lead_paragraph: WESTWOOD, MO.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: 'Spectacular Now'
abstract: The director James Ponsoldt narrates a scene from his film featuring Miles Teller and Shailene Woodley.
lead_paragraph: The director James Ponsoldt narrates a scene from his film featuring Miles Teller and Shailene Woodley.

headline: Recipe Lab Video Chat on ‘Jerusalem’
abstract: The authors of “Jerusalem: A Cookbook,” Yotam Ottolenghi and Sami Tamimi, joined Julia Moskin and three home cooks for a live video chat to discuss a recipe for chicken with onions and rice.
lead_paragraph: For this month’s Recipe Lab, The Times’s Julia Moskin asked home cooks what recipe from “Jerusalem: A Cookbook” they’d most like to discuss with the authors, Yotam Ottolenghi and Sami Tamimi, in our Google+ Hangout.

headline: Whistle-Blowers in Limbo, Neither Hero Nor Traitor
keywords: ['Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Whistle-Blowers', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Privacy', 'Freedom of the Press']
abstract: Edward Snowden and Pfc. Bradley Manning say they obeyed a moral imperative on behalf of the public, but the public is divided on whether that’s a good thing.
lead_paragraph: Even as Americans expressed increasing concerns about government intrusions into their life in a recently released Pew Research Center study, they have hardly embraced those who decide to take matters into their own hands.

headline: Egypt Vows to End Sit-Ins by Supporters of Deposed President
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: An order by the government to security forces to break up the protests aroused fears of a new round of violent clashes.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Egypt’s military-backed government instructed its security forces on Wednesday to end two sit-ins by tens of thousands of supporters of the deposed Islamist president, a decree that many feared could lead to a new round of violent confrontations.

headline: Not Everything’s Ho-Hum as the Trade Deadline Approaches
abstract: Baseball’s simmering drug investigation could boil over into suspensions and then there is the new Red Sox, Jake Peavy, and his peanut butter pitch.
lead_paragraph: Ah, the joys of baseball’s trading deadline. No, it is not very dramatic and is painfully lacking in team executives acting like game show contestants (see: N.H.L. and N.B.A. trade deadlines), and as we know, it is not actually a deadline. Trades made before 4 p.m. Eastern time do not require a trip through waivers. We get another month until the waiver trade deadline. And then after that, teams have to have a note from Mom. We all know how complicated that can be.

headline: House Hunting in ... Amsterdam
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: A richly historic area, described by brokers as a more affordable alternative to London or Berlin, attracts a healthy share of foreign buyers.
lead_paragraph: A FIVE-BEDROOM HOUSE ON AN AMSTERDAM CANAL

headline: A Canal-Side Home in Amsterdam
abstract: A restored 17th-century house on the Prinsengracht, one of Amsterdam’s main canals, is priced at $3,652,592 million.
lead_paragraph: A restored 17th-century house on the Prinsengracht, one of Amsterdam’s main canals, is priced at $3,652,592 million.

headline: A Suburban Jersey Spin in the 2014 Ford Fiesta
abstract: Ford’s new Fiesta, although not big on power, is a nice-looking way to get from place to place for little money.
lead_paragraph: Ford gave us an opportunity to take its 2014 Fiesta for a spin Tuesday morning; great timing, considering it would have been Henry Ford’s 150th birthday. From the brief interaction I had with the car, the new Fiesta turned out to be a capable, if somewhat predictable, economy car. But there was one thing that set it apart from its competition: styling.

headline: On ‘Tonight,’ Playful Advice for Weiner to Be ‘Popular’
abstract: Kristin Chenoweth helped Jay Leno poke fun at Anthony D. Weiner by singing a reworked version of a song from “Wicked.”
lead_paragraph: New York’s campaign for mayor is getting a little wicked.

headline: Rising G.O.P. Star Expected to Challenge Arkansas Democrat
abstract: Representative Tom Cotton, a freshman, is expected to announce a run against Senator Mark Pryor, one of 2014’s most vulnerable Democrats.
lead_paragraph: Representative Tom Cotton, Republican of Arkansas, is expected to announce his challenge to Senator Mark Pryor of Arkansas in 2014, according to two Republicans familiar with his thinking. For Mr. Pryor, a two-term Democrat, the bid would further complicate his efforts to hold onto his already vulnerable seat.

headline: Image of the Day: July 31
abstract: Women in Andhra Pradesh welcome the central government’s endorsement of the creation of Telangana as a separate state.

headline: Brides: Steal His Heart, but Borrow the Jewelry
keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Jewels and Jewelry', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Weddings and Engagements']
abstract: A few hotels, undeterred by the theft in Cannes, are allowing brides to borrow jewelry as part of their wedding package.
lead_paragraph: Want jewelry from a hotel? You can save your mask and gloves, but you’d better bring a wedding dress. Despite the theft at the Carlton in Cannes, a number of hotels are continuing new programs in which they lend jewels out to brides.

headline: Scents for Men, Minus the Mating Calls
keywords: ['Cosmetics and Toiletries', 'Men and Boys', 'E-Commerce', 'Perfumes and Fragrances']
abstract: Darren Criss, the “Glee” actor, will offer advice on The Motley, a men’s grooming Web site that targets a more sophisticated customer.
lead_paragraph: THREE YEARS AGO, the siblings Matthew and Madison Ruggieri of Los Angeles had a smart idea for an online company. With $10,000 and a spare bedroom in their San Fernando Valley home, they started The Motley, a retailer of men’s grooming products with an eye for quality and aesthetics. Their theory was that guys, when shopping for moisturizers and such, have evolved at a faster pace than most stores.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene Video: ‘The Spectacular Now’
abstract: The director James Ponsoldt narrates a scene from his film featuring Miles Teller and Shailene Woodley.
lead_paragraph: “The Spectacular Now” looks at the budding relationship between two misfit teens, Sutter (Miles Teller) and Aimee (Shailene Woodley). In this video feature, the film’s director James Ponsoldt narrates a scene where the two characters first meet.

headline: Choking Still Sends Too Many Children to the E.R.
abstract: What food item is most likely to cause children to choke? Candy.
lead_paragraph: Choking continues to be a leading cause of injury among children, a new study shows, reminding us to remain vigilant about what and how they eat.

headline: Air Products Faces Modern Form of Hostile Takeover
abstract: William A. Ackman’s firm, Pershing Square Capital Management, is likely to follow a well-worn path taken by both activist investors and his own fund in seeking to shake up the management and strategy at Air Products and Chemicals.
lead_paragraph: The hunter becomes the hunted.

headline: Why Aren’t Direct Public Offerings More Common?
abstract: Still somewhat obscure, D.P.O.’s have been around for decades. Would you consider using one?
lead_paragraph: We’ve just published a small-business guide to using direct public offerings to raise money. Also known as “do-it-yourself I.P.O.’s,” they have been around for decades but have been gaining prominence of late — especially with the rise of social media. They are considered especially useful for businesses with strong, loyal followings. And beyond raising money, they can be extremely useful as marketing.

headline: Bond Purchases by Fed Will Continue, at Least for Another Month
abstract: The Federal Reserve said its purchase of $85 billion a month in securities would continue, citing the weak pace of growth during the first half of the year.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve issued a 700-word statement on Wednesday, but four words would have sufficed: see you in September.

headline: Poll Shows Republican Voters at Odds on Party Leadership and Direction
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: As a number of prominent Republicans trade barbs and jostle to become the party’s standard-bearer, a new poll finds a majority of Republican voters support significant changes in the party’s direction, but there is no consensus on which direction the party should take.
lead_paragraph: As a number of prominent Republicans trade barbs and jostle to become the party’s standard-bearer after a disappointing showing in the 2012 election, a new poll finds a majority of Republican voters support significant changes in the party’s direction, but there is no consensus on what direction the party should take.

headline: Perfectly Reasonable Question No. 2: On Identifying Writers of Letters to the Editor
abstract: The public editor is answering questions from readers about The Times.
lead_paragraph: As the famous line from “Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid” goes: “Who are those guys?” A version of that alarmed question sometimes comes up regarding letters to the editor in The Times.

headline: To Make It Up to Rowling, Law Firm Makes a Donation
abstract: Russells, the law firm responsible for revealing that J.K. Rowling wrote a mystery novel under a pen name, also apologized to her.
lead_paragraph: The London law firm responsible for revealing that J. K. Rowling is the author of the detective novel “The Cuckoo’s Calling” has agreed to make a “substantial” donation to charity as part of an apology.

headline: Making the Case for Eating Fruit
abstract: Fresh fruit should not become a casualty in the sugar wars, many nutrition experts say.
lead_paragraph: Experts agree that we are eating too much sugar, which is contributing to obesity and other health problems. But in the rush to avoid sugar, many low-carb dieters and others are avoiding fruits. But fresh fruit should not become a casualty in the sugar wars, many nutrition experts say.

headline: Selena Gomez Hits No. 1
abstract: “Stars Dance,” her fourth album, sold 97,000 copies in its first week.
lead_paragraph: After five weeks of rap albums topping the Billboard charts, it’s back to pop. Selena Gomez, who made her name as part of Disney’s fold of singing, smiling teens, has scored her first No. 1 album with “Stars Dance” (Hollywood). The album, her fourth, sold 97,000 copies last week, according to Nielsen SoundScan, and Billboard notes that Ms. Gomez, now 21, enjoys a distinction that is getting rarer: each of her last three albums has opened with more sales than the one before it.

headline: Essence Magazine Names New Top Editor
abstract: This is its fifth editor in 13 years. The last one had been dismissed in February.
lead_paragraph: After being without an editor in chief since February, Essence magazine has announced a new leader, its fifth in 13 years. Vanessa K. Bush will assume the top job immediately.

headline: George Saunders’s Advice to Graduates
abstract: George Saunders shared with us his notes for a speech he gave at Syracuse University, in which he shares how one of his biggest regrets sprang from something very small.
lead_paragraph: It’s long past graduation season, but we recently learned that George Saunders delivered the convocation speech at Syracuse University for the class of 2013, and George was kind enough to send it our way and allow us to reprint it here. The speech touches on some of the moments in his life and larger themes (in his life and work) that George spoke about in the profile we ran back in January — the need for kindness and all the things working against our actually achieving it, the risk in focusing too much on “success,” the trouble with swimming in a river full of monkey feces.

headline: Facebook’s I.P.O. Breakthrough
abstract: But the shares of the social network giant still have a way to go. In comparison, the Nasdaq market is up more than 20 percent, and Google more than 40 percent since the May 17, 2012, market debut of Facebook.,
lead_paragraph: Facebook has at last mobilized back to square one. Its shares finally broke above the $38 price set in the company’s messy initial public offering 14 months ago. That’s largely thanks to Mark Zuckerberg, the chief executive, making the social network’s platform work on smartphones and tablets even as his tech rivals mostly flounder at the task.

headline: The Gun Report: July 31, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: On July 18, four young girls were caught in the crossfire of a shooting in a residential neighborhood in East Lansdowne, Pa., and yesterday they told the local ABC News affiliate what it was like.

headline: Conservative Catholics and the New Pope
abstract: What a more “liberal” papacy might offer to conservative believers.
lead_paragraph: A number of Catholics of my acquaintance are resistant to the idea, raised in my last post on Pope Francis, that there might be real daylight between the new pontiff’s emerging program and the approach of his two predecessors. In their view, the possibility that Francis intends to be a social-justice pope who deliberately soft-pedals debates over doctrine and morals is just a media creation, reflecting press caricatures of the church’s divisions rather than Francis’s actual statements and intent.

headline: In Search of Her Romeo, This Juliet Gains a Friar Laurence
abstract: Finn Wittrock has dropped out of the Classic Stage Company’s “Romeo and Juliet,” and William Hurt has signed on as Friar Laurence.
lead_paragraph: Classic Stage Company’s new production of “Romeo and Juliet” has lost its leading man to a film, but gained a film star and onetime New York theater luminary – William Hurt – in the role of Friar Laurence.

headline: Hagel Gives Dire Assessment of Choices He Expects Cuts to Force on the Pentagon
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Regardless of whether sequester cuts are lifted or reduced, the defense secretary indicated that the Army and Air Force would most likely shrink.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel warned on Wednesday that if across-the-board budget cuts were not lifted, the United States would have to reduce its global security objectives by trading away the size of its armed forces or its edge in technology as the Pentagon seeks to remain solvent.

headline: Obama to Appear on ‘Tonight’ Show
abstract: His topics, NBC said, will be “job initiatives and the economy.”
lead_paragraph: President Obama, who has made the rounds of most of the late-night shows in the past, will return to the most-watched of the genre on Tuesday when he visits “The Tonight Show With Jay Leno” on NBC for the fourth time since taking office.

headline: What Republican Voters Want
abstract: Fifty-four percent said the party should move further to the right.
lead_paragraph: Republican voters have surveyed the wreckage of their party’s 2008 and 2012 presidential tickets and concluded that something important must be done. In a new survey by the Pew Research Center, solid majorities of Republicans said the party needs to “address major problems” (69 percent), which would require shifting positions on some issues (59 percent).

headline: Governments, Led by U.S., Seek More Data About Twitter Users
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA)', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: In its semiannual transparency report, the micro-blogging service said it received 1,157 data requests, mostly from government officials in the United States, in the first half of 2013. But the data excludes national security requests, which have become a hot political issue in Washington.
lead_paragraph: The number of requests for Twitter user data from governments around the world continued to grow in the first half of 2013, the microblogging service said in its semiannual transparency report, released Wednesday.

headline: The Consolations of a Schubert Sonata Surplus
abstract: Pondering the happy results of listening to three performances of Schubert’s final piano sonata, the B flat, in one week.
lead_paragraph: SANTA FE, N.M. — The world would be a better place if Schubert’s final piano sonata, the B flat (D. 960), were everywhere in it. The first two movements of this majestic piece are its heart and soul, each gorgeous in its own way, and if the slighter third and fourth movements disappoint at all, it can only be in relation to that impossibly beautiful first half, with its heavenly lengths.

headline: The Wind Shifts to ‘Buy’ and East Harlem Beckons
abstract: After years as a renter, David Karpa was hoping to buy a one-bedroom.
lead_paragraph: David Karpa used to be dead set against buying. It seemed financially imprudent. “I don’t want to stretch just to get into an apartment,” Mr. Karpa would say. His Midtown rent was $2,400 and, for the same price, he didn’t think he could find a nicer place to buy.

headline: The Marginalized, Front and Center
abstract: The photographer Peter Baryshnikov, the dance icon’s son, trains his camera on a destitute slice of life in Guatemala.
lead_paragraph: Peter Baryshnikov is following in the footsteps of his father, Mikhail — but not with jetés and battements.

headline: Turn the Showers Off. Splash Is Closing.
abstract: Splash, the 22-year-old Chelsea gay bar, is closing.
lead_paragraph: Last week, Splash, a sprawling two-floor gay club on West 17th Street in Chelsea, announced that it was closing on Aug. 11 after a storied 22-year run.

headline: A Shifting Workplace Experience
keywords: ['Cloud Computing', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Mobile Applications', 'Word Processing']
abstract: As mobility and collaboration become standards of work, the design and function of things like document creation and sharing are changing, too.
lead_paragraph: Compared with offices of the past, the modern workplace is paradoxically both more informal and more relentless. Doors have been replaced by cubicles, formal desks with tables, and long-planned meetings with ad hoc collaboration. Work and home have blended, to the general benefit of work: more and more of us are available at all times, on smartphones and tablets, for e-mail and instant messaging.

headline: In Store | French Satchels Make Their Debut Stateside
abstract: On the recommendation of Narciso Rodriguez, Barneys New York picked up exclusive handbags from the French leather-goods house Moreau-Paris.
lead_paragraph: The French leather-goods house Moreau-Paris dates back to the mid-19th century and finally made its stateside debut last week at Barneys New York. “It happened through a rather unorthodox referral,” said Daniella Vitale, C.O.O. and executive vice president of Barneys. “Narciso Rodriguez was in Paris on holiday and walked past a tiny shop on Rue de Miromesnil, and sent me an e-mail telling me that I should take a look at it next time we were in Paris.” The brand is most famous for its embossed leather travel trunks and accessories, but in recent years, under the design leadership of Fedor Georges Savchenko, formerly of Goyard, it has gained interest for its hand-sewn carryalls. In this five-piece collection designed exclusively for Barneys, fine and exotic leathers are complemented with clean lines, minimal hardware and sophisticated shapes ranging from messenger bags to the open and zip totes sure to be spotted during fashion week. While the just-released basic leather versions are worth a trip to Madison Avenue or barneys.com, the crocodile versions that come out in September may be worth the wait.

headline: Using the Masses to Improve Apps
abstract: Crowdsourced mobile apps can provide new perspectives, but how much may depend on the size of the crowd weighing in.
lead_paragraph: Crowds are a hit. Millions of people, connected by the Internet, are now contributing ideas and information to projects big and small. Crowdsourcing, as it is called, is helping to solve tricky problems and providing localized information. And with the right mobile apps, contributing to the crowd — and using its wisdom — is easier than ever.

headline: ‘Bronx Bombers,’ a Yankees Play, Comes to Primary Stages
abstract: The company will mount Eric Simonson’s play that features Derek Jeter, Yogi Berra and other Yankees stars as characters.
lead_paragraph: The playwright Eric Simonson has explored the worlds of professional basketball (“Magic/Bird”) and football (“Lombardi”) in recent New York theater seasons. Now it’s baseball’s turn. On Monday the Off Broadway company Primary Stages announced that Mr. Simonson would direct his latest play, “Bronx Bombers,” a drama about the New York Yankees, this fall at the Duke on 42nd Street. The show is to run Sept. 17 through Oct. 19, with opening night to be announced.

headline: Some Syria Missiles Eluded Israeli Strike, Officials Say
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Missiles and Missile Defense Systems']
abstract: American officials said further Israeli strikes are likely after concluding that a recent strike was not successful in destroying all of the missiles they had been targeting.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American intelligence analysts have concluded that a recent Israeli airstrike on a warehouse in Syria did not succeed in destroying all of the Russian-made antiship cruise missiles that were its target, American officials said on Wednesday, and that further Israeli strikes are likely.

headline: Pataki Is Cleared in Lawsuit Over Sex Offenders’ Rights
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: Former Gov. George E. Pataki was found not liable for violating the rights of six men confined to psychiatric hospitals after completing their prison sentences.
lead_paragraph: A federal jury in Manhattan found on Wednesday that former Gov. George E. Pataki of New York was not liable for violating the rights of six convicted sex offenders who had sued, claiming they were wrongly confined in state psychiatric hospitals after completing prison sentences for their crimes.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Zimbabwe and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Zimbabwe, Syria, Russia and India.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Zimbabwe, Syria, Russia and India.

headline: The Silent Partner Behind the Shale Energy Boom – Taxpayers
keywords: ['Drilling and Boring', 'Energy and Power', 'Hydraulic Fracturing', 'Inventions and Patents', 'Natural Gas', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Shale']
abstract: A closer look at the public investments behind the private success of a shale-fracking pioneer.
lead_paragraph: Since 2011, Alex Trembath, a tireless and talented energy analyst at nonprofit The Breakthrough Institute, has been digging into the complicated history of public and private initiatives and investments that unlocked the vast gas and oil resource contained in layers of shale rock.

headline: Decades After a Strike, Still Living With the Fallout
abstract: In John S. Anastasi’s “I Forgive you, Ronald Reagan,” a family is permanently scarred by the 1981 air traffic controllers’ walkout.
lead_paragraph: “I Forgive You, Ronald Reagan” wants very much to be a modern-day “Death of a Salesman,” with its very own working-class hero who loses his identity (and ultimately his sanity) after being forced out of his livelihood, and who compensates by pinning unrealistic hopes upon his coddled, lazy offspring.

headline: Decoding the Fed’s Statement
abstract: Compare the June and July statements issued by the Federal Open Market Committee.
lead_paragraph: Compare the June and July statements issued by the Federal Open Market Committee.

headline: Scene City: Film on Porn Classic With All-Star Cast
abstract: Amanda Seyfried, Sharon Stone, Peter Sarsgaard and other “Lovelace” stars were at New York premiere.
lead_paragraph: Amanda Seyfried, Sharon Stone, Peter Sarsgaard and other “Lovelace” stars were at New York premiere.

headline: The Greek Bailout Isn’t Working
abstract: A member of the I.M.F. board said the notion that Greece would pay back its debts in full was “all but a delusion.”
lead_paragraph: For some time now, it’s been clear to many analysts that the European and International Monetary Fund bailout program for Greece is not working. The country is mired in a depression and its government shoulders a large and unsustainable debt. Few policy makers have been willing to acknowledge that reality in public because doing so would be an admission of failure and require them to change  their approach, which they have already done once before. But on Wednesday, a member of the I.M.F.’s board who represents Brazil and 10 other countries broke that silence by issuing an unusual and refreshingly candid statement.

headline: Keen Company and Women’s Project Announce New Seasons
abstract: Keen Company will begin its season with a revival of Jon Robin Baitz’s 1989 play “The Film Society.”
lead_paragraph: Keen Company and the Women’s Project, two Off Broadway theater companies, have announced their 2013-14 season offerings.

headline: It’s Time to Vote for a Sticker on Voting
abstract: A contest held by the New York City Campaign Finance Board to design a voter pride sticker is down to four finalists and balloting on Facebook.
lead_paragraph: It’s not quite as striking as an ink-stained finger — the proud marker in many countries signifying that someone voted. But the New York City Campaign Finance Board hopes that a sticker saying “I voted!” will help motivate New Yorkers to go to the polls in the mayoral election this year.

headline: Celebrating a Film About a Film
abstract: Guests gather for the screening, then an after-party.
lead_paragraph: For a 62-minute pornographic film made for $30,000 in 1972, “Deep Throat” had remarkable impact. It became a barrier-breaking piece of pop culture, a First Amendment cause and even a Watergate reference. And later its star, Linda Lovelace, became an advocate for women against pornography and abuse.

headline: Spoofy Heroes, Super and Otherwise, Join the Streaming Fray
abstract: “The Awesomes” and “Quick Draw,” two original series from Hulu, are among the latest shows available through streaming-video services.
lead_paragraph: One way to judge a streaming-video service — the only way, if you look at recent news coverage — is by its original series. By that measure, Hulu is the scrappy, undersized contender of the Big Three, ranking below Netflix, the steamrollering champion, but above Amazon, which is still standing outside the ring lacing its gloves.

headline: Ludwig Meets Wolfgang in a First-Night Encounter
abstract: The mezzo-soprano Alice Coote and the pianist Jean-Efflam Bavouzet were the soloists with the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra at Avery Fisher Hall on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: For all the advances that Lincoln Center’s Mostly Mozart Festival has brought to New York’s music scene — offering a launching pad for rising artists, lending Avery Fisher Hall a modicum of intimacy with a thrust stage and surround seating — its core orchestral programs remain stubbornly conservative.

headline: Defending a Spingold Knockout Title in Philadelphia
abstract: The premier event at the Summer North American Championships, this year in Atlanta, is the Spingold Knockout Teams, which starts on Monday.
lead_paragraph: The premier event at the Summer North American Championships, this year in Atlanta, is the Spingold Knockout Teams, which starts on Monday.

headline: Judging Breaks, on Greens and on the Calendar
abstract: This current stretch of the PGA Tour, with four tournaments in four weeks, is not for the meek or those trying to find their game.
lead_paragraph: AKRON, Ohio — When Brandt Snedeker headed out the door for work Wednesday morning, his 2-year-old daughter, Lily, asked him to stay.

headline: Virtual Currency Gains Ground in Actual World
keywords: ['Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Currency', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Bitcoins trade like a commodity, but more businesses are accepting them as money.
lead_paragraph: Depending on whom you ask, bitcoins are a goofy geek invention with as much long-term value as Monopoly money — or a technology development that could transform currency the way e-mail and texting have transformed correspondence.

headline: Marginalized, Yes, but Also a Nasty Guy
abstract: “Dreadful,” David Margolick’s new biography of John Horne Burns, a largely forgotten novelist with a poisonous character, illuminates the gay experience in the mid-20th century.
lead_paragraph: “An unpitiable swine.” “He liked to hurt people — being extremely sensitive to wounds himself — and as he drove the knife in he smiled.” “A total narcissist.”

headline: Rashida Jones and Rob Lowe Leaving ‘Parks and Recreation’
abstract: The exits of Rob Lowe and Rashida Jones are the first substantial departures in the run of the NBC comedy.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:16 p.m. |

headline: Spotify Losses Grow, Despite Successful Expansion
abstract: A quarter of the streaming service’s 24 million customers pay for their music,  but that hasn’t been enough for Spotify to turn a profit.
lead_paragraph: After five years, the streaming music service Spotify has established itself as a financial force in the music industry, with more than $500 million in revenue last year. Yet its losses have also grown as the company expands around the world and tries to attract paying customers.

headline: Banning Guests That Bite or Buzz
abstract: The battle against ticks and mosquitoes now requires more work and a bit of strategy, as new breeds gain a foothold.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, the raspberry bushes on our property exploded with berries, thanks to the season’s big rains. Unfortunately, the backyard puddles that had harbored bug larvae exploded with life, too, so our berry harvest exacted a high price in mosquito bites.

headline: Cute and Cozy (for a Loaf of Bread)
keywords: ['Mobile Homes and Trailers', 'Baby Boomers', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: A 1950s trailer — who cared if there was no plumbing? That would be me, as it turned out.
lead_paragraph: Every once in a while I fall for cute in a really bad way. One of the worst times, about 40 years ago, involved a pale blue Fiat 850 convertible that I bought from a guy I knew. It overheated the first time I took it out on the road, teaching me the meaning of the terms “cracked engine block” and “trust.”

headline: Shopping for Faucets
abstract: Eve Robinson goes shopping for functional, attractive water faucets.
lead_paragraph: Eve Robinson goes shopping for functional, attractive water faucets.

headline: Where Fitness and Zombies Collide
abstract: To start running, sometimes you need something scary chasing you.
lead_paragraph: To start running, sometimes you need something scary chasing you.

headline: Kitchen Faucets for Cooks and Wannabes
abstract: Searching for faucets attractive enough for a hypothetical cook and functional enough to satisfy a real one.
lead_paragraph: For a while now, the kitchen has been the center of most people’s homes. “Just like the hearth was a place where people congregated,” said Eve Robinson, a New York interior designer, “the kitchen is now the place.”

headline: Goodbyes and Grief in Real Time
abstract: Scott Simon, the journalist and NPR host, posted Twitter updates from his mother’s deathbed, connecting with a vast and supportive audience.
lead_paragraph: Scott Simon’s first Twitter message about his mother, dated July 16, squeezed a universal story involving heartbreak and humor into 21 words. He wrote: “Mother called: ‘I can’t talk. I’m surrounded by handsome men.’ Emergency surgery. If you can hold a thought for her now ... ”

headline: At Zombie Races, It’s Survival of the Undeadest
abstract: Escapism and fun are the point of zombie-themed runs, not pushing to the point of muscle failure.
lead_paragraph: Even with the looming prospect of fitting into a wedding gown, the only way Cindy Brandecker could imagine taking up running was if someone were chasing her.

headline: U.N. Warns It Will Disarm Congo Rebels
abstract: In an uncharacteristically stern warning, the United Nations ordered individuals near the eastern city of Goma to turn in their weapons or be deemed “an imminent threat to civilians.”
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — The United Nations has threatened to forcibly disarm rebels in the Democratic Republic of Congo, an early test of the robust new mandate for the multinational peacekeeping contingent that includes going on the offensive there.

headline: Sharing Sahara Sentiments of Romance and Roots
abstract: The Niger-born guitarist and songwriter Bombino, backed by his three-man band, had the audience dancing at Brooklyn Bowl on Tuesday night.
lead_paragraph: The most direct route for African music to reach American listeners is via the dance floor, which was full and overjoyed when Bombino, a Tuareg guitarist and songwriter born in Niger, brought his band to Brooklyn Bowl on Tuesday night. Bombino and his three band members wore desert robes and turbans; he sang in his native language, Tamashek, and thanked the audience between songs in French. But it looked like ethnomusicological curiosity mattered far less to the audience than Bombino’s pithy, incantatory electric guitar lines and the band’s perpetual grooves. By the end of the set, their robes were drenched in sweat.

headline: ‘Dark Sheep of the Family’ Has a History to Uphold
abstract: The five-part works were the focus of “Concertos à 5,” the first of four one-hour, free concerts featuring well-known composers and worthy rarities at St. Peter’s Lutheran Church.
lead_paragraph: Introducing “Concertos à 5,” the opening program of the 4x4 Baroque Music Festival on Tuesday, the harpsichordist Avi Stein said that each era has its ubiquitous format, like the string quartet in the 20th and 21st centuries and the Trio sonata in the Baroque era. The five-part ensemble, an invention of an earlier period, is the “dark sheep of the family,” he added. Its Renaissance flavor, with a rich polyphonic texture created by the instrumental combination, lingered in scores written in later centuries.

headline: A Blacklist Delays Book on Iran
abstract: “Iranian Living Room” presents photos of people at home in Iran. But when the publisher tried to sell it on its Web site using PayPal, the orders were initially blocked.
lead_paragraph: Last month, Fabrica, a think tank in Treviso, Italy, run by the fashion company Benetton, released a book that offered a rare view of the domestic lives of Iranians. Overseen by Enrico Bossan, Fabrica’s head of photography, “Iranian Living Room” (about $45) presents images by photojournalists in Tehran and other cities of people in residential settings occupied with chores, socializing, leisure and prayer. But when Fabrica tried to sell “Iranian Living Room” on its Web site, with transactions processed through PayPal, the orders were initially blocked.

headline: Riding a Carpet Back to the 1950s
abstract: A group of Raymond Loewy rugs is reintroduced.
lead_paragraph: In the early 1950s, the industrial designer Raymond Loewy created area rugs in defiance of the fashion in America for wall-to-wall carpeting. As his client, the elite carpet manufacturer Edward Fields, recognized, small rooms were giving way to the open floor plans of postwar architecture, and floor coverings were useful for breaking up spaces. Such rugs were “a big deal at that time,” said Yasmina Benazzou, director of design and creative development for Tai Ping/Edward Fields, which is reintroducing Mr. Loewy’s original collection.

headline: Plumped Up on Perennial Grasses
abstract: At Tara Firma Farms, pigs, cattle and chickens thrive without relying on fertilizers, pharmaceuticals or hormones.
lead_paragraph: At Tara Firma Farms, pigs, cattle and chickens thrive without relying on fertilizers, pharmaceuticals or hormones.

headline: Life on the Farm: E-I-E-I ...Oh?
abstract: Tara Smith and her husband, Craig, knew nothing about farming. But that didn’t stop them from buying and operating a 300-acre spread in Northern California.
lead_paragraph: Petaluma, Calif. — Tara Smith does not mind squealing on herself about the mistakes she has made since becoming a farmer at 47.

headline: A Sleek Way to Add Fizz, but Not Much
abstract: Purefizz, a French product, never achieves more than gentle carbonation.
lead_paragraph: A recent entry into the field of carbonate-your-own-drink devices, Purefizz ($80), from a French company called Mastrad, puts bubbles into a wide variety of beverages. This sets it apart from products like SodaStream that carbonate water before flavoring is added.

headline: Boardroom to Barnyard
abstract: Tara Smith, a California business woman, traded in her plush city life for the hard work of starting a farm from scratch.
lead_paragraph: Tara Smith, a California business woman, traded in her plush city life for the hard work of starting a farm from scratch.

headline: In Gaza, Iran Finds an Ally More Agreeable Than Hamas
abstract: Unlike Hamas, Islamic Jihad, also a militant group, has kept up relations with the government of President Bashar al-Assad, a longtime Iranian ally.
lead_paragraph: BEIT LAHIYA, Gaza Strip — The oil, sugar, pasta and other staples looked innocuous enough as dozens of young Palestinian volunteers, sweating in the heat at a warehouse here, packed them into cartons destined for Gaza’s poor during the holy month of Ramadan.

headline: An Outdoor Shower Inspired by P.S. 122
abstract: The shower manufactured by Oborain was named after the New York City school-turned-performance-space.
lead_paragraph: Kirsten Oxboel and Jim Lobley, founders of the outdoor shower manufacturer Oborain, recently released their third design, which they named after a New York City school-turned-performance-space. “We both went to public schools, so we thought it would be cool to do a P.S. 122 shower,” Ms. Oxboel said.

headline: Midcentury, Even for Baby
abstract: A new shop called Triangle in the East London borough of Hackney is devoted to a midcentury modern aesthetic for a variety of products.
lead_paragraph: Three friends from the British design world have collaborated on Triangle, a new shop on Chatsworth Road in the East London borough of Hackney. The owners — Matthew Naylor, a graphic designer; Victoria Mullen, a former visual merchandiser; and Mary Wagstaff, a trained ceramist — are devoted to midcentury modern, and Triangle reflects that aesthetic with both vintage and new products, many from local artists and crafters.

headline: Sales at Cassina, Didriks, Fishs Eddy and Others
keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'Beds and Bedding', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: Discounts on beds, linens, glassware and more.
lead_paragraph: Cassina is discounting all beds by 20 percent through Sunday (the Moov king-size bed, by Piero Lissoni, in midgrade fabric with the Motion Fissa slatted base, regularly $6,135, is $4,908); 151 Wooster Street (Houston Street), (212) 228-8186, and 155 East 65th Street (Third Avenue), (212) 245-2121, cassinausa.com.

headline: The President’s Men, at the Lenses
abstract: “Our Nixon,” a CNN documentary, uses recently released Super 8 footage of insider perspectives of the White House.
lead_paragraph: It always comes back to the tapes.

headline: Should We Build a Fence So Buyers Won’t Worry About Privacy?
abstract: If neighbors can see into a house that is for sale, planting trees may be a better option than having a fence built.
lead_paragraph: Q. Our neighbors can see straight into our house from their backyard. Should we build a fence so buyers won’t worry about privacy?

headline: City Allots $50 Million to Favored Arts Project
abstract: Some cultural groups are taken aback by the size of a $50 million New York City appropriation for a new arts group, the Culture Shed.
lead_paragraph: When the details of Michael R. Bloomberg’s last capital budget as mayor were made final in June, one project stood out in particular: a $50 million appropriation for a nascent arts organization, the Culture Shed.

headline: Food Matters | A Meeting of the United Nations of Gastronomy
abstract: The Club des Chefs des Chefs, an organization composed entirely of chefs who serve international heads of state, kicked off its fun-loving annual summit in New York last weekend.

headline: Welcome to Summer Camp
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'ARCHITECTURE']
abstract: The bunk-bed aesthetic appeals to design-minded guests. So does the well-stocked vintage bar cart.
lead_paragraph: George Yabu and Glenn Pushelberg’s beach house has a cantilevered construction, complicated sliding-glass doors made in Germany and a clever push-button dumbwaiter, but the element that best captures its spirit are the playful wood lockers. Lined in a row opposite a wall of bunk beds in a small downstairs room, the lockers suggest a summer camp for design-minded adults and practically scream “houseguests welcome.”

headline: Architecture Curator at MoMA to Return to Columbia
abstract: After six years as a curator at the Museum of Modern Art, Barry Bergdoll announced Wednesday that he is returning to teach at Columbia University.
lead_paragraph: Barry Bergdoll is stepping down after six and a half years as chief curator of architecture and design at the Museum of Modern Art, he announced in a letter to journalists late Wednesday afternoon.

headline: A Hamptons Beach House Where Everyone Is Welcome
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: With plenty of bunk beds, lockers and towels.
lead_paragraph: With plenty of bunk beds, lockers and towels.

headline: Playland Motel
abstract: The Playland Motel is an urban beach resort in the Rockaways.
lead_paragraph: The Rockaways are already home to a colony of raffish surfers, young artists piled into bungalows and Bushwick-types who have made it their urban beach resort. Now it has a designer motel with a hopping bar scene populated by the sort of young, well-coiffed life-forms that might otherwise go to Montauk. Opened last month, the Playland Motel is run by the owners of the Output dance club and Rosarito Fish Shack in Williamsburg. “It feels like Berlin or Ibiza,” David Terranova, a music video producer from Brooklyn, said last weekend at a crowded dance party.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Facebook Is Like Playing the Slots
abstract: The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for important and peculiar items. Wednesday’s selections include an examination of the psychology of gambling to understand better why we tend to be obsessed with certain social networks. Plus, a case of person getting fired for a poorly thought-out tweet.
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: ‘The Croods’ Helps DreamWorks Animation Increase Quarterly Profit
abstract: The company reported net income of $22.2 million, or 26 cents a share, up from $12.8 million a year ago and better than analysts’ forecasts of 20 cents a share.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Glass half full: The cave people of “The Croods” came through for DreamWorks Animation in the second quarter, as strong ticket sales for that movie raised the company’s profit by 73 percent, to $22.2 million.

headline: Songs and Sunscreen Spread the Health Insurance Message

abstract: Advertising is upbeat in the states that are setting up marketplaces where residents will buy health insurance in accordance with the Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: THE part of President Obama’s Affordable Care Act that requires Americans to obtain health insurance has been a contentious issue politically, but new advertising from the 17 states setting up marketplaces where residents will buy insurance tends to be buoyant.

headline: Documents Show Thatcher-Reagan Rift Over U.S. Decision to Invade Grenada
abstract: Documents released by the British government said that Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher was angered by a lack of warning from President Ronald Reagan.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Thirty-year-old documents newly released by the British government reveal just how severely America’s decision to invade the Caribbean island of Grenada in 1983 tested the warm ties between Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and President Ronald Reagan.

headline: Crowds Return to Las Vegas, but Gamble Less
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Gambling', 'Casinos', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Bars and Nightclubs']
abstract: Though tourists have returned, and jobs and construction are up, some fear another bubble and see a fundamental shift away from gambling.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — When the last recession battered the nation, the bottom fell out in Las Vegas. One out of every six jobs vanished. Home prices dropped as much as 50 percent. Construction projects stopped in place, and tourist spending on the Las Vegas Strip, the economic driver of this city, went into an alarming slide.
